description: The Cisco Cybersecurity Operations show (Exam 210-255) will help prepare someone preparing for the 2 exams of the CCNA Cyber Ops Certification.  It also aids them to get ready to begin working as an associate level analyst within a Security Operations Center (SOC) and help the candidate handle the tasks, duties and responsibilities working as an analyst in the SOC.  The show will focus on introductory-level skills of basic threat analysis, event correlation, identifying malicious activities and using a playbook for incident response.
descriptionMD: The Cisco Cybersecurity Operations show (Exam 210-255) will help prepare someone preparing for the 2 exams of the CCNA Cyber Ops Certification.  It also aids them to get ready to begin working as an associate level analyst within a Security Operations Center (SOC) and help the candidate handle the tasks, duties and responsibilities working as an analyst in the SOC.  The show will focus on introductory-level skills of basic threat analysis, event correlation, identifying malicious activities and using a playbook for incident response.
name: CCNA Cyber Ops (210-255 SECOPS)
subtitle: Cisco Cybersecurity Operations

episodes.description: The Cisco Cybersecurity Operations show (Exam 210-255) will help prepare someone preparing for the 2 exams of the CCNA Cyber Ops Certification. It also aids them to get ready to begin working as an associate level analyst within a Security Operations Center (SOC) and help the candidate handle the tasks, duties and responsibilities working as an analyst in the SOC. The show will focus on introductory-level skills of basic threat analysis, event correlation, identifying malicious activities and using a playbook for incident response.
episodes.title: Overview
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.111 --> 00:00:06.487
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:06.487 --> 00:00:10.935
Hello, welcome to the overview for
the Cisco Cybersecurity Operations show.

3
00:00:10.935 --> 00:00:12.705
You'll see that during this show,

4
00:00:12.705 --> 00:00:15.959
we'll probably end up referring
to it as CCNA SECOPS very often.

5
00:00:15.959 --> 00:00:21.132
And that is because this particular
show matches up to the exam for,

6
00:00:21.132 --> 00:00:25.950
of course,
your CCNA Cyber Ops certification as well.

7
00:00:25.950 --> 00:00:30.260
Now, let's talk about a few details on
the exam as we actually get started this

8
00:00:30.260 --> 00:00:30.992
too, okay?

9
00:00:30.992 --> 00:00:34.193
If you are getting ready for the exam,
we want to know a little bit about,

10
00:00:34.193 --> 00:00:37.230
of course, preparing and
getting access to the exam as well.

11
00:00:37.230 --> 00:00:39.790
Let's take a look at my screen,
that will help us out.

12
00:00:39.790 --> 00:00:42.929
Make sure you go to the Pearson VUE
website, and when you do so,

13
00:00:42.929 --> 00:00:45.077
you, of course, can select the program.

14
00:00:45.077 --> 00:00:49.680
For us, it's gonna be Cisco, and
that should pop up Cisco Systems.

15
00:00:49.680 --> 00:00:53.780
And once we do this, you, if you have
not yet actually created an account,

16
00:00:53.780 --> 00:00:56.920
make sure you create an account
over here on the right-hand side.

17
00:00:56.920 --> 00:01:00.490
Once you do so, of course,
you'll log back in, come to the same site.

18
00:01:00.490 --> 00:01:03.498
From this point, you will go down
to where it says View exams, so

19
00:01:03.498 --> 00:01:05.523
that you can find the correct exam number.

20
00:01:07.631 --> 00:01:12.644
And once we do so, we're gonna actually be
underneath these Proctored Exams, okay?

21
00:01:12.644 --> 00:01:15.998
So Cisco does offer some
of the other ones, but

22
00:01:15.998 --> 00:01:22.021
we're underneath the Proctored Exams,
and we're looking for 210-255,

23
00:01:22.021 --> 00:01:27.029
210-255, Implementing Cisco
Cybersecurity Operations.

24
00:01:29.115 --> 00:01:33.256
And once you do that, notice that there's
actually a couple of different languages,

25
00:01:33.256 --> 00:01:34.403
English and Japanese.

26
00:01:34.403 --> 00:01:38.504
Let's select English at this point and
click Next.

27
00:01:38.504 --> 00:01:42.910
From that point, of course, you'll
schedule the exam, which will be near you.

28
00:01:42.910 --> 00:01:45.430
There's a button over on the lower
right-hand corner that will allow you to

29
00:01:45.430 --> 00:01:48.520
pick a center near you, and
that's what you'll have to do.

30
00:01:48.520 --> 00:01:52.770
Make sure that you arrive about 15 minutes
early, and that way you also bring,

31
00:01:52.770 --> 00:01:57.040
of course, a photo ID, and
that you are ready for the exam as well.

32
00:01:57.040 --> 00:02:00.833
Now when we start taking a look
at the details of the exam,

33
00:02:00.833 --> 00:02:03.372
that is what we're also here for too.

34
00:02:03.372 --> 00:02:07.652
The entire, of course, CCNA
Cybersecurity Operations show is based

35
00:02:07.652 --> 00:02:10.191
around the exam objectives themselves,

36
00:02:10.191 --> 00:02:14.310
that you can download directly
from Cisco Learning website.

37
00:02:14.310 --> 00:02:16.800
So make sure you do that first, okay?

38
00:02:16.800 --> 00:02:20.600
Notice that the exam is a 90 minute exam,
and

39
00:02:20.600 --> 00:02:24.290
there's between 60 to 70 questions
in this assessment, okay?

40
00:02:24.290 --> 00:02:28.950
Now, to achieve the overall certification
itself, you must take two exams.

41
00:02:28.950 --> 00:02:32.220
The first one, of course,
is the Security Fundamentals exam, and

42
00:02:32.220 --> 00:02:36.300
then this one on the Implementing
Cisco Cybersecurity Operations.

43
00:02:36.300 --> 00:02:41.598
Both of those will lead you to your
CCNA Cyber Ops certification, okay?

44
00:02:41.598 --> 00:02:46.379
Now the whole goal, of course, as we
actually take a look at this particular

45
00:02:46.379 --> 00:02:50.654
show is, not only for you to be
able to achieve your certification.

46
00:02:50.654 --> 00:02:55.652
But also to help prepare you as an entry
level analyst in working in a security

47
00:02:55.652 --> 00:02:56.992
operation center.

48
00:02:56.992 --> 00:03:01.656
And so, the goal and the show,
of course, is designed around that, and

49
00:03:01.656 --> 00:03:05.120
it's also designed around
these exam topics.

50
00:03:05.120 --> 00:03:09.930
So throughout the show, we will be
covering every exam topic as well.

51
00:03:09.930 --> 00:03:13.959
We talk about endpoint threat and
computer forensics analysis,

52
00:03:13.959 --> 00:03:18.806
as we break it down through using these
different terms using the CVSS 3.0.

53
00:03:18.806 --> 00:03:21.359
And we'll make sure that we
cover all the details in that.

54
00:03:21.359 --> 00:03:25.239
We, of course, will take a look at some
of the different items that pertain to

55
00:03:25.239 --> 00:03:28.240
the Windows file system,
as well as the Linux file system.

56
00:03:29.380 --> 00:03:32.110
We'll also talk, of course,
about evidence, and

57
00:03:32.110 --> 00:03:36.240
the different image types that
we may also be using, in terms

58
00:03:36.240 --> 00:03:39.530
of making sure that we're ready to work
in that security operations center.

59
00:03:39.530 --> 00:03:43.940
And then, of course, describe the idea
of an investigation, and the threats,

60
00:03:43.940 --> 00:03:46.122
and the threat actors that are in place.

61
00:03:46.122 --> 00:03:50.230
Under the Network Intrusion Analysis,
we, of course, will go through each and

62
00:03:50.230 --> 00:03:54.098
every one of these topics as well,
including the protocol headers,

63
00:03:54.098 --> 00:03:56.240
in which we'll take a look at in depth.

64
00:03:56.240 --> 00:04:01.340
We'll also see, of course, different
elements using NetFlow Version 5.

65
00:04:01.340 --> 00:04:06.240
We, of course, will work with Wireshark
and using PCAP files as well.

66
00:04:06.240 --> 00:04:10.300
And we, of course, will talk about the
five tuples of data as we go through this.

67
00:04:10.300 --> 00:04:16.370
We'll show you how to extract a file from
a TCP stream given a PCAP file as well.

68
00:04:16.370 --> 00:04:19.020
And then, of course, different
elements that are involved there,

69
00:04:19.020 --> 00:04:20.491
making sure we can identify them too.

70
00:04:22.370 --> 00:04:26.076
As we move into the third section,
we'll now move into incident responses.

71
00:04:26.076 --> 00:04:32.025
And we will heavily focus in upon
the NIST documentation here on

72
00:04:32.025 --> 00:04:37.088
SP800-61, or excuse me, 800-61 r2.

73
00:04:37.088 --> 00:04:41.221
And this will help us to go ahead and
prepare, as you see, it's referred to in

74
00:04:41.221 --> 00:04:45.375
multiple sections throughout, of course,
this third domain objectives.

75
00:04:45.375 --> 00:04:48.736
We, of course,
will describe the idea of using CSIRT

76
00:04:48.736 --> 00:04:53.230
in our particular centers as well,
and then, the network profiling.

77
00:04:55.194 --> 00:04:58.830
And then we'll look at, of course,
data and event analysis.

78
00:04:58.830 --> 00:05:02.420
And we'll take a look at all the elements
that are described right here,

79
00:05:02.420 --> 00:05:03.900
going from data normalization,

80
00:05:03.900 --> 00:05:08.290
of course, to actually comparing different
analytic methods that we have in hand.

81
00:05:08.290 --> 00:05:13.220
And lastly, we'll also end up focusing on
a couple of other NIST documents too, or

82
00:05:13.220 --> 00:05:15.270
at least one other one, okay?

83
00:05:15.270 --> 00:05:19.300
So we'll take a look at the kill
chain right here in 5.1,

84
00:05:19.300 --> 00:05:22.760
as well as the same NIST document
we referred to earlier, and

85
00:05:22.760 --> 00:05:25.700
then later on,
another NIST document as well.

86
00:05:25.700 --> 00:05:29.100
And lastly, we'll talk about other
schemas that are also involved

87
00:05:29.100 --> 00:05:34.210
in what you may find very common,
inside of your security operations center.

88
00:05:34.210 --> 00:05:39.644
So if you are now in this process
of preparing for this second exam,

89
00:05:39.644 --> 00:05:44.496
or for the CCNA Cyber Ops overall,
I do have to actually make

90
00:05:44.496 --> 00:05:50.532
a particularly good recommendation
to you before you proceed on, okay?

91
00:05:50.532 --> 00:05:55.000
You can choose to take either one of
the exams in whatever order you choose to.

92
00:05:55.000 --> 00:05:59.257
The recommendation, of course, is that you
take the Security Fundamentals first and

93
00:05:59.257 --> 00:06:02.600
then take, of course,
the SECOPS exam second, okay?

94
00:06:02.600 --> 00:06:06.980
Do not be surprised to find that you'll
see a lot of the elements that are in

95
00:06:06.980 --> 00:06:12.210
the Security Fundamentals exam also
appear in the SECOPS exam as well.

96
00:06:12.210 --> 00:06:17.710
So just be prepared for
that as you continue to go ahead and

97
00:06:17.710 --> 00:06:23.200
study, as well as watch the shows that
we've created right here to help you too.

98
00:06:23.200 --> 00:06:26.951
Don't forget to take advantage of
the forums that are also at the ITProTV

99
00:06:26.951 --> 00:06:27.511
website.

100
00:06:27.511 --> 00:06:32.361
But if you're ready to get started, all
you have to do is actually go ahead and

101
00:06:32.361 --> 00:06:35.121
get forwarded into
the very first video on,

102
00:06:35.121 --> 00:06:38.572
of course,
our CCNA Cybersecurity Operations show.

103
00:06:38.572 --> 00:06:39.435
Thank you for watching.

104
00:06:39.435 --> 00:06:45.463
[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss traditional malware detection and mitigation and the analyzing of reports to that end. Here they specifically look at using Cisco's AMP ThreatGRID suite to gather information and generate reports for analysis.
episodes.title: Read Analysis Reports
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.300 --> 00:00:02.495
Welcome to ITPRO TV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.495 --> 00:00:06.241
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.241 --> 00:00:08.151
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.151 --> 00:00:11.990
>> You're watching ITPRO.TV.

5
00:00:11.990 --> 00:00:13.975
>> All right, greetings everyone and

6
00:00:13.975 --> 00:00:16.694
welcome to another great
episode of ITPRO.TV.

7
00:00:16.694 --> 00:00:18.732
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie, and

8
00:00:18.732 --> 00:00:23.611
in today's episode we are kicking off our
new Cisco Cybersecurity Operations series.

9
00:00:23.611 --> 00:00:26.235
Which henceforth will be known as SecOps-
>> [LAUGH]

10
00:00:26.235 --> 00:00:27.965
>> Cuz I'm not saying that every episode.

11
00:00:27.965 --> 00:00:32.345
SecOps is much nicer, and
more common to the series anyway.

12
00:00:32.345 --> 00:00:35.175
Joining us in the studio to help us
with that endeavor, our good friend,

13
00:00:35.175 --> 00:00:36.345
the master blaster himself.

14
00:00:36.345 --> 00:00:37.510
Mr. Ronnie Wong.

15
00:00:37.510 --> 00:00:38.400
Ronnie, welcome back, man.

16
00:00:38.400 --> 00:00:39.290
How is it going today?

17
00:00:39.290 --> 00:00:40.610
>> It is going great, Daniel.

18
00:00:40.610 --> 00:00:44.877
Thank you for having me back on the show
as we start this particular series in

19
00:00:44.877 --> 00:00:47.466
learning about some of
the different tools.

20
00:00:47.466 --> 00:00:51.395
And of course the ideal security
operations and what we need to do.

21
00:00:51.395 --> 00:00:52.597
And so today, Daniel,

22
00:00:52.597 --> 00:00:56.970
we're actually looking into reading
reports is what we're talking about.

23
00:00:56.970 --> 00:01:00.745
And this is a big important part of
some of the things that we have to be

24
00:01:00.745 --> 00:01:01.416
able to do.

25
00:01:01.416 --> 00:01:04.692
And the reason for it,
right, is that security,

26
00:01:04.692 --> 00:01:08.988
as far as most beginners go,
we tend to take a look at it in one way.

27
00:01:08.988 --> 00:01:10.748
Which is always about the idea of,

28
00:01:10.748 --> 00:01:13.610
let's sit down those security
fundamentals, right?

29
00:01:13.610 --> 00:01:17.840
We take a look at our iron triangle,
we make sure that we follow those rules.

30
00:01:17.840 --> 00:01:21.220
And it really comes down to
saying my system is hardened.

31
00:01:21.220 --> 00:01:24.420
We're protected,
that's all that I need to do.

32
00:01:24.420 --> 00:01:29.680
But, Daniel, you and I have worked
in the industry long enough to

33
00:01:29.680 --> 00:01:33.810
know something that even if we
do all that have you, Daniel,

34
00:01:33.810 --> 00:01:38.440
in your work experience found an enduser's
workstation infected by something?

35
00:01:38.440 --> 00:01:40.370
>> Yeah, maybe like a bazillion times,

36
00:01:40.370 --> 00:01:44.520
like it was a part of my everyday job,
for quite some time.

37
00:01:44.520 --> 00:01:49.810
Especially back a few years ago,
before we really had some

38
00:01:49.810 --> 00:01:54.970
really good advanced threat management,
when it came to the end user workstation.

39
00:01:54.970 --> 00:01:56.710
And God love those users out there,

40
00:01:56.710 --> 00:02:00.100
they find a way to get some
baddies onto their computers.

41
00:02:00.100 --> 00:02:02.793
So, part of my day was
always give taking a call,

42
00:02:02.793 --> 00:02:05.040
my computer seems to be running slowly.

43
00:02:05.040 --> 00:02:09.626
Or I just it seems you're acting weird
doing something on don't expect that I'll

44
00:02:09.626 --> 00:02:10.299
look at it.

45
00:02:10.299 --> 00:02:14.028
It was against malware on it maybe we
would run an anti-virus solutions of

46
00:02:14.028 --> 00:02:15.160
an hour by sure.

47
00:02:15.160 --> 00:02:17.720
If it was just to host the premises.

48
00:02:17.720 --> 00:02:20.823
>> And now Daniel see anything you want
at least one step further away, and

49
00:02:20.823 --> 00:02:23.111
I actually ever with as I
started thinking about it.

50
00:02:23.111 --> 00:02:26.639
And the more that I started
to do too kind of two things,

51
00:02:26.639 --> 00:02:31.703
I would go that extra step and go,
all right, let's run some anti-malware,

52
00:02:31.703 --> 00:02:35.410
anti-spyware, antivirus,
whatever system is on it.

53
00:02:35.410 --> 00:02:38.942
And even if it caught it,
Daniel, it took time.

54
00:02:38.942 --> 00:02:39.850
>> Yeah.

55
00:02:39.850 --> 00:02:41.920
>> All the sudden, that user's
just standing there, like, okay,

56
00:02:41.920 --> 00:02:46.310
well, I guess I'm going to lunch
while Ronnie works on this system.

57
00:02:46.310 --> 00:02:48.770
And if it found something,
it found something, but

58
00:02:48.770 --> 00:02:50.790
what I would normally end up finding,
right?

59
00:02:50.790 --> 00:02:54.710
If it found nothing I would
kind of still be frustrated.

60
00:02:54.710 --> 00:02:56.210
And after awhile you'd kinda just go,

61
00:02:56.210 --> 00:02:59.900
right, here's what our solution
is gonna end up being.

62
00:02:59.900 --> 00:03:02.870
And a lot of companies end up doing this,
which is simple.

63
00:03:02.870 --> 00:03:05.940
If we suspect that there's a virus and
we just check and go,

64
00:03:05.940 --> 00:03:08.820
you haven't been saving anything
on the computer system, right?

65
00:03:08.820 --> 00:03:10.990
No, I didn't say that for
central share, right?

66
00:03:10.990 --> 00:03:14.500
Yes, great,
because what can I do immediately then,

67
00:03:14.500 --> 00:03:16.330
instead of having to go through that?

68
00:03:16.330 --> 00:03:18.910
>> You just blow the thing away,
and start all over from scratch.

69
00:03:18.910 --> 00:03:20.131
>> Yeah.
>> But that's a lie,

70
00:03:20.131 --> 00:03:21.841
cuz they save stuff on their computers.

71
00:03:21.841 --> 00:03:24.750
>> Yeah, it is a lie, yeah,
they don't, where did this go?

72
00:03:24.750 --> 00:03:26.640
Well, you told me you saved everything.

73
00:03:26.640 --> 00:03:29.300
Too bad, it's gone,
because I have now started over

74
00:03:29.300 --> 00:03:32.500
it should work like a brand new machine
and we are and we're ready to go.

75
00:03:32.500 --> 00:03:36.686
>> And that's why the prevalence of using
virtualized environments to do things like

76
00:03:36.686 --> 00:03:41.216
thin clients is very, very, it's becoming
more prevalent anyway cuz it's so easy.

77
00:03:41.216 --> 00:03:42.640
You're having trouble with your computer?

78
00:03:42.640 --> 00:03:44.150
No problem restart it.

79
00:03:44.150 --> 00:03:48.890
And a brand new virtual environment it's
pumped down into that little system and

80
00:03:48.890 --> 00:03:50.650
they have all their tools that they need.

81
00:03:50.650 --> 00:03:52.410
Like Ronnie said, everything
should be up on the central share,

82
00:03:52.410 --> 00:03:53.980
you don't have to worry about it anymore,
right?

83
00:03:53.980 --> 00:03:57.850
>> Yeah, it seemed like that that should
be the ideal and the way that it goes.

84
00:03:57.850 --> 00:03:59.240
But we find out something, right,

85
00:03:59.240 --> 00:04:04.880
because we've now entered into this age
of cyber attacks happening so often now.

86
00:04:04.880 --> 00:04:07.320
And so many different things going on,
Daniel.

87
00:04:07.320 --> 00:04:12.200
That we're no longer keeping up with
it as easy as just reimaging machine.

88
00:04:12.200 --> 00:04:15.231
If I had to do that now, I'd probably
be reimaging everybodyâ€™s machine

89
00:04:15.231 --> 00:04:17.232
at least once a week if
not more often than that.

90
00:04:17.232 --> 00:04:18.329
>> Here comes the weekly rollout, right?

91
00:04:18.329 --> 00:04:22.090
[LAUGH]
>> And so we have to be begin to take

92
00:04:22.090 --> 00:04:25.530
a little bit more time in doing
the analysis of these things.

93
00:04:25.530 --> 00:04:28.150
But really, when it comes down
to right in our analysis and

94
00:04:28.150 --> 00:04:29.750
what we would actually discover is,
all right.

95
00:04:29.750 --> 00:04:32.834
There's malware, we just fix it and
that's pretty much it.

96
00:04:32.834 --> 00:04:36.800
>> That's not really-- you're just kinda
putting a band-aid on the problem instead

97
00:04:36.800 --> 00:04:40.010
of finding what's causing the problem and
fixing that, right?

98
00:04:40.010 --> 00:04:42.000
>> Yeah, and that's the problem,
right, is that we do.

99
00:04:42.000 --> 00:04:43.520
We tend to put a band-aid on it, why?

100
00:04:43.520 --> 00:04:44.470
Do to productivity.

101
00:04:44.470 --> 00:04:45.980
>> Right.
>> We want things to be productive.

102
00:04:45.980 --> 00:04:47.425
>> It's quicker.
>> So it's quicker and

103
00:04:47.425 --> 00:04:49.209
so we can get everybody back to work.

104
00:04:49.209 --> 00:04:51.665
But it really doesn't help
anybody else out, and

105
00:04:51.665 --> 00:04:54.150
it doesn't help your organization out.

106
00:04:54.150 --> 00:04:57.236
If that's what end up
happening is that you only go.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie continue discussing the importance of report analysis for threat mitigation. Here they dive deeper into Cisco's AMP ThreatGRID suite, specifically its Dynamic Analysis, Network File Trajectory, Indications of Compromise, and Security Intelligence events.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie finish their look at analyzing reports for threat mitigation by looking at the open-source solution, Cuckoo. Here they will look at Cuckoo's ability to create a sandbox environment for testing malware and then they show you how to submit threats for evaluation by the Antimalware establishment.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie introduce you to the CVSS 3.0 scoring system. Here they will describe what the CVSS is and reasons for its development, how it's maintained, and its metrics. Then they will begin to explore how to calculate a Base score; looking at Exploitability Metrics like Attack Vector(AV) and Attack Complexity(AC).

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the importance of filesystems when it comes to computer security. Here they dive into filesystems supported by the Windows Operating System, which includes: File Allocation Table(FAT) and New Technology File System(NTFS), as well as how we handle them in a forensically sound way.
episodes.title: Understand Windows File Systems

file size limitation.

317
00:16:47.020 --> 00:16:49.730
And we'll talk about volume size as well,

00:16:49.730 --> 00:16:53.920
On FAT or FAT32, which is probably what
we normally mean when we talk about FAT

00:16:53.920 --> 00:16:59.790
today, a single file size,
the max size is gonna be four gigs.

320
00:16:59.790 --> 00:17:05.780
Now, if you were running like FAT16,
I believe it was 2 Gigs was kinda the max,

321
00:17:05.780 --> 00:17:10.730
but usually on FAT32 it's 4
Gigs is the maximum file size.

322
00:17:10.730 --> 00:17:13.820
In terms of volumes that you do this,

323
00:17:13.820 --> 00:17:17.910
a max of up to 2 terabytes is
what you also have as well.

324
00:17:17.910 --> 00:17:21.030
So you couldn't access drives that
were larger than 2 terabytes.

325
00:17:21.030 --> 00:17:24.726
If you did have a hard drive larger than
2 Terabytes you'd have to partition it

326
00:17:24.726 --> 00:17:27.589
off form another volume to build
be able to access it as well.

327
00:17:27.589 --> 00:17:32.077
The limitation also that we have here
no compression and no encryption.,

328
00:17:32.077 --> 00:17:34.480
that's pretty much it, okay.

329
00:17:34.480 --> 00:17:40.200
So good to kinda solve the little

But good reminder if you're

So when it comes back

So let's come back to this idea.

What are some of those details that I

you might do that or if you go, hey,

00:18:44.960 --> 00:18:49.250
So you've got to understand some of

00:18:49.250 --> 00:18:50.650
the information.

And what might actually have

And this is gonna take the majority of the

now, that I look at it, maybe even

Because this is the one that we all

that we need to make sure that we do take

With the NTFS, there's a couple

00:19:21.146 --> 00:19:24.333
here that we wanna make

00:19:24.333 --> 00:19:29.880
With NTFS, it keeps track of

359
00:19:29.880 --> 00:19:33.690
All right, Daniel,
I just spewed out a gigantic term there.

00:19:33.690 --> 00:19:38.725
Metadata, it sounds fancy, it sounds
French, Daniel, what do you think?

00:19:38.725 --> 00:19:39.373
>> It's Greek actually.

362
00:19:39.373 --> 00:19:43.000
>> It's Greek, it is,
yeah, so feta, fetadata.

363
00:19:43.000 --> 00:19:43.828
It's about cheese [LAUGH].

364
00:19:43.828 --> 00:19:45.540
>> Meta is a Greek term.

365
00:19:45.540 --> 00:19:46.244
>> It is, it is a Greek.

366
00:19:46.244 --> 00:19:48.693
>> It means like under or around.

367
00:19:48.693 --> 00:19:49.878
>> Yeah, kinda surrounding.

368
00:19:49.878 --> 00:19:51.982
>> Right, surrounding and basically,

369
00:19:51.982 --> 00:19:55.010
I always say metadata is
information about data.

370
00:19:55.010 --> 00:19:55.520
>> That's it.

371
00:19:55.520 --> 00:19:56.960
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, it's information about

372
00:19:56.960 --> 00:19:57.524
the information.

373
00:19:57.524 --> 00:19:59.925
>> Right.
>> Okay, so let's kinda make sure that we,

374
00:19:59.925 --> 00:20:01.380
cuz most of the time.

375
00:20:01.380 --> 00:20:04.894
I kinda go, yeah, sure, we'll deal
with the metadata on that stuff.

376
00:20:04.894 --> 00:20:07.253
I may not have a clue what
I'm even talking about, but

377
00:20:07.253 --> 00:20:09.782
let's make sure we know what
we're talking about here.

378
00:20:09.782 --> 00:20:14.080
So for example, Daniel,
it's not the data that's in a file.

379
00:20:14.080 --> 00:20:18.777
So if I say here's a file that has
pay information into it, okay.

380
00:20:18.777 --> 00:20:19.441
>> Right.

381
00:20:19.441 --> 00:20:24.098
>> The metadata of that file might
be information that you might

find out about that file itself,

383
00:20:28.860 --> 00:20:32.530
When that file was actually generated,

384
00:20:32.530 --> 00:20:35.650
When it was modified,
information like that.

385
00:20:35.650 --> 00:20:38.550
Did somebody post a tag on it and

00:20:38.550 --> 00:20:43.710
add additional data to that file, so
that it can be found in some way?

387
00:20:43.710 --> 00:20:47.360
So is data about the actual file or

388
00:20:47.360 --> 00:20:50.990
about the data itself,
when we start to take a look?

389
00:20:50.990 --> 00:20:56.117
Well, NTFS says, look, it's not enough
to say that I can put a file in place,

390
00:20:56.117 --> 00:20:59.243
and make sure that you
can retrieve it back out.

391
00:20:59.243 --> 00:21:04.032
But it also is about keeping
track of metadata here, okay?

392
00:21:04.032 --> 00:21:07.087
And, very important process,
in terms of forensics,

393
00:21:07.087 --> 00:21:09.687
when it comes to things
like time stamping, and

394
00:21:09.687 --> 00:21:14.890
some different information that we have,
you know, that we wanna talk about too.

395
00:21:14.890 --> 00:21:19.320
When we start to take a look
at the metadata of NTFS,

396
00:21:19.320 --> 00:21:22.870
it really does track, let me see,
one, two, three, four, okay?

397
00:21:22.870 --> 00:21:25.050
It tracks four different aspects here and

398
00:21:25.050 --> 00:21:30.040
let me go and type this in,
cuz I didn't do it right here.

399
00:21:30.040 --> 00:21:36.049
And that will help us and this should be
something you want to take a look at too.

400
00:21:36.049 --> 00:21:39.260
And they're all hidden when
you start to take a look here.

401
00:21:39.260 --> 00:21:44.807
So it begins with, oops, all hidden
which would be dollar sign, right?

402
00:21:44.807 --> 00:21:47.988
>> MFT master file table, okay?

403
00:21:47.988 --> 00:21:48.699
>> Yep.

404
00:21:48.699 --> 00:21:55.170
So MFT that makes sense, and
then there's also going to be a bit map.

405
00:21:57.910 --> 00:22:02.410
Then there's also gonna be log, and
nlogs are essentially metadata.

406
00:22:02.410 --> 00:22:08.513
So there's gonna be a log file, and
then ultirnately boot data, all right?

407
00:22:08.513 --> 00:22:12.262
So those are kind of the big things
in terms of metadata that we

408
00:22:12.262 --> 00:22:14.360
keep track, okay?

409
00:22:14.360 --> 00:22:19.690
So it has the ability to actually take
the information, the metadata and store

410
00:22:19.690 --> 00:22:24.190
it in these kind of hidden files that we
have there on the actual drive itself.

411
00:22:24.190 --> 00:22:28.670
To give us what we need, besides just
the files and retrieving the files,

412
00:22:28.670 --> 00:22:32.260
and being able to write and
modify the files themselves.

413
00:22:32.260 --> 00:22:35.510
It keeps track of all that because of
the other things that it does, such as

414
00:22:35.510 --> 00:22:40.310
compression and encryption, which are kind
of the two things that we really do like.

415
00:22:40.310 --> 00:22:44.570
Disk quotas gives us the ability to do
recovery as well as some performance

416
00:22:44.570 --> 00:22:49.330
aspects that are really
neat about NTFS as well.

417
00:22:49.330 --> 00:22:54.070
And even some of the reliability features
that we have available through NTFS.

418
00:22:54.070 --> 00:22:59.200
So these are very important types of
things that we need to know about

419
00:22:59.200 --> 00:23:02.770
the idea of using NTFS for us, okay?

420
00:23:02.770 --> 00:23:06.980
Now, when we start to take a look at this,
right?

421

Remember that because of the preferred
file system, we're likely to see it,

I just don't know of anybody that's said,

I don't even know if you can,

I [CROSSTALK]

[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, so I'm gonna say that,

I mean Windows, yeah.

I can't even remember anybody

00:23:35.200 --> 00:23:36.080
>> Yeah.
>> I just don't

431
00:23:36.080 --> 00:23:36.900
remember anything like that.

So I'm gonna say you're

And that means you have to deal with a lot

When you think that all you're looking for

Those things that we just talked about,

All that about every single file

Okay, now we do need to talk

443

But I have once again come to that point

>> So we need to go ahead and

Who would have guessed,
Daniel that I would-

we never have multiple [INAUDIBLE] wait.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the importance of filesystems when it comes to computer security. Here they dive into filesystems supported by the Windows Operating System, which includes: File Allocation Table(FAT) and New Technology File System(NTFS), as well as how we handle them in a forensically sound way. Also covered: Alternate Data Streams, MACE, EFI, and Timestamps.
episodes.title: Understand Windows File Systems Part 2

Now as we move into NTFS, we start to

Daniel, I'm going to ask you cuz

NTFS goes, sure,

Well, imagine now what

00:16:38.659 --> 00:16:43.809
wherever it's stored on the drive,
it's gonna be kept as a record right here.

296
00:16:43.809 --> 00:16:45.402
So that when your operating system goes,

297
00:16:45.402 --> 00:16:47.880
it doesn't have to search
the entire hard drive.

298
00:16:47.880 --> 00:16:52.270
It can go ahead and look right here and
find where the location of the files and

299
00:16:52.270 --> 00:16:55.060
directories are on that partition.

300
00:16:55.060 --> 00:16:59.400
But this is also the location where it
stores all those additional attributes

301
00:16:59.400 --> 00:17:01.290
that we were talking about,
including file names,

302
00:17:01.290 --> 00:17:04.740
security descriptors and a timestamps.

303
00:17:04.740 --> 00:17:06.620
So this is an important location for

304
00:17:06.620 --> 00:17:10.450
somebody doing forensics
to be able to dive into,

305
00:17:10.450 --> 00:17:14.840
look at all the rich information
that they can get here too, okay?

306
00:17:14.840 --> 00:17:19.272
On top of that, of course,
hidden files that are stored as well,

307
00:17:19.272 --> 00:17:23.622
metadata on the file, NTFS volumes,
logs, file attributes,

308
00:17:23.622 --> 00:17:27.990
all that is stored in what we call
the System Files of partition.

309
00:17:27.990 --> 00:17:31.700
And then this is actually where we
store data, okay, the File Area.

310
00:17:31.700 --> 00:17:34.863
Now, I'm not trying to make too
much of an emphasis of this.

00:17:34.863 --> 00:17:42.908

sector is, where is it stored or

how does NTFS deal with
the corruption of the boot partition?

I mean [CROSSTALK]
>> Out there to get a big flashing warning

just small information that you and

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie discuss the importance of filesystems when it comes to computer security. Here they dive into filesystems supported by the Linux Operating System, which includes: EXT3, EXT4, ReiserFS, Journaling, MBR, Swap files, HFS, and UEFI vs BIOS.
episodes.title: Understand Linux File Systems

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore how to identify, handle, and process digital forensic evidence. Here they continue by comparing and contrasting the three types of evidence (Best/Corroborative/Indirect) as well as the two types of images (Altered/Unaltered), and finally describe the role of Attribution.
episodes.title: Identify Forensic Evidence Part 2

It doesn't always have to

00:15:27.630 --> 00:15:32.255
For electronically stored information and

00:15:36.666 --> 00:15:41.301
Electronically stored information,
original then,

00:15:41.301 --> 00:15:45.837
means any printout or
other output readable by sight,

314
00:15:45.837 --> 00:15:49.950

00:15:49.950 --> 00:15:54.586
An original of a photograph includes

00:15:54.586 --> 00:15:58.079
But for us though, a lot of times

Well here they're saying when it comes

00:16:08.354 --> 00:16:10.675
are especially about computers-

00:16:10.675 --> 00:16:12.330

00:16:12.330 --> 00:16:14.400
And that's one of the things

00:16:15.580 --> 00:16:18.630

The training of it is part of

00:16:22.570 --> 00:16:27.570
Is if the computer is on,

00:16:27.570 --> 00:16:30.940
But rule number two immediately

00:16:30.940 --> 00:16:35.640

00:16:35.640 --> 00:16:39.330
So that they can see what was

00:16:39.330 --> 00:16:41.580

And that is what they want, they want

332
00:16:49.380 --> 00:16:52.090
But that's the key so,

333
00:16:52.090 --> 00:16:56.870
Because there are gonna be issues with

00:16:56.870 --> 00:16:58.218

For example, and I was trying to remember

00:17:00.590 --> 00:17:01.770

00:17:01.770 --> 00:17:05.424
Even though digital evidence may be

00:17:05.424 --> 00:17:09.290

339
00:17:09.290 --> 00:17:13.110
which means If somebody accidentally

00:17:13.110 --> 00:17:16.135

00:17:16.135 --> 00:17:16.740
Okay?
Or

00:17:16.740 --> 00:17:21.350

00:17:21.350 --> 00:17:25.220
the image kind of glitched at

00:17:25.220 --> 00:17:28.037
now you're gonna say, this is what was

345
00:17:28.037 --> 00:17:31.710
Electronic data can be damaged
even during the investigation or

00:17:31.710 --> 00:17:35.200

347
00:17:35.200 --> 00:17:39.210
And I present that and go, but

which means it was modified.

00:17:40.980 --> 00:17:44.740
So it's kinda one of those things

350
00:17:44.740 --> 00:17:49.550
that this is where that order of
volatility draws in, that pulls in here.

351
00:17:49.550 --> 00:17:53.150
And you also want to make sure that you

00:17:53.150 --> 00:17:57.380
It's not always that it has to be that

We actually take the whole and

led approach instead.

In the suspect led approach I say,

The only way to really guard against

Is you have the two different

00:28:03.730 --> 00:28:06.720

00:28:10.550 --> 00:28:14.370

00:28:14.370 --> 00:28:17.130
So when you have that whatever

00:28:19.500 --> 00:28:23.970

00:28:23.970 --> 00:28:29.080

I'm actually talking about it's

00:28:39.550 --> 00:28:41.242

00:28:59.290 --> 00:29:02.710

00:29:13.850 --> 00:29:17.620

topics.title: Endpoint Threat Analysis and Computer Forensics

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore interpreting basic Regular Expressions, aka RegEx. Here they will give you a quick walkthrough of common RegEx functions and operators, then using that knowledge to help them filter the output of a Cisco router's configuration output down to only pertinent data.
episodes.title: Interpret Basic Regular Expressions

Well Daniel, if you were to try and

30 right there in that third octet, and

00:14:49.300 --> 00:14:51.910

It matches a character or

00:15:30.090 --> 00:15:31.580

It means go to the beginning of this,

00:15:35.685 --> 00:15:39.023

00:15:46.095 --> 00:15:50.549

00:15:50.549 --> 00:15:56.065

00:15:57.477 --> 00:16:00.442
The other one, it can actually be there,

00:16:00.442 --> 00:16:04.000

00:16:15.400 --> 00:16:18.840

Anything at the beginning that

00:17:19.500 --> 00:17:21.260

00:17:21.260 --> 00:17:26.020

00:17:33.020 --> 00:17:35.720
And here, now, notice,

00:17:36.860 --> 00:17:42.063

And then we have this other one over here

00:17:53.850 --> 00:17:57.820

00:18:01.760 --> 00:18:06.080

00:18:06.080 --> 00:18:08.730

00:18:16.180 --> 00:18:20.140

yeah this is kinda more of more towards

00:19:02.541 --> 00:19:08.926

00:19:08.926 --> 00:19:10.786

00:19:10.786 --> 00:19:16.370
So if you take a look and you see

00:19:16.370 --> 00:19:21.977

13 at the beginning and at the end, or

Whether you're seeing an opening,

00:19:37.457 --> 00:19:43.900

00:19:43.900 --> 00:19:47.200

00:19:47.200 --> 00:19:51.010

00:19:51.010 --> 00:19:54.410

probably more often than not, that
you're going to get questions on this,

371
00:20:11.330 --> 00:20:16.080
especially about identifying certain
things and about retrieving information.

372
00:20:16.080 --> 00:20:20.470
So let's see just at least
the basic example here,

373
00:20:20.470 --> 00:20:22.190
using the router like I promised you.

374
00:20:23.570 --> 00:20:26.970
So I'm going to our practice labs,
which is a great platform for

375
00:20:26.970 --> 00:20:27.890
us to be able to practice in.

376
00:20:27.890 --> 00:20:29.502
And the great thing is,
you can do this too.

377
00:20:29.502 --> 00:20:31.984
I just opened up the first
Cisco lab that was there.

378
00:20:31.984 --> 00:20:36.130
I turned on the New York edge
router is all I did, and

379
00:20:36.130 --> 00:20:42.020
I put a couple of IP addresses in and
turned on some interfaces.

380
00:20:42.020 --> 00:20:44.980
I'm trying to get it to where
it doesn't look too bad here.

381
00:20:44.980 --> 00:20:45.650
There we go.

382
00:20:45.650 --> 00:20:50.630
Okay, so that way we can go ahead and
put this in here and see what happens.

383
00:20:51.860 --> 00:20:55.160
All right, so
I'm going to do enable, and oops.

384
00:20:55.160 --> 00:20:56.300
Where is my.

385
00:20:56.300 --> 00:20:58.050
Had to press enter.

386
00:20:58.050 --> 00:21:01.730
Here we go, all right so now there it is.

387
00:21:01.730 --> 00:21:07.080
I am now into the router itself and
I am ready to use regular expressions.

388
00:21:07.080 --> 00:21:09.930
Just about everything we type
in is a regular expression but

389
00:21:09.930 --> 00:21:13.290
at the beginning,
kind of the first basic command

390
00:21:13.290 --> 00:21:17.170
that we normally run to when we
don't remember anything else.

391
00:21:17.170 --> 00:21:21.980
Especially on a Cisco router,
it's gonna be show running-config.

392
00:21:21.980 --> 00:21:24.780
And when I do this,
it shows me everything, okay?

393
00:21:24.780 --> 00:21:25.710
So, Daniel, there it is.

394
00:21:25.710 --> 00:21:27.410
There's the current configuration.

395
00:21:27.410 --> 00:21:31.440
As we go through this, we see everything
that we want to and this is great.

396
00:21:31.440 --> 00:21:37.480
I see the interfaces there, descriptions,
IP addresses, whether to shut down or not.

397
00:21:37.480 --> 00:21:41.890
I can see all that great information,
and it continues to scroll on and on.

398
00:21:41.890 --> 00:21:44.390
And this is just a small configuration,

399
00:21:44.390 --> 00:21:48.882
it's probably one of the smallest
configurations we'll normally ever get to.

400
00:21:48.882 --> 00:21:52.560
But now,imagine this as being a production
router or a switch, in which there's a ton

401
00:21:52.560 --> 00:21:57.990
more interfaces on these devices and
there's a ton more information.

402
00:21:57.990 --> 00:22:03.302
And now, if you had to find a certain
amount of information, what would I have

00:22:03.302 --> 00:22:08.972
to do to actually go back into gigabit
Ethernet, or gigabit Ethernet interface.

404
00:22:08.972 --> 00:22:11.592
Interface gigabit ethernet 0/1.

405
00:22:11.592 --> 00:22:16.921
Well, in a regular configuration,
I don't even have to do that.

406
00:22:16.921 --> 00:22:20.528
Let me type in show Int, but
let's go ahead and type those off,

00:22:20.528 --> 00:22:23.440
just in case somebody doesn't know.

408
00:22:23.440 --> 00:22:27.188
And at this point,
it's actually spelled this way.

409
00:22:27.188 --> 00:22:32.108
Gigabit ethernet 0/0 here,

410
00:22:32.108 --> 00:22:36.130
if I remember correctly.

411
00:22:36.130 --> 00:22:37.590
I'm just trying to, okay?

412
00:22:37.590 --> 00:22:40.970
So now you notice, no spaces, nothing.

413
00:22:40.970 --> 00:22:41.870
>> You've got a space.

414
00:22:41.870 --> 00:22:44.290
>> And
I've got a space in my command here.

415
00:22:44.290 --> 00:22:45.760
Well, I did.

416
00:22:45.760 --> 00:22:48.660
There we go.
All right, so

417
00:22:48.660 --> 00:22:50.380
that's the way that she ends up looking.

00:22:50.380 --> 00:22:53.160
Now, that's a lot of typing to
do at the beginning of the your

00:22:53.160 --> 00:22:54.290
actually working with Cisco.

420
00:22:54.290 --> 00:22:57.580
Even though we can use
abbreviations everywhere, and

421
00:22:57.580 --> 00:23:01.190
I recommend that you do, on the exam

422
00:23:01.190 --> 00:23:04.980
So make sure you learn them, don't just

423
00:23:04.980 --> 00:23:07.780
it's not gonna matter that Ryan said
that when you go into the exam, so

00:23:07.780 --> 00:23:09.030
just kind of remember.

425
00:23:09.030 --> 00:23:12.440
Well, I can find that information out and
be able to type that in, but

426
00:23:12.440 --> 00:23:15.500
there are abbreviations,
so we can do that.

427
00:23:15.500 --> 00:23:19.310
But what if we're looking for
something a little bit more specific or

00:23:19.310 --> 00:23:22.550
a little bit more generalized,
whatever it might be here.

429
00:23:22.550 --> 00:23:25.900
So this is where we can use some
of these regular expressions.

430
00:23:25.900 --> 00:23:27.690
So the first one that I'm going to use,

431
00:23:27.690 --> 00:23:31.380
we're gonna start off with
the show running-config again.

432
00:23:31.380 --> 00:23:35.075
And then, we're going to use that pipe
command, which says hey let's go ahead and

00:23:35.075 --> 00:23:39.570

together in this way.

434
00:23:39.570 --> 00:23:43.720
Then I'm gonna do an include and

435
00:23:43.720 --> 00:23:44.820
if I wanted to as well.

436
00:23:44.820 --> 00:23:49.350
I want to say,
I wanna show all of the interfaces here.

437
00:23:49.350 --> 00:23:52.818
Now, if I do that,
I've got an issue sometimes.

438
00:23:52.818 --> 00:23:55.350
Let me go back and
show you what I'm talking about.

439
00:23:55.350 --> 00:23:58.582
Now, even though all of these
are at the beginning of the line.

440
00:23:58.582 --> 00:24:01.643
I wanna make sure that I pick up
only those at the beginning of

441
00:24:01.643 --> 00:24:02.571
the line as well.

442
00:24:02.571 --> 00:24:10.400
So I'm gonna start off with the caret, and
then type in interface and press Enter.

443
00:24:10.400 --> 00:24:13.728
And now notice the output
that I got instead.

444
00:24:13.728 --> 00:24:17.981
It still showed running config,
but now notice it went ahead and

445
00:24:17.981 --> 00:24:22.575
just gave me everything that has
an interface on it, which is great.

446
00:24:22.575 --> 00:24:26.898
It allows me to kind of limit what I
want to see and what I want to do.

447
00:24:26.898 --> 00:24:30.498
If I need to see every single interface,
right, I can do the show run,

448
00:24:30.498 --> 00:24:33.440
which is probably at least
the easiest thing for us to do.

449
00:24:33.440 --> 00:24:36.993
But it puts so much more
information on the machine itself.

450
00:24:36.993 --> 00:24:41.327
And on a router that's really busy,
doing a show run, even though it's not

451
00:24:41.327 --> 00:24:45.067
the hardest thing in the world,
it still adds compute cycles in.

452
00:24:45.067 --> 00:24:46.321
It still has to hold it in RAM,

453
00:24:46.321 --> 00:24:49.660
it still has to do all that stuff
while the router is still functioning.

454
00:24:49.660 --> 00:24:53.250
So it can take away a little bit of
the processing power that we have.

455
00:24:53.250 --> 00:24:56.217
The other thing that we also
want to think about here, okay,

456
00:24:56.217 --> 00:24:57.856
is that the more times I run this.

457
00:24:57.856 --> 00:25:02.615
Let's say that I do one for
each one, for show interface,

458
00:25:02.615 --> 00:25:06.810
gigabit, ethernet, 0/0, 0/1, 0/2.

459
00:25:06.810 --> 00:25:12.725
That's three, whereas in one particular
use of regular expressions here,

460
00:25:12.725 --> 00:25:15.280
and you see it kind of right here.

461
00:25:15.280 --> 00:25:18.560
It's kind of the use of the regular
expression at this point.

462
00:25:18.560 --> 00:25:20.820
In just doing something like this,

463
00:25:20.820 --> 00:25:24.720
it allowed me to actually bring in
all that and put it into one command.

464
00:25:24.720 --> 00:25:28.606
And this is a lot more efficient than
the way that we would have to do this,

465
00:25:28.606 --> 00:25:31.970
if I didn't know at least
the regular expression.

466
00:25:31.970 --> 00:25:36.520
So seeing something like this,
let's take for an example here, okay.

467
00:25:36.520 --> 00:25:41.040
And if they were to show you,
let's say, A, B, C, or D, okay?

468
00:25:41.040 --> 00:25:44.090
Which of the following would
actually include this output?

469
00:25:44.090 --> 00:25:47.550
Well, again, just kind of think
about what this actually shows you,

470
00:25:47.550 --> 00:25:51.360
that the output would actually include,
and what you might end up seeing.

471
00:25:51.360 --> 00:25:54.430
Now along with this,
let's go ahead and do this too.

472
00:25:54.430 --> 00:25:57.470
We did see IP address is assigned on here,
right?

473
00:25:57.470 --> 00:26:00.280
So we saw it, but what if I
wanted to actually go, all right.

474
00:26:01.560 --> 00:26:04.491
Let's kind of add in four or
five more in our minds.

475
00:26:04.491 --> 00:26:07.997
But we'll add all this,
let's say that I want to find out like,

476
00:26:07.997 --> 00:26:11.643
I'm supposed to add an another route
back to Daniel's branch office.

477
00:26:11.643 --> 00:26:16.443
All right, I know that there is one
of these interfaces that doesn't

478
00:26:16.443 --> 00:26:18.195
have an IP address on it.

479
00:26:18.195 --> 00:26:19.736
Again, I'd have to hit show run.

480
00:26:19.736 --> 00:26:23.904
And on the big router, it's just, okay,
click, click, click, click, click, click,

481
00:26:23.904 --> 00:26:25.355
click, whichever one it is..

482
00:26:25.355 --> 00:26:29.905
But instead, what I can do,
maybe, is type in show run.

483
00:26:33.685 --> 00:26:34.580
Gotta spell running right.

484
00:26:36.560 --> 00:26:40.140
And we'll go back and
do just about the same command here.

485
00:26:40.140 --> 00:26:42.985
Actually, we're going to do it
differently, not do the show run here.

486
00:26:42.985 --> 00:26:47.681
That's going to be show
ip interface brief.

487
00:26:47.681 --> 00:26:50.735
So we're doing a very brief
output of the interface.

488
00:26:50.735 --> 00:26:56.484
And then we're going
to tell it to include.

489
00:26:56.484 --> 00:26:58.890
Let's do first exclude here, okay?

490
00:26:58.890 --> 00:27:01.930
Exclude all of the unassigned ones.

491
00:27:01.930 --> 00:27:05.194
Now I'm going to abbreviate this one at
the end, because I don't want to spell out

492
00:27:05.194 --> 00:27:07.059
unassigned cuz I may
actually spell it wrong.

493
00:27:07.059 --> 00:27:09.255
Or let's say that at the beginning here,

494
00:27:09.255 --> 00:27:12.500
unassigned is actually
capitalized in the config.

495
00:27:12.500 --> 00:27:16.060
So I'm just trying to abbreviate what
we have here, and see what happens.

496
00:27:16.060 --> 00:27:19.750
Now as we do this, notice that I'm
actually excluding some of them.

497
00:27:19.750 --> 00:27:22.410
I see all of these interfaces.

498
00:27:22.410 --> 00:27:26.280
But now notice that what's happened
here as I'm excluding the ones

499
00:27:26.280 --> 00:27:30.270
that may actually not be
assigned any IP addresses.

500
00:27:30.270 --> 00:27:32.190
Now, can I confirm that for sure?

501
00:27:32.190 --> 00:27:35.455
Yes, definitely because I can just
run essentially the same command,

502
00:27:35.455 --> 00:27:38.090
show ip interface brief.

503
00:27:39.360 --> 00:27:44.150
And then this time do an include.,
and let's just do the unassigned.

504
00:27:44.150 --> 00:27:47.200
And now, look at this Daniel, there it is.

505
00:27:47.200 --> 00:27:52.120
I can see that it found exactly what I was
looking for on, unassigned right here.

506
00:27:52.120 --> 00:27:55.670
And it sees that those IP
addresses were right here too.

507
00:27:55.670 --> 00:27:57.630
So I could pick one of
those interfaces and

00:27:57.630 --> 00:28:01.212

509
00:28:01.212 --> 00:28:05.091
I should have wrote that down,

510
00:28:05.091 --> 00:28:07.720
Yeah here it is, and

511
00:28:07.720 --> 00:28:12.970
So just a basic idea here of some of

512
00:28:12.970 --> 00:28:16.940
So just using those simple
ones are really neat as well.

513
00:28:18.010 --> 00:28:19.580
Also, Daniel, I can even see,

00:28:19.580 --> 00:28:22.520
even though you can see it right

515
00:28:22.520 --> 00:28:26.849
Remember that on a router that

00:28:26.849 --> 00:28:31.429

which ones are actually down?

517
00:28:31.429 --> 00:28:33.701
So I think I've got every one up, but

518
00:28:33.701 --> 00:28:37.390
I wanna confirm which
ones are actually down.

519
00:28:37.390 --> 00:28:40.633
So, again we can do show run,
but that means I have to go and

520
00:28:40.633 --> 00:28:42.763

521
00:28:42.763 --> 00:28:46.683
Or, I can do show run, oops, maybe not.

Too many n's.

523
00:28:52.730 --> 00:28:57.213
And then, I can also say include.

524
00:28:59.702 --> 00:29:02.602
I'm going to do all
the interfaces in this command.

525
00:29:04.484 --> 00:29:08.084
And then I'm gonna pipe

00:29:08.084 --> 00:29:11.281
And now, oops,
why didn't that show my inter?

00:29:11.281 --> 00:29:14.030
I know why,

528
00:29:16.674 --> 00:29:17.906
>> Interfaces.

529
00:29:17.906 --> 00:29:19.556
>> Interfaces, yeah.

530
00:29:19.556 --> 00:29:20.619
See, this is where it can bite you.

531
00:29:20.619 --> 00:29:21.549
>> Not interface.

532
00:29:21.549 --> 00:29:22.173
>> Right.

533
00:29:22.173 --> 00:29:23.382
>> Yes.
>> This is where it can bite you,

534
00:29:23.382 --> 00:29:25.954
so this is why it's one of those
things where if you're like me,

535
00:29:25.954 --> 00:29:27.972
you're like okay Ronnie,
try and hurry up here.

536
00:29:31.354 --> 00:29:32.453
Try it again.

537
00:29:38.067 --> 00:29:39.340
Oops.

538
00:29:39.340 --> 00:29:42.888
Put my space back in, there we go.

539
00:29:42.888 --> 00:29:44.596
So now I can see, of the interfaces,

540
00:29:44.596 --> 00:29:48.363
let's say that I thought I configured
everything but it still wasn't working.

541
00:29:48.363 --> 00:29:52.454
And then I had to go back and go,
which one didn't I actually shut down?

542
00:29:52.454 --> 00:29:55.755
Now let's say it's this one,
so there it was, okay?

543
00:29:55.755 --> 00:29:58.358
So this one I forgot to do a no shutdown.

544
00:29:58.358 --> 00:30:01.355
And that way I can go and
find out exactly which ones.

545
00:30:01.355 --> 00:30:04.110
The other two do show up, okay?

546
00:30:04.110 --> 00:30:08.658
But notice that we don't have the word
shutdown immediately afterwards,

547
00:30:08.658 --> 00:30:13.072
which helps me to identify these as
being possibilities of what we have.

548
00:30:13.072 --> 00:30:16.611
So this is at least the beginning
of what we're seeing now.

549
00:30:16.611 --> 00:30:22.387
I'm pretty much emphasizing really just
the use of that one expression so far.

550
00:30:22.387 --> 00:30:25.222
But there's gonna be others
that we're going to see.

551
00:30:25.222 --> 00:30:30.128
But what we're going to do is because
I'm running out of time here is

552
00:30:30.128 --> 00:30:34.963
that I wanna continue on with this and
do a couple of more examples.

553
00:30:34.963 --> 00:30:38.542
But then, I wanna show you how we actually
would use this in an analysis type of

554
00:30:38.542 --> 00:30:39.610
way as well.

555
00:30:39.610 --> 00:30:42.370
So Daniel, we'll have to save this for
episode number two.

556
00:30:42.370 --> 00:30:44.290
>> No, no, problem Ronnie,
you have been really cool so far.

557
00:30:44.290 --> 00:30:47.470
As you can see,
it's a bit to wrap your head around.

558
00:30:47.470 --> 00:30:50.910
But if you do get your head wrapped
around it, man, it's extremely powerful.

559
00:30:50.910 --> 00:30:54.250
It will help you out in your day
to day life, that's for sure.

560
00:30:54.250 --> 00:30:55.880
Ronnie, thanks for
showing us Regex so far.

561
00:30:55.880 --> 00:30:58.640
Looking forward to a couple more
examples that he's got lined up for

562
00:30:58.640 --> 00:30:59.270
us in that part two.

563
00:30:59.270 --> 00:31:01.330
So definitely come on back for that.

564
00:31:01.330 --> 00:31:04.460
As for this episode it's time
to sign off for ITProTV.

565
00:31:04.460 --> 00:31:05.722
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

566
00:31:05.722 --> 00:31:06.919
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

567
00:31:06.919 --> 00:31:09.502
>> And we'll see you next time.

568
00:31:09.502 --> 00:31:15.090

00:31:15.090 --> 00:31:18.232
>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore interpreting basic Regular Expressions, aka RegEx. Here they continue using RegEx to filter configuration output in a Cisco router and then transition to using RegEx in Wireshark to filter conversations, drastically reducing the output to only pertinent information.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie explore ethernet headers and their importance as a security vector. Here they will describe the different sections of the header, Layer 2's lack of security measures, and types of common Layer 2 attacks such as DHCP Starvation, ARP Spoofing, and CAM Table Exhaustion.

I'm like?

But all those to our layer

So just be aware.

That list that I just put out there

Which of the following

I mean it makes sense to me, and

Cuz that's when it starts playing tricks

DHCP is an application.

00:21:42.190 --> 00:21:44.230

that's not a layer two attack, but

we'll talk about it when we get to it.

440

So lete's go ahead and take a look here.

441
00:21:48.860 --> 00:21:53.110
And we will start the idea

442
00:21:53.110 --> 00:21:57.920
of doing a CAM table exhaustion attack,
is what we'll take a look at.

443
00:21:57.920 --> 00:22:00.220
So here's the ultimate goal, right?

444
00:22:00.220 --> 00:22:02.500
So when we start, let me move this up.

445
00:22:02.500 --> 00:22:04.610
A normal operation, right?

446
00:22:04.610 --> 00:22:06.410
A switch has a CAM table.

447
00:22:06.410 --> 00:22:10.190
Mac addresses essentially are linked
to switch ports that make sense.

448
00:22:10.190 --> 00:22:12.700
When devices communicate with the switch,

449
00:22:12.700 --> 00:22:16.450
they send their MAC
address table populates.

450
00:22:16.450 --> 00:22:21.278
But there's only a limited amount
of spaces that are available

451
00:22:21.278 --> 00:22:22.744
in that CAM table.

452
00:22:22.744 --> 00:22:27.795
So, the attacker can send many
different MAC address mappings

453
00:22:27.795 --> 00:22:32.572
that are essentially erroneous,
fill-up the CAM table.

454
00:22:32.572 --> 00:22:35.258
And when something like
this ends up happening,

455
00:22:35.258 --> 00:22:40.360
look at the ultimate result here Daniel is
essentially the switch turns into a hub.

456
00:22:40.360 --> 00:22:44.100
And that is because it starts to say,
I don't know what to do.

457
00:22:44.100 --> 00:22:46.550
>> Yeah,
you've confused it beyond all hope.

458
00:22:46.550 --> 00:22:49.920
Now it says well,
I don't want to stop service for you,

459
00:22:49.920 --> 00:22:53.210

go wherever they want to go.

460
00:22:53.210 --> 00:22:57.670
And now we're opened up to listening
to the network at that point.

461
00:22:57.670 --> 00:23:00.620
>> Yeah, and
that's the ultimate goal, right,

462
00:23:00.620 --> 00:23:05.020
behind the idea of a CAM
table exhaustion attack.

463
00:23:05.020 --> 00:23:09.330
Is that if they know that you're not
running any type of protection on

464
00:23:09.330 --> 00:23:10.640

465
00:23:10.640 --> 00:23:16.370
They ultimately know that if they send
enough Mac addresses to that CAM table,

466
00:23:16.370 --> 00:23:20.460
they will essentially exhaust
the possible mappings that are out there.

467
00:23:20.460 --> 00:23:24.220
And the switch has three
basic behaviors right?

468
00:23:24.220 --> 00:23:27.430
It forwards data from
one port to the other.

469
00:23:27.430 --> 00:23:30.390
Or it floods data out

470
00:23:30.390 --> 00:23:33.946
it drops data if it's coming out

471
00:23:33.946 --> 00:23:36.310
So here it's saying look,

472
00:23:36.310 --> 00:23:39.650
I normally would actually forward it as
long there's a match in the CAM table.

473
00:23:39.650 --> 00:23:44.000
But if there is no place now that
you start sending those packets and

474
00:23:44.000 --> 00:23:45.900
I can look up an address.

475
00:23:45.900 --> 00:23:48.430
It doesn't wanna stop
the traffic like Daniel says.

476
00:23:48.430 --> 00:23:50.530
It now just says let me just go ahead and

477
00:23:50.530 --> 00:23:54.900

is still out there and that works.

478
00:23:54.900 --> 00:23:57.930
That means that everybody else
is also communicating broadcast.

479
00:23:57.930 --> 00:24:00.757
Daniel can be sitting over

00:24:00.757 --> 00:24:05.300
Or whatever other device that he wants

482

>> We can use clear FTP here

no one's gonna be able to

484

Until this type of thing happens,

485

486
00:24:19.610 --> 00:24:21.170
>> And so this is important.

487
00:24:21.170 --> 00:24:26.710
It is important for us to understand and

488

Now this is where the for

something.

And then I'm gonna show you where

Go ,Ronnie I can't set that up.

I don't have enough equipment

right here at the end of this episode.

So let's go ahead and-

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into describing the importance of IP headers as a source of security and network information. Here they continue to breakdown the IP packet header, discussing possible security issues. They pick up with the Time-to-Live(TTL) field, Protocol Number, Checksum, and IP addresses.

Or it drops it, so if it goes in and it

Well, a CAM table exhaustion, right,

the goal behind it is to make

Which is, okay, let's just ford out data

Most people don't really even get

And describing,

Because everybody's still gonna get their

The end computer is now making the

So no one is none the wiser, and yet

the attacker is able to glean

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into describing the importance of IP headers as a source of security and network information. Here they cover what's in an IP header (version, length, source&destination addresses, type of service, datagram length, don't fragment flag, more fragment flag) and IP addresses for both IPv4 and IPv6.
episodes.title: Describe IP Headers

>> It is going great.

17

Thank you, Daniel once again,
for having me back on the show.

18

And today, we are continuing on taking

19

Who would have guessed that headers would
actually be such a gigantic field except

20
00:00:42.690 --> 00:00:43.859
for people in Cyber Ops?

21
00:00:43.859 --> 00:00:45.617
>> There's a little bit of them.

22
00:00:45.617 --> 00:00:49.850
>> Yeah,
there's just a few of them [LAUGH].

23
00:00:49.850 --> 00:00:51.650
As we started taking a look at this,

24
00:00:51.650 --> 00:00:55.360
we began with talking about
really layer two headers.

25
00:00:55.360 --> 00:00:58.525
Not transport layer,
that's layer 4, weird.

26
00:00:58.525 --> 00:01:02.120
The Ethernet headers that
we've been talking about.

27
00:01:02.120 --> 00:01:05.460
And now we're moving into
well a little bit of layer 3,

28
00:01:05.460 --> 00:01:08.350
which of course are gonna
be our IP headers.

29
00:01:08.350 --> 00:01:12.765
And we need to have a solid understanding
of what we find in the IP headers

30
00:01:12.765 --> 00:01:17.638
because that's where we can also spot
some of the attacks that go on there too.

31
00:01:17.638 --> 00:01:23.077
So in this one it's a lot more about

32

that we find in the IP 4 headers

33
00:01:28.290 --> 00:01:32.270
So that we can spot where we might
actually have to look as we continue to

34
00:01:32.270 --> 00:01:36.810
move forward in understanding more about
the analysis of what we have to do.

35
00:01:36.810 --> 00:01:39.100
Now, there's a lot more,
of course, to come after this,

36
00:01:39.100 --> 00:01:41.840
we still have layer 4 to go through
as well as the application layer,

37
00:01:41.840 --> 00:01:43.750
the upper layer headers to go through.

38
00:01:43.750 --> 00:01:46.880
But at least kind of start right here.

39
00:01:46.880 --> 00:01:50.340
Now, before we get started into
the IP headers themselves and

40
00:01:50.340 --> 00:01:55.790
start examining them, let's just do a bit
of a refresher on the idea of IP itself

41
00:01:56.790 --> 00:02:00.320
to make sure that we have an understanding
of what we're taking a look at now.

42
00:02:00.320 --> 00:02:04.450
So if we start off with
the Ethernet headers that we

43
00:02:04.450 --> 00:02:08.540
really just took a look at
in previous episodes here.

44
00:02:08.540 --> 00:02:12.940
Remember that everything that we started
off with there in terms of describing

45
00:02:12.940 --> 00:02:16.280
all happens on layer 2 of the OSI model.

46
00:02:16.280 --> 00:02:20.210
And that primarily deals around the fact
that what well we're using MAC addresses

47
00:02:20.210 --> 00:02:25.018
as a source and
destination addresses that we use there.

48
00:02:25.018 --> 00:02:30.269
At layer 3, though, we start moving
into the IP addresses instead and

49
00:02:30.269 --> 00:02:33.696
that's what we need to
focus in on right here.

50
00:02:33.696 --> 00:02:38.456
And there's a lot of information
surrounding layer 3 that we also have

51
00:02:38.456 --> 00:02:39.110
to now.

52
00:02:39.110 --> 00:02:42.580
But let's start off with just making
sure we have a fundamental understanding

53
00:02:42.580 --> 00:02:44.500
of the IP address itself.

54
00:02:44.500 --> 00:02:49.190
And this is kind of the main information
that really is significant to you and

55
00:02:49.190 --> 00:02:51.110
I in terms of networking.

56
00:02:51.110 --> 00:02:54.900
The rest of the data that we're gonna
look at is significant in terms of

57
00:02:54.900 --> 00:02:56.220
Cyber Ops as well.

58
00:02:56.220 --> 00:02:58.812
But this is the one that's
significant in networking and

59
00:02:58.812 --> 00:03:01.406
is a solid foundation that we
need to have before we go on.

60
00:03:01.406 --> 00:03:06.000
And we'll take a look at both IP version
4 and IP version 6 as we see this.

61
00:03:06.000 --> 00:03:09.970
So, on my screen, this is just
a basic tier as we go through.

62
00:03:09.970 --> 00:03:14.340
So in IPv4, let's just kinda make
sure that we understand something.

63
00:03:14.340 --> 00:03:19.180
At this point in your IT career, you and

64
00:03:19.180 --> 00:03:22.580
I are gonna end up starting to
use IP version 6 more often.

65
00:03:22.580 --> 00:03:24.344
Do you still need to know IP version 4?

66
00:03:24.344 --> 00:03:25.640
Yes.

67
00:03:25.640 --> 00:03:27.980
Why?
Because everybody is still using

68
00:03:27.980 --> 00:03:29.270
it right now.

69
00:03:29.270 --> 00:03:33.540
But as the future continues to roll along
at a pace that's it's rolling along,

70
00:03:33.540 --> 00:03:37.860
companies are switching over and they are
starting to move faster towards that end.

71
00:03:37.860 --> 00:03:41.070
But there's millions and
millions of companies and

72
00:03:41.070 --> 00:03:44.180
there's millions of companies that
are slow, kind of lagging behind,

73
00:03:44.180 --> 00:03:49.310
but there are also hundreds of thousands
that's moving forward with this idea.

74
00:03:49.310 --> 00:03:51.220
So it's still gonna take
a little bit of time.

75
00:03:51.220 --> 00:03:52.550
So you need to know both.

76
00:03:52.550 --> 00:03:56.034
But as you head into the future, the great
thing is if you start off knowing now at

77
00:03:56.034 --> 00:03:59.575
least the basics, it's gonna help you as
you actually get into it in the future.

78
00:03:59.575 --> 00:04:04.360
So in IPv4, which is pretty much
the addressing that we've been using

79
00:04:04.360 --> 00:04:09.318
all along at this point, remember
that this is a 32 bit binary address.

80
00:04:09.318 --> 00:04:13.676
And when we take a look at,
here's an example that I went ahead and

81
00:04:13.676 --> 00:04:18.450
typed out for us as well, is that it
normally ends up looking like this.

82
00:04:18.450 --> 00:04:22.200
Binary, of course, is a string of 1s and
0s, there's 32 of them.

83
00:04:22.200 --> 00:04:25.560
And what we do to help us to separate
this out, to make it a little bit more

84
00:04:25.560 --> 00:04:31.800
manageable, is that we put in
a dot in between every eight bits.

85
00:04:31.800 --> 00:04:35.960
So that we end up with four chunks
of eight bits, what we call octets.

86
00:04:35.960 --> 00:04:41.900
Each one of these essentially is in
octet of the actual address itself.

87
00:04:41.900 --> 00:04:48.880
Now that's not super significant for
networking, but what is significant though

88
00:04:48.880 --> 00:04:55.300
is that this 32 bit number is
divided to 2 separate portions.

89
00:04:55.300 --> 00:04:57.960
One that tells us what
we call the NetworkID.

90
00:04:57.960 --> 00:05:04.660
In other words, the group that this
particular address belongs to.

91
00:05:04.660 --> 00:05:08.150
And then of course,
