A router is supposed to see that and
go done, it's invalid on this network.

321
00:17:46.289 --> 00:17:51.218
So if you get something like this,
hopefully this follows the logic, Dan.

322
00:17:51.218 --> 00:17:55.132
And now all of a sudden it arrives at your
machine and you're running Wireshark.

323
00:17:55.132 --> 00:17:59.219
And you go hey let me look at the version,
IP version 7.

324
00:17:59.219 --> 00:18:02.444
>> [LAUGH]
>> Hm, what do you think Daniel?

325
00:18:02.444 --> 00:18:03.499
Do you think somebody's manipulated that?

326
00:18:03.499 --> 00:18:08.250
>> Yeah, I think someone's probably having
a little fun and some tomfoolery is afoot.

327
00:18:08.250 --> 00:18:09.164
And we need to pay attention to it.

328
00:18:09.164 --> 00:18:12.940
>> Yeah, the very fact is at least
something happened that the RFC said

329
00:18:12.940 --> 00:18:14.630
shouldn't happen, right?

330
00:18:14.630 --> 00:18:19.231
Which says, hey if it's not a 4 or
6, the router says drop it.

331
00:18:19.231 --> 00:18:23.787
Somehow they are able to take at
least that one field and say what, 7,

332
00:18:23.787 --> 00:18:25.830
router doesn't drop it.

333
00:18:25.830 --> 00:18:30.728
Well, that kind of lets you know
something else may be happening here.

334
00:18:30.728 --> 00:18:35.399
[LAUGH] So just even something that
simple could be what you want to also pay

335
00:18:35.399 --> 00:18:39.878
attention to as you start seeing this in-
>> Something is rotten in Denmark, Ronnie.

336
00:18:39.878 --> 00:18:42.314
[LAUGH]
>> Something is very rotten in Denmark as

337
00:18:42.314 --> 00:18:43.780
you start to see this.

338
00:18:43.780 --> 00:18:46.170
The other thing that we also have
right next to it, of course,

339
00:18:46.170 --> 00:18:48.250
is the header link field, okay?

340
00:18:48.250 --> 00:18:51.820
So this is a 4-bit field on
the length of the IP header.

341
00:18:51.820 --> 00:18:57.290
Now, this is important, as well, because
we told you what the limitations are.

342
00:18:57.290 --> 00:18:59.740
So if we start to take a look at it,
right,

343
00:18:59.740 --> 00:19:05.180
because of the way that this is going
across horizontally, it's the 32 bits.

344
00:19:05.180 --> 00:19:09.832
And unless my math was
wrong cuz I counted 32,

345
00:19:09.832 --> 00:19:14.133
64, 96, 128, 160, 192 and

346
00:19:14.133 --> 00:19:18.221
I think there is a possibility of 256.

347
00:19:18.221 --> 00:19:22.291
If you get a header length
field that says something,

348
00:19:22.291 --> 00:19:26.645
what maximum of 256,
that should also tell you what?

349
00:19:26.645 --> 00:19:30.660
Somebody else has added in additional data

350
00:19:30.660 --> 00:19:33.550
into the header that probably
shouldn't be there, okay?

351
00:19:33.550 --> 00:19:36.762
So if it was able to do that,
now this does have to have

352
00:19:36.762 --> 00:19:40.573
a minimum header length of 20,
make sure I'm telling you.

353
00:19:40.573 --> 00:19:45.569
Yeah, 20 bytes, but overall though,

354
00:19:45.569 --> 00:19:50.437
okay, it should at least be 20 bytes.

355
00:19:50.437 --> 00:19:53.470
But it shouldn't be over 256
if I remember correctly.

356
00:19:54.770 --> 00:19:58.990
So pay attention right there as well,
that is something else

357
00:19:58.990 --> 00:20:02.160
that could be taken advantage of too,
if you start seeing that.

358
00:20:02.160 --> 00:20:04.580
And that means you have to inspect
a little bit more closely.

359
00:20:04.580 --> 00:20:07.801
And type of service,
this is the one that gets confusing,

360
00:20:07.801 --> 00:20:11.443
because you'll see a couple of
different names for this as well.

361
00:20:11.443 --> 00:20:17.346
So you might end up where inside of
Wireshark it doesn't just say TOS or

362
00:20:17.346 --> 00:20:18.857
Type of Service.

363
00:20:18.857 --> 00:20:23.838
You end up seeing something that
says like this, DSCP or ECM, okay?

364
00:20:23.838 --> 00:20:30.250
This stands for Data Service Code Point
and Explicit Congestion Notification.

365
00:20:31.980 --> 00:20:36.065
Both of those are different types of
service, and what the heck is that about?

366
00:20:36.065 --> 00:20:40.535
Well, remember that as I told you that
different types of data have different

367
00:20:40.535 --> 00:20:42.685
requirements that may have to go on.

368
00:20:42.685 --> 00:20:45.673
And they use the IP address
to help deliver that.

369
00:20:45.673 --> 00:20:50.404
Well, this is just telling us the type
of service literally that we might

370
00:20:50.404 --> 00:20:53.670
need according to what is told here.

371
00:20:53.670 --> 00:20:56.577
So for example let's take void traffic, or

372
00:20:56.577 --> 00:21:01.854
we can actually take just regular FTP
traffic, whatever we want to do, right?

373
00:21:01.854 --> 00:21:06.976
Well, one we can say, take as long
as you want to get there, okay?

374
00:21:06.976 --> 00:21:12.571
So if I'm transferring files
over to Daniel over FTP, okay?

375
00:21:12.571 --> 00:21:15.779
Well Daniel just knows I just
have to wait for it to finish,

376
00:21:15.779 --> 00:21:18.010
it takes however long time it is.

377
00:21:18.010 --> 00:21:20.051
Well, that comes under that
type of service as well.

378
00:21:20.051 --> 00:21:22.830
It just says it's gonna
take a little bit of time.

379
00:21:22.830 --> 00:21:25.995
But if I wanted to prioritize
that service, okay,

380
00:21:25.995 --> 00:21:29.982
I could change this here,
explicit congestion notification.

381
00:21:29.982 --> 00:21:32.609
Saying, look as it goes
across these devices,

382
00:21:32.609 --> 00:21:35.510
let me say I've experienced
some congestion here.

383
00:21:35.510 --> 00:21:40.160
And kind of wrap it around the right
particular path it needs to go

384
00:21:40.160 --> 00:21:41.860
to do whatever else it needs.

385
00:21:41.860 --> 00:21:46.730
So it's right here that you also end up
seeing this type of information as well

386
00:21:46.730 --> 00:21:53.358
inside of that DSCP,
the data service code protection point.

387
00:21:53.358 --> 00:21:55.920
We don't tend to see a lot
of manipulation here

388
00:21:55.920 --> 00:21:58.300
as it is really not needed right here.

389
00:21:58.300 --> 00:22:03.800
The other one, of course, is the overall
datagram length or the packet length.

390
00:22:03.800 --> 00:22:06.150
You'll see both of those terms here.

391
00:22:06.150 --> 00:22:08.560
I chose the more technical of the two.

392
00:22:08.560 --> 00:22:11.630
Remember in the OSI Model,
at layer three we call them packets.

393
00:22:11.630 --> 00:22:13.488
At layer two, we call them frames.

394
00:22:13.488 --> 00:22:16.062
I don't know why I'm going in this order,
[LAUGH] but

395
00:22:16.062 --> 00:22:18.118
layer four we call them segments, okay?

396
00:22:18.118 --> 00:22:21.951
So segments at layer four,
packets at layer three, and

397
00:22:21.951 --> 00:22:25.670
layer two frames,
as far as the OSI Model goes.

398
00:22:25.670 --> 00:22:30.209
But inside of the header itself, okay,
you may see where people describe this,

399
00:22:30.209 --> 00:22:33.744
as like I said, what you call
the idea of the total length here,

400
00:22:33.744 --> 00:22:37.046
of the entirety of everything
that it's sending, okay?

401
00:22:37.046 --> 00:22:41.769
I just called it the datagram length
because that's technically more correct at

402
00:22:41.769 --> 00:22:43.234
this particular point.

403
00:22:43.234 --> 00:22:48.342
This is tricky, okay, and
the reason why this is tricky,

404
00:22:48.342 --> 00:22:52.629
let's do a kind of exam suggestion hint,
okay?

405
00:22:52.629 --> 00:22:55.990
Daniel, so a little pop up should
actually appear and then [SOUND].

406
00:22:55.990 --> 00:22:58.781
>> [LAUGH]
>> Here is an example that you should pay

407
00:22:58.781 --> 00:22:59.760
attention to.

408
00:22:59.760 --> 00:23:00.900
There is what we should see.

409
00:23:00.900 --> 00:23:05.022
So if you see something like this and
you will get weird numbers, right?

410
00:23:05.022 --> 00:23:09.340
So let's go back to the diagram and let me
kind of show you what I'm talking about.

411
00:23:09.340 --> 00:23:13.185
Remember I just described header length,
right, okay?

412
00:23:13.185 --> 00:23:19.993
Datagram length, those two,
it sounds like it can be a bit confusing,

413
00:23:19.993 --> 00:23:24.780
right, 4 bits here okay,
and versus 16 bits.

414
00:23:24.780 --> 00:23:27.835
But the header length is really
describing how long this header is.

415
00:23:27.835 --> 00:23:32.424
Whereas the datagram describes this as
well as the payload that can be done.

416
00:23:32.424 --> 00:23:36.943
So we have a maximum of 16
bits here that's actually just

417
00:23:36.943 --> 00:23:39.438
describing the length, okay?

418
00:23:39.438 --> 00:23:44.776
Now, when we start to see that, if you
actually start to take a look at that.

419
00:23:44.776 --> 00:23:51.425
It's very easy, okay, to kind of get
numbers confused a little bit, right?

420
00:23:51.425 --> 00:23:54.864
4 bits here, okay, 2 to the 4th power,

421
00:23:54.864 --> 00:23:58.794
yeah, you start to think
about stuff like that.

422
00:23:58.794 --> 00:24:04.000
And then you start getting 16 bits
here and you start going 2 to that.

423
00:24:04.000 --> 00:24:05.809
What is this actually about?

424
00:24:05.809 --> 00:24:10.756
Is it 16, or is it 2 to the 16,

425
00:24:10.756 --> 00:24:17.079
65,536 as far as the overall length?

426
00:24:17.079 --> 00:24:19.500
And that's why you have to
pay attention to the MAC.

427
00:24:19.500 --> 00:24:24.920
If they ask you about the overall
length of the entire packet,

428
00:24:26.360 --> 00:24:30.270
make sure you know that this is 16 bits,
here, okay?

429
00:24:30.270 --> 00:24:34.810
And that is what we want, because that's
actually gonna be 65,000 bytes is gonna be

430
00:24:34.810 --> 00:24:40.860
your maximum IP data packet that
you'll also see right here, too.

431
00:24:40.860 --> 00:24:42.150
Don't get confused.

432
00:24:42.150 --> 00:24:45.966
Don't try and do this, which is what most
people do, go, Ryan actually did this.

433
00:24:45.966 --> 00:24:51.106
32, 64, and you start adding up all
of this stuff and go, all of that.

434
00:24:51.106 --> 00:24:53.320
Yeah, that's 192.

435
00:24:53.320 --> 00:24:54.180
Don't do that.

436
00:24:54.180 --> 00:24:55.980
Pay attention to what they're looking for,

437
00:24:55.980 --> 00:24:59.330
which is right here under
the datagram length itself.

438
00:24:59.330 --> 00:25:05.470
This particular field, not so
much an attack field for hackers.

439
00:25:05.470 --> 00:25:06.240
Don't get me wrong.

440
00:25:06.240 --> 00:25:09.670
All of a sudden somebody's gonna say
it is an attack field, and that's fine.

441
00:25:09.670 --> 00:25:12.772
But, it's not really
the focus of most of them.

442
00:25:12.772 --> 00:25:16.200
This is just reporting what
the maximum size is possibly.

443
00:25:16.200 --> 00:25:18.770
Everything else should be less than that,
okay?

444
00:25:18.770 --> 00:25:22.750
So as we send chunks of data across,
the packets itself,

445
00:25:22.750 --> 00:25:27.370
it shouldn't get any larger
than 65,536 bytes, okay?

446
00:25:27.370 --> 00:25:31.530
So if we start seeing abnormally
large ones, called jumbos, okay?

447
00:25:31.530 --> 00:25:36.220
And if we start seeing little
tiny ones underneath the,

448
00:25:36.220 --> 00:25:39.740
like 42 bytes or so, whatever it is.

449
00:25:39.740 --> 00:25:42.440
They're called runts, something like that.

450
00:25:42.440 --> 00:25:44.380
Yeah, I can't remember the thing but

451
00:25:44.380 --> 00:25:46.980
they're fairly similar to
what we see there, okay.

452
00:25:48.000 --> 00:25:53.086
Every single datagram that is sent
across must also essentially come up and

453
00:25:53.086 --> 00:25:55.270
generate a unique ID number.

454
00:25:55.270 --> 00:25:58.640
Okay, now this unique ID number,

455
00:25:58.640 --> 00:26:03.370
along with what we call these different
flags here, and this fragment offset,

456
00:26:03.370 --> 00:26:08.310
these all work together and they all
help us in a lot of different things.

457
00:26:08.310 --> 00:26:12.640
But, the unique ID number is to almost
make sure that we don't lose it in its

458
00:26:12.640 --> 00:26:15.290
transit as it goes across network and
also,

459
00:26:15.290 --> 00:26:18.265
these different frags,
these different, I keep saying frags.

460
00:26:18.265 --> 00:26:20.010
>> [LAUGH]
>> Fragments and

461
00:26:20.010 --> 00:26:23.410
flags here also help us out, too, okay?

462
00:26:23.410 --> 00:26:26.500
These ideas of different
flags that you might have,

463
00:26:26.500 --> 00:26:30.070
okay, there's what we call
a don't fragment frag.

464
00:26:30.070 --> 00:26:31.295
Don't fragment flag.

465
00:26:31.295 --> 00:26:32.400
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm not gonna be able to say it.

466
00:26:32.400 --> 00:26:34.220
>> That's a tongue-twister,
Ronnie, isn't it?

467
00:26:34.220 --> 00:26:35.170
>> It is, my gosh.

468
00:26:35.170 --> 00:26:37.880
Don't fragment flag, okay?

469
00:26:37.880 --> 00:26:41.460
And then you'll also have
a fragment more flag.

470
00:26:41.460 --> 00:26:43.540
Well, what the heck is that about?

471
00:26:43.540 --> 00:26:45.681
Well, the very fact is all
data is not the same size.

472
00:26:45.681 --> 00:26:48.775
Just like what Daniel was describing
a little bit earlier, okay?

473
00:26:48.775 --> 00:26:54.190
And that means that if now I am ready
to send out a chunk of data that's

474
00:26:54.190 --> 00:27:00.110
bigger than what my maximum datagram
may be, well, do I just toss it?

475
00:27:00.110 --> 00:27:01.550
Is that my goal?

476
00:27:01.550 --> 00:27:04.040
No, the goal is to get it
delivered to the other side.

477
00:27:04.040 --> 00:27:05.500
And well, how do I do that?

478
00:27:05.500 --> 00:27:11.000
Well all of this information, it is about
keeping that identification, right?

479
00:27:11.000 --> 00:27:14.429
So Daniel's example of the ten page or
ten gig,

480
00:27:14.429 --> 00:27:18.046
whatever it was that we
said a little bit earlier.

481
00:27:18.046 --> 00:27:22.918
If we have to divide that up, well,
what do we actually also put there

482
00:27:22.918 --> 00:27:26.871
that will allow us to be able
to get it all back together?

483
00:27:26.871 --> 00:27:31.176
So, dividing it all back up
here in the 16-bit identifier,

484
00:27:31.176 --> 00:27:36.062
saying where we are actually gonna
allow for fragmentation to happen.

485
00:27:36.062 --> 00:27:38.412
And we're saying,
here's where it's going to happen and

486
00:27:38.412 --> 00:27:41.702
this is where you're essentially gonna
stamp every single one of those pieces, so

487
00:27:41.702 --> 00:27:44.477
that the other side's gonna be able
to put everything back together.

488
00:27:44.477 --> 00:27:45.810
That's fine.

489
00:27:45.810 --> 00:27:50.870
And then, there's also the do not
fragment flag that can also happen, too.

490
00:27:50.870 --> 00:27:57.230
This can be a target of what we
call an insertion attack, okay?

491
00:27:57.230 --> 00:27:59.425
Insertion attack essentially changes that,

492
00:27:59.425 --> 00:28:02.080
it says look,
what I'm gonna do is say this.

493
00:28:02.080 --> 00:28:04.545
Look at how big it is,
I'm not gonna allow it to fragment.

494
00:28:04.545 --> 00:28:07.450
Well, what essentially happens
is it gets larger than this.

495
00:28:07.450 --> 00:28:08.750
It's not allowed.

496
00:28:08.750 --> 00:28:13.135
So if I do a do not fragment flag.

497
00:28:13.135 --> 00:28:14.655
>> [LAUGH]
>> I'm not gonna be able to say it.

498
00:28:14.655 --> 00:28:18.119
>> Yeah, it's gonna do [CROSSTALK]
>> It's gonna cause

499
00:28:18.119 --> 00:28:22.040
some issues where I might never
receive that particular packet.

500
00:28:22.040 --> 00:28:26.240
So, just kind of realize that
that is something else that can

501
00:28:26.240 --> 00:28:27.950
also be seen right here.

502
00:28:27.950 --> 00:28:34.530
So this whole 32 bits right across here,
really, it does help in making sure that

503
00:28:34.530 --> 00:28:39.140
data gets across to where it needs to go,
especially when it does need to fragment.

504
00:28:39.140 --> 00:28:44.320
Sometimes you do have these unusual
things that don't need to fragment, and

505
00:28:44.320 --> 00:28:48.780
you just have to take it as it, but
those devices also then must be set.

506
00:28:48.780 --> 00:28:50.360
Say, I will accept these.

507
00:28:50.360 --> 00:28:52.000
And you will see certain things like that,

508
00:28:52.000 --> 00:28:56.060
especially in things like
sands that are out there.

509
00:28:56.060 --> 00:28:58.843
The jumbo frames,
when you start doing stuff like that.

510
00:28:58.843 --> 00:29:00.217
You're essentially saying,

511
00:29:00.217 --> 00:29:03.806
don't fragment exactly where this actually
is saying that needs to be done, but

512
00:29:03.806 --> 00:29:06.738
just kind of realize that this is
part of that stuff that happens.

513
00:29:06.738 --> 00:29:08.630
>> But
this is a very controlled environment.

514
00:29:08.630 --> 00:29:09.470
>> Very controlled environment.

515
00:29:09.470 --> 00:29:12.230
>> We're doing that for
a specific purpose.

516
00:29:12.230 --> 00:29:15.990
We're not taking advantage of it for
maliciousness.

517
00:29:15.990 --> 00:29:16.680
>> Yeah.

518
00:29:16.680 --> 00:29:20.080
If you're setting this,
it's because you're changing it, and

519
00:29:20.080 --> 00:29:21.260
not a machine, normally.

520
00:29:21.260 --> 00:29:22.630
>> Yeah.
>> A machine will actually be

521
00:29:22.630 --> 00:29:23.561
the one that says, and

522
00:29:23.561 --> 00:29:26.753
they'll actually make sure that everything
else works the way they want to.

523
00:29:26.753 --> 00:29:29.470
But, just kinda realize
that this is a part and

524
00:29:29.470 --> 00:29:31.846
portion of what we end up seeing, okay?

525
00:29:31.846 --> 00:29:36.545
Now there are a lot, well,
a few more headers for us to check out.

526
00:29:36.545 --> 00:29:40.910
But I'm realizing something, Daniel, as I
looked over my shoulder over here that I

527
00:29:40.910 --> 00:29:46.772
have once again been able to challenge
the clock and beaten it, again.

528
00:29:46.772 --> 00:29:47.380
[LAUGH].
>> [LAUGH].

529
00:29:47.380 --> 00:29:50.720
>> Guess it has ticked its last tock for
this episode, but

530
00:29:50.720 --> 00:29:52.270
Ronnie has a little bit more for
us to go through.

531
00:29:52.270 --> 00:29:55.981
And when I say a little bit, I probably
mean probably two more episodes.

532
00:29:55.981 --> 00:29:56.506
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

533
00:29:56.506 --> 00:29:57.690
>> So we will have to make room for

534
00:29:57.690 --> 00:29:59.770
that in a part two,
maybe even a part three.

535
00:29:59.770 --> 00:30:01.210
So definitely join us back for that.

536
00:30:01.210 --> 00:30:02.350
Ronnie, thanks for dropping by today.

537
00:30:02.350 --> 00:30:03.980
I appreciate your time and effort.

538
00:30:03.980 --> 00:30:06.365
We do appreciate our audience out

As for this episode,

>> Thank you for watching ITPro.TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into describing the importance of IP headers as a source of security and network information. Here they continue to breakdown the IP packet header, discussing possible security issues. They pick up with the Time-to-Live(TTL) field, Protocol Number, Checksum, and IP addresses.
episodes.title: Describe IP Headers Part 2

thank you again for

If not Daniel, you'd be the one that

favorite topic in the world.

Now, we understand all of us yeah,

You do need to at least pay attention

And that's kind of the big major

So that's where we're picking up from.

So remember that last time we really
just started diving into some of

29

the different headers that you see at,
of course their IP header here and

that's where we will

So let's go and take a look at my screen.

Last time we really did talk about pretty

And I wanted to go back for a moment and

Because of the way that this particular

On the 16-bit identifier,
we talked about is the way that it

The flags,

And of course, even the more,

>> [LAUGH]
>> The more fragments as far as

the offset,
all these are combined together and

45

work together very well to ensure that
we have smooth delivery of the data.

46
00:02:20.461 --> 00:02:24.978
When it sends and knows exactly where
to break it apart, when it gets at

47
00:02:24.978 --> 00:02:30.122
the receiving machine, it knows exactly

48
00:02:30.122 --> 00:02:34.998
That is pretty much what this

49
00:02:34.998 --> 00:02:40.912
All right, here in the flags,
which again I'm gonna kinda mangle here.

50
00:02:40.912 --> 00:02:44.761
Remember that we can actually have an
insertion tag where somebody actually does

51
00:02:44.761 --> 00:02:45.788
changes the values.

52
00:02:45.788 --> 00:02:52.361
And one of the ones that could absolutely
be a kind of downfall of your network,

53
00:02:52.361 --> 00:02:57.556
right, is if these D16-bit
identifier also get changed.

54
00:02:57.556 --> 00:03:01.908
Remember that because this

55
00:03:01.908 --> 00:03:05.347
is designed to help us

56
00:03:05.347 --> 00:03:08.542
If somebody is able to come in here and

57
00:03:08.542 --> 00:03:12.945
they don't have to do a heavy

58
00:03:12.945 --> 00:03:16.488
All they have to do and actually do just

59

change it to now where it doesn't know

60
00:03:20.046 --> 00:03:24.975
So this is also subject to an attack of
something like an insertion attack as

61
00:03:24.975 --> 00:03:27.412
well in which it can be manipulated.

62
00:03:27.412 --> 00:03:30.946
So be very careful about this, too.

63
00:03:30.946 --> 00:03:36.091
The other portion on the 13-bit
frag offset that we also

64
00:03:36.091 --> 00:03:41.131
see in these flags as well is
that it can end up helping with

65
00:03:41.131 --> 00:03:46.178
somebody trying to do what we
call an ICMP attack as well.

66
00:03:46.178 --> 00:03:49.935
Inside of this ICMP attack, right?

67
00:03:49.935 --> 00:03:55.222
We can get it to where this
particular type of fragment offset,

68
00:03:55.222 --> 00:04:01.031
gives us this ability to have ICMP
generate at the other end, right?

69
00:04:01.031 --> 00:04:06.627
A reassembly time exceeded command
when it's not really necessary.

70
00:04:06.627 --> 00:04:10.193
And that just let's whoever
actually sent it, the attacker,

71
00:04:10.193 --> 00:04:12.962
know that something else is going on here,
too.

72
00:04:12.962 --> 00:04:16.674
So just pay attention to some of these
other things that we'll also see.

73
00:04:16.674 --> 00:04:19.946
The Time-To-Live, hey,
is exactly like it sounds.

74
00:04:19.946 --> 00:04:24.610
This is kinda the loop prevention
that we also have setup here, too.

75
00:04:24.610 --> 00:04:28.664
Every time a packet goes through a router,
it has,

76
00:04:28.664 --> 00:04:33.109
the first time it sets
whatever the Time-To-LIve is.

77
00:04:33.109 --> 00:04:35.677
So usually whatever the maximum value is,
let's say,

78
00:04:35.677 --> 00:04:37.870
I'm just making this up at this point,
right?

79
00:04:37.870 --> 00:04:39.924
Let's say it's 255, okay?

80
00:04:39.924 --> 00:04:44.596
At the first router it says I'm setting it
255, then it goes to another router, and

81
00:04:44.596 --> 00:04:47.422
then decrements to 254 and
continues to go down.

82
00:04:47.422 --> 00:04:52.728
So we have it where it's 16, the next
one would go through 15, it makes sense.

83
00:04:52.728 --> 00:04:57.510
All right, so Daniel let's talk
about which type of attack could end

84
00:04:57.510 --> 00:05:00.981
up happening here at this
idea of the time to live.

85
00:05:00.981 --> 00:05:05.124
I think about it and
go what's the big deal, so what?

86
00:05:05.124 --> 00:05:09.131
It just tells me it's not
gonna loop forever, okay?

87
00:05:09.131 --> 00:05:13.467
So I think about it, didn't sound like
it is really a big deal, does it?

88
00:05:13.467 --> 00:05:18.017
>> I would think that the fact that you
say, it's not going to loop forever, that

89
00:05:18.017 --> 00:05:22.325
should key something in our brains that
says, what if we made it loop forever?

90
00:05:22.325 --> 00:05:24.193
Or we gave it no time at all.

91
00:05:24.193 --> 00:05:24.774
>> Yeah.

92
00:05:24.774 --> 00:05:27.738
>> That kind of thing, and these can
start playing havoc on a network,

93
00:05:27.738 --> 00:05:29.725
maybe lead to some sort
of denial of service.

94
00:05:29.725 --> 00:05:33.079
>> Yeah, it really can because
ultimately what it's helping

95
00:05:33.079 --> 00:05:35.234
to do of course is get to the other end.

96
00:05:35.234 --> 00:05:39.586
If it never gets to the other end, well
then we're actually in a denial of service

97
00:05:39.586 --> 00:05:41.453
again in not being able to do that.

98
00:05:41.453 --> 00:05:46.439
With this idea of the Time-To-Live,
we can manipulate the TTL value to be

99
00:05:46.439 --> 00:05:50.013
too low as well,
before it reaches the destination.

100
00:05:50.013 --> 00:05:52.663
And if you think about that, right?

101
00:05:52.663 --> 00:05:53.652
That's what Daniel is talking about.

102
00:05:53.652 --> 00:05:57.010
We set it too low,
well now no packets get there.

103
00:05:57.010 --> 00:06:00.308
So imagine that we could go
to a router that'll say this,

104
00:06:00.308 --> 00:06:04.310
maybe two hops before the destination,
before Daniel's network.

105
00:06:04.310 --> 00:06:08.444
And I'm able to get in there and
manipulate something to where I'm saying,

106
00:06:08.444 --> 00:06:10.640
I'm gonna change the TTL at this point,

107
00:06:10.640 --> 00:06:13.885
anything that comes into one
maybe goes to this IP address.

108
00:06:13.885 --> 00:06:18.033
Well, it's two hops away from Daniel,
and that means at that router, though,

109
00:06:18.033 --> 00:06:20.534
Daniel might not get data
that's coming back and

110
00:06:20.534 --> 00:06:24.630
has got this time limit, and says, no,
it should make it to the end there.

111
00:06:24.630 --> 00:06:26.580
And it's not gonna make it to the end.

112
00:06:26.580 --> 00:06:31.693
So this is where we have something like
this that can really kind of trip us up.

113
00:06:31.693 --> 00:06:34.895
The other thing that TTL
also helps us with, right?

114
00:06:34.895 --> 00:06:39.914
You take this and of course the IP
identity field up here at the top.

115
00:06:39.914 --> 00:06:44.532
You can use that to help spot
a spoofing attack too, okay?

116
00:06:44.532 --> 00:06:48.659
Now the reason why is because
a long with the identity, okay?

117
00:06:48.659 --> 00:06:52.019
If you start seeing the TTL value, okay?

118
00:06:52.019 --> 00:06:55.562
And it's all coming from
the same exact source.

119
00:06:55.562 --> 00:06:58.476
In other words the same
identifier is identical.

120
00:06:58.476 --> 00:07:00.464
Well, remember that this is
supposed to be identical.

121
00:07:00.464 --> 00:07:02.206
If we chop up a block, right?

122
00:07:02.206 --> 00:07:04.265
It's suppose to be
essentially a serial number,

123
00:07:04.265 --> 00:07:06.038
so that you can go and
kinda reassemble it.

124
00:07:06.038 --> 00:07:07.812
But what if it's identical?

125
00:07:07.812 --> 00:07:10.445
Like 16,000 of them and is identical and

126
00:07:10.445 --> 00:07:12.818
the TTL is exactly
the same on all of them.

127
00:07:12.818 --> 00:07:16.675
Well, they're sending repeating packets
which shouldn't be repeating, okay?

128
00:07:16.675 --> 00:07:18.795
So somehow this can help you go hey,,

129
00:07:18.795 --> 00:07:22.190
somebody is trying to spoof
something else is going on here.

130
00:07:22.190 --> 00:07:23.968
So just kind of be aware.

131
00:07:23.968 --> 00:07:26.822
And the other thing also in
these identifiers, right?

132
00:07:26.822 --> 00:07:31.067
Because of the way that they're also
randomly generated at times and

133
00:07:31.067 --> 00:07:35.166
doing what they need to,
if you start seeing unusual sequencing or

134
00:07:35.166 --> 00:07:37.745
very minute sequencing of these things.

135
00:07:37.745 --> 00:07:40.770
Whatever the regular interval is and
all of a sudden it changes and

136
00:07:40.770 --> 00:07:44.079
these values tend to change,
then you know something else is going on.

137
00:07:44.079 --> 00:07:46.526
Now you're going, Ronnie,
if we're gonna have to look at that.

138
00:07:46.526 --> 00:07:47.978
Not necessarily, okay?

139
00:07:47.978 --> 00:07:52.888
But just trying to let you know that this
is what people are generally looking for

140
00:07:52.888 --> 00:07:57.138
is some of the information that we're
likely to see there is that type

141
00:07:57.138 --> 00:07:58.255
of information.

142
00:07:58.255 --> 00:08:00.744
The neat thing of course then,

143
00:08:00.744 --> 00:08:06.040
along with the TTL is the next
value that we call protocol, okay.

144
00:08:06.040 --> 00:08:11.370
This particular protocol field really
does point towards what we are going

145
00:08:11.370 --> 00:08:17.100
to end up seeing at least the majority
of the time, TCP and UDP.

146
00:08:17.100 --> 00:08:22.380
Which means, it might be pointing to what
we're expecting to happen at layer 4.

147
00:08:22.380 --> 00:08:27.640
But notice the ICMP is set up here and

148
00:08:27.640 --> 00:08:32.700
in that, we might assume
the ICMP as a layer for protocol.

149
00:08:32.700 --> 00:08:38.080
But it is not, ICMP is in an inherently

150
00:08:38.080 --> 00:08:41.740
internal portion of
the IP protocol itself.

151
00:08:41.740 --> 00:08:47.290
So there is a chance that you
might see ICMP messages go on or

152
00:08:47.290 --> 00:08:50.470
you might see where it says,
go to layer four here, okay?

153
00:08:50.470 --> 00:08:54.790
So this is what the protocol also tells us
is what we're normally expecting to see

154
00:08:54.790 --> 00:09:01.400
next is also what we'll see too, so that's
the information that we're likely to see.

155
00:09:01.400 --> 00:09:05.516
So there's a lot that we can tell in just
the information right there on those

156
00:09:05.516 --> 00:09:08.043
different headers that we've talked about.

157
00:09:08.043 --> 00:09:13.625
That may indicate that someone has
manipulated our IP packets and

158
00:09:13.625 --> 00:09:15.255
this could be bad.

159
00:09:15.255 --> 00:09:19.349
Now this is the one that I want to get to
cuz I wanna see Daniel's reaction to this

160
00:09:19.349 --> 00:09:23.207
cuz I haven't shown him, I've been
holding this off as a secret Daniel.

161
00:09:23.207 --> 00:09:24.500
>> Okay [LAUGH].

162
00:09:24.500 --> 00:09:28.120
>> The checksum header, we know what
checksums are for right, Daniel?

163
00:09:28.120 --> 00:09:31.280
>> Right, it's just to make sure that
everything is what we expect it to be.

164
00:09:31.280 --> 00:09:35.855
>> Yeah, so at the beginning, we said
something, we said, let me calculate this,

165
00:09:35.855 --> 00:09:40.895
and we calculated, we assigned that value
to it, I send it to you, and you do what?

166
00:09:40.895 --> 00:09:42.125
>> I recalculate the value and

167
00:09:42.125 --> 00:09:44.695
then compare the values to make
sure that everything is right.

168
00:09:44.695 --> 00:09:45.575
>> And they should match.

169
00:09:45.575 --> 00:09:47.065
>> Correct.
>> If they don't match,

170
00:09:47.065 --> 00:09:48.035
we know-
>> Something's wrong.

171
00:09:48.035 --> 00:09:49.592
>> Something is absolutely
wrong somewhere or

172
00:09:49.592 --> 00:09:51.525
something has actually changed in there.

173
00:09:51.525 --> 00:09:55.095
The checksum header says, I'm gonna take
a look at all this header information,

174
00:09:55.095 --> 00:09:58.720
that's exactly what I'm gonna do,
I'm gonna calculate this.

175
00:09:58.720 --> 00:10:02.770
And so if anything has changed
between the source and destination,

176
00:10:03.770 --> 00:10:07.530
when I send out here's what it should be,
it arrives at Daniel's machine.

177
00:10:07.530 --> 00:10:12.480
Daniel's machine says, here at the value
that I got and it should match.

178
00:10:12.480 --> 00:10:12.980
>> Correct.

179
00:10:12.980 --> 00:10:19.740
>> Correct okay, what have I told
you that this doesn't have to match?

180
00:10:19.740 --> 00:10:23.140
>> That's an interesting thing,
that doesn't even make sense [LAUGH].

181
00:10:23.140 --> 00:10:26.370
>> And your machine may not
be able to figure it out.

182
00:10:26.370 --> 00:10:27.975
>> That's even more terrifying.

183
00:10:27.975 --> 00:10:30.143
>> [LAUGH]
>> Because the whole purpose of it is to

184
00:10:30.143 --> 00:10:34.200
make sure that it does match and
that your computer can figure that out.

185
00:10:34.200 --> 00:10:37.370
>> Yeah, so we have to dive into
this a little bit more then, right?

186
00:10:37.370 --> 00:10:38.242
>> Apparently, yes?

187
00:10:38.242 --> 00:10:43.370
>> Because it freaked me out too when
I first saw it, I was like, what?

188
00:10:43.370 --> 00:10:46.595
And it's because of the way that
the checksum is done, okay?

189
00:10:46.595 --> 00:10:47.280
>> Okay.
>> So

190
00:10:47.280 --> 00:10:51.450
the way that we do the checksum here,
let's go ahead and take a look at this.

191
00:10:51.450 --> 00:10:56.332
Here's the way that the calculation works
at now this is not the same as the TCP

192
00:10:56.332 --> 00:10:58.920
checksum, so
that's a little bit different, okay.

193
00:10:58.920 --> 00:11:02.676
But at later three though,
we can do this here,

194
00:11:02.676 --> 00:11:08.550
in TCP/IP,
the data is divided into 16 bit fields.

195
00:11:08.550 --> 00:11:12.126
Each field does what we call
a ones complement operation and

196
00:11:12.126 --> 00:11:15.501
then complements are added together for
the checksum.

197
00:11:15.501 --> 00:11:19.321
Let's make sure that we understand this,
so this is where you and I map, you and

198
00:11:19.321 --> 00:11:23.100
I are on agreement, it's not our best,
it's not our strongest soup.

199
00:11:23.100 --> 00:11:26.487
>> Two plus two is chicken
if I'm not mistaken [LAUGH].

200
00:11:26.487 --> 00:11:29.170
>> [LAUGH] I'm not that bad yet
I'm gonna get there [INAUDIBLE],

201
00:11:29.170 --> 00:11:30.572
I assume I'm gonna get there.

202
00:11:30.572 --> 00:11:32.270
>> I can count to potato [LAUGH].

203
00:11:32.270 --> 00:11:37.098
>> All right, so what is a compliment,
well let's just take look at these

204
00:11:37.098 --> 00:11:42.360
first four bits, let me see if I can
zoom in so that we can take a look.

205
00:11:42.360 --> 00:11:45.371
So what I've done is showed you
essentially the [INAUDIBLE], Daniel,

206
00:11:45.371 --> 00:11:48.293
notice that here, let's say that
these are our hex values, okay.

207
00:11:48.293 --> 00:11:48.897
>> Okay.

208
00:11:48.897 --> 00:11:51.447
>> 5600, so the first 16 bits,

209
00:11:51.447 --> 00:11:57.230
the first four bits of it representing
the five, that's five in binary, okay.

210
00:11:57.230 --> 00:11:58.130
>> Yes.
>> Makes sense?

211
00:11:58.130 --> 00:12:02.950
Okay, the compliment to this is
what essentially makes it all 1.

212
00:12:02.950 --> 00:12:04.752
So if we go over here
to this yellow portion,

213
00:12:04.752 --> 00:12:06.820
notice it's essentially the opposite,
right?

214
00:12:06.820 --> 00:12:07.670
>> Okay.

215
00:12:07.670 --> 00:12:10.127
>> And
then let's take a look at the second one,

216
00:12:10.127 --> 00:12:14.895
if this represents a six, that seems-
>> They're doing

217
00:12:14.895 --> 00:12:17.786
the opposite thing of what we
see on the hex side of things.

218
00:12:17.786 --> 00:12:22.887
>> Yep, so the way that that ends up
working out is that every value that

219
00:12:22.887 --> 00:12:28.362
comes across in the header, that we

why is SSH being nailed by this weird IP?

449
00:24:38.970 --> 00:24:42.860
>> Yep, so yeah, all that stuff
really does kind of help us.

450
00:24:42.860 --> 00:24:44.830
And we have to think about this, too.

451
00:24:44.830 --> 00:24:47.600
So just take a look at
something like that as well.

452
00:24:47.600 --> 00:24:52.380
The other thing you should never see here,
Dan, it sounds logical enough when

453
00:24:52.380 --> 00:24:56.210
we think about it, but
until you actually see it,

454
00:24:56.210 --> 00:25:01.726
it doesn't because you and
I know the loopback address, okay?

455
00:25:01.726 --> 00:25:02.476
>> Yeah.

456
00:25:02.476 --> 00:25:03.177
>> Right?

457
00:25:03.177 --> 00:25:04.833
127 117.

458
00:25:04.833 --> 00:25:08.780
>> Yeah, 1270.0.1, okay?

459
00:25:08.780 --> 00:25:11.160
Well, that sounds great.

460
00:25:11.160 --> 00:25:14.430
All of us use it at one point or
another for something, okay?

461
00:25:14.430 --> 00:25:15.180
>> Testing usually.

462
00:25:15.180 --> 00:25:15.780
>> Testing.

463
00:25:15.780 --> 00:25:17.410
>> Yeah.
>> Okay, but

464
00:25:17.410 --> 00:25:22.320
I should never see it as a source from
the outside of my network coming in.

465
00:25:22.320 --> 00:25:24.776
>> Yeah, that should be an impossibility.

466
00:25:24.776 --> 00:25:25.742
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH]

467
00:25:25.742 --> 00:25:26.613
>> Seeing as that

468
00:25:26.613 --> 00:25:28.935
is the address of your local adapter,

469
00:25:28.935 --> 00:25:33.255
I don't know how the heck it would
ever be from outside of my computer.

470
00:25:33.255 --> 00:25:34.010
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, but

471
00:25:34.010 --> 00:25:37.510
if you start seeing this as being
the source of data that's coming in and

472
00:25:37.510 --> 00:25:39.000
all this other stuff?

473
00:25:39.000 --> 00:25:40.260
Yeah, and it has a payload?

474
00:25:40.260 --> 00:25:41.380
Something else is wrong.

475
00:25:41.380 --> 00:25:45.280
>> Hm.
[LAUGH] Again, things that make you go hm.

476
00:25:45.280 --> 00:25:47.430
>> So we should never see 127.0.0.1,

477
00:25:47.430 --> 00:25:52.691
our home address as being the source
that we're also getting as well.

478
00:25:52.691 --> 00:25:57.230
Internet traffic, also Internet traffic,
remember, that's key.

479
00:25:57.230 --> 00:25:57.900
Coming off the Internet,

480
00:25:57.900 --> 00:26:02.670
it should never really come from
a private IP address as well, okay?

481
00:26:02.670 --> 00:26:05.110
So if it's coming across the router and

482
00:26:05.110 --> 00:26:08.040
it's still giving you those
private IP addresses.

483
00:26:08.040 --> 00:26:10.723
They'll go no big deal, okay?

484
00:26:10.723 --> 00:26:11.391
That shouldn't be happening.

485
00:26:11.391 --> 00:26:12.319
>> [LAUGH]
>> Yeah,

486
00:26:12.319 --> 00:26:15.085
if you know anything about
networking at all, you're like,

487
00:26:15.085 --> 00:26:16.319
how is that even possible?

488
00:26:16.319 --> 00:26:18.520
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's not how this works.

489
00:26:18.520 --> 00:26:20.145
That's not how any of this works.

490
00:26:20.145 --> 00:26:23.130
>> [LAUGH] It does mean that
somebody's comprised your network more

491
00:26:23.130 --> 00:26:23.630
than you think.

492
00:26:23.630 --> 00:26:25.370
That's what it really means.

493
00:26:25.370 --> 00:26:27.380
But just kinda realize,
if you're getting traffic like that,

494
00:26:27.380 --> 00:26:31.090
something else is going on from the way
that you shouldn't be worrying about.

495
00:26:32.360 --> 00:26:35.560
Also, traffic that is leaving, okay,

496
00:26:35.560 --> 00:26:41.240
should never have a different IP
subnet range than the one that you're

497
00:26:41.240 --> 00:26:45.540
actually on from that thicker one or
from a loopback.

498
00:26:45.540 --> 00:26:47.490
You shouldn't have to worry
about anything like that.

499
00:26:47.490 --> 00:26:49.510
So check that out as well.

500
00:26:49.510 --> 00:26:51.880
It should not actually be that way, too.

501
00:26:51.880 --> 00:26:55.710
And then, of course, if you get broadcasts
that are coming through a router or

502
00:26:55.710 --> 00:26:58.920
you're actually sending out broadcasts and
your router is passing it on,

503
00:26:58.920 --> 00:27:01.240
something else maybe happening as well.

504
00:27:01.240 --> 00:27:05.180
So just make sure that when you take
a look at it, it's not that all broadcasts

505
00:27:05.180 --> 00:27:11.330
are bad, but at the same time unless you
have explicitly allowed for a broadcast

506
00:27:11.330 --> 00:27:15.850
to go across your router, you're probably
not supposed to have it that way.

507
00:27:15.850 --> 00:27:19.640
Because the default is don't let
broadcasts go across the router.

508
00:27:19.640 --> 00:27:22.010
And if you go, hey,
a broadcast has gone across my router.

509
00:27:22.010 --> 00:27:24.538
I didn't think that that
was supposed to happen.

510
00:27:24.538 --> 00:27:26.642
[LAUGH]
>> [LAUGH] You're right.

511
00:27:26.642 --> 00:27:29.350
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah, that should kind of alarm you

512
00:27:29.350 --> 00:27:33.970
just a little bit as you start
to see the information, okay?

513
00:27:33.970 --> 00:27:35.808
So take some time.

514
00:27:35.808 --> 00:27:37.530
Open up Wireshark and

515
00:27:37.530 --> 00:27:41.300
just take a look at these different
values that you do see here.

516
00:27:41.300 --> 00:27:43.880
And notice that we can see all of them,
okay?

517
00:27:43.880 --> 00:27:47.390
Each one of those headers, it's not
that you're learning a ton at this point

518
00:27:47.390 --> 00:27:51.020
from this, but at least from
the descriptions that we gave you,

519
00:27:51.020 --> 00:27:55.420
it will help you out to be able to
understand this a little bit more, okay?

520
00:27:55.420 --> 00:28:00.050
All right, so Daniel, that is,
at least at this point,

521
00:28:00.050 --> 00:28:03.220
everything, at least the basics of

522
00:28:03.220 --> 00:28:08.500
doing a little bit of intrusion analysis
on the IP version 4 headers, okay?

523
00:28:08.500 --> 00:28:12.760
But we did begin with IP version 4 and
IP version 6.

524
00:28:12.760 --> 00:28:13.660
>> Don't leave them out.

525
00:28:13.660 --> 00:28:15.010
>> Yeah, we don't wanna leave them out.

526
00:28:15.010 --> 00:28:17.814
And I love that she jumped right in that,
but once again, Daniel,

527
00:28:17.814 --> 00:28:19.631
I have raced the clock and
I have won again.

528
00:28:19.631 --> 00:28:21.346
>> [LAUGH]
>> So,

529
00:28:21.346 --> 00:28:23.161
I think we're gonna have
to do a part three here.

530
00:28:23.161 --> 00:28:25.263
>> [LAUGH]
>> The quick and nimble, Ronnie Wong,

531
00:28:25.263 --> 00:28:27.270
ladies and gentlemen,
at your beck and call.

532
00:28:27.270 --> 00:28:29.512
No problem,
we'll definitely roll that part three in.

533
00:28:29.512 --> 00:28:32.346
We wanna make sure that all
the information necessary for

534
00:28:32.346 --> 00:28:33.999
you out there who are studying for

535
00:28:33.999 --> 00:28:37.677
this exam have it and are equipped with
it so that you can go pass that exam.

536
00:28:37.677 --> 00:28:39.508
Ronnie, thanks so much for
dropping by today.

537
00:28:39.508 --> 00:28:41.120
Again, we appreciate that.

538
00:28:41.120 --> 00:28:43.146
We appreciate our viewers for
watching as well.

539
00:28:43.146 --> 00:28:44.980
I hope you have enjoyed this episode.

540
00:28:44.980 --> 00:28:46.392
But it is time for us to sign off.

541
00:28:46.392 --> 00:28:48.620
For ITProTV, I've been your host,
Daniel Lowrie.

542
00:28:48.620 --> 00:28:49.515
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

543
00:28:49.515 --> 00:28:51.548
And we'll see you next time.

544
00:28:51.548 --> 00:28:57.449
[MUSIC]

545
00:28:57.449 --> 00:29:00.892
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie dive into describing the importance of IP headers as a source of security and network information. Here they turn their focus toward IPv6 headers, looking at the header fields in detail and security concerns associated with them.
episodes.title: Describe IP Headers Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:01.240 --> 00:00:04.978
Welcome to ITPROTV I'm
your host Don [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:04.978 --> 00:00:08.276
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:08.276 --> 00:00:12.361
>> You're watching ITPROTV.

4
00:00:12.361 --> 00:00:14.281
>> All right, good evenings everyone and

5
00:00:14.281 --> 00:00:16.792
welcome back to another
great episode of ITPROTV.

6
00:00:16.792 --> 00:00:22.632
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie and it's
observe back in our Cisco SECOPS series.

7
00:00:22.632 --> 00:00:26.544
Joining us back in studio yet again
lending his expertise on this very topic,

8
00:00:26.544 --> 00:00:28.303
our good friend Mr. Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:28.303 --> 00:00:29.127
Ronnie, glad to have you again.

10
00:00:29.127 --> 00:00:29.995
How's it going sir?

11
00:00:29.995 --> 00:00:30.996
>> It's going great Daniel.

12
00:00:30.996 --> 00:00:32.659
Thank you once again for

13
00:00:32.659 --> 00:00:37.740
having me back as we now have trekked
through a bit of the IP headers here.

14
00:00:37.740 --> 00:00:38.798
>> [LAUGH] We have waded
our way through it.

15
00:00:38.798 --> 00:00:41.747
>> [LAUGH] We have,
there's a ton of information,

16
00:00:41.747 --> 00:00:46.632
make sure you check out the first two
episodes in this little miniseries here.

17
00:00:46.632 --> 00:00:51.323
I cannot overemphasize that enough,
especially as you're preparing for

18
00:00:51.323 --> 00:00:55.499
some of the intrusion analysis
portions of the Cisco SECOPS exam.

19
00:00:55.499 --> 00:00:58.988
So make sure you go back and
watch those as well.

20
00:00:58.988 --> 00:01:01.992
Now IPV6,
that is what we're jumping into next.

21
00:01:01.992 --> 00:01:03.707
We've all ready talked about IPV4.

22
00:01:03.707 --> 00:01:06.540
We're moving into the realm of IPv6.

23
00:01:06.540 --> 00:01:08.102
This is where it gets,

24
00:01:08.102 --> 00:01:12.803
most people get a little bit scared
because it does look different.

25
00:01:12.803 --> 00:01:16.702
It sounds insanely foreign
to everything that we do.

26
00:01:16.702 --> 00:01:19.903
And then we take a look at
the headers it even looks different.

27
00:01:19.903 --> 00:01:24.120
Let me see if I can kinda do a side by
side here but let our close as we can do.

28
00:01:24.120 --> 00:01:27.403
So let's go ahead and take a look at
what we're normally used to seeing.

29
00:01:27.403 --> 00:01:30.051
So here it is,
in the IP version four header,

30
00:01:30.051 --> 00:01:34.379
we've already gone through this
description in the first couple of parts

31
00:01:34.379 --> 00:01:38.177
of this little mini-series here
that we've had on IP headers.

32
00:01:38.177 --> 00:01:38.973
All right,

33
00:01:38.973 --> 00:01:43.917
this is the typical IP version four
header when we take a look here, okay.

34
00:01:43.917 --> 00:01:48.777
In IP version 6 the headers
are simplified a lot more, okay.

35
00:01:48.777 --> 00:01:52.583
Now why are people so
then when we start talking about,

36
00:01:52.583 --> 00:01:55.824
they seem to treat as
a such of a foreign beast.

37
00:01:55.824 --> 00:01:59.033
It's still in the realm of IP,
the Internet protocol.

38
00:01:59.033 --> 00:02:03.435
The big differences here,
really happen to be of course the,

39
00:02:03.435 --> 00:02:07.668
at least the main difference is
the size of the IEP source and

40
00:02:07.668 --> 00:02:12.764
destination address, which I'm
apparently not gonna be able to say.

41
00:02:12.764 --> 00:02:16.004
But those are kind of about
the two biggest ones,

42
00:02:16.004 --> 00:02:18.861
as well as what we call extension headers.

43
00:02:18.861 --> 00:02:22.622
And I've tried to make this to look
where it's not actually a solid box.

44
00:02:22.622 --> 00:02:26.860
So the reason why is that that one
is not exactly set in stone in

45
00:02:26.860 --> 00:02:31.364
terms of how big it is, or
how many that we actually have to have.

46
00:02:31.364 --> 00:02:34.613
But it actually can be there as well,
okay.

47
00:02:34.613 --> 00:02:38.960
But the other fields that we
have existing right here.

48
00:02:38.960 --> 00:02:43.187
This is what we also have to kind of pay
attention to as far as identifying what

49
00:02:43.187 --> 00:02:43.794
they are.

50
00:02:43.794 --> 00:02:47.460
There's not a lot of attacks
in a lot of the fields

51
00:02:47.460 --> 00:02:50.955
that we end up seeing up here at the top,
okay.

52
00:02:50.955 --> 00:02:53.163
There are probably just a couple, but

53
00:02:53.163 --> 00:02:55.992
overall though most of
it we don't worry about.

54
00:02:55.992 --> 00:03:00.298
So it's right here where now we have
security kind of built into a couple of

55
00:03:00.298 --> 00:03:03.841
different things that IPV6 really
does helps us out with and

56
00:03:03.841 --> 00:03:06.496
that's kind of the big difference, right.

57
00:03:06.496 --> 00:03:09.405
IP version 4 was really not
build with security in mind.

58
00:03:09.405 --> 00:03:14.325
IPV6 though has the opportunity
to really implement

59
00:03:14.325 --> 00:03:18.159
security inside of the protocol itself.

60
00:03:18.159 --> 00:03:22.540
The size of the headers, the ability
that you have these extensions,

61
00:03:22.540 --> 00:03:24.330
the flow labels, all this.

62
00:03:24.330 --> 00:03:29.178
It really can revolve around the nature
of the issues of security in the way that

63
00:03:29.178 --> 00:03:29.769
we know.

64
00:03:29.769 --> 00:03:32.812
So that's what we wanna
pay attention to here.

65
00:03:32.812 --> 00:03:37.080
Even so, like I said, people really
do talk about with some trepidation,

66
00:03:37.080 --> 00:03:39.879
like it is a foreign animal but
it really isn't.

67
00:03:39.879 --> 00:03:45.408
It really is kind of a big but
a better replacement to IP version four.

68
00:03:45.408 --> 00:03:49.358
And this is why it should be something
we feel comfortable in talking about and

69
00:03:49.358 --> 00:03:51.866
working with even though
most people will just.

70
00:03:51.866 --> 00:03:56.146
And I've had multiple
conversations where I said IPV6 and

71
00:03:56.146 --> 00:04:00.978
people are like well, what's- [CROSSTALK]
>> It's big and scary Ronnie.

72
00:04:00.978 --> 00:04:02.178
>> Yeah, it's big and scary.

73
00:04:02.178 --> 00:04:04.063
>> [LAUGH] There's x values man,
haven't you seen it?

74
00:04:04.063 --> 00:04:06.054
>> Yeah and
that's the scariest portion of it.

75
00:04:06.054 --> 00:04:06.665
>> Yeah, yeah.

76
00:04:06.665 --> 00:04:07.294
>> That's the weird thing.

77
00:04:07.294 --> 00:04:09.945
It really is the scariest portion
of everything that we see.

78
00:04:09.945 --> 00:04:13.268
Now let me try and ease your mind
on some of the things here, okay.

79
00:04:13.268 --> 00:04:16.933
So just as we described pretty
much the major-, everything,

80
00:04:16.933 --> 00:04:18.464
I'm gonna say majority.

81
00:04:18.464 --> 00:04:20.085
We described everything here, okay.

82
00:04:20.085 --> 00:04:25.219
Up here at the top we're gonna
see that even though all of these

83
00:04:25.219 --> 00:04:30.366
look like an insane mess of
stuff that we've added in, okay.

84
00:04:30.366 --> 00:04:33.695
IPv6 didn't really take it,
I switched the wrong.

85
00:04:33.695 --> 00:04:34.545
>> [LAUGH] The wrong way.

86
00:04:34.545 --> 00:04:39.038
>> IPv6 didn't really take it away, but
kind of reformed a lot of those fields and

87
00:04:39.038 --> 00:04:42.270
really kind of meshed them
together a little bit, okay.

88
00:04:42.270 --> 00:04:44.984
So notice the version field is still here,
okay.

89
00:04:44.984 --> 00:04:50.083
So the version field still says IPv4,
IPv6 according to RFC,

90
00:04:50.083 --> 00:04:56.703
we see anything different in other IPv6
and we see IPv5 or, seven or nine come in.

91
00:04:56.703 --> 00:05:00.697
Once again,
the router is supposed to drop that, okay.

92
00:05:00.697 --> 00:05:03.139
It don't even want to take
a look at the rest of it,

93
00:05:03.139 --> 00:05:04.719
it just says you should drop it.

94
00:05:04.719 --> 00:05:07.578
So if it gets on your machine, okay.

95
00:05:07.578 --> 00:05:12.364
And now you're looking at it in Wireshark
at the end result and you're saying,

96
00:05:12.364 --> 00:05:16.876
it got to my machine with a version
header that was something besides this.

97
00:05:16.876 --> 00:05:20.574
That means someone was able to
successfully manipulate something that

98
00:05:20.574 --> 00:05:23.480
they should not have actually
been able to manipulate.

99
00:05:23.480 --> 00:05:26.625
And here they are, it's ready to go, okay.

100
00:05:26.625 --> 00:05:31.235
Now the other thing that we see that
now begins to frighten people has,

101
00:05:31.235 --> 00:05:33.670
not traffic class, traffic class.

102
00:05:33.670 --> 00:05:37.097
But when we start thinking about class and
stuff like that,

103
00:05:37.097 --> 00:05:41.632
I start thinking about the idea of what
traffic again and the class of service.

104
00:05:41.632 --> 00:05:45.491
And the quality of service and
that's kind of the same thing.

105
00:05:45.491 --> 00:05:49.503
Well, if we start to think about that way
I keep proning this swipe all I need to do

106
00:05:49.503 --> 00:05:51.729
is switch tabs here
>> [LAUGH]

107
00:05:51.729 --> 00:05:53.381
>> Well, it's just saying that's

108
00:05:53.381 --> 00:05:56.044
the really the majority of
the type of service field.

109
00:05:56.044 --> 00:06:01.221
They just changed the name and
they added in just a few more bits.

110
00:06:01.221 --> 00:06:04.153
Notice that this is 8 bits all together?

111
00:06:04.153 --> 00:06:08.905
Whereas in the IP version 4, it actually
is, no actually it's the same 8 bits here.

112
00:06:08.905 --> 00:06:10.544
>> [LAUGH]
>> So now that I see it,

113
00:06:10.544 --> 00:06:14.524
it says 4 to 11 bits,
that is about 12 bits all together.

114
00:06:14.524 --> 00:06:16.230
Now what we could possibly end up with?

115
00:06:16.230 --> 00:06:19.342
So a little bit larger, but
not too much larger, okay.

116
00:06:19.342 --> 00:06:23.222
So it gives you the ability to have more
different classes of traffic as we need

117
00:06:23.222 --> 00:06:23.947
them, okay.

118
00:06:23.947 --> 00:06:26.815
Now this is where a lot of
the stuff kind of disappears.

119
00:06:26.815 --> 00:06:27.789
I'm swiping again,

120
00:06:27.789 --> 00:06:31.043
this is where a lot of the other
things have actually disappeared here.

121
00:06:31.043 --> 00:06:34.659
But notice this idea of flow labels, okay.

122
00:06:34.659 --> 00:06:38.802
Flow labels for
us is a 20 bit IETF field, but

123
00:06:38.802 --> 00:06:44.444
that the way that the IETF kind
of says is they're flow labels.

124
00:06:44.444 --> 00:06:48.010
They are essentially for
whatever you need them to be for.

125
00:06:48.010 --> 00:06:50.735
So you need added stuff
in terms of security,

126
00:06:50.735 --> 00:06:53.184
you can use those flow labels to do that.

127
00:06:53.184 --> 00:06:54.710
Whatever you want,

128
00:06:54.710 --> 00:07:00.560
this particular field is not strictly
defined at this point for what we have.

129
00:07:00.560 --> 00:07:05.060
So, but it doesn't actually have
any specificity about management or

130
00:07:05.060 --> 00:07:09.039
the process, or how flow labels
are supposed to be processed.

360
00:19:25.660 --> 00:19:28.720
So all of this is actually
chained together.

00:19:28.720 --> 00:19:33.699
If I do not process extension header
number one, okay, then I should not be

number two, okay, and that is key.

00:19:38.376 --> 00:19:40.861
If I only have one extension header,
then from that point,

00:19:40.861 --> 00:19:42.980

365
00:19:42.980 --> 00:19:48.320
So each of these has to fall in
line like dominoes I cannot skip.

00:19:48.320 --> 00:19:53.180
But do some operating systems go,
that doesn't work for

me because I'd rather process this

00:19:58.450 --> 00:20:00.170

There are operating systems
out there that do that, okay?

00:20:05.224 --> 00:20:06.330
And, yeah, and

371
00:20:06.330 --> 00:20:11.380
that's because they're saying it's
okay because we're at the end machine.

372
00:20:11.380 --> 00:20:12.530
Well, that doesn't matter.

00:20:12.530 --> 00:20:15.330
Well, it matters if somebody knows
that that's the way your machine's

Where do you tend to stick

the third one that it finds instead.

00:20:32.730 --> 00:20:35.390

00:20:35.390 --> 00:20:36.940
I just go and I do what?

00:20:40.210 --> 00:20:43.700

and

So very important that we can pay
attention to just some simple and

So, Daniel, I'm gonna go back to exam tip-

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use and importance of ICMP from a security standpoint. Here they will define what ICMP is and how it works. Then they look at the header information associated with ICMP, analyze a packet capture of a ping sweep, and begin to talk about the ICMP types.

00:31:29.528 --> 00:31:32.305
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowry.

587
00:31:32.305 --> 00:31:33.252
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

588
00:31:33.252 --> 00:31:35.077
>> We'll see you next time.

589
00:31:35.077 --> 00:31:41.752
[MUSIC]

590
00:31:41.752 --> 00:31:47.050
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use and importance of ICMP from a security standpoint. Here they continue discussing ICMP types that you should be aware of and their associated attack vectors such as ICMP Source Quench and Time Exceeded.
episodes.title: Describe ICMP Intrusion Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.280 --> 00:00:01.170
Welcome to ITPro.TV.

2
00:00:01.170 --> 00:00:03.357
I'm your host [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:03.357 --> 00:00:08.478
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.478 --> 00:00:11.045
You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:11.045 --> 00:00:12.969
>> All right, greeting everyone, and

6
00:00:12.969 --> 00:00:16.540
welcome back to another
great episode of ITPro.TV.

7
00:00:16.540 --> 00:00:17.730
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie.

8
00:00:17.730 --> 00:00:21.706
And in today's episode, we're back
with more in our Cisco SecApps series.

9
00:00:21.706 --> 00:00:26.230
Then joining us back in the studio yet
again our good friend Mr. Ronnie Wong.

10
00:00:26.230 --> 00:00:27.610
Ronnie we're glad to have you again today.

11
00:00:27.610 --> 00:00:28.660
How's it going, sir?

12
00:00:28.660 --> 00:00:31.850
>> Well, thank you again for having me
on the show as we continue on in taking

13
00:00:31.850 --> 00:00:35.800
a look at ICMP vulnerabilities and
attacks that we can see there.

14
00:00:35.800 --> 00:00:39.937
So we are picking up in a part two where
what we've talked about of course is

15
00:00:39.937 --> 00:00:42.607
the ICMP header as being
able to analyze them and

16
00:00:42.607 --> 00:00:44.833
understand what's actually in them.

17
00:00:44.833 --> 00:00:48.471
So, let's make sure that we do a brief
little review cuz it might have been

18
00:00:48.471 --> 00:00:51.420
a couple of days before you have
actually taken a look at it.

19
00:00:51.420 --> 00:00:52.501
We are picking back up here.

20
00:00:52.501 --> 00:00:55.580
So let's take a look at my screen and
we will jump right into it.

21
00:00:55.580 --> 00:00:59.970
Remember that ICMP itself is
not a layer four protocol.

22
00:00:59.970 --> 00:01:01.785
It is a layer three protocol.

23
00:01:01.785 --> 00:01:06.744
And so even though you see right here
where we have the IP headers up there

24
00:01:06.744 --> 00:01:10.080
on the top, ICMP is really a part of that.

25
00:01:10.080 --> 00:01:14.370
So a lot of times we do tend to think that
because we stack at the right near there,

26
00:01:14.370 --> 00:01:17.030
that we believe that it
turns into layer four.

27
00:01:17.030 --> 00:01:20.580
It doesn't, it's really
internally a part of layer three.

28
00:01:20.580 --> 00:01:24.870
So we of course are gonna focus
in on these four headers here.

29
00:01:24.870 --> 00:01:29.390
So if we just focus in on those four
headers, and we also talked about

30
00:01:29.390 --> 00:01:33.520
this in the previous episode as well,
that really what we are concerned about

31
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:37.160
a lot of times is gonna be right
here in the type and the code.

32
00:01:37.160 --> 00:01:38.970
Because we get different messages and

33
00:01:38.970 --> 00:01:42.550
we also described why ICMP
works the way that it does.

34
00:01:42.550 --> 00:01:43.470
So make sure you go back and

35
00:01:43.470 --> 00:01:46.260
check out part one if you
are not as familiar with ICMP.

36
00:01:46.260 --> 00:01:50.193
But if you are, this little review as well
as part one you are probably going okay,

37
00:01:50.193 --> 00:01:51.580
I know that stuff.

38
00:01:51.580 --> 00:01:55.828
We also of course showed you
the beginnings of some type of

39
00:01:55.828 --> 00:01:58.584
an attack that you can use with ICMP.

40
00:01:58.584 --> 00:02:02.666
And normally with ICMP the attacks
kinda come in two stages or

41
00:02:02.666 --> 00:02:07.610
three depending on how old you
are in the networking world, right.

42
00:02:07.610 --> 00:02:10.970
We used to talk about the idea
of reconnaissance and

43
00:02:10.970 --> 00:02:14.800
then there would be a brief bit
of exploitation and figuring out

44
00:02:14.800 --> 00:02:18.650
the true vulnerability that you could get
and then of course the ultimate attack.

45
00:02:18.650 --> 00:02:21.410
Today they just kind of go,
all right, there's reconnaissance,

46
00:02:21.410 --> 00:02:24.328
there's scanning, and
then there's the vulnerability and attack.

47
00:02:24.328 --> 00:02:29.255
So everybody has kind of truncated things,
move them all together and

48
00:02:29.255 --> 00:02:31.060
tried to make into two.

49
00:02:31.060 --> 00:02:33.000
So it doesn't really matter
whether it's two or three but

50
00:02:33.000 --> 00:02:38.200
just kind of get the idea that it normally
happens in a couple of different stages.

51
00:02:38.200 --> 00:02:42.999
The reconnaissance stage or the scanning
stage really gives us a ton of information

52
00:02:42.999 --> 00:02:45.959
because that's what ICMP is built around,
okay?

53
00:02:45.959 --> 00:02:48.860
It's built around returning
those types of messages.

54
00:02:48.860 --> 00:02:52.850
So we did show you like we said
the ability here to do something like

55
00:02:52.850 --> 00:02:57.360
a simple or a manual type of what
we call ICMP sweeping attack.

56
00:02:57.360 --> 00:03:01.850
Where we can just start pinging
sequentially those IP addresses

57
00:03:01.850 --> 00:03:04.580
to see what type of response that we get.

58
00:03:04.580 --> 00:03:09.540
So any type of response that we get, that
comes back is an ICMP type of message.

59
00:03:09.540 --> 00:03:12.050
And if it shows anything besides real,

60
00:03:12.050 --> 00:03:16.079
a lot of times where the request
timed out or the host timed out,

61
00:03:16.079 --> 00:03:20.662
whatever the message normally is,
then we know that that device is on.

62
00:03:20.662 --> 00:03:23.244
Even if we're not getting
any other information,

63
00:03:23.244 --> 00:03:26.607
we know that that's a possibility
of a connection at that point but

64
00:03:26.607 --> 00:03:29.084
there's other things
that are also happening.

65
00:03:29.084 --> 00:03:33.311
So today we want to jump in to
those particular types of messages

66
00:03:33.311 --> 00:03:37.139
that are a little bit just
beyond what we see sometimes and

67
00:03:37.139 --> 00:03:40.070
we don't understand what they are.

68
00:03:40.070 --> 00:03:42.870
And talk about why they may be
important to us as well and

69
00:03:42.870 --> 00:03:45.000
what they can help us to be able to do.

70
00:03:45.000 --> 00:03:48.930
And show you what attacks or
the idea of what

71
00:03:48.930 --> 00:03:53.860
information is given to the attacker
when they run stuff like this, okay.

72
00:03:53.860 --> 00:03:57.950
So the first one is kind of grouped
together in what we call some type of

73
00:03:57.950 --> 00:04:01.420
destination unreachable attack, okay?

74
00:04:01.420 --> 00:04:07.161
Remember that with ICMP, there is no
port number normally assigned to ICMP.

75
00:04:07.161 --> 00:04:10.791
You will see certain programs that
will show you something like,

76
00:04:10.791 --> 00:04:14.860
if you go into a firewall and
you say hey I'm gonna deny this.

77
00:04:14.860 --> 00:04:16.720
You'll see where you can
pick the protocol and

78
00:04:16.720 --> 00:04:20.880
right beside it they'll have a little in
parentheses a number, okay, of some sort.

79
00:04:20.880 --> 00:04:25.482
And we automatically assume that's the
port number because if you scroll on down

80
00:04:25.482 --> 00:04:29.147
and go to HTTP port 80,
you'll see HTTP or www on the say 80.

81
00:04:29.147 --> 00:04:32.971
So we automatically assume that this
is gonna be that same idea of the port

82
00:04:32.971 --> 00:04:35.050
number, but it really isn't, okay?

83
00:04:35.050 --> 00:04:38.111
In ICMP,
there's no real port number attached but

84
00:04:38.111 --> 00:04:43.540
there are what we'll call types, and there
is also what we call a message or a code.

85
00:04:43.540 --> 00:04:47.194
So that's why these two
fields are important, okay.

86
00:04:47.194 --> 00:04:52.328
With that type of information, okay,
if I can identify the message and

87
00:04:52.328 --> 00:04:58.232
code, I might be able to understand along
with the functioning of how ICMP works,

88
00:04:58.232 --> 00:05:02.490
how far someone can get and
also some of the information.

89
00:05:02.490 --> 00:05:06.610
So for example, notice that I'm
just kind of eliminated a lot.

90
00:05:06.610 --> 00:05:08.717
There's a lot more code than
what I put up here, and

91
00:05:08.717 --> 00:05:11.460
there's really a lot more
codes than what I put up here.

92
00:05:11.460 --> 00:05:15.240
But really these are the ones that we're
gonna focus in on for the exam, okay.

93
00:05:15.240 --> 00:05:18.890
>> Yeah Ronnie, I actually came across
this as a red team member, right,

94
00:05:18.890 --> 00:05:21.920
trying to look into and
break into networks.

95
00:05:21.920 --> 00:05:23.895
I discovered this in Nmap.

96
00:05:23.895 --> 00:05:25.409
>> Mm-hm.
>> A lot of people they block ping, right?

97
00:05:25.409 --> 00:05:27.225
>> Yeah.
>> They don't want you to find out whether

98
00:05:27.225 --> 00:05:28.138
or not something is,

99
00:05:28.138 --> 00:05:31.253
at least they don't want you easily
discerning what's on the network.

100
00:05:31.253 --> 00:05:34.074
Nmap has an ability to use
one of the different types or

101
00:05:34.074 --> 00:05:37.090
codes because that's
typically not being blocked.

102
00:05:37.090 --> 00:05:39.170
>> Right.
>> The time stamp or the time, yeah,

103
00:05:39.170 --> 00:05:40.390
I think there's a time stamp.

104
00:05:40.390 --> 00:05:43.570
>> Yeah, there's a lot of different
things that we may go, no,

105
00:05:43.570 --> 00:05:45.430
let's just turn off ICMP totally.

106
00:05:45.430 --> 00:05:49.500
Well, remember there is other devices
on your network that heavily depend

107
00:05:49.500 --> 00:05:53.210
on these messages saying that
things are up and operating.

108
00:05:53.210 --> 00:05:57.340
Now you may not outside of your network
want to actually return anything, okay?

109
00:05:57.340 --> 00:06:00.340
And that's up to you, and
that's fine for the majority of things.

110
00:06:00.340 --> 00:06:04.175
But if you are having testing going on,
if you're connecting to a cloud service

111
00:06:04.175 --> 00:06:06.693
sometimes, or
if you're connecting to a partner,

112
00:06:06.693 --> 00:06:09.290
you may go ahead and
turn that particular feature on.

113
00:06:09.290 --> 00:06:13.616
Just so that you can establish that
those devices can see each other and

114
00:06:13.616 --> 00:06:15.532
that they are communicating.

115
00:06:15.532 --> 00:06:18.669
But there are some times you actually
have more that happens here, okay.

116
00:06:18.669 --> 00:06:23.515
So these particular messages that we
get really do correspond to a type and

117
00:06:23.515 --> 00:06:28.908
a code and what you and I at least want to
understand as the basic functioning here,

118
00:06:28.908 --> 00:06:32.502
because that may help to reveal
the idea of the attack or

119
00:06:32.502 --> 00:06:36.488
analysis that we can take if we
get these types of messages and

120
00:06:36.488 --> 00:06:39.960
we're not expecting to get these messages,
okay?

121
00:06:39.960 --> 00:06:42.510
So that's what we want to focus in on.

122
00:06:42.510 --> 00:06:46.880
Okay, now we're gonna do where we'll
show you how this actually comes across,

123
00:06:46.880 --> 00:06:47.420
Wireshark.

124
00:06:47.420 --> 00:06:49.302
So that's gonna go, Ronnie you're
gonna talk through the whole thing.

125
00:06:49.302 --> 00:06:52.875
Hopefully not, okay but
you can't count me out on that,

126
00:06:52.875 --> 00:06:56.380
I can talk a little bit on
a lot of different things here.

127
00:06:56.380 --> 00:06:58.620
So, but let's go ahead and
make sure that we understand.

128
00:06:58.620 --> 00:07:00.830
So here's kind of the basic three.

129
00:07:00.830 --> 00:07:03.925
I just wanna go as and
graphical understanding that way,

130
00:07:03.925 --> 00:07:07.805
cuz me I just go all right, I'm issuing
a ping here's a response on it.

131
00:07:07.805 --> 00:07:08.584
>> Yeah.
>> Okay great.

132
00:07:08.584 --> 00:07:11.994
Nice, I've seen ping before Ronnie,
you're not impressing me.

133
00:07:11.994 --> 00:07:15.525
>> [LAUGH] It just kinda help to account
a break down the process to us so

134
00:07:15.525 --> 00:07:19.010
we can better solidify in our
minds what is actually happening.

135
00:07:19.010 --> 00:07:20.530
>> Yeah, and that's what we want.

136
00:07:20.530 --> 00:07:23.530
We want you to kind of go in,
not only for the exam but

137
00:07:23.530 --> 00:07:26.174
as you see the information to understand,

138
00:07:26.174 --> 00:07:30.630
get an understanding of what is happening
when you get these messages here, okay?

139
00:07:30.630 --> 00:07:33.980
So the common one that you and
I generally end up doing,

140
00:07:33.980 --> 00:07:37.300
right, is that we just ping
some end user device out there.

141
00:07:37.300 --> 00:07:38.640
>> Correct.
>> Whether it's across the Internet,

142
00:07:38.640 --> 00:07:41.010
whether it's inside our network, we ping.

143
00:07:41.010 --> 00:07:44.155
When we do so, we normally send
what we call an echo-request,

144
00:07:44.155 --> 00:07:49.010
and that echo-request is at layer
three because it is an ICMP message.

145
00:07:49.010 --> 00:07:54.378
The other side takes it and they send
back automatically and echo reply, okay?

146
00:07:54.378 --> 00:07:57.866
When they do so, we of course get
that response that comes back.

147
00:07:57.866 --> 00:08:02.846
And depending on the operating system,
right, we know that by default, okay,

148
00:08:02.846 --> 00:08:06.453
Windows does Four,
[SOUND] I can't count anymore, okay?

149
00:08:06.453 --> 00:08:09.460
Four ICMP messages that
normally come back.

150
00:08:09.460 --> 00:08:12.710
If you're on a Cisco router,
it choose five.

151
00:08:12.710 --> 00:08:14.430
So we don't see that-
>> On a Linux machine,

152
00:08:14.430 --> 00:08:16.335
it just keeps going until
you tell it to stop.

153
00:08:16.335 --> 00:08:18.160
[LAUGH]
>> So yeah,

154
00:08:18.160 --> 00:08:21.300
I don't know what the difference or
why some people chose four, five, or-

155
00:08:21.300 --> 00:08:22.924
>> I think it's just a preference thing.

156
00:08:22.924 --> 00:08:26.200
>> Yeah, it's a preference thing depending
on what we need that's available.

157
00:08:26.200 --> 00:08:29.209
But apparently, according to Windows,
they're saying look, if you got four,

158
00:08:29.209 --> 00:08:30.396
that means you're connected.

159
00:08:30.396 --> 00:08:31.043
>> Yeah.

160
00:08:31.043 --> 00:08:35.820
>> What happens 10 or 15 down the line and
just goes none [LAUGH]?

161
00:08:35.820 --> 00:08:37.580
So you kind of see that idea.

162
00:08:37.580 --> 00:08:42.492
With Cisco routers because ideally, right,
you're connecting to other Cisco routers,

163
00:08:42.492 --> 00:08:45.247
they're saying they should
respond within five.

164
00:08:45.247 --> 00:08:49.488
And normally, you drop the first one, so
you normally get an 80% the first time,

165
00:08:49.488 --> 00:08:52.505
second time,
100% because the first time [CROSSTALK].

166
00:08:52.505 --> 00:08:55.210
Yeah, it's too hard is
what we're doing there.

167
00:08:55.210 --> 00:08:59.031
>> And it's funny how as a network
administrator, you use ping a lot.

168
00:08:59.031 --> 00:09:02.045
I used to have two or
three ping sessions just scrolling by.

169
00:09:02.045 --> 00:09:06.770
Okay, I gotta make sure that switch is up
before I pull the plug on the old switch.

170
00:09:06.770 --> 00:09:09.330
And you're watching to make sure
all the connectivity's right.

171
00:09:09.330 --> 00:09:10.640
>> And that's what you're hoping for,
right?

172
00:09:10.640 --> 00:09:13.549
A lot of times, we also, now we're
kind of move, but let's go ahead and

173
00:09:13.549 --> 00:09:14.516
do this cuz it's cool.

174
00:09:14.516 --> 00:09:15.700
>> We digress [LAUGH].

175
00:09:15.700 --> 00:09:17.200
>> Yeah, but it's cool, right?

176
00:09:17.200 --> 00:09:20.540
If you're new to the idea of
doing network infrastructure and

177
00:09:20.540 --> 00:09:23.090
set up, it is doing what Daniel said.

178
00:09:23.090 --> 00:09:27.090
You kind of turn on a ping and
go all right, so I know it's working now.

179
00:09:27.090 --> 00:09:28.366
What happens when I change
this configuration?

180
00:09:28.366 --> 00:09:29.684
Look, the pings dropped.

181
00:09:29.684 --> 00:09:31.039
>> That was wrong [LAUGH].

182
00:09:31.039 --> 00:09:31.539
>> Let me put that back.
>> [LAUGH]

183
00:09:31.539 --> 00:09:33.617
>> Let me put that back right away, here.

184
00:09:33.617 --> 00:09:35.210
>> Hopefully no one noticed that,

185
00:09:35.210 --> 00:09:38.818
cuz I just took down the network [LAUGH].
>> And so you're kind of,

186
00:09:38.818 --> 00:09:42.560
that's the goal is to see
stuff like that as well.

187
00:09:42.560 --> 00:09:45.050
Sometimes you'll see it in just
different things in the way that

188
00:09:45.050 --> 00:09:46.890
we respond to them as well.

189
00:09:46.890 --> 00:09:47.810
So let's take, for an example,

190
00:09:47.810 --> 00:09:51.390
we're setting up something
like a fail over, right?

191
00:09:51.390 --> 00:09:55.680
The idea is that device fails,
the other one picks up.

192
00:09:55.680 --> 00:09:57.736
What do we want to see
though in terms of ping?

193
00:09:57.736 --> 00:10:01.082
Well, we wanna see-
>> No ping loss at all, That's ideal.

194
00:10:01.082 --> 00:10:07.030
>> That's 100% ideal, so
we can see how helpful ICMP really can be.

195
00:10:07.030 --> 00:10:10.299
Even though most of us, at the beginning,
even if we have a little network

196
00:10:10.299 --> 00:10:14.840
knowledge, it's okay, I pinged it, I got
replies back, I know connectivity is up.

197
00:10:14.840 --> 00:10:16.244
Don't get me wrong, that's what
we do the majority of the time.

198
00:10:16.244 --> 00:10:19.134
>> It's like a carpenter without
a hammer it's weird [LAUGH].

199
00:10:19.134 --> 00:10:23.014
>> But at the same time, we can see where
it can be very useful in those types of

200
00:10:23.014 --> 00:10:24.860
setups and what we want to do.

201
00:10:24.860 --> 00:10:29.190
Even if you only drop one, you'll probably
just go okay, I'm gonna lose one ping.

202
00:10:29.190 --> 00:10:32.570
32 bytes?
That's gonna recover really quickly.

203
00:10:32.570 --> 00:10:36.927
But all of a sudden you connected up,
and now you setup your VPN tunnel and

204
00:10:36.927 --> 00:10:38.051
you go none.

205
00:10:38.051 --> 00:10:40.040
Something's wrong [LAUGH].

206
00:10:40.040 --> 00:10:42.040
So, yeah, it makes sense.

207
00:10:42.040 --> 00:10:45.361
Now the other one that you may
also see but not as common,

208
00:10:45.361 --> 00:10:48.930
cuz most of us don't tend
to do this too often here.

209
00:10:48.930 --> 00:10:53.753
But if I send out a ping, and let's say
it's to this particular address here,

210
00:10:53.753 --> 00:10:55.666
192.168.30.2.

211
00:10:55.666 --> 00:10:59.656
And let's say that this is
the 30.2 network over here, but

212
00:10:59.656 --> 00:11:04.090
let's say it's not,
cuz I'm gonna get confused if I do that.

213
00:11:04.090 --> 00:11:08.083
So it goes in here and
the routing table, it looks for what?

214
00:11:08.083 --> 00:11:10.818
192.168.30.0 for the network.

215
00:11:10.818 --> 00:11:13.990
And it doesn't find it
in the routing table.

216

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use and importance of ICMP from a security standpoint. Here they continue discussing ICMP types that you should be aware of and their associated attack vectors. They begin by looking at a packet capture of ICMP traffic to see the different types being used. Then they explore attacks like Firewalking, OS Fingerprinting, and ICMP Route Redirects.
