And here is what we can do.

425
00:23:39.310 --> 00:23:41.530
So, it can be identified.

426
00:23:41.530 --> 00:23:43.791
But there's other ways
that we can also use it.

427
00:23:43.791 --> 00:23:48.660
Now this is not the 100% tried and
true way, okay?

428
00:23:48.660 --> 00:23:51.723
But it does seem to be
a general rule of thumb.

429
00:23:51.723 --> 00:23:54.205
So let me show you what I'm
talking about here, okay?

430
00:23:54.205 --> 00:23:57.924
So just as I mentioned this
a little bit earlier So

431
00:23:57.924 --> 00:24:02.550
if I ping my Windows 7 device from here,
just taking a look at

432
00:24:02.550 --> 00:24:07.630
the information that's going
across the screen right now.

433
00:24:07.630 --> 00:24:11.040
There are a couple of values that
we're actually seeing here, okay?

434
00:24:11.040 --> 00:24:14.110
First, I can tell what machine,
a lot of times,

435
00:24:14.110 --> 00:24:18.200
just because of how much data I'm
sending across in a ping, okay?

436
00:24:18.200 --> 00:24:23.030
So I know that, just by usage,
right, that Windows has

437
00:24:23.030 --> 00:24:27.540
always sent four bytes of information,
32 bits okay?

438
00:24:27.540 --> 00:24:30.523
Or 30, yeah, so when we do that, right,

439
00:24:30.523 --> 00:24:33.840
those 4 packets of 8 bits each,
so 32 bytes.

440
00:24:33.840 --> 00:24:37.568
So I know it can do it, but notice that
this one, that generates 64 bytes,

441
00:24:37.568 --> 00:24:38.460
and it came back.

442
00:24:38.460 --> 00:24:41.980
So it requested 64 and it came back, and

443
00:24:41.980 --> 00:24:47.460
the TTL 128 tells me it also
came from a Windows machine too.

444
00:24:47.460 --> 00:24:51.240
So at this point I can tell
a couple of different things, okay?

445
00:24:51.240 --> 00:24:54.910
That, more than likely, that means
the Kali Linux machine is actually

446
00:24:54.910 --> 00:24:58.480
requesting 64 bytes, okay,
when it sent the ping.

447
00:24:58.480 --> 00:25:02.030
And it's getting that,
because that's what the Linux boxes do.

448
00:25:02.030 --> 00:25:06.418
And then the TTL is the one that,
of course when it replied back,

449
00:25:06.418 --> 00:25:09.524
Windows actually replied back with 128.

450
00:25:09.524 --> 00:25:14.020
All right, now, let's come over
here to our Windows 7 machine.

451
00:25:15.640 --> 00:25:17.120
And let's run the command prompt here.

452
00:25:19.861 --> 00:25:23.380
Our ping here,
at the command prompt, ping.

453
00:25:31.709 --> 00:25:36.420
And when we see this,
notice there's the four 32 bytes here.

454
00:25:36.420 --> 00:25:40.470
So there's four different packets
that we see, each one with 32 bytes.

455
00:25:40.470 --> 00:25:42.772
So I might have mangled my math there,
whatever.

456
00:25:42.772 --> 00:25:44.332
>> [LAUGH]
>> I said I can't remember.

457
00:25:44.332 --> 00:25:47.030
But notice the TTL at this point, okay?

458
00:25:47.030 --> 00:25:52.030
So the reply from that particular box,
okay, notice it tells me TTL and

459
00:25:52.030 --> 00:25:54.530
usually this is a Linux kind of thing.

460
00:25:54.530 --> 00:25:59.010
That says Windows requested 32 bytes,
instead.

461
00:25:59.010 --> 00:26:02.490
So it was able to actually
send back what it requested.

462
00:26:02.490 --> 00:26:04.030
So simple things like this,

463
00:26:04.030 --> 00:26:08.610
where we can see something like
even the TTL values is enough.

464
00:26:08.610 --> 00:26:10.690
And sometimes even
the amount of information,

465
00:26:10.690 --> 00:26:12.780
you cannot always count on that.

466
00:26:12.780 --> 00:26:15.735
The reason why is that there are options
that you can run with ping, okay,

467
00:26:15.735 --> 00:26:20.310
to actually, say, send more than
you actually want to, or send less.

468
00:26:20.310 --> 00:26:23.760
So you can actually make it do some other
things, but just kind of realize that

469
00:26:23.760 --> 00:26:28.080
normally the combination of
those can also help out as well.

470
00:26:28.080 --> 00:26:31.941
There's also something called
an ICMP error quoting size, okay?

471
00:26:31.941 --> 00:26:35.530
That are also different for
each operating system.

472
00:26:35.530 --> 00:26:39.226
Most of us are never gonna get that deep
into it, okay, but if you're hacking,

473
00:26:39.226 --> 00:26:40.176
you probably will.

474
00:26:40.176 --> 00:26:44.491
But at this point, in terms of spotting,
and spotting quickly, okay,

475
00:26:44.491 --> 00:26:47.038
these are kind of two
types of machines that

476
00:26:47.038 --> 00:26:50.540
you may want to take a look at
the information as it goes by.

477
00:26:50.540 --> 00:26:54.750
And see, hey, which one's requiring what,
and what's the TTL values?

478
00:26:54.750 --> 00:26:58.220
That usually helps us out more than
anything to spot something very quickly,

479
00:26:58.220 --> 00:27:05.840
okay, for something like just a basic OS
fingerprinting analysis that we can do.

480
00:27:05.840 --> 00:27:10.790
All right, let's see, what are some of
the other ones that we also have here?

481
00:27:10.790 --> 00:27:13.820
I'm trying to look, and,
I'm noticing something here on time.

482
00:27:13.820 --> 00:27:19.300
Let's talk about just a one more,
before we get too much further, okay?

483
00:27:19.300 --> 00:27:23.768
There is also what is called
a redirect message, okay?

484
00:27:23.768 --> 00:27:28.280
A redirect message normally is a router
redirect, and this is a type 5.

485
00:27:28.280 --> 00:27:30.823
Notice that code 0 is obsoleted, and

486
00:27:30.823 --> 00:27:35.780
that means we're probably not
gonna see a code generally.

487
00:27:35.780 --> 00:27:40.910
But notice the code 1, though, and
the way that it's described here.

488
00:27:40.910 --> 00:27:47.328
Redirects all future datagrams for
the original destination address, okay?

489
00:27:47.328 --> 00:27:52.211
The reason why this one is important
is because it can actually be a part of

490
00:27:52.211 --> 00:27:54.520
a spoofing attack here.

491
00:27:54.520 --> 00:27:59.840
Where what I can do is, I can redirect
packets, and then tell every packet

492
00:27:59.840 --> 00:28:06.210
after the original one that was sent,
to go where I want it to go, okay?

493
00:28:06.210 --> 00:28:10.600
And that is a key one for
us to actually think about, okay?

494
00:28:10.600 --> 00:28:14.460
Now I don't have that,
where I can do this in lab in easy time,

495
00:28:14.460 --> 00:28:19.680
but I kinda tried to walk us through
at least a portion of it, okay?

496
00:28:19.680 --> 00:28:23.464
An attacker over here on
the left-hand side first,

497
00:28:23.464 --> 00:28:28.367
which is step number 1,
it takes over control of this router okay?

498
00:28:29.810 --> 00:28:35.059
When it does that, okay, what it's wanting
to do of course, then, is it's wanting,

499
00:28:35.059 --> 00:28:39.560
then, at this particular point,
to be able, now that it's got control of

500
00:28:39.560 --> 00:28:45.140
the router,
to send to its target here, okay?

501
00:28:45.140 --> 00:28:50.070
Actually what it wants to become a proxy,
to say look, here's what's gonna happen.

502
00:28:50.070 --> 00:28:55.993
I am gonna become your new proxy address,
okay?

503
00:28:55.993 --> 00:28:58.757
Now, once it does that,
that's perfectly fine,

504
00:28:58.757 --> 00:29:00.854
that's exactly what we want it to do.

505
00:29:00.854 --> 00:29:04.865
Because PC1 will then respond and
go, sure thing,

506
00:29:04.865 --> 00:29:09.159
let me make sure that all my
packets get sent back to you.

507
00:29:09.159 --> 00:29:15.290
Now, when it sends it from this
step number 2 here as the router,

508
00:29:15.290 --> 00:29:21.096
it's actually putting this as
pretending to be PC2, okay?

509
00:29:21.096 --> 00:29:25.509
It's just sending a reply back, so this is
where it's actually redirecting something.

510
00:29:25.509 --> 00:29:28.629
And saying yeah, just,
if you need something on router number 2,

511
00:29:28.629 --> 00:29:30.700
send it to me over here instead.

512
00:29:30.700 --> 00:29:34.820
This guy thinks he's replying and says, no
problem, I'll send it over to you, okay?

513
00:29:34.820 --> 00:29:38.130
At the same, he now starts crafting

514
00:29:38.130 --> 00:29:42.480
what his particular response
is to take this over, okay?

515
00:29:42.480 --> 00:29:46.510
So, now what happens is, every time
router number 2 thinks that he's

516
00:29:46.510 --> 00:29:51.530
sending something out to this default
router, or his default gateway here,

517
00:29:51.530 --> 00:29:55.410
he really is actually sending
it back to PC number 1.

518
00:29:55.410 --> 00:29:58.088
PC number 1 is actually
forwarding it over to router, and

519
00:29:58.088 --> 00:29:59.629
who's in control of the router?

520
00:29:59.629 --> 00:30:00.770
Right here.

521
00:30:00.770 --> 00:30:04.166
So, it is all because of using
those redirect messages, and

522
00:30:04.166 --> 00:30:07.130
he's saying,
send this as a redirect over here.

523
00:30:07.130 --> 00:30:08.670
And this guy's saying, sure thing.

524
00:30:08.670 --> 00:30:13.140
So, every single message that comes
from PC2 will eventually end up

525
00:30:13.140 --> 00:30:15.240
getting over to router number 1.

526
00:30:15.240 --> 00:30:18.662
Even though its default gateway is
supposed to be router number 2.

527
00:30:18.662 --> 00:30:22.680
He just acts like this is just
another guy in the stream of the data.

528
00:30:22.680 --> 00:30:24.690
So even though it's all on
a different network, he just goes,

529
00:30:24.690 --> 00:30:28.880
fine, I'll just treat that as another one,
and allow that path to go on.

530
00:30:28.880 --> 00:30:31.711
So this is why we shouldn't
see these messages.

531
00:30:31.711 --> 00:30:35.377
If you ever get a redirect with number
1 on it, a lot of times and you go,

532
00:30:35.377 --> 00:30:37.820
I don't know those IP addresses.

533
00:30:37.820 --> 00:30:41.450
It's probably a sign that somebody
is redirecting you to their box,

534
00:30:41.450 --> 00:30:44.092
instead of the one you think
it's supposed to be going to.

535
00:30:44.092 --> 00:30:48.744
Just realize,
this one is pretty hefty and it takes-

536
00:30:48.744 --> 00:30:49.354
>> Insidious.

537
00:30:49.354 --> 00:30:49.854
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah.

538
00:30:49.854 --> 00:30:50.744
>> It's pretty hefty,

539
00:30:50.744 --> 00:30:54.540
it does take a lot to set it up,
and I just did not have.

540
00:30:54.540 --> 00:30:58.410
When I think about it, I don't think I
had the wherewithal to actually bring up

541
00:30:58.410 --> 00:31:01.840
all the utilities that normally is
also required in doing this, and

542
00:31:01.840 --> 00:31:02.900
to get it up and running.

543
00:31:02.900 --> 00:31:06.270
But you can kind of see the idea,
they're not gonna, but you kinda know.

544
00:31:06.270 --> 00:31:10.614
If you see this, especially code 1s,
you know something else is going on.

545
00:31:10.614 --> 00:31:14.324
All right, Daniel,
it looks like I have done this once again,

546
00:31:14.324 --> 00:31:16.190
where I have outran the clock.

547
00:31:16.190 --> 00:31:16.720
>> Mm!

548
00:31:16.720 --> 00:31:20.240
>> And it means that I've
still got a bit more to go.

549
00:31:20.240 --> 00:31:22.454
So we're gonna have to actually
do a part four here Daniel.

550
00:31:22.454 --> 00:31:23.106
>> Well who-
>> [LAUGH]

551
00:31:23.106 --> 00:31:24.953
>> Would have thought there would be so

552
00:31:24.953 --> 00:31:28.970
much information about ICMP, and
attack vectors associated with it.

553
00:31:28.970 --> 00:31:30.520
So it's a good thing that we continue on,

554
00:31:30.520 --> 00:31:33.170
we wanna make sure that you're fully
aware of these attack vectors.

555
00:31:33.170 --> 00:31:37.060
So that you understand how to spot
them and maybe even mitigate them.

556
00:31:37.060 --> 00:31:39.520
And at least be aware of them
if they're happening, and

557
00:31:39.520 --> 00:31:42.860
set up your network, and
prepare for that SecOps exam.

558
00:31:42.860 --> 00:31:44.522
Ronnie, thanks for joining us today,
we do appreciate it.

559
00:31:44.522 --> 00:31:46.825
And we would look forward
to seeing you in part four.

560
00:31:46.825 --> 00:31:50.654
We do thank our audience for joining
us as well, but it is that time for

561
00:31:50.654 --> 00:31:51.520
us to sign off.

562
00:31:51.520 --> 00:31:53.945
For ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie

563
00:31:53.945 --> 00:31:55.005
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

564
00:31:55.005 --> 00:32:00.842
>> And we'll see you next time.

565
00:32:00.842 --> 00:32:03.521
[MUSIC]

566
00:32:03.521 --> 00:32:06.096
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie describe the use and importance of ICMP from a security standpoint. Here they continue discussing ICMP types that you should be aware of and their associated attack vectors such as Router Discovery spoofing, Tunneling attack, and Denial of Service attacks like Oversized ICMP messages, ICMP floods, and Smurf attacks.
episodes.title: Describe ICMP Intrusion Part 4

WEBVTT

1

Welcome to ITProTV.

3

4

5

6
00:00:11.994 --> 00:00:13.743
>> All right, greetings everyone and

7
00:00:13.743 --> 00:00:16.431
welcome back to another
exciting episode of ITProTV.

8
00:00:16.431 --> 00:00:19.094
I'm your host, Daniel Lowrie,
and in today's episode,

9
00:00:19.094 --> 00:00:21.259
if I can get that out of my mouth-
>> [LAUGH]

10
00:00:21.259 --> 00:00:25.090
>> Is our Cisco Sec Op series.

11
00:00:25.090 --> 00:00:28.640
Joining us back, as Ronnie laughs
hysterically at me fumbling my words,

12
00:00:28.640 --> 00:00:29.710
is our good friend Mr. Ronnie Wong.

13
00:00:29.710 --> 00:00:30.730
Ronnie, welcome back, how's it going?

14
00:00:30.730 --> 00:00:33.054
>> I am doing fine, Daniel, thank you.

15
00:00:33.054 --> 00:00:36.972
And I remember, the last episode I said
notify at least 66 times in five minutes.

16
00:00:36.972 --> 00:00:41.430
>> [LAUGH]
>> Notice, notify, something like that.

17
00:00:41.430 --> 00:00:45.540
But I do understand this is a long
topic for us to be covering,

18
00:00:45.540 --> 00:00:47.375
and we are still taking a look at ICMP.

19
00:00:47.375 --> 00:00:48.175
>> [LAUGH]
>> So

20
00:00:48.175 --> 00:00:51.413
that means that [LAUGH] we have a bit more
to cover, just a little bit more to cover.

21
00:00:51.413 --> 00:00:53.628
>> It's like the Transformer series,
[INAUDIBLE].

22
00:00:53.628 --> 00:00:54.136
>> I know, yeah.
>> [LAUGH]

23
00:00:54.136 --> 00:00:55.720
>> It's one of those where it's like keep

24
00:00:55.720 --> 00:00:56.530
making money, keep doing it.

25
00:00:56.530 --> 00:00:58.420
>> Yeah.
>> Yeah, keep extending that.

26
00:00:58.420 --> 00:00:58.921
No, that's [CROSSTALK]
>> We'll get

27
00:00:58.921 --> 00:01:00.268
Michael Bay to produce the next one.

28
00:01:00.268 --> 00:01:01.040
>> That would be true.
>> [LAUGH]

29
00:01:01.040 --> 00:01:02.740
>> Yeah, that would be the way to go.

30
00:01:02.740 --> 00:01:07.380
But for us, we are now taking a look at
just a few more attacks that we should be

31
00:01:07.380 --> 00:01:12.370
familiar with, of course with ICMP, and
that is what we're heading into now.

32
00:01:12.370 --> 00:01:18.460
We don't talk a lot about IPv6 and
ICMP's types of information, but

33
00:01:18.460 --> 00:01:23.920
we are gonna talk at least one particular
attack that can be done as well.

34
00:01:23.920 --> 00:01:28.430
And the attack, remember, is not so much
that they're doing something malicious

35
00:01:28.430 --> 00:01:34.980
with it as much as taking advantage of the
nature and the way that ICMP works, okay?

36
00:01:34.980 --> 00:01:37.060
So what we're talking about now,
of course,

37
00:01:37.060 --> 00:01:42.566
is the idea of what we call router
discovery messages that are out there.

38
00:01:42.566 --> 00:01:48.030
In IPv6, when you start putting IP
addresses on devices, especially

39
00:01:48.030 --> 00:01:52.630
like routers, they normally start to do
what they call a router advertisement.

40
00:01:52.630 --> 00:01:57.034
That's an ICMP message that's
essentially going out over IPv6 as well.

41
00:01:57.034 --> 00:02:00.192
And that one, of course,
is just saying hey, I'm out here.

42
00:02:00.192 --> 00:02:02.959
And then,
other devices that are ICMP enabled,

43
00:02:02.959 --> 00:02:07.009
they of course will respond to that and
assign themselves, normally,

44
00:02:07.009 --> 00:02:10.520
an IP address within that range and
there we go.

45
00:02:10.520 --> 00:02:11.840
So, we can do that as well.

46
00:02:11.840 --> 00:02:14.640
But other times,
if it's looking for that router,

47
00:02:14.640 --> 00:02:17.620
it can send out what we call
router solicitation messages.

48
00:02:17.620 --> 00:02:19.410
So an advertisement,
of course, is from the router.

49
00:02:19.410 --> 00:02:21.110
The router advertisement, it makes sense.

50
00:02:21.110 --> 00:02:24.850
A router solicitation message
is when some device says hey,

51
00:02:24.850 --> 00:02:29.220
I need to find the nearest router near
me and let's take a look at that.

52
00:02:29.220 --> 00:02:32.657
So here's how the attack plays out,
let's go ahead and

53
00:02:32.657 --> 00:02:36.660
take a look at my diagram to
help us at least a little bit.

54
00:02:36.660 --> 00:02:38.640
So let's say that PC1,

55
00:02:38.640 --> 00:02:44.530
right here, it starts to put out a router
solicitation message out on that.

56
00:02:44.530 --> 00:02:45.390
Now of course,

57
00:02:45.390 --> 00:02:50.420
that means the router itself is gonna
receive that router solicitation message.

58
00:02:50.420 --> 00:02:54.540
And when it does that, it can also send
out a router advertisement saying, yes,

59
00:02:54.540 --> 00:02:56.440
I'm out here and I'm ready to go.

60
00:02:56.440 --> 00:03:00.250
But remember, every other device
also is going to be listening and

61
00:03:00.250 --> 00:03:03.850
let's say the attacker listens, too.

62
00:03:03.850 --> 00:03:08.280
Well when the attacker listens,
if he is active and

63
00:03:08.280 --> 00:03:13.510
he is absolutely waiting for
a reply like this, he can then spoof

64
00:03:13.510 --> 00:03:18.650
the router's reply to try and
get the message down

65
00:03:18.650 --> 00:03:24.220
to PC 1 before PC 1 knows that it's
not really the router over here.

66
00:03:24.220 --> 00:03:29.240
At that point,
he can say I am the default route.

67
00:03:29.240 --> 00:03:31.405
So instead of everybody
sending anything or

68
00:03:31.405 --> 00:03:35.900
PC1 sending outbound to router over here,
router one.

69
00:03:35.900 --> 00:03:40.770
It instead believes that the attacker
now becomes the default gateway,

70
00:03:40.770 --> 00:03:44.829
and he can then start proxying and
forwarding data the way that he wants to.

71
00:03:44.829 --> 00:03:45.905
>> It's a man in the middle attack.

72
00:03:45.905 --> 00:03:47.090
Classic.
>> Man in the middle attack.

73
00:03:47.090 --> 00:03:48.550
Very much a classic.

74
00:03:48.550 --> 00:03:53.740
But very simply done, not because we
had to set up anything a lot, right?

75
00:03:53.740 --> 00:03:56.930
The only thing that the attacker
really did actively

76
00:03:56.930 --> 00:04:01.079
is to really spoof the reply that
a router would normally send out.

77
00:04:02.130 --> 00:04:05.320
Now, I went ahead and captured some
of this data a little bit earlier,

78
00:04:05.320 --> 00:04:06.290

00:16:22.500 --> 00:16:23.545
Who notices pings?

304
00:16:23.545 --> 00:16:24.136
>> Nobody.

305
00:16:24.136 --> 00:16:24.823
>> What's the big deal?

306
00:16:24.823 --> 00:16:28.802
>> This might be a bit suspect that
you have a gazillion pings happening.

307
00:16:28.802 --> 00:16:32.971
>> [LAUGH]
>> And they all have random sizes.

308
00:16:32.971 --> 00:16:35.129
>> Yeah, they are different random.

309
00:16:35.129 --> 00:16:35.661
>> Or seem.

310
00:16:35.661 --> 00:16:36.813
>> Yeah.
Not too badly, but-

311
00:16:36.813 --> 00:16:38.378
>> Not too randomly, but different.

312
00:16:38.378 --> 00:16:38.937
>> The same one.

313
00:16:38.937 --> 00:16:40.784
This is where it should start to notice,
right?

314
00:16:40.784 --> 00:16:41.305
>> Yeah.

315
00:16:41.305 --> 00:16:45.330
>> So if you saw random pings it's no big
deal as long as they're different ones.

316
00:16:45.330 --> 00:16:46.583
>> Right.
>> Different sources,

317
00:16:46.583 --> 00:16:48.283
different destinations, but all the same.

318
00:16:48.283 --> 00:16:49.850
This is part of something.

319
00:16:49.850 --> 00:16:50.653
>> Yeah, yeah.

320
00:16:50.653 --> 00:16:51.651
>> Yeah, it's part of a stream.

321
00:16:51.651 --> 00:16:56.158
This is what we're expecting, well not
normally what we're expecting, but

322
00:16:56.158 --> 00:16:59.111
you can kind of see why this is so
fairly effective.

323
00:16:59.111 --> 00:17:04.316
But today, of course people don't just
do it here, you can use DNS to do this.

324
00:17:04.316 --> 00:17:05.188
>> Yeah.

325
00:17:05.188 --> 00:17:06.070
>> You can use HTTP to do this.

326
00:17:06.070 --> 00:17:11.386
You name it, it's really just
the beginning, but to show you ICMP.

327
00:17:11.386 --> 00:17:17.130
Remember that this, unlike what
we're just talking about HTTP and

328
00:17:17.130 --> 00:17:19.890
all that, this doesn't have
to happen at layer seven.

329
00:17:21.000 --> 00:17:25.595
This happens at layer three, and I've
just showed you that I can actually send,

330
00:17:25.595 --> 00:17:29.109
essentially, the TCP traffic over layer,
I know we can, but

331
00:17:29.109 --> 00:17:31.678
inside, within, tunneling through ICMP,

332
00:17:31.678 --> 00:17:36.024
that is something that you do want to
make sure that you can pay attention to.

333
00:17:36.024 --> 00:17:37.717
So how do you stop something like that?

334
00:17:37.717 --> 00:17:38.683
It's deep packet inspection.

335
00:17:38.683 --> 00:17:39.205
>> Yep.

336
00:17:39.205 --> 00:17:40.331
>> Okay?
Just like what we were talking about.

337
00:17:40.331 --> 00:17:44.525
Yes, if you can do depack
inspection this stuff, then again,

338
00:17:44.525 --> 00:17:46.910
gets readily noticed all the time.

339
00:17:46.910 --> 00:17:52.823
But just as an example of what happens
here, no TCP information going on here.

340
00:17:52.823 --> 00:17:57.132
Not going across it,
it's all pings, and I may not pay

341
00:17:57.132 --> 00:17:59.797
attention to it all unless I-
>> Yeah and

342
00:17:59.797 --> 00:18:02.652
if somebody had a filter in Wire Shark for
just looking for TCP connections,

343
00:18:02.652 --> 00:18:04.046
they wouldn't even see this at all.

344
00:18:04.046 --> 00:18:04.618
>> Yeah.

345
00:18:04.618 --> 00:18:07.078
So that, look, look at that.

346
00:18:07.078 --> 00:18:08.193
It's blank.

347
00:18:08.193 --> 00:18:11.562
>> [LAUGH]
>> So there you start to see some of

348
00:18:11.562 --> 00:18:14.359
the information and some of
the different things that can happen.

349
00:18:14.359 --> 00:18:18.970
But just realize, yes,
ICMP, it seems easy enough.

350
00:18:18.970 --> 00:18:23.932
We're not focusing in too much on a lot
of information, but there you have it.

351
00:18:23.932 --> 00:18:27.790
All right, so let's take a look
at just a couple of other things,

352
00:18:27.790 --> 00:18:30.597
which we're not gonna
dive too deep into this,

353
00:18:30.597 --> 00:18:34.971
cuz we did talk about this in the security
fundamentals a little bit more.

354
00:18:34.971 --> 00:18:41.776
But ICMP can be, if you really choose to
use some type of denial-of-service attack.

355
00:18:41.776 --> 00:18:45.579
Remember that if you talk about
denial of service attacks that go on,

356
00:18:45.579 --> 00:18:50.103
ICMP flooding is just a way to overwhelm
a device, essentially is what we have, so

357
00:18:50.103 --> 00:18:52.420
there's a couple of different methods.

358
00:18:52.420 --> 00:18:54.986
You send enough to actually overwhelm,
let's say, a router's interface.

359
00:18:54.986 --> 00:18:58.290
It happens, okay, so
you can do the attack.

360
00:18:58.290 --> 00:19:02.600
You can, of course, have thousands, if
not hundreds of thousands of people send

361
00:19:02.600 --> 00:19:05.390
enough data to overwhelm the attack,
it makes sense.

362
00:19:05.390 --> 00:19:07.771
You can do this with pings,
not as easy anymore.

363
00:19:07.771 --> 00:19:08.356
[LAUGH]
>> Yeah.

364
00:19:08.356 --> 00:19:11.580
>> But it can be done, cuz you can craft
different packet size if you need to.

365
00:19:13.050 --> 00:19:16.260
If you do that idea of a SMURF attack,
remember you're saying essentially right

366
00:19:16.260 --> 00:19:21.420
here, like look, here it is,
I'm gonna actually send let's say a ping,

367
00:19:21.420 --> 00:19:26.470
but I want the reply to go this guy, but
you actually send it to everybody here.

368
00:19:26.470 --> 00:19:28.150
That's what you end up doing.

369
00:19:28.150 --> 00:19:31.630
So you send it to everybody in this
network right here, and when they actually

370
00:19:31.630 --> 00:19:37.650
reply, they reply back to this guy up
here, and now he gets overwhelmed as well.

371
00:19:37.650 --> 00:19:40.455
So not exactly the hardest and
most difficult concept to understand.

372
00:19:40.455 --> 00:19:46.595
Realize that this is a part of the ICMP
attacks that you can also see.

373
00:19:46.595 --> 00:19:51.148
So Daniel, right there,
in a nutshell, and four episodes

374
00:19:51.148 --> 00:19:51.809
>> [LAUGH] Yeah.

375
00:19:51.809 --> 00:19:54.540
>> We uncovered ICMP.

376
00:19:54.540 --> 00:19:55.570
>> ICMP.

377
00:19:55.570 --> 00:19:58.081
>> [LAUGH]
>> Well I definitely will not,

378
00:19:58.081 --> 00:20:02.580
I am more respecting of the ICP
protocol and it's danger vector.

379
00:20:02.580 --> 00:20:06.695
This is definitely a legitimate attack
surface that you have to be aware of and

380
00:20:06.695 --> 00:20:09.353
have to prepare for,
start looking at that kind of

381
00:20:09.353 --> 00:20:13.022
data to make sure it's not being used
as such as an attack vector, and

382
00:20:13.022 --> 00:20:15.849
now that we're aware of it
we can do that very thing.

383
00:20:15.849 --> 00:20:18.111
Ronnie thank you for
making us aware of it, but

384
00:20:18.111 --> 00:20:20.210
it does look like we do
have run out of time.

385
00:20:20.210 --> 00:20:22.529
For this episode we do appreciate you for
dropping by.

386
00:20:22.529 --> 00:20:26.236
We appreciate our audience for
watching, but signing off for ITProTV,

387
00:20:26.236 --> 00:20:28.368
I've been your host Daniel Lowry,
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

388
00:20:28.368 --> 00:20:29.553
>> We'll see you next time.

389
00:20:29.553 --> 00:20:37.198
[MUSIC]

390
00:20:37.198 --> 00:20:40.043
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

Well remember that part of

And if you take a look at the idea here,

So, Daniel you have to help out

on the OSI module,

we talked about ethernet which essentially

Now, in ethernet and what we've talked

But, it does have a layer one component

46

It does also communicate and
put things onto the wire itself.

47
00:01:48.130 --> 00:01:50.445
But we're really focused in on layer two.

48

Then we spent a good bit of
time taking a look at layer 3.

49
00:01:54.543 --> 00:01:59.385
Talked about IPs, the IP header itself,
and then spent a good

50
00:01:59.385 --> 00:02:03.865
bit of time even on another
protocol inside of there, the ICMP.

51
00:02:03.865 --> 00:02:08.905
So there's layer 3, so logically then,
this particular section and

52
00:02:08.905 --> 00:02:13.750
just at least a few more after this,
is gonna be involving headers which

00:02:13.750 --> 00:02:16.270
means that we'll cover the upper

54
00:02:16.270 --> 00:02:22.430
So today and describing transport headers,
or transport layer headers, I should say.

55
00:02:22.430 --> 00:02:27.680
We are really going to cover kind of
the basics of the layer for headers.

56
00:02:27.680 --> 00:02:30.800
And for most of us,
that really divides up into,

57
00:02:30.800 --> 00:02:35.420
well two particular protocols,
TCP and UDP.

58
00:02:35.420 --> 00:02:40.110
Those are kind of the two major headers,
as far as different

59
00:02:40.110 --> 00:02:43.980
protocols go that we want to focus in on
and pay attention to some of the details.

60
00:02:43.980 --> 00:02:48.810
A great thing is we pay attention to more
TCP, a lot more headers in there than UDP.

61
00:02:48.810 --> 00:02:52.490
And in the UDP, where I'm kinda fudging or
sandbagging a little bit,

62
00:02:52.490 --> 00:02:55.770
Daniel, because there's a lot
more to come in that later on,

63
00:02:55.770 --> 00:02:57.800
even when we get up to
the application layer.

64
00:02:57.800 --> 00:03:02.500
But because there is a lot of that to go,
we're gonna kinda do a brief overview of

65
00:03:02.500 --> 00:03:08.220
that one too, in at least just
a little episode that we're doing,

66
00:03:08.220 --> 00:03:12.070
maybe a couple of episodes that we'll
do here, is what we'll take a look at.

67
00:03:12.070 --> 00:03:15.010
So let's start off with just a primer,

68
00:03:15.010 --> 00:03:20.820
in terms of the way that TCP
normally ends up working.

69
00:03:20.820 --> 00:03:23.835
So Daniel,
when we start to talk about this,

70
00:03:23.835 --> 00:03:29.380
there's a couple of things that are going
on here that we want to take a look at.

71
00:03:29.380 --> 00:03:31.560
But the easiest thing as we begin,

72
00:03:31.560 --> 00:03:35.260
is that we wanna make sure that we
understand what TCP provides for us.

73
00:03:35.260 --> 00:03:38.130
Transport Control Protocol.

74
00:03:38.130 --> 00:03:41.050
Or Transmission Control,
I keep saying transport.

75
00:03:41.050 --> 00:03:44.080
>> Transmission Control Protocol.

76
00:03:44.080 --> 00:03:46.862
I will get that wrong every time,
and I don't know why [INAUDIBLE].

77
00:03:46.862 --> 00:03:47.709
[CROSSTALK]
>> Didn't it used to be called

78
00:03:47.709 --> 00:03:48.720
the transport control protocol?

79
00:03:48.720 --> 00:03:50.982
>> People have said it more
regularly that way, but

80
00:03:50.982 --> 00:03:53.310
it's actually transmission
control protocol.

81
00:03:53.310 --> 00:03:56.760
I know that if I don't say it, somebody
will actually go, Ronnie you got that one,

82
00:03:56.760 --> 00:03:59.920
I did get that one wrong because I
said it multiple times here, but

83
00:03:59.920 --> 00:04:02.010
it is transmission control protocol.

84
00:04:02.010 --> 00:04:05.690
Now in the transmission control protocol,
what does it really provide for

85
00:04:05.690 --> 00:04:07.040
us that we need?

86
00:04:07.040 --> 00:04:09.081
And that's why this comes about.

87
00:04:09.081 --> 00:04:11.365
Remember that really at the beginning,

88
00:04:11.365 --> 00:04:15.201
the idea of just simply sending down
from one location to the other.

89
00:04:15.201 --> 00:04:20.250
It really doesn't involve much more
besides us saying, all right I need

90
00:04:20.250 --> 00:04:25.630
a source IP address and a source Mac
address sorry, destination address,

91
00:04:25.630 --> 00:04:30.874
I can deliver from one location to
another, that's pretty much about it.

92
00:04:30.874 --> 00:04:32.719
Don't really need anything else.

93
00:04:32.719 --> 00:04:36.654
But if you are going to be communicating,
then you are probably going to be using

94
00:04:36.654 --> 00:04:39.122
some kind of application
in that communication,

95
00:04:39.122 --> 00:04:41.705
which now means we have to be
able to take that data and

96
00:04:41.705 --> 00:04:44.500
attach it a little bit higher
into the [INAUDIBLE] model.

97
00:04:44.500 --> 00:04:48.500
And the way that we do that is
of course using the TCP here.

98
00:04:48.500 --> 00:04:53.710
So when we do this, what does TCP
offer and why do we actually need it?

99
00:04:53.710 --> 00:04:56.890
We need it because it does
connect us to the application.

100
00:04:56.890 --> 00:05:01.440
So it takes that ability to send data,
and really relay it on to those upper

101
00:05:01.440 --> 00:05:04.550
layers which attaches it to
the application that we need.

102
00:05:04.550 --> 00:05:06.700
The other things that it provides,
generally,

103
00:05:06.700 --> 00:05:08.730
are things like what we call reliability.

104
00:05:09.740 --> 00:05:13.409
Also the idea here of flow control and
providing for

105
00:05:13.409 --> 00:05:15.895
stateful communication as well.

106
00:05:15.895 --> 00:05:20.521
Now, let's make sure that we kind of
break that down and understand that.

107
00:05:20.521 --> 00:05:25.690
So using that and understanding
the idea of something like reliability.

108
00:05:25.690 --> 00:05:31.431
Well, what in the world is reliability
about, and why is it so important?

109
00:05:31.431 --> 00:05:38.034
It is absolutely probably the key feature
inside of TCP that we want to talk about,

110
00:05:38.034 --> 00:05:42.929
because it does require what
we call a connection oriented.

111
00:05:42.929 --> 00:05:44.960
It's actually a connection
oriented protocol.

112
00:05:44.960 --> 00:05:50.040
It requires both sides of that
communication, really do establish and

113
00:05:50.040 --> 00:05:52.760
talk to each other as what it does.

114
00:05:52.760 --> 00:05:54.220
So at the beginning here,

115
00:05:54.220 --> 00:05:57.550
let me see if, I don't think I
actually have the dive down there.

116
00:05:57.550 --> 00:05:58.359
That'll work.

117
00:05:58.359 --> 00:06:01.264
So let me move this off to a side for
a moment here.

118
00:06:01.264 --> 00:06:03.951
>> [LAUGH] Put them back.

119
00:06:03.951 --> 00:06:05.900
Hopefully, do not pay attention to that.

120
00:06:05.900 --> 00:06:07.730
And we'll start with this.

121
00:06:07.730 --> 00:06:11.550
So, remember there's actually what we
call a three way handshake to begin,

122
00:06:11.550 --> 00:06:13.670
and kind of get everything set up.

123
00:06:13.670 --> 00:06:14.990
The way that we want to.

124
00:06:14.990 --> 00:06:16.520
So the initial side is,

125
00:06:16.520 --> 00:06:20.980
of course, is what you designing to
communicate with the other side.

126
00:06:20.980 --> 00:06:23.241
So let's just mark this and make it easy.

127
00:06:23.241 --> 00:06:24.829
We'll say, A and then.

128
00:06:27.690 --> 00:06:29.090
We'll make this one B over here.

129
00:06:31.550 --> 00:06:35.710
So when we want to do that,
before any data is transmitted back and

130
00:06:35.710 --> 00:06:41.620
fourth across these two devices,
what A will do is it will send

131
00:06:41.620 --> 00:06:46.820
a synchronization or
a SYN header, is what it will do.

132
00:06:46.820 --> 00:06:49.820
A SYN pack,
is what it will end up sending.

133
00:06:49.820 --> 00:06:51.778
When it does so,
it includes a sequence number.

134
00:06:51.778 --> 00:06:54.050
We're not gonna get into
sequence numbers right now, but

135
00:06:54.050 --> 00:06:55.520
it will go ahead and send that.

136
00:06:55.520 --> 00:07:00.106
What it's telling B is,
I want to send data to you.

137
00:07:00.106 --> 00:07:05.040
It is sort of like going into a room for
the first time, and you're meeting people.

138
00:07:05.040 --> 00:07:07.590
When you walk into, I hope.

139
00:07:07.590 --> 00:07:09.140
There's two types of people,
right, Daniel?

140
00:07:09.140 --> 00:07:12.050
There's the one that walks in the room and

We don't send data before we have

We also include inside of TCP, the ability

00:11:25.310 --> 00:11:27.420

Instead of just relying on

moves on the next port.

527
00:29:27.700 --> 00:29:31.670
So it's very backwards is what
I'm typically used to seeing.

528
00:29:31.670 --> 00:29:32.630
>> Right.

529
00:29:32.630 --> 00:29:34.120
And I understand that.

530
00:29:34.120 --> 00:29:36.574
But those are some of the things,
make sure you pay attention.

531
00:29:37.915 --> 00:29:40.475
Think about using Wireshark,
if you haven't been using Wireshark.

532
00:29:41.535 --> 00:29:43.625
That's also gonna be key for us as well.

533
00:29:43.625 --> 00:29:45.865
>> Kind of the bread and
butter in this whole thing, isn't it?

534
00:29:45.865 --> 00:29:47.055
>> It really is key.

535
00:29:47.055 --> 00:29:49.925
We're gonna also start seeing
something in security onion,

536
00:29:49.925 --> 00:29:52.305
which is gonna introduce
us to a couple more tools.

537
00:29:52.305 --> 00:29:53.915
But being able to work with Wireshark,

538
00:29:53.915 --> 00:29:57.730
is a key aspect of what you'll also
be facing on the exam, as well.

539
00:29:57.730 --> 00:30:00.640
So getting ready to do all this,
make sure you pay attention there

540
00:30:00.640 --> 00:30:03.900
as you start seeing the scans,
that's what we wanna be able to do.

541
00:30:03.900 --> 00:30:06.230
All right Daniel,
there's a little bit more to go on UDP but

542
00:30:06.230 --> 00:30:09.555
I once again apparently
challenged the clock and won.

543
00:30:09.555 --> 00:30:11.490
>> [LAUGH]
>> So here it is, so

544
00:30:11.490 --> 00:30:13.290
apparently we're gonna
do a part three here.

545
00:30:13.290 --> 00:30:17.480
>> Not a problem Ronnie, we're enjoying,
it's been Good times had by all so far.

546
00:30:17.480 --> 00:30:20.310
So let the revelries
continue in our Part 3.

547
00:30:20.310 --> 00:30:22.220
All right, Ronnie, thanks for
joining us today, though.

548
00:30:22.220 --> 00:30:23.670
We do thank our audience for watching.

549
00:30:23.670 --> 00:30:27.220
But as the man has said,
we are done for this episode.

550
00:30:27.220 --> 00:30:28.770
Come on back for that Part 3, though.

551
00:30:28.770 --> 00:30:31.320
Signing off for ITProTV,
I've been your host Daniel Lowrie.

552
00:30:31.320 --> 00:30:31.970
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

553
00:30:31.970 --> 00:30:34.889
And we'll see you next time.

554
00:30:34.889 --> 00:30:40.857

555
00:30:40.857 --> 00:30:44.314
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Ronnie take a look at Transport layer headers. Specific topics covered here includes: Invalid TCP flag combinations, UDP Headers breakdown, UDP Flooding, and UDP Max length.

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.182 --> 00:00:01.872
Welcome to ITProTV, I'm your host.

2
00:00:01.872 --> 00:00:06.445

3
00:00:06.445 --> 00:00:08.476

4
00:00:08.476 --> 00:00:12.137
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.137 --> 00:00:14.217
>> All right, greetings everyone, and

6
00:00:14.217 --> 00:00:17.016
welcome back to another
great episode of ITProTV.

7
00:00:17.016 --> 00:00:21.217
I'm your host Daniel Lowrie, and
in today's episode we are coming back at

8
00:00:21.217 --> 00:00:23.762
you with more and
our Cisco Cyber Ops series.

9
00:00:23.762 --> 00:00:27.902
And joining us back in studio, yet
again, you know him, the man, the myth,

10
00:00:27.902 --> 00:00:28.617
the legend.

11
00:00:28.617 --> 00:00:29.786
>> [LAUGH]
>> I think he's actually a chicken

12
00:00:29.786 --> 00:00:30.338
wing by this point.

13
00:00:30.338 --> 00:00:32.418
>> [LAUGH]
>> He's eaten so many of them,

14
00:00:32.418 --> 00:00:34.711
I've seen it first hand,
it's incredible to watch.

15
00:00:34.711 --> 00:00:37.427
Our good friend, Mr. Ronnie Wong,
Ronnie, welcome back, how's it going?

16
00:00:37.427 --> 00:00:39.165
>> Well, I do love chicken wings, so-
>> He does love chicken wings.

17
00:00:39.165 --> 00:00:43.528
>> So I am good today, Daniel, thank you
again for having me back on the show,

18
00:00:43.528 --> 00:00:47.706
as we complete the idea here of taking
a look at some layer four headers.

19
00:00:47.706 --> 00:00:50.872
We've got a little bit of more information
to go, and we've gotta talk about,

20
00:00:50.872 --> 00:00:51.876
of course, UDP as well.

21
00:00:51.876 --> 00:00:56.789
So let's jump right into it, and make sure
that we understand just a few more things

22
00:00:56.789 --> 00:00:58.908
that we need to take a look at, too.

23
00:00:58.908 --> 00:01:02.212
So last thing we were talking about,
of course,

24
00:01:02.212 --> 00:01:05.448
in our part two of this
little miniseries here.

25
00:01:05.448 --> 00:01:08.640
We were talking about some of
the different attacks that we may see,

26
00:01:08.640 --> 00:01:11.339
and I want to mention just
a couple more before we move on.

27
00:01:11.339 --> 00:01:15.726
And also, a couple of things that I forgot
to mention in those previous episodes as

28
00:01:15.726 --> 00:01:17.453
well, so this will help us out.

29
00:01:17.453 --> 00:01:21.846
Let's take a look on my screen here, okay,
we've talked about session hijacking,

30
00:01:21.846 --> 00:01:23.628
so I'm not so worried about that.

31
00:01:23.628 --> 00:01:26.745
But here's the reset idea that I
left off with, remember, Daniel,

32
00:01:26.745 --> 00:01:28.100
I was telling you that, hey.

33
00:01:28.100 --> 00:01:32.425
If you start getting this idea where you
continue incrementing on your side, but

34
00:01:32.425 --> 00:01:35.542
the [CROSSTALK] zero,
something like this can happen, but

35
00:01:35.542 --> 00:01:37.722
it shouldn't happen too often, okay?

36
00:01:37.722 --> 00:01:42.240
If it does, it's because somebody is
trying to reset something at the other

37
00:01:42.240 --> 00:01:45.142
end, so
here there is what is called a TCP reset.

38
00:01:45.142 --> 00:01:48.140
So if you start off with
just a three way handshake,

39
00:01:48.140 --> 00:01:53.095
remember that what should end up happening
is that the acknowledgment should show,

40
00:01:53.095 --> 00:01:57.658
at least even after the first one, that
I got the SYN which normally says a 1.

41
00:01:57.658 --> 00:02:02.474
That's what I'm sending you back is a 1,
but if someway somehow, okay,

42
00:02:02.474 --> 00:02:06.145
what has actually happened is,
I don't send that back,

43
00:02:06.145 --> 00:02:08.909
that means that I have
to start over again.

44
00:02:08.909 --> 00:02:11.688
Okay, and
that means that whoever the originating

45
00:02:11.688 --> 00:02:15.706
sender is just continues to resend,
he didn't get my last message.

46
00:02:15.706 --> 00:02:19.062
So I'm not gonna continue,
I'm just gonna go ahead and reset and

47
00:02:19.062 --> 00:02:20.295
start that over again.

48
00:02:20.295 --> 00:02:24.719
So when this ends up going on,
this is when we start having some issues.

49
00:02:24.719 --> 00:02:28.498
Anytime you actually set like the sequence
back to zero for one reason or another,

50
00:02:28.498 --> 00:02:31.643
you're just telling them,
I'm not ready for anything to happen.

51
00:02:31.643 --> 00:02:35.224
And that idea of resetting
everything is kind of a,

52
00:02:35.224 --> 00:02:39.324
the result is a denial of service,
is what happens, too.

53
00:02:39.324 --> 00:02:41.909
So even using a SYN scan,
if somebody's trying to do that,

54
00:02:41.909 --> 00:02:45.649
they're trying to disconnect, especially
if somebody is using the ports, right?

55
00:02:45.649 --> 00:02:49.754
They're just trying to go, let's just go
ahead and see how many of these we can hit

56
00:02:49.754 --> 00:02:53.460
and see what happens too, so not exactly
the harshest thing in the world.

57
00:02:53.460 --> 00:02:57.934
A lot of times those applications and
even firewalls start to drop these things

58
00:02:57.934 --> 00:03:02.365
immediately, once they start to see it,
too, so we don't see a lot of that.

59
00:03:02.365 --> 00:03:06.402
But synth-leading is a big one, so
my diagram is not the best, but

60
00:03:06.402 --> 00:03:08.001
you kind of get this idea.

61
00:03:08.001 --> 00:03:11.779
The attacker essentially spoofs
whoever the real guy is, so

62
00:03:11.779 --> 00:03:15.789
here's the real person,
supposed to be sending traffic here.

63
00:03:15.789 --> 00:03:19.764
But let's say that the attacker
spoofs his IP address, okay,

64
00:03:19.764 --> 00:03:23.889
sends all those SYN messages that
are supposed to be spoofed, and

65
00:03:23.889 --> 00:03:26.740
now nobody's actually really responding.

66
00:03:26.740 --> 00:03:30.150
So he sends a SYN-ACK, well, what's
supposed to happen in the third part?

67
00:03:30.150 --> 00:03:34.162
He's supposed to reply back with ACK,
okay, so there you go,

68
00:03:34.162 --> 00:03:37.585
you now have that idea of
the flooding that can occur.

69
00:03:37.585 --> 00:03:42.144
And now you have a connection that is
pretty much open and they are just and

70
00:03:42.144 --> 00:03:43.353
they are waiting.

71
00:03:43.353 --> 00:03:48.311
While they're waiting, other people can't
actually respond or can't do anything and

72
00:03:48.311 --> 00:03:50.370
that's where you also see that too.

73
00:03:50.370 --> 00:03:52.907
And the reason why this
is actually a good one,

74
00:03:52.907 --> 00:03:55.324
as far as what we're talking about, okay.

75
00:03:55.324 --> 00:03:59.729
When jumping to UDP you're gonna see that
there is only one form of attack here,

76
00:03:59.729 --> 00:04:03.821
which is some type of flooding attack,
is what we normally end up seeing.

77
00:04:03.821 --> 00:04:08.114
That's pretty much it about that, but
we'll take at the headers in a moment and

78
00:04:08.114 --> 00:04:10.690
then we'll also talk
about a few other things.

79
00:04:10.690 --> 00:04:14.375
Now, there's only one last thing I
wanted to say back on the headers,

80
00:04:14.375 --> 00:04:16.635
which as I looked over my notes, I forgot.

81
00:04:16.635 --> 00:04:21.199
There are certain combinations of
these flags, okay, and there's only

82
00:04:21.199 --> 00:04:25.704
really one that I want to point out here,
okay, that you should not see.

83
00:04:25.704 --> 00:04:30.354
We know that we can see a SYN and
an ACK flag set, okay, that make sense?

84
00:04:30.354 --> 00:04:33.099
Because that's about the second part
of the handshake, we can see that.

85
00:04:33.099 --> 00:04:36.672
But the one that we should not see is,

86
00:04:36.672 --> 00:04:42.328
you shouldn't see the SYN and
the FIN set at the same time.

87
00:04:42.328 --> 00:04:47.249
If you do, this is actually
a real violation of RFC 793, now,

88
00:04:47.249 --> 00:04:52.079
that doesn't mean that the RFC
police are gonna come after you,

89
00:04:52.079 --> 00:04:55.853
but it lets you know what,
this should not occur.

90
00:04:55.853 --> 00:04:57.091
>> It's abomination before [INAUDIBLE].

91
00:04:57.091 --> 00:04:58.374
>> Yes [LAUGH].

92
00:04:58.374 --> 00:04:59.342
>> [LAUGH]
>> Right, and

93
00:04:59.342 --> 00:05:00.484
you will be stricken [LAUGH].

94
00:05:00.484 --> 00:05:05.552
>> [LAUGH]
>> So, but it does, right, that should be

95
00:05:05.552 --> 00:05:11.584
kind of a red flag to you that hey, why
would anybody ever set a SYN and a FIN?

96
00:05:11.584 --> 00:05:15.050
The only reason to do that is to kind of
go, all right, I don't care if we're gonna

97
00:05:15.050 --> 00:05:18.172
synchronize, but we're gonna just
say it's finished immediately, so

98
00:05:18.172 --> 00:05:19.609
that you can essentially reset.

99
00:05:19.609 --> 00:05:23.723
So why not just use the reset
flag is what should happen, but

100
00:05:23.723 --> 00:05:27.193
those two should not be set
at the same exact time.

101
00:05:27.193 --> 00:05:32.277
>> I know in nmap, they encourage you
to play around with these flags and

102
00:05:32.277 --> 00:05:35.793
as you attempt to enumerate
a certain machine.

103
00:05:35.793 --> 00:05:38.913
And sometimes certain flag
combinations don't give you anything.

104
00:05:38.913 --> 00:05:42.330
But just getting crazy with them
sometimes can elicit a good

105
00:05:42.330 --> 00:05:46.379
response out of the machine,
letting you know that port is open.

106
00:05:46.379 --> 00:05:50.436
All my other attempts are just being
masked behind some sort of rules,

107
00:05:50.436 --> 00:05:52.450
so playing with these can happen.

108
00:05:52.450 --> 00:05:55.106
So if you see SYN and FIN put together,

109
00:05:55.106 --> 00:05:59.681
maybe it was someone crafting
an nmap scan to illicit a response.

110
00:05:59.681 --> 00:06:04.694
>> Yeah, it is not someone crafting it,
in theory, in a very small,

111
00:06:04.694 --> 00:06:08.991
small, tiny,
atomic theory that's out there, okay,

112
00:06:08.991 --> 00:06:15.188
it could be data corruption that has
caused this thing to, right, it's one bit.

113
00:06:15.188 --> 00:06:19.900
I'm not saying you can't lose a bit
here or there, but at the same time,

114
00:06:19.900 --> 00:06:22.988
it's so
small in which you're saying, wait,

115
00:06:22.988 --> 00:06:27.878
this is happening during the midst of
these other things that are going on.

116
00:06:27.878 --> 00:06:32.799
It seems to be more than just missing a
bit, it seems to be some type of something

117
00:06:32.799 --> 00:06:37.443
crafted, and that's the idea that
that's trying to be put across here.

118
00:06:37.443 --> 00:06:41.407
So when you see unusual flag
combinations like Daniel was saying,

119
00:06:41.407 --> 00:06:46.287
this is something we shouldn't be dealing
with too much, so, okay, as well, so

120
00:06:46.287 --> 00:06:48.517
what in the world fixes a lot of this?

121
00:06:48.517 --> 00:06:51.377
Authentication is what
fixes a lot of this, right,

122
00:06:51.377 --> 00:06:55.935
verifying that this is who the originator
is, and who the sender is supposed to be.

123
00:06:55.935 --> 00:07:00.223
Doing that idea of the two way mutual
authentication really does help,

124
00:07:00.223 --> 00:07:04.589
because that way, you know somebody
else is not hijacking the session.

125
00:07:04.589 --> 00:07:06.300
They're not sending these floods,

126
00:07:06.300 --> 00:07:09.236
cuz you're not actually
establishing that authentication.

127
00:07:09.236 --> 00:07:13.819
It just makes sense to do something
like that, now, it is a lot more set up.

128
00:07:13.819 --> 00:07:17.520
You do have to do a lot more things to
make that ready to go as well, all right.

129
00:07:17.520 --> 00:07:20.211
Now let's move to our final
topic here if I can get to it,

130
00:07:20.211 --> 00:07:22.002
look how exciting this is, Daniel.

131
00:07:22.002 --> 00:07:24.282
>> [LAUGH]
>> Can you believe it?

132
00:07:24.282 --> 00:07:27.788
>> Man that's a lot of headers to
memorize, I don't know if they can do it,

133
00:07:27.788 --> 00:07:28.546
Ronnie [LAUGH].

134
00:07:28.546 --> 00:07:30.792
>> Well after all the ones
that we've gone through,

135
00:07:30.792 --> 00:07:32.672
it's probably just kind of this, okay.

136
00:07:32.672 --> 00:07:37.283
So what is the difference here
between what we see in TCP versus UDP?

137
00:07:37.283 --> 00:07:40.770
The great thing about this
as far as a primer goes,

138
00:07:40.770 --> 00:07:43.854
it's easier to understand versus the TCP.

139
00:07:43.854 --> 00:07:46.745
Remember, in TCP,
both sides have to be connected,

140
00:07:46.745 --> 00:07:50.812
have to agree that they're gonna connect,
they have to be synchronized.

141
00:07:50.812 --> 00:07:54.103
One side's gonna send, one side gonna
receive, that's what has to happen.

142
00:07:54.103 --> 00:07:59.136
In this one, all Daniel has to say is,
give me, and I don't even have-

143
00:07:59.136 --> 00:08:00.224
>> Turn on the fire hose, Ronnie.

144
00:08:00.224 --> 00:08:04.036
>> I don't have to find who is there,
I don't even have to actually go sure,

145
00:08:04.036 --> 00:08:05.954
it's just like- here you go [LAUGH].

146
00:08:05.954 --> 00:08:10.525
That's it, it's not exactly
are hard them to understand.

147
00:08:10.525 --> 00:08:13.409
>> And even if the door's shut,
doesn't matter, here it comes anyway,

148
00:08:13.409 --> 00:08:15.007
it's gonna pile up on the welcome mat.

149
00:08:15.007 --> 00:08:19.145
>> Yeah, it's just there,
it just sends and sends and sends, and

150
00:08:19.145 --> 00:08:21.995
once you actually say gimme, it does that.

151
00:08:21.995 --> 00:08:26.904
It probably don't technically say gimme,
but you kinda get the idea, as soon as you

152
00:08:26.904 --> 00:08:31.971
request it, the response is there, so it's
much quicker, so why don't we use this?

153
00:08:31.971 --> 00:08:36.202
Because a lot of other things really
do require the idea of the reliability,

154
00:08:36.202 --> 00:08:38.051
as well as need the flow control,

155
00:08:38.051 --> 00:08:41.312
as well as need the ability to
put things back in sequence.

156
00:08:41.312 --> 00:08:45.721
If, so if you watch movies,
they talk about, especially in,

157
00:08:45.721 --> 00:08:48.730
I don't why I like legal dramas, but I do.

158
00:08:48.730 --> 00:08:50.774
They talk about this idea of,

159
00:08:50.774 --> 00:08:55.212
here's this one piece of information
that would really help the defense,

160
00:08:55.212 --> 00:08:59.449
let's send them everything, and
they send them a truckload of boxes.

161
00:08:59.449 --> 00:09:00.392
>> It's in there.

162
00:09:00.392 --> 00:09:04.805
>> It's in there, okay, well,
that's what would happen with UDP.

163
00:09:04.805 --> 00:09:11.007
The key is in there to how all this stuff
goes back together, but you figure it out.

164
00:09:11.007 --> 00:09:14.006
There's not even a key,
you're just getting it, and so

165
00:09:14.006 --> 00:09:15.515
that's where UDP comes in.

166
00:09:15.515 --> 00:09:18.695
So we can see why,
the way that Daniel described it,

167
00:09:18.695 --> 00:09:22.837
we can see why UDP flooding is kind
of the real big attack here [LAUGH].

168
00:09:22.837 --> 00:09:26.462
>> It's UDP is a little easy to do, you
just turn on the hose and let it happen.

169
00:09:26.462 --> 00:09:29.997
>> And that's pretty much it, so
these particular types of floods,

170
00:09:29.997 --> 00:09:33.162
you do that, and you might go,
all right, so how bad is it?

171
00:09:33.162 --> 00:09:36.280
It can be really bad if you
have enough of this, but

172
00:09:36.280 --> 00:09:40.003
do understand that UDP flooding
is pretty much the big one.

173
00:09:40.003 --> 00:09:44.173
Now are there a couple of other things
that I wanna point out, yes, okay?

174
00:09:44.173 --> 00:09:48.782
One, take a look at the source port here,
okay, on UDP especially,

175
00:09:48.782 --> 00:09:52.928
it doesn't mean that it always
has to happen this way, okay?

176
00:09:52.928 --> 00:09:57.672
But it really depends on the application
that you're using, usually,

177
00:09:57.672 --> 00:10:00.872
the source port is one of
those ephemeral ports.

178
00:10:00.872 --> 00:10:04.729
Hey, look,
a term I just brought up out of the blue,

179
00:10:04.729 --> 00:10:08.615
an ephemeral port,
make sure you understand that.

180
00:10:08.615 --> 00:10:11.506
Okay, so these source ports
should not be the dynamic ones,

181
00:10:11.506 --> 00:10:13.615
normally are not also
the well known ports.

182
00:10:13.615 --> 00:10:17.682
Can it be, yes, but
normally those are ephemeral ports,

183
00:10:17.682 --> 00:10:23.326
when we start talking about, so
anything above 1023 is what we're seeing.

184
00:10:23.326 --> 00:10:28.572
Also along with this, of course,
is that since you also have layer three,

185
00:10:28.572 --> 00:10:32.319
remember that this also goes
into part of that tuple,

186
00:10:32.319 --> 00:10:35.504
tuple, whatever we wanna call it, as well.

187
00:10:35.504 --> 00:10:38.941
You still need unique tuples
throughout this if you're also going to

188
00:10:38.941 --> 00:10:41.498
make sure that this ends
up working as well, okay?

189
00:10:41.498 --> 00:10:44.446
The other thing, of course,
is the way that ICMP works with this.

190
00:10:44.446 --> 00:10:50.345
You have a couple of things that can
tell you something is going right and

191
00:10:50.345 --> 00:10:51.535
going wrong.

192
00:10:51.535 --> 00:10:55.151
If your destination normally responds with

193
00:10:55.151 --> 00:10:59.945
a port unreachable message
to a non-listening UDP port.

194
00:10:59.945 --> 00:11:01.591
In other words,
if you get a port unreachable,

195
00:11:01.591 --> 00:11:03.168
and that's what we're expecting, right.

196
00:11:03.168 --> 00:11:05.934
The port's not on, we get a port
unreachable, something like that.

197
00:11:05.934 --> 00:11:09.254
That actually tells us something, but
what if you don't get that message?

198
00:11:09.254 --> 00:11:13.194
What if you do the regular thing
that you do, as far as a ping goes,

199
00:11:13.194 --> 00:11:16.575
and it's supposed to be a UDP
port that you ping, okay?

200
00:11:16.575 --> 00:11:20.580
And you don't get a port unreachable,
what does that tell you?

201
00:11:20.580 --> 00:11:23.780
We know that the port unreachable,
though, says what?

202
00:11:23.780 --> 00:11:27.906
It's closed, it's not open, but
what if you don't get that response?

203
00:11:27.906 --> 00:11:29.287
>> Maybe it's being firewalled.

204
00:11:29.287 --> 00:11:31.507
>> Firewalled, okay, or
it could just be open.

205
00:11:31.507 --> 00:11:34.193
>> Yeah, cuz it's not supposed
to respond if it's open, right?

206
00:11:34.193 --> 00:11:37.449
>> Yeah, it's not supposed to respond,
so the absence of the response,

207
00:11:37.449 --> 00:11:40.397
unlike what I would think,
I should get something coming back.

208
00:11:40.397 --> 00:11:42.561
No, it's the absence of
the response that says,

209
00:11:42.561 --> 00:11:46.131
you might not get anything back in that
way, depending on what you actually need.

210
00:11:46.131 --> 00:11:49.201
But it can be that false positive,
because of what you were talking about,

211
00:11:49.201 --> 00:11:49.845
the firewall.

212
00:11:49.845 --> 00:11:54.674
>> So just be aware of certain things
like that, too, so if you're an attacker,

00:11:54.674 --> 00:11:57.761

00:12:06.530 --> 00:12:09.240
not really, but

00:12:09.240 --> 00:12:12.565
Also, there is another one here, okay,

00:12:12.565 --> 00:12:16.563

219
00:12:16.563 --> 00:12:20.493
Theoretically, the length field here,
for one reason or another,

00:12:20.493 --> 00:12:24.083
the maximum length, 65,515,
I had to write that down,

221
00:12:24.083 --> 00:12:29.187

222
00:12:29.187 --> 00:12:34.641
But theoretically,
the maximum length here is 65,515,

00:12:34.641 --> 00:12:37.268
not that that matters so much.

00:12:37.268 --> 00:12:42.181
It's close enough to 65,536 that
it really doesn't matter, but

225
00:12:42.181 --> 00:12:45.413
if you start to get in
here in the 16 bit field.

226
00:12:45.413 --> 00:12:50.982
Okay, it should never be any
longer than 65,536 anyways, but

00:12:50.982 --> 00:12:56.853
what they're saying is it's longer
than 16 all the way through 35.

228
00:12:56.853 --> 00:12:58.775
It may also indicate a compromise,

00:12:58.775 --> 00:13:01.470
something else has happened here as well,

00:13:01.470 --> 00:13:07.572
Most applications that use UDP tend

231
00:13:07.572 --> 00:13:09.928
So this is not everybody, but

00:13:09.928 --> 00:13:15.687

00:13:15.687 --> 00:13:20.413

00:13:20.413 --> 00:13:25.073
10,000 then might be considered

00:13:25.073 --> 00:13:29.959

236
00:13:29.959 --> 00:13:35.967
So those are key information that we

237
00:13:35.967 --> 00:13:39.364
This is a little bit more

00:13:39.364 --> 00:13:43.588

there was actually a checksum for

239
00:13:43.588 --> 00:13:48.364

240
00:13:48.364 --> 00:13:51.539
Notice that in UDP,
it does it both, but at one time,

241
00:13:51.539 --> 00:13:53.669

242
00:13:53.669 --> 00:13:56.574
That's because it doesn't want to
slow down and do anything else.

243
00:13:56.574 --> 00:13:59.760
But this one we're not really
concerned about too much, but

244
00:13:59.760 --> 00:14:04.072
all the rest that we've just talked here,
all those are elements that we should be

And the idea of UDP vulnerabilities

00:17:42.958 --> 00:17:45.062

00:17:50.004 --> 00:17:50.671
But POST though,

00:17:50.671 --> 00:17:53.659

339
00:17:53.659 --> 00:17:58.393
So if you get a GET, that's perfectly fine

00:18:05.922 --> 00:18:08.464
Head works in the same way like GET but

00:18:08.464 --> 00:18:11.672

345
00:18:11.672 --> 00:18:15.911
Now, why in the world would I choose to do
that, when I could actually get whatever

00:18:15.911 --> 00:18:20.171
else I wanted back, cuz you're really

00:18:20.171 --> 00:18:24.676

348
00:18:24.676 --> 00:18:28.823

349
00:18:28.823 --> 00:18:33.617
The dangerous ones that we really have
to pay attention to is when we see

350
00:18:33.617 --> 00:18:36.637

00:18:36.637 --> 00:18:39.637
PUT because it's really
replacing something or

352
00:18:39.637 --> 00:18:42.277

353
00:18:42.277 --> 00:18:45.430
In only post you're not doing that.

354
00:18:45.430 --> 00:18:48.338
POST, you're kind of going hey, here's
the stuff and I'm sending it to you.

355
00:18:48.338 --> 00:18:50.157
You decide what to do with it.

356
00:18:50.157 --> 00:18:53.029
PUT though is actually changing
something over on the other end.

357
00:18:53.029 --> 00:18:56.132
DELETE is changing something
on the other end as well.

358
00:18:56.132 --> 00:18:59.938
So you wanna make sure that

00:18:59.938 --> 00:19:00.924
And we'll come back and

00:02:55.708 --> 00:03:00.131

that will be stored on your computer.

61
00:03:00.131 --> 00:03:04.291
Your browser will essentially

00:03:04.291 --> 00:03:10.829

I've been here before

So the cookie information the second time

00:03:33.803 --> 00:03:35.499

My machine over here, okay?

The same thing I just told you,

When it did that,

Now that I have it on my computer and

Well, if we didn't have the cookie

00:04:43.044 --> 00:04:46.890
it would probably ask me to log

But it actually keeps a cookie.

90
00:04:48.558 --> 00:04:51.414
So if I log in, it keeps a cookie

91
00:04:51.414 --> 00:04:53.773
So I don't have to log

92
00:04:53.773 --> 00:04:56.957
If I change another page,

It uses the cookie information to keep

that allows me to browse within that

So that's where cookies

The other thing that also happens,

So you may end up with what

They want to send information over to

So it is there for us in this lab.

But you kind of get this idea

Now remember that there are a lot

If you go to one of those sites and

There's plenty of blockers out

00:08:06.066 --> 00:08:07.488
your browser as an add on.

151
00:08:07.488 --> 00:08:10.596
But just be careful, and
you'll end up seeing that.

152
00:08:10.596 --> 00:08:14.528
That's another thing that can be
taken advantage of in the HTTP world,

153
00:08:14.528 --> 00:08:16.965
which is the idea of cookies as well,
okay?

154

Now, Zach, I mentioned that we're not
getting into this because we talked about

We talk about SQL or SQL attacks

164

And this is why it's important.

It's important because you have to be

capture, it also means something

So let's take a look at something

I want to give you a broad example of

25
00:01:17.589 --> 00:01:20.375
NetFlow is a very neat utility Zach.

26
00:01:20.375 --> 00:01:23.840
If we're not familiar with it, I was
trying to describe this to you a little

27
00:01:23.840 --> 00:01:26.436
bit earlier, so
let me describe it again, in this way.

28
00:01:26.436 --> 00:01:27.168

29
00:01:27.168 --> 00:01:32.691
>> So, Zach, if you and I ended up
getting invited to a party, okay?

30
00:01:32.691 --> 00:01:33.654
>> That'd be difficult.

31
00:01:33.654 --> 00:01:38.293
>> It would be difficult, but if we
were invited to a party together, and

32
00:01:38.293 --> 00:01:43.169
there were a 1,000 people there,
and we looked out across the room,

33
00:01:43.169 --> 00:01:48.144
and we noticed that there were two
people that were having a conversation.

34
00:01:48.144 --> 00:01:50.688
It'd be difficult for you and I or
even one of us to actually go,

35
00:01:50.688 --> 00:01:53.856
I wondering what they're talking about,
and actually be able to listen, and

36
00:01:53.856 --> 00:01:55.296
hear what they're talking about.

37
00:01:55.296 --> 00:01:55.911
>> Right.

38
00:01:55.911 --> 00:02:00.647
>> NetFlow though, gives us that ability
to actually zoom in, or to fill in, drill

39
00:02:00.647 --> 00:02:05.874
down, whatever the terminology you want to
use, and essentially filter out everything

40
00:02:05.874 --> 00:02:10.211
else, but what we really want to see
there, and be able to go, all right.

41
00:02:10.211 --> 00:02:14.879
I wanna see that traffic and that flow of
data between that sender, or that source,

42
00:02:14.879 --> 00:02:18.561
and that destination, and
pull the information that I want out.

43
00:02:18.561 --> 00:02:22.183
So, you might be wondering,
well, why is that valuable?

44
00:02:22.183 --> 00:02:26.872
It's valuable because so much data
goes across the wires in our network.

45
00:02:26.872 --> 00:02:29.501
>> Yeah
>> There's just a ton of data that goes

46
00:02:29.501 --> 00:02:32.063
across there, and it flows so quickly.

47
00:02:32.063 --> 00:02:35.493
So in something like Wireshark, when we
did a live capture in previous episodes,

48
00:02:35.493 --> 00:02:37.869
and Zach, you've seen a few of those-
>> Yeah, it was great.

49
00:02:37.869 --> 00:02:42.549
>> And even different shows, you see
that it just rolls by within 90 seconds,

50
00:02:42.549 --> 00:02:45.645
within maybe a minute, or
maybe even two minutes,

51
00:02:45.645 --> 00:02:48.835
we can get thousands of packets going by-
>> Lots of packets.

52
00:02:48.835 --> 00:02:52.597
>> And just finding the right
one is a challenge unto itself.

53
00:02:52.597 --> 00:02:57.231
So with NetFlow we can capture that
information, store it, or cache it,

54
00:02:57.231 --> 00:03:02.388
technically is the proper term, cache it,
and then we can go back and examine that

55
00:03:02.388 --> 00:03:07.518
particular traffic flow, and make it a
little bit easier for us to learn from it.

56
00:03:07.518 --> 00:03:08.681
>> Wow, that's great.

57
00:03:08.681 --> 00:03:11.712
>> So that is what net flow
essentially does for us.

58
00:03:11.712 --> 00:03:14.693
Now it is a valuable technology,
because learning

59
00:03:14.693 --> 00:03:18.922
about the network in that particular way,
with that much information,

60
00:03:18.922 --> 00:03:23.525
it essentially provides for us what we
call full visibility into our network.

61
00:03:23.525 --> 00:03:27.693
As long as we have NetFlow turned on
to those devices that are connecting

62
00:03:27.693 --> 00:03:32.279
everything else, then we can actually
have that information get captured and

63
00:03:32.279 --> 00:03:33.054
come about.

64
00:03:33.054 --> 00:03:34.777
Now, when I talk about visibility,

65
00:03:34.777 --> 00:03:37.733
a lot of times you might we
wondering what are we talking about.

66
00:03:37.733 --> 00:03:40.194
Well, it's application utilization.

67
00:03:40.194 --> 00:03:43.118
We can find out what applications
are running on a network.

68
00:03:43.118 --> 00:03:45.000
You go, okay, well, big deal there.

69
00:03:45.000 --> 00:03:49.101
But it's not only that, it's the flow,
it's the information that's flowing

70
00:03:49.101 --> 00:03:51.886
between that application and
something else as well.

71
00:03:51.886 --> 00:03:55.509
So you combine that together you can find
out a lot more information, whether or

72
00:03:55.509 --> 00:03:58.159
not that's high traffic, or
whether it's low traffic,

73
00:03:58.159 --> 00:04:01.100
or is that what you're expecting for
that application as well.

74
00:04:01.100 --> 00:04:04.051
The same thing with your
regular network utilization.

75
00:04:04.051 --> 00:04:06.479
You might have actually
set this up in saying,

76
00:04:06.479 --> 00:04:10.150
I think I'm only gonna have this much
amount of traffic on my network,

77
00:04:10.150 --> 00:04:13.514
and all of a sudden you find yourself
overwhelmed by the amount of

78
00:04:13.514 --> 00:04:17.590
traffic just connecting there, and
you're wondering what's happening.

79
00:04:17.590 --> 00:04:21.087
Well you can even find out that
in terms of network utilization,

80
00:04:21.087 --> 00:04:25.752
using NetFlow that helps you to know where
your experiencing some different issues in

81
00:04:25.752 --> 00:04:27.716
terms of the amount of data as well.

82
00:04:27.716 --> 00:04:29.464
Productivity on your network,

83
00:04:29.464 --> 00:04:33.034
you can find out areas that aren't
as productive as other areas.

84
00:04:33.034 --> 00:04:35.940
In other words, do you have devices
that are not configured correctly?

85
00:04:35.940 --> 00:04:40.495
It can kind of lead you when all of
a sudden, everything's avoiding the flow

86
00:04:40.495 --> 00:04:45.069
of data to that area that you're expecting
to see the data go through, too.

87
00:04:45.069 --> 00:04:46.614
You can also, of course,

88
00:04:46.614 --> 00:04:51.480
find out the impact that it makes when you
add in different additional equipment.

89
00:04:51.480 --> 00:04:55.900

that's the information

00:23:03.984 --> 00:23:07.956

The first thing we want

00:24:49.316 --> 00:24:52.473

00:25:10.242 --> 00:25:13.072

00:25:33.536 --> 00:25:38.993

00:25:38.993 --> 00:25:42.121

00:25:42.121 --> 00:25:45.364

00:25:50.031 --> 00:25:52.500

00:27:08.929 --> 00:27:11.491

475
00:27:11.491 --> 00:27:17.244
So that's where that flow record helps

00:27:17.244 --> 00:27:23.191

477
00:27:23.191 --> 00:27:27.435

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach interrupt common artifact elements from an event to identify an alert, identify key elements in an in intrusion from a given PCAP file, extract files from a TCP stream when given a PCAP file from Wireshark, and explain Wireshark>File>extract objects
episodes.title: Examine Intrusion Events

intrusion events with Ronnie Wong.

Of course, to learn what they need to or

00:01:11.710 --> 00:01:13.838

So what we've done is we kind of fast

So what we're taking a look at then,

SecurityOnion is a distribution that

It really does allow us to be able to

00:02:33.808 --> 00:02:37.640

And it's something that you can download

52

>> I was just gonna ask you that,

It's a great utility.

00:02:48.165 --> 00:02:50.046
It's something that we can learn on and

57
00:02:53.768 --> 00:02:57.283
So that's what we're also

58

I was hoping to show this, but

I downloaded a premade pcap file, okay?

A pcap file is essentially a packet

65
00:03:24.029 --> 00:03:25.515
We can open all that stuff up.

And it shows us the information

67

By using Tcpreplay, I ran it through

00:03:35.327 --> 00:03:40.768

the intrusion detection system,

69
00:03:40.768 --> 00:03:43.003
something like Sguil here.

So it's not just that I imported it in,

Now this is not something

00:04:02.493 --> 00:04:04.350

And so once I did that, I opened up Sguil.

It's weird, it's spelled a little bit

00:04:12.080 --> 00:04:12.997
S-G-U-I-L.

But according to their website

00:04:15.669 --> 00:04:17.627

82
00:04:17.627 --> 00:04:19.984
That's exactly how it's pronounced here.

83

And once I did that,
it generated all these different types of

84
00:04:24.746 --> 00:04:29.427

real time events that come across here.

00:04:29.427 --> 00:04:31.734
Okay, now it went through

00:04:31.734 --> 00:04:35.681
>> So
it's about 9,950 packets it went through.

And these are the ones that it pulled in

00:04:39.838 --> 00:04:40.701

Along with that,
this screen that we see, we can also see

So these rules, of course, are gonna be

00:04:56.305 --> 00:04:58.330
All that's actually in place for us.

00:04:58.330 --> 00:05:01.691
I was able to do the analysis on each one

00:05:01.691 --> 00:05:03.219
a little bit more information.

95
00:05:03.219 --> 00:05:05.541
Adn that's why this is a great utility.

00:05:05.541 --> 00:05:07.112
We don't have to pay a cent for it.

It all is pretty much in there and

So this time as we want to focus in on

This entire thing really

Don't get me wrong, okay?

>> It is.

>> But what is it that keys us in

This is where we go and

That's what we're really taking a look at.

And that kind of keys us in that

So for example, as I look here

Notice that on this one,

Now there's a return

The destination IP is now the source.

And then the source port over here.

So I know that that's pretty much part

Sweet Orange CDN Gate Method 2,

If you're asking that question about

You better take a look

So now we can zoom in on these

Here's the URI, HTTP URI,

Start seeing a bunch of little

Well, we can just simply select the third

So we're able to pull some of

Just the data and the rules that

So we can pull in,

And even the source identities and

00:08:16.350 --> 00:08:18.912
And then see how it actually

00:08:18.912 --> 00:08:23.580
Just when you and I think that we

Some of these columns if

it will give you some information and

Let me see if I can zoom in on that, and

Notice on Alert ID, I can use this tool

And I can even use Bro, which is another

So all this information that's

If I right-click on CNT here,

So notice this actually saying that
this particular line on this event

00:09:28.273 --> 00:09:29.281

EK stands for exploit kit, okay,

00:09:34.136 --> 00:09:39.050
I can see that 15 packets have

00:09:39.050 --> 00:09:41.695

00:09:41.695 --> 00:09:44.945
And if I right-click and

00:09:44.945 --> 00:09:47.412

00:09:47.412 --> 00:09:52.117
That are sent to here, and

00:09:56.614 --> 00:10:00.724
Source IP, Source Port,

PR actually does stand for

00:10:04.907 --> 00:10:08.216

185
00:10:08.216 --> 00:10:12.609
But when all those are identical
across all of these,

186
00:10:12.609 --> 00:10:15.248
this is one particular attack.

187
00:10:15.248 --> 00:10:18.104
So all of these particular events here,

188
00:10:18.104 --> 00:10:21.891
are all this one single
attack is what we're seeing.

189
00:10:21.891 --> 00:10:23.562
When we see something like that.

190
00:10:23.562 --> 00:10:26.548
So it does allow us to kind of see that.

191
00:10:26.548 --> 00:10:28.379
Let me go ahead and close this out for

00:10:28.379 --> 00:10:31.077
a moment as we get back to

00:10:31.077 --> 00:10:34.803
So just being able to identify

00:10:34.803 --> 00:10:38.186

00:10:38.186 --> 00:10:42.774
So if we continue to select on down here,
we can see a little bit more here,

00:10:42.774 --> 00:10:44.631

197
00:10:44.631 --> 00:10:49.699
So let's go ahead, and

00:10:49.699 --> 00:10:53.539
I'm going to select on the alert ID here,

00:10:53.539 --> 00:10:57.395

I can now start examining inside of the

Right at the beginning of course, we have

And on this get, it's somehow decided

00:11:23.920 --> 00:11:26.451
that we don't know what it's about.

00:11:26.451 --> 00:11:28.493
But it's gonna get that information.

So you continue to see the source

00:11:30.591 --> 00:11:34.778
It start announcing some of the other

And then some encrypted
data as we go on through-

00:11:37.493 --> 00:11:38.527

Then we could see another

Notice that this is giving a little bit

hey, I need to get more of this.

00:11:49.359 --> 00:11:50.634
What is that?

00:11:50.634 --> 00:11:51.621
Again, I don't know.

00:11:51.621 --> 00:11:53.354
I don't know exactly what it is.

But now, you can see the refer field,

00:11:55.596 --> 00:12:00.295
which if you're not exactly sure and
you're going, this sound foreign to me,

00:12:00.295 --> 00:12:03.962
make sure you go back and

00:12:03.962 --> 00:12:07.894
Tax that we were talking about and

And you'll notice on that the referral
field normally doesn't have
