00:27:37.760 --> 00:27:42.090
you can check out every single episode
of Cisco SECOPS in that series.

496
00:27:42.090 --> 00:27:43.540
And when you're there,

497
00:27:43.540 --> 00:27:47.640
take a look at all the hundreds of videos
that are available to help you go further.

498
00:27:47.640 --> 00:27:49.910
And tell all your friends about ITProTV.

499
00:27:49.910 --> 00:27:51.390
They'll be glad you did.

500
00:27:51.390 --> 00:27:52.830
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

501
00:27:52.830 --> 00:27:53.566
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

502
00:27:53.566 --> 00:27:55.165
>> And we'll see you again very soon.

503
00:27:55.165 --> 00:28:02.415
[MUSIC]

504
00:28:02.415 --> 00:28:08.067
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach conclude the discussion about intrusion event technologies, IDS/IP{S (Sguil), 5-Tuple information, Alert Data, Firewall (NGFW), Packet Capture, TOP Information, Network Application Control, Proxy Logs, Transaction Data, Extracted Data, and Identity & Access Management/Cisco ISE.
episodes.title: Intrusion Event Technologies Part 3
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.220 --> 00:00:01.400
Welcome to ITProTV.

2
00:00:01.400 --> 00:00:06.088
I'm your host Don Pezet coming at you
live from San Francisco, California.

3
00:00:06.088 --> 00:00:07.425
>> [CROSSTALK]

4
00:00:07.425 --> 00:00:08.467
[MUSIC]

5
00:00:08.467 --> 00:00:12.024
>> You're watching ITProTV.

6
00:00:12.024 --> 00:00:13.599
>> Hello again and thank you for

7
00:00:13.599 --> 00:00:17.220
choosing ITProTV helping you
learn everywhere you go.

8
00:00:17.220 --> 00:00:21.120
I'm your host, Zach Memos,
as we continue on with Cisco SecOps,

9
00:00:21.120 --> 00:00:25.580
as also continue on with intrusion
event technologies part three.

10
00:00:25.580 --> 00:00:28.040
Make sure you see part one and
part two, but this is part three.

11
00:00:28.040 --> 00:00:30.890
And Ronnie Wong has decided to
come on back here and help us out.

12
00:00:30.890 --> 00:00:32.400
Thanks for joining us, Ronnie.

13
00:00:32.400 --> 00:00:34.500
>> Thank you again for
having me back on the show, Zach,

14
00:00:34.500 --> 00:00:36.560
as we continue to take a look
at some of these different

15
00:00:37.750 --> 00:00:40.430
technologies that help us
to spot the intrusions.

16
00:00:40.430 --> 00:00:43.977
The great thing is we've already to talk
about some of them in depth a bit in

17
00:00:43.977 --> 00:00:45.330
earlier episodes.

18
00:00:45.330 --> 00:00:49.360
Now we're just going back and we're
taking a look as a reminder of what else

19
00:00:49.360 --> 00:00:52.750
we can see here and some of the different
technologies that are available.

20
00:00:52.750 --> 00:00:56.780
And we're back into
Cisco's Firepower Management Center

21
00:00:56.780 --> 00:01:00.780
to take a look at the utilities that
it really does gather together for us.

22
00:01:00.780 --> 00:01:04.890
Cisco Firepower Management Center and
FirePOWER is a neat technology, but

23
00:01:04.890 --> 00:01:07.400
it also is kind of a hubbed
technology as well.

24
00:01:07.400 --> 00:01:11.294
In which, multiple different
technologies can communicate and

25
00:01:11.294 --> 00:01:12.930
they can be used together.

26
00:01:12.930 --> 00:01:16.852
And then, of course, it means we can
also get information out of them that

27
00:01:16.852 --> 00:01:20.333
correlate, that allow us to
actually see that information, but

28
00:01:20.333 --> 00:01:23.120
from one particular location and place.

29
00:01:23.120 --> 00:01:25.680
So that is what we're also doing as well.

30
00:01:25.680 --> 00:01:31.030
So previously, in another episode, we did
talk about NetFlow a little bit earlier,

31
00:01:31.030 --> 00:01:35.230
and we even have an entire episode, or
actually two or three episodes on NetFlow.

32
00:01:35.230 --> 00:01:37.310
Make sure you check that out as well.

33
00:01:37.310 --> 00:01:40.770
And then now, we're actually going in and
we're taking a look at well a couple

34
00:01:40.770 --> 00:01:43.065
other technologies that
are available right here.

35
00:01:43.065 --> 00:01:46.830
But take some time, take a look at it and
that's what we are going to do.

36
00:01:46.830 --> 00:01:50.040
So we wanna move into the room
of firewalls here and

37
00:01:50.040 --> 00:01:51.840
talk about the idea of firewalls.

38
00:01:51.840 --> 00:01:54.630
Firewalls are kind of
unusual technology in

39
00:01:54.630 --> 00:01:58.900
the very fact that we don't tend to
replace them as often as we think, okay?

40
00:02:00.230 --> 00:02:02.510
So they tend to work like routers and
switches.

41
00:02:02.510 --> 00:02:07.140
They are in place, they tend to
work insanely efficiently well, and

42
00:02:07.140 --> 00:02:09.260
in that sense, they're very durable.

43
00:02:09.260 --> 00:02:11.838
They don't tend to be
the first thing that, ooh,

44
00:02:11.838 --> 00:02:14.520
we've got to replace that technology.

45
00:02:14.520 --> 00:02:16.450
We're not always working
with the latest and

46
00:02:16.450 --> 00:02:18.860
greatest equipment in terms of firewalls.

47
00:02:18.860 --> 00:02:21.670
We're working with what is standard and
what is true and

48
00:02:21.670 --> 00:02:24.410
what we actually feel like we're
comfortable with a lot of the times.

49
00:02:24.410 --> 00:02:26.840
And that's where we come in, okay?

50
00:02:26.840 --> 00:02:32.010
Well, in Cisco's world, the firewalls
that they had at the beginning,

51
00:02:32.010 --> 00:02:36.810
they bought a company called Pix and
Pix turned into the Cisco ASA.

52
00:02:36.810 --> 00:02:43.280
And now the Cisco ASA is beginning kind of
its journey into the kind of background.

53
00:02:43.280 --> 00:02:49.640
And that's because, well now you have
what we call Cisco's ASA with FirePOWER.

54
00:02:49.640 --> 00:02:53.800
And that is FirePOWER is in
itself is a threat containment or

55
00:02:53.800 --> 00:02:58.300
a threat management system that includes
in all these other advanced security tools

56
00:02:58.300 --> 00:03:01.510
and not just the ability
to do what a firewall does.

57
00:03:01.510 --> 00:03:06.780
So in today's firewalls, you may hear
the term next generation firewall.

58
00:03:06.780 --> 00:03:11.535
That's because it really is combining
in elements of an intrusion prevention

59
00:03:11.535 --> 00:03:16.074
system, intrusion detection system,
as well as the firewall capacities

60
00:03:16.074 --> 00:03:20.467
that are there to help us to be able to
stop as much of the intrusion as we can

61
00:03:20.467 --> 00:03:24.089
right at the perimeter of our network and
even before that.

62
00:03:24.089 --> 00:03:25.883
And we're also using
the thread intelligence and

63
00:03:25.883 --> 00:03:29.410
we're learning from the information that
we have out there on the Internet too.

64
00:03:29.410 --> 00:03:33.290
So this is why it's important
that we understand this.

65
00:03:33.290 --> 00:03:35.350
A lot of this is also going
to be managed through

66
00:03:35.350 --> 00:03:38.100
Cisco Firepower Management Console.

67
00:03:38.100 --> 00:03:41.665
So let's take a look here at what
we can normally end up seeing.

68
00:03:41.665 --> 00:03:44.545
So I pulled up the Connections and
the Events here as well and

69
00:03:44.545 --> 00:03:47.450
you can actually see it
in two different ways.

70
00:03:47.450 --> 00:03:50.960
The security intelligence events
as well as the events here.

71
00:03:50.960 --> 00:03:54.540
Security intelligence also
deals with the idea of

72
00:03:54.540 --> 00:03:57.570
understanding more about
the malware that's out there.

73
00:03:57.570 --> 00:03:58.320
So that's a part of it.

74
00:03:58.320 --> 00:04:03.170
But the events, this is where you start
seeing more of actions and reasons, and

75
00:04:03.170 --> 00:04:05.780
what type of data was actually
allowed through here.

76
00:04:05.780 --> 00:04:06.770
And that's what we're seeing.

77
00:04:06.770 --> 00:04:11.270
These are actual events that we're, oops,
I kinda went too far and too fast and

78
00:04:11.270 --> 00:04:13.500
kinda zoomed out of the scope there.

79
00:04:13.500 --> 00:04:15.275
But you're actually seeing all this.

80
00:04:15.275 --> 00:04:19.321
And you can see that there's actually,
well,

81
00:04:19.321 --> 00:04:24.900
7,516 different rows of data and
this is just the firewall.

82
00:04:24.900 --> 00:04:29.186
It's actually seeing every single one
of these pieces of traffic here and

83
00:04:29.186 --> 00:04:33.968
making a decision on whether to allow it
or to deny the traffic from going through.

84
00:04:33.968 --> 00:04:37.060
And that's pretty much
a firewall's perspective.

85
00:04:37.060 --> 00:04:41.978
You add Cisco's FirePOWER into this,
it now examines the data that's in it.

86
00:04:41.978 --> 00:04:44.261
It now examines files
that are coming across.

87
00:04:44.261 --> 00:04:47.525
And now, it actually takes a look
at all that information and

88
00:04:47.525 --> 00:04:51.980
tries to actually mitigate it if it's
actually in action at that point.

89
00:04:51.980 --> 00:04:55.900
So you can start to see this,
and you also, of course,

90
00:04:55.900 --> 00:04:58.800
if you had the old console.

91
00:04:58.800 --> 00:05:02.640
Now I don't have a connection to the old,
old console any more.

92
00:05:02.640 --> 00:05:04.590
They've actually
disconnected it from here.

93
00:05:04.590 --> 00:05:08.048
Let me see if I can get to this thing,
for a moment.

94
00:05:08.048 --> 00:05:12.620
But we all use to run
this guy which is called

95
00:05:12.620 --> 00:05:18.500
the Cisco ASDM to get us
access into our Cisco ASAs.

96
00:05:18.500 --> 00:05:23.830
This would launch a Java utility
that would give you the interface

97
00:05:23.830 --> 00:05:29.000
to configure your firewall to make it do
what you actually want it to do here.

98
00:05:29.000 --> 00:05:34.740
It actually did give you a little bit
of information to be able to do that.

99
00:05:34.740 --> 00:05:39.990
Today, because it's actually bound up
into the Firepower Management Center,

100
00:05:39.990 --> 00:05:42.460
I just access it through a web browser and

101
00:05:42.460 --> 00:05:47.390
it makes the connection then and now we
have a lot more detailed information.

102
00:05:47.390 --> 00:05:52.140
If I scroll across, notice that there's
actually even more information and

103
00:05:52.140 --> 00:05:56.370
that is how much more data
that Cisco Firepower,

104
00:05:56.370 --> 00:06:00.350
as well as all of the other elements,
have in place for this

105
00:06:01.670 --> 00:06:08.390
idea of what the actual firewall can
do as an intrusion prevention device.

106
00:06:08.390 --> 00:06:11.690
So not only are we looking
at the firewall itself,

107
00:06:11.690 --> 00:06:15.560
we're also looking at the idea of
the intrusion prevention device.

108
00:06:15.560 --> 00:06:20.360
So firewalls then do help us to
spot the session data as well.

109
00:06:20.360 --> 00:06:24.270
Network address translation
data if we need to.

110
00:06:24.270 --> 00:06:27.730
We can even take a look at capture files.

111
00:06:27.730 --> 00:06:32.410
There's a lot of times where if you go I
need to look at this in something like I

112
00:06:32.410 --> 00:06:36.650
can run Wireshark instead,
you can even create pcat files out of what

113
00:06:36.650 --> 00:06:41.460
you end up seeing here, and then you
can go into Wireshark and see this too.

114
00:06:41.460 --> 00:06:45.990
And then it also is partly the idea of
using the intrusion prevention system

115
00:06:45.990 --> 00:06:49.650
as well, which normally is based
on the same things, rules and

116
00:06:49.650 --> 00:06:52.180
alerts to help us to spot what's going on,
too.

117
00:06:52.180 --> 00:06:55.840
>> And, Ronnie, this will help you if
you have even more than one firewall?

118
00:06:55.840 --> 00:06:59.990
>> Yes, there's no doubt, it just
depends on how they're actually set up.

119
00:06:59.990 --> 00:07:01.630
But normally, there's a reason for

120
00:07:01.630 --> 00:07:04.780
you setting up multiple
firewalls into your network.

121
00:07:04.780 --> 00:07:07.835
And so, if there is,
then yes, it can do it.

122
00:07:07.835 --> 00:07:12.180
Cisco's Firepower Management Center
can do multiple firewalls as well.

123
00:07:12.180 --> 00:07:12.810
>> That's great.

124
00:07:12.810 --> 00:07:15.740
>> So
it's great in terms of how we can do this.

125
00:07:15.740 --> 00:07:16.430
Is it expensive?

126
00:07:16.430 --> 00:07:17.720
Yes, okay?

127
00:07:17.720 --> 00:07:19.420
>> You said that multiple times.

128
00:07:19.420 --> 00:07:23.170
>> Yeah, this is not a cheap
utility that's out there,

129
00:07:23.170 --> 00:07:27.090
but it is one if your network can
afford it and invest into it.

130
00:07:27.090 --> 00:07:31.310
It also means that you might take some
time to actually invest into the training

131
00:07:31.310 --> 00:07:33.250
on something like Cisco FirePOWER.

132
00:07:33.250 --> 00:07:36.880
And right here at ITProTV, we not
only have somebody that actually says

133
00:07:36.880 --> 00:07:41.320
I know FirePOWER, we actually had
Todd Lammle who's a world famous

134
00:07:41.320 --> 00:07:45.920
Cisco FirePOWER instructor
that does this stuff.

135
00:07:45.920 --> 00:07:49.775
And he came in and he did a show for
us on just learning about Cisco FirePOWER.

136
00:07:49.775 --> 00:07:50.680
>> And
that's in the course library isn't it?

137
00:07:50.680 --> 00:07:51.637
>> That is in our course library.

138
00:07:51.637 --> 00:07:52.220
>> Fantastic.

139
00:07:52.220 --> 00:07:56.000
>> So make sure you check out those
particular episode episodes too.

140
00:07:56.000 --> 00:07:57.860
And that will help you out as well.

141
00:07:57.860 --> 00:08:00.680
So it's a combination here is
what we're taking a look at.

142
00:08:00.680 --> 00:08:04.790
So it's more than just a regular firewall
that we would just see certain events.

143
00:08:04.790 --> 00:08:09.180
Now this idea of actually being that, it
is kind of a combination of a firewall and

144
00:08:09.180 --> 00:08:11.330
an intrusion prevention system as well.

145
00:08:11.330 --> 00:08:12.070
>> Wonderful.

146
00:08:12.070 --> 00:08:15.330
>> Along with this
particular technology then,

147
00:08:15.330 --> 00:08:19.420
it also then has to include
intrusion detection systems.

148
00:08:19.420 --> 00:08:23.492
So not only do we talk about the idea
of intrusion prevention, but

149
00:08:23.492 --> 00:08:27.573
we did kind of an entire show on
also intrusion detection as well.

150
00:08:27.573 --> 00:08:31.120
But we took a look at something,
this is not the right one, there it is,

151
00:08:31.120 --> 00:08:35.860
security is, I'm like why does that
not look like the security and login?

152
00:08:35.860 --> 00:08:39.020
And this particular product
here is called Squeal.

153
00:08:40.040 --> 00:08:45.140
Squeal is a nice intrusion detection
system, which shows us the information

154
00:08:45.140 --> 00:08:49.910
that we really are looking for
when we start making connections.

155
00:08:49.910 --> 00:08:53.600
So here's an example, we'll see,
it won't let me select both of these here.

156
00:08:53.600 --> 00:08:56.872
But let me zoom in on those two rows,
if I can.

157
00:08:56.872 --> 00:08:59.310
>> And Ronnie, Squeal is something
that you don't have to pay for.

158
00:08:59.310 --> 00:09:00.580
>> You don't have to pay for it.

159
00:09:00.580 --> 00:09:08.710
It is actually freely available to you as
an actual distribution on Security Onion.

160
00:09:08.710 --> 00:09:13.324
So you can actually take a look at
Security Onion, follow their instructions.

161
00:09:13.324 --> 00:09:17.172
If you are gonna download this and put it
into a virtual machine like I am using, or

162
00:09:17.172 --> 00:09:20.340
make sure you actually,
if you're gonna load it onto a computer,

163
00:09:20.340 --> 00:09:22.970
follow those instructions as well and
pay attention.

164
00:09:24.680 --> 00:09:28.292
Remember that what we are looking for
here is the 5-tuple information,

165
00:09:28.292 --> 00:09:30.922
and we can see this is actually
a pretty good example.

166
00:09:30.922 --> 00:09:35.620
As you start noticing the same port
numbers, and the same destination and

167
00:09:35.620 --> 00:09:38.140
port IP addresses, as well.

168
00:09:38.140 --> 00:09:39.610
And then even the protocol.

169
00:09:39.610 --> 00:09:41.438
This is protocol 6.

170
00:09:41.438 --> 00:09:45.330
That particular type of information
allows us to know that this is a single

171
00:09:45.330 --> 00:09:47.100
particular attack that we have.

172
00:09:47.100 --> 00:09:50.640
And this is an intrusion
that was detected here.

173
00:09:50.640 --> 00:09:55.100
And it actually allows us then to
coordinate this with other types of

174
00:09:55.100 --> 00:10:01.220
security monitoring systems that are also
out there and available with us as well.

175
00:10:01.220 --> 00:10:06.550
So being able to take a look
at this data is also key in

176
00:10:06.550 --> 00:10:11.090
understanding what your normally looking
for and just about everything, right?

177
00:10:11.090 --> 00:10:16.880
We've kind of emphasized IP
5-tuple information pretty

178
00:10:16.880 --> 00:10:21.730
much throughout just about every other
show, if not every show that I've done, or

179
00:10:21.730 --> 00:10:23.740
every episode that I've done for
this particular series.

180
00:10:23.740 --> 00:10:28.440
And that's because it is key to being able
to spot a lot of these different things

181
00:10:28.440 --> 00:10:31.460
when you start seeing
unchanging information.

182
00:10:31.460 --> 00:10:34.750
It normally is a sign that somebody
has actually manually manipulated

183
00:10:34.750 --> 00:10:35.350
something too.

184
00:10:36.570 --> 00:10:39.800
So those are kinda the big technologies

185
00:10:39.800 --> 00:10:42.840
as far as the intrusion
detection technologies.

186
00:10:42.840 --> 00:10:45.540
There's only one more that
we're going to mention here.

187
00:10:45.540 --> 00:10:46.670
And we're just going to mention it,

188
00:10:46.670 --> 00:10:51.800
which is the idea of what we call
network application control.

189
00:10:51.800 --> 00:10:56.530
And sometimes, you also hear the idea of
network access control, or identity and

190
00:10:56.530 --> 00:10:57.970
access management.

191
00:10:57.970 --> 00:11:01.570
So both of those terms kind of come
in when you start to hear that.

192
00:11:01.570 --> 00:11:05.170
So it depends on the way that
is actually interpreted.

193
00:11:05.170 --> 00:11:10.430
Network application control is
essentially preventing, applications

194
00:11:10.430 --> 00:11:15.050
that you don't want to be on your network
to actually not be on your network.

195
00:11:15.050 --> 00:11:18.827
And at that point it goes back to the kind
of fundamental rule that we've been

196
00:11:18.827 --> 00:11:19.662
talking about.

197
00:11:19.662 --> 00:11:23.547
So I don't have a network application
control technology to show you, but

198
00:11:23.547 --> 00:11:26.470
they are out there, and
they are available.

199
00:11:26.470 --> 00:11:29.110
But take a look, look for
those screenshots if you need to.

200
00:11:29.110 --> 00:11:31.970
>> So Ronnie,
would Cisco ISE be on the exam?

201
00:11:31.970 --> 00:11:35.280
>> Cisco ISE is actually the other
part that we're about to talk about.

202
00:11:35.280 --> 00:11:39.009
So yeah, this why I said
there's kind of two different-

203
00:11:39.009 --> 00:11:40.010
>> I just jumped the gun.

204
00:11:40.010 --> 00:11:44.203
And that's because this is
normally abbreviated as NAC, and

205
00:11:44.203 --> 00:11:46.790
network application control is one.

206
00:11:46.790 --> 00:11:50.296
And it was just me not filling
out the rest of my notes here and

207
00:11:50.296 --> 00:11:52.773
that is why Zach is asking about ISE here.

208
00:11:52.773 --> 00:11:57.890
Network application control is like
what I've just spoken about here.

209
00:11:57.890 --> 00:12:00.300
The very fact that you have application,
and

210
00:12:00.300 --> 00:12:02.312
there's certain applications that
you don't want on your note.

211
00:12:02.312 --> 00:12:08.290
For example, we all know something,
that today, running Adobe Flash,

212
00:12:08.290 --> 00:12:15.120
as great as a display that it gives you,
it is a completely vulnerable application.

213
00:12:15.120 --> 00:12:18.290
Running anything with
Java in the background,

214
00:12:18.290 --> 00:12:20.910
it is a completely vulnerable application.

It just depends on how-

00:05:12.234 --> 00:05:16.202
Which knocks you out,

00:05:16.202 --> 00:05:17.602
It's not the same thing.

00:05:17.602 --> 00:05:21.249
It is not what we have to think about.

00:05:21.249 --> 00:05:25.450
So, we know that in a boxing match,
somebody is going to get usually

00:05:28.785 --> 00:05:32.660
Well, if we assume then from our
standpoint of network security and

down a little bit more, and

331
00:17:47.899 --> 00:17:52.940
let's talk about this idea
of the negatives here, okay?

332
00:17:52.940 --> 00:17:58.232
Now, a true-negative is another
thing that we really do value, okay?

333
00:17:58.232 --> 00:18:02.690
We value this fact, that it's true and
that we actually don't have something.

334
00:18:02.690 --> 00:18:06.653
So in this sense,
we might not get an alert that says, okay,

335
00:18:06.653 --> 00:18:11.967
everything is good, but the very fact is
it's not really making us do anything.

336
00:18:11.967 --> 00:18:15.166
So we might actually say, hey, here's all
the regular traffic that's coming through,

337
00:18:15.166 --> 00:18:18.251
and that's actually being filtered out in
this way, or it's matching this traffic.

338
00:18:18.251 --> 00:18:23.055
But it's not the harmful traffic that
we want to, so it does help us out.

339
00:18:23.055 --> 00:18:25.923
Most of us that are brand new to this,
in terms of networking,

340
00:18:25.923 --> 00:18:28.955
we don't normally see a lot of this,
as far of a marker that says,

341
00:18:28.955 --> 00:18:32.790
this is a true-negative, this is
a true-negative, this is a true-negative.

342
00:18:32.790 --> 00:18:37.195
But for those of you that are just
finishing your CCNA Routing and

343
00:18:37.195 --> 00:18:41.111
Switching, or
you've just gone through your CCT exam,

344
00:18:41.111 --> 00:18:44.554
and you're now working with a router and
switch.

345
00:18:44.554 --> 00:18:49.527
If you work with access control lists,
okay, at the end of that, right,

346
00:18:49.527 --> 00:18:51.704
there's an implicit deny all.

347
00:18:51.704 --> 00:18:55.043
In other words, it's designed to
actually go deny all the traffic, okay,

348
00:18:55.043 --> 00:18:56.359
that actually goes through.

349
00:18:56.359 --> 00:18:59.202
That's the very last rule in that list,
okay?

350
00:18:59.202 --> 00:19:00.257
Well, how do you know if something
actually is getting denied or not?

351
00:19:00.257 --> 00:19:05.572
Well, it doesn't tell you.

352
00:19:05.572 --> 00:19:08.473
You can actually do this,
show output that you need to,

353
00:19:08.473 --> 00:19:10.833
to show you what it
actually says I'm doing.

354
00:19:10.833 --> 00:19:13.722
But it's not gonna show you
that it's denying everything.

355
00:19:13.722 --> 00:19:17.812
So in that sense,
it could be a true-negative as well.

356
00:19:17.812 --> 00:19:18.946
It actually is working, and
is actually denying those things as well.

357
00:19:18.946 --> 00:19:23.638
So nothing is actually really happening,
but

358
00:19:23.638 --> 00:19:26.775
is the rule actually working?

359
00:19:26.775 --> 00:19:27.710
So that's what you're testing for.

360
00:19:27.710 --> 00:19:32.347
Well, the way that you can change that,
and especially in that access control

361
00:19:32.347 --> 00:19:35.874
list, is that you just add in
the word log at the end of that.

362
00:19:35.874 --> 00:19:40.365
So instead of making an implicit denial,
you type it out,

363
00:19:40.365 --> 00:19:46.611
the access control rule that you need, and
then you add in the word log at the end.

364
00:19:46.611 --> 00:19:50.902
And then when you run it again, it will
then display for you the number of packets

365
00:19:50.902 --> 00:19:55.258
or the number of bytes, whatever it is,
I can't remember off the top of my head,

366
00:19:55.258 --> 00:19:59.702
that has gone through and has hit that
particular rule and it's denied access in.

367
00:19:59.702 --> 00:20:04.057
So even though you don't tend to see a lot
of it, is it still working against a rule?

368
00:20:04.057 --> 00:20:08.001
Probably, okay, and is it actually
working the way that I want it to?

369
00:20:08.001 --> 00:20:10.795
Yes, so sometimes you do need to see that,
and if you do,

370
00:20:10.795 --> 00:20:12.618
a lot of times, you can turn that on.

371
00:20:12.618 --> 00:20:16.313
But most of time,
we don't need to see that much data, so

372
00:20:16.313 --> 00:20:18.394
we tend not to turn it on as well.

373
00:20:18.394 --> 00:20:22.089
So both of these on this side,
okay, the true-positive and

374
00:20:22.089 --> 00:20:26.221
the true-negatives, this is what
we hope for everything inside of

375
00:20:26.221 --> 00:20:30.510
our intrusion detection systems to
really be able to point out for us.

376
00:20:30.510 --> 00:20:34.817
Okay, on the other side, we really don't
want anything, but we still get them.

377
00:20:34.817 --> 00:20:38.213
So the reality is that not everything
is gonna be set up perfectly.

378
00:20:38.213 --> 00:20:42.314
Now, I left this one for
last here, the false-negative,

379
00:20:42.314 --> 00:20:47.243
because this one is the one that's
a little bit more worrisome, okay?

380
00:20:47.243 --> 00:20:50.853
So Zach, let's see if we can
kind of figure this one out, so

381
00:20:50.853 --> 00:20:55.637
even if we don't have a lot of networking
knowledge in our background, okay?

382
00:20:55.637 --> 00:21:00.867
So what I'm telling you is that
an intrusion may not have happened,

383
00:21:00.867 --> 00:21:06.766
okay, and it says that here, on the rule,
it didn't actually match here.

384
00:21:06.766 --> 00:21:13.306
Okay, so in this sense, why would this
be something that we worry about, okay?

385
00:21:13.306 --> 00:21:16.376
Well, this is the one that
says I can't detect it, okay?

386
00:21:16.376 --> 00:21:19.009
So in other words, I can't tell
you if this is a negative or not.

387
00:21:19.009 --> 00:21:22.393
So in that sense,
it's actually stealthy in this way,

388
00:21:22.393 --> 00:21:27.365
where it's not matching anything, and
it's not matching anything that at all.

389
00:21:27.365 --> 00:21:29.632
We don't know what actually it could be.

390
00:21:29.632 --> 00:21:33.348
So that's where that false-negative
really is kind of harmful for

391
00:21:33.348 --> 00:21:34.921
what we want to be able to do.

392
00:21:34.921 --> 00:21:35.951
>> I think it would be.

393
00:21:35.951 --> 00:21:40.416
>> It really would, so
no rule is present, but

394
00:21:40.416 --> 00:21:45.488
we can actually think about
the idea here that what

395
00:21:45.488 --> 00:21:50.790
could end up happening
on the false-negative.

396
00:21:50.790 --> 00:21:54.105
I did twist that around a little bit,
didn't I?

397
00:21:54.105 --> 00:22:01.557
This one should be up here where
I am working that out, yeah.

398
00:22:01.557 --> 00:22:03.478
So the false-negative, no, that's right,

399
00:22:03.478 --> 00:22:05.359
I just wanna make sure
I'm telling you right.

400
00:22:05.359 --> 00:22:08.545
No rule is matched, but
then this one, though,

401
00:22:08.545 --> 00:22:12.370
is actually even telling you
that the intrusion is false.

402
00:22:12.370 --> 00:22:14.358
Now, the reality of this, right,

403
00:22:14.358 --> 00:22:17.754
is that we don't know if
an intrusion is really false or not.

404
00:22:17.754 --> 00:22:18.311
>> Mm hm.

405
00:22:18.311 --> 00:22:22.398
>> So it could be still that idea
that it is actually not happening, or

406
00:22:22.398 --> 00:22:25.980
it is happening as well, so
this one we may not know at all.

407
00:22:25.980 --> 00:22:28.702
Now, you might go, well,
why is it still doing that?

408
00:22:28.702 --> 00:22:31.818
And it's because nothing is tuned
the way that it needs to be, so

409
00:22:31.818 --> 00:22:34.262
that's why we want to be
careful on these as well.

410
00:22:34.262 --> 00:22:37.436
Okay, this one could be
the worst one as well.

411
00:22:37.436 --> 00:22:41.949
The very fact that we could have something
that says, hey, it's not actually going

412
00:22:41.949 --> 00:22:46.226
on, but the rule actually isn't catching
it and something is really going on.

413
00:22:46.226 --> 00:22:48.282
That's when we have an issue, okay, so

414
00:22:48.282 --> 00:22:51.800
that's why we want to make sure that
we pay attention to those, too.

415
00:22:51.800 --> 00:22:55.167
So it's not every time that an actual
intrusion does end up happening, but

416
00:22:55.167 --> 00:22:58.172
there are times when it does happen,
and when it doesn't happen.

417
00:22:58.172 --> 00:23:00.893
But we need to know what's
going through that device.

418
00:23:00.893 --> 00:23:04.400
So our intrusion detection systems,
how do we overcome this?

419
00:23:04.400 --> 00:23:08.057
Well, we overcome it by what we
call doing some tuning to the way

420
00:23:08.057 --> 00:23:09.587
that the rules are set up.

421
00:23:09.587 --> 00:23:13.350
So this is where you do have to
do a couple of different things.

422
00:23:13.350 --> 00:23:17.315
Make sure that if you're using,
of course, the intrusion detection system

423
00:23:17.315 --> 00:23:21.169
updates that are out there for your
system, make sure those are up to date.

424
00:23:21.169 --> 00:23:24.978
But if you have the ability to
turn on what we call heuristics,

425
00:23:24.978 --> 00:23:26.308
it will also happen.

426
00:23:26.308 --> 00:23:31.252
Heuristics, of course, it actually comes
from the Greek word eureka, which means

427
00:23:31.252 --> 00:23:36.006
I found it, and this means that it is a
system that actually learns what they are.

428
00:23:36.006 --> 00:23:39.985
It takes a long time to be able to get
this to the place that it needs to, but

429
00:23:39.985 --> 00:23:42.286
this is the most effective way to do this.

430
00:23:42.286 --> 00:23:46.085
But at the same time, you're gonna get
more false-positives then, and you may,

431
00:23:46.085 --> 00:23:49.140
of course, even get false-negatives
that come through as well.

432
00:23:49.140 --> 00:23:54.044
But once that system of learning is over,
the false-positives will end up reducing,

433
00:23:54.044 --> 00:23:57.078
and the false-negatives
will end up reducing down.

434
00:23:57.078 --> 00:24:01.674
To where you'll hit more of the true
positives and the true negatives,

435
00:24:01.674 --> 00:24:05.129
is what we want to be able to
understand and do as well.

436
00:24:05.129 --> 00:24:07.962
So just be aware that as
far as the impact goes,

437
00:24:07.962 --> 00:24:11.242
you'll have these things
that will end up matching.

438
00:24:11.242 --> 00:24:15.053
And that's something that we really want
to make sure that we understand here.

439
00:24:15.053 --> 00:24:18.106
So when we do have the matches
that end up going on and

440
00:24:18.106 --> 00:24:23.005
everything else is happening here, we've
got to be aware of that type of impact,

441
00:24:23.005 --> 00:24:25.361
and contrast and compare them as well.

442
00:24:25.361 --> 00:24:29.343
Because that's gonna be helpful when
understanding what has to be done.

443
00:24:29.343 --> 00:24:34.497
Everybody always believes, especially as
a beginner, that we buy these systems,

444
00:24:34.497 --> 00:24:37.992
we turn it on, and it just works,
the majority of it may.

445
00:24:37.992 --> 00:24:42.626
But if you do find yourself where there's
a ton of false positives coming back in,

446
00:24:42.626 --> 00:24:46.521
it probably means that the system
needs to be tuned a little bit better

447
00:24:46.521 --> 00:24:50.957
to actually match the patterns that your
network traffic is gonna generate and

448
00:24:50.957 --> 00:24:52.737
do what we need it to do as well.

449
00:24:52.737 --> 00:24:56.878
Now once we actually have
this information down, Zach,

450
00:24:56.878 --> 00:25:02.068
once we get everything here down,
I'm like okay, so what do I do next?

451
00:25:02.068 --> 00:25:04.046
Well this is where that
tuning comes in and

452
00:25:04.046 --> 00:25:06.882
we're not getting into the aspects
of setting that all up.

453
00:25:06.882 --> 00:25:11.186
But we do want to show you where you
do see this type of information coming

454
00:25:11.186 --> 00:25:15.224
across and even how that actually
gets evaluated that way as well.

455
00:25:15.224 --> 00:25:17.187
And we'll actually do that and

456
00:25:17.187 --> 00:25:22.323
we'll use Cisco's Firepower Management
Center to help us to be able to show that

457
00:25:22.323 --> 00:25:27.252
the way that they register impacts that
are happening on their networks too.

458
00:25:27.252 --> 00:25:29.054
Now just when I say something like that,
and

459
00:25:29.054 --> 00:25:30.964
I'd love to get into it
to show you right away.

460
00:25:30.964 --> 00:25:36.201
But I realize that we are coming close
on the time limit for this episode Zach.

461
00:25:36.201 --> 00:25:38.279
So it looks like we'll have to
pick up then in part two here.

462
00:25:38.279 --> 00:25:41.128
>> That's okay,
taking step by step is the best way to go.

463
00:25:41.128 --> 00:25:43.908
Intrusion Impact Analysis part one,
there will be a part two.

464
00:25:43.908 --> 00:25:46.158
Before we move on, though,
I had a question for you,

465
00:25:46.158 --> 00:25:48.011
you mentioned heuristics, is that right?

466
00:25:48.011 --> 00:25:50.284
>> Yep.
>> So where do we find that?

467
00:25:50.284 --> 00:25:53.730
>> Yeah, in terms of heuristics,
there's actually different features inside

468
00:25:53.730 --> 00:25:57.346
of those intrusion detection systems,
and they're designed to do heuristics.

469
00:25:57.346 --> 00:26:00.311
That means that they can
actually learn your system and

470
00:26:00.311 --> 00:26:03.416
the patterns of behavior that
will allow them to do that.

471
00:26:03.416 --> 00:26:06.589
So, in other words,
it is set up as being a learning process.

472
00:26:06.589 --> 00:26:08.598
And they'll start sampling your data,

473
00:26:08.598 --> 00:26:11.921
which will actually include those
false positives a lot of times.

474
00:26:11.921 --> 00:26:15.044
They'll get more of them at the beginning,
but once they start learning that

475
00:26:15.044 --> 00:26:17.512
pattern and you start marking,
these are false positives.

476
00:26:17.512 --> 00:26:20.613
After a while they will go all right,
I figured that one out, and

477
00:26:20.613 --> 00:26:22.350
will start eliminating that down.

478
00:26:22.350 --> 00:26:25.748
So different systems will give you
different levels to be able to do that.

479
00:26:25.748 --> 00:26:30.185
But just realize if you're going to set up
heuristics, it takes longer in times of

480
00:26:30.185 --> 00:26:33.226
the true ramp up to the production
that you want it to do.

481
00:26:33.226 --> 00:26:36.156
So don't expect it to go overnight,
we're done,

482
00:26:36.156 --> 00:26:40.741
it takes a little bit more monitoring,
it takes a little bit more time to set up.

483
00:26:40.741 --> 00:26:43.577
And you've got to pay attention to
everything that comes across there.

484
00:26:43.577 --> 00:26:46.450
And you want a better system at
giving you, as close as possible,

485
00:26:46.450 --> 00:26:48.657
to you true negatives and
to your true positives.

486
00:26:48.657 --> 00:26:52.215
>> Which we're going to delve into in
intrusion impact analysis part two,

487
00:26:52.215 --> 00:26:54.564
great information Ronnie,
thanks very much.

488
00:26:54.564 --> 00:26:57.147
And why don't you check
out our course library so

489
00:26:57.147 --> 00:26:59.796
you can see every single
episode of Cisco SECOPS.

490
00:26:59.796 --> 00:27:01.453
I mean, you'll be glad you did, and

491
00:27:01.453 --> 00:27:04.835
also there's hundreds of other videos
in there too to help you go further.

492
00:27:04.835 --> 00:27:09.101
And by the way, tell a friend about
ITProTV, they'll be glad you did.

493
00:27:09.101 --> 00:27:10.648
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

494
00:27:10.648 --> 00:27:11.479
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

495
00:27:11.479 --> 00:27:12.701
>> And we'll see you again soon.

496
00:27:12.701 --> 00:27:20.034
[MUSIC]

497
00:27:20.034 --> 00:27:22.607
>> Thank you for watching ITPRO.TV.

episodes.description: Ronnie and Zach continue discussing Intrusion Impact Analysis, interpret a provided intrusion event & host profile to calculate the Impact Flag generated by FMC, explain what Firepower Management Center (FMC) is, and conclude with an FMC demo.
episodes.title: Intrusion Impact Analysis Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss incidence response plans. They describe what they are and the elements that hsould be included in them according to NIST.SP800-61 r2
episodes.title: Incident Response Elements
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:06.507
You're watching ITProTV,
I'm your host, [CROSSTALK]

2
00:00:06.507 --> 00:00:07.451
[MUSIC]

3
00:00:07.451 --> 00:00:10.963
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:10.963 --> 00:00:13.799
>> Hello and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

5
00:00:13.799 --> 00:00:16.169
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.169 --> 00:00:21.623
I'm your host, Zach Memos, and this is
CCNA SECOPS, with me is Ronnie Wong.

7
00:00:21.623 --> 00:00:25.040
And we're gonna be plumbing the depths
of incidence response elements,

8
00:00:25.040 --> 00:00:26.455
aren't we, Ronnie?

9
00:00:26.455 --> 00:00:27.575
>> We really are, Zach.

10
00:00:27.575 --> 00:00:29.305
Thank you, again, for
having me on the show as we-

11
00:00:29.305 --> 00:00:30.100
>> Thank you.

12
00:00:30.100 --> 00:00:32.914
>> Continue on, and
we take a look, of course,

13
00:00:32.914 --> 00:00:35.295
at now the idea of incident response.

14
00:00:35.295 --> 00:00:40.209
And this is kind of a larger field of
things than what we're probably used to

15
00:00:40.209 --> 00:00:41.224
dealing with.

16
00:00:41.224 --> 00:00:43.900
In security, we think about details a lot.

17
00:00:43.900 --> 00:00:48.894
And we think about of course a lot of
the actual technical challenges to

18
00:00:48.894 --> 00:00:52.463
what needs to be done, so
that we are more secure.

19
00:00:52.463 --> 00:00:55.681
But now when we move into
the idea of incident response,

20
00:00:55.681 --> 00:00:59.797
notice that it's not that we don't
have technical details involved.

21
00:00:59.797 --> 00:01:05.000
But this is more of our response, or
our response, I should say properly.

22
00:01:05.000 --> 00:01:07.900
And that means that it actually
involves a human element,

23
00:01:07.900 --> 00:01:12.060
in terms of managing what happens
when an incident actually comes up.

24
00:01:12.060 --> 00:01:14.965
>> And Ronnie,
this is in the NIST SP 800-61 plan,

25
00:01:14.965 --> 00:01:18.707
incident response plan, is what
we're going to be looking at right?

26
00:01:18.707 --> 00:01:22.142
>> Right, and we're actually gonna
get some guidance when we start

27
00:01:22.142 --> 00:01:26.078
talking about this idea of incident
response, right, from, of course,

28
00:01:26.078 --> 00:01:28.395
the special publications in terms of NIST.

29
00:01:28.395 --> 00:01:32.327
And this is important, that we
understand what's happening here, and

30
00:01:32.327 --> 00:01:35.044
why we're actually using
this guidance as well.

31
00:01:35.044 --> 00:01:38.832
Because learning about the technical
details and what I was referring to just

32
00:01:38.832 --> 00:01:41.637
a little bit earlier,
we can get all that set up, right?

33
00:01:41.637 --> 00:01:45.568
We can take classes or
we can watch shows right here in ITProTV,

34
00:01:45.568 --> 00:01:48.546
we can understand
the technology a lot better.

35
00:01:48.546 --> 00:01:52.062
But what about actually
developing teams that help

36
00:01:52.062 --> 00:01:56.200
you to respond with a security
incident does happen?

37
00:01:56.200 --> 00:01:59.986
Well, that's not exactly outside
of the scope of what we can do.

38
00:01:59.986 --> 00:02:03.675
But most of us may not have experience,
especially even at the associate level,

39
00:02:03.675 --> 00:02:04.986
in which we're looking at.

40
00:02:04.986 --> 00:02:08.693
In other words, like an entry-level
person going into cybersecurity.

41
00:02:08.693 --> 00:02:12.551
To understand what it is that
actually has to come together for

42
00:02:12.551 --> 00:02:16.794
those teams to do what they need to,
and even have some type of plan.

43
00:02:16.794 --> 00:02:20.392
So the great thing is we can turn to,
well, the idea is here is NIST,

44
00:02:20.392 --> 00:02:23.551
right, National Institute of Standards and
Technology,

45
00:02:23.551 --> 00:02:26.080
this is where we're
going to find guidance.

46
00:02:26.080 --> 00:02:28.440
Let's go ahead and
take a look at my computer screen, and

47
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:31.313
this will help us out as we go through,

So when you start seeing that,

494
00:27:21.430 --> 00:27:24.230
you might be going,
how the heck do I figure that out?

495
00:27:24.230 --> 00:27:28.200
Well, let me go back over here, and
now I wanna show you something.

496
00:27:28.200 --> 00:27:30.420
And this is from reading the document,
right?

497
00:27:30.420 --> 00:27:33.950
Okay, so this is not from anything else,
it's from reading the document.

498
00:27:33.950 --> 00:27:35.016
>> Read the document.

499
00:27:35.016 --> 00:27:36.180
Very important.
>> Read the document, yep.

500
00:27:36.180 --> 00:27:38.350
It actually does help you out, okay?

501
00:27:38.350 --> 00:27:42.050
So now once you have this,
let me see if I can highlight this.

502
00:27:42.050 --> 00:27:43.544
Just a moment here, Zach.

503
00:27:43.544 --> 00:27:44.044
>> Okay.

504
00:27:45.210 --> 00:27:46.440
Of course it's not highlighting.

505
00:27:46.440 --> 00:27:47.320
Why would it highlight?

506
00:27:47.320 --> 00:27:48.097
So there we go.

507
00:27:48.097 --> 00:27:49.040
>> That would be too easy!

508
00:27:49.040 --> 00:27:53.023
>> That would be silly, and easy to do.

509
00:27:54.718 --> 00:27:57.100
So now, [INAUDIBLE] it's not gonna do it.

510
00:27:57.100 --> 00:27:58.898
Follow the arrow, is what we're gonna do.

511
00:27:58.898 --> 00:28:01.110
>> [LAUGH]
>> So let me see if I can zoom in here.

512
00:28:01.110 --> 00:28:06.281
The organization's mission, strategies,
and goals for incident response

513
00:28:06.281 --> 00:28:11.616
should help in determining the structure
of the incident response capability.

514
00:28:11.616 --> 00:28:16.026
Well, you can kind of see I was
able to come up with question

515
00:28:16.026 --> 00:28:19.448
directly from reading the document itself.

516
00:28:19.448 --> 00:28:21.857
Okay, so it's not that, ooh, dang,

517
00:28:21.857 --> 00:28:26.614
Ronnie kind of just threw these one out
there and he pulled that out of the air.

518
00:28:26.614 --> 00:28:28.120
It's not that, right.

519
00:28:28.120 --> 00:28:32.150
It's from within the document itself
that you will find questions like this

520
00:28:32.150 --> 00:28:34.850
that tend to, and answer,
that's what it's actually doing.

521
00:28:34.850 --> 00:28:35.660
It's answering.

522
00:28:35.660 --> 00:28:39.490
It's saying, you have a whole
list of these elements over here.

523
00:28:39.490 --> 00:28:42.405
Well, which two helped you determined
the structure at this point?

524
00:28:42.405 --> 00:28:46.580
Well, I went back over here and I found
the answer in the very next paragraph

525
00:28:46.580 --> 00:28:50.280
where it says mission,
strategies, and goals.

526
00:28:50.280 --> 00:28:55.847
Help me to determine the structure of
the organization's IR capabilities.

527
00:28:55.847 --> 00:28:58.320
>> If you were gonna ask me, the first
one I was gonna choose is mission.

528
00:28:58.320 --> 00:28:59.230
>> Yep.
No that would.

529
00:28:59.230 --> 00:29:03.780
Yeah, it's kind of interesting when we
start seeing the elements like this, okay?

530
00:29:03.780 --> 00:29:08.580
So when you start to take a look at
this document, don't just go around,

531
00:29:08.580 --> 00:29:11.580
Ronnie just said,
look at this portion here.

532
00:29:11.580 --> 00:29:15.600
It's not just looking at a portion,
it is showing you that there is a lot more

533
00:29:15.600 --> 00:29:18.320
that's actually right there
that can help you out.

534
00:29:18.320 --> 00:29:22.750
And on this exam, especially,
okay, you're not gonna get away

535
00:29:22.750 --> 00:29:26.962
without you reading through this
document and understanding it.

536
00:29:26.962 --> 00:29:29.820
It's gonna take you through it probably
a couple of times, believe it or

537
00:29:29.820 --> 00:29:34.550
not, in the way that we take a look at
the exam objectives that are laid out.

538
00:29:34.550 --> 00:29:38.400
There's no other way for you to do this
besides you knowing this document.

539
00:29:38.400 --> 00:29:41.873
So I wish I could tell you, here's
the simple things you've got to know, and

540
00:29:41.873 --> 00:29:44.451
there you go,
you don't have to worry about it anymore.

541
00:29:44.451 --> 00:29:45.847
It's not gonna be like that.

542
00:29:45.847 --> 00:29:49.405
For the exam you're gonna see probably
more questions than you think.

543
00:29:49.405 --> 00:29:52.783
Especially on something like this and
don't put it past them to do just

544
00:29:52.783 --> 00:29:56.059
something like what I showed you
right there, very easily as well.

545
00:29:56.059 --> 00:29:59.141
Now, Zach, there is,
I know this whole show.

546
00:29:59.141 --> 00:30:00.106
>> Just touched the surface.

547
00:30:00.106 --> 00:30:02.868
>> Yeah,
this whole show that we've done so far,

548
00:30:02.868 --> 00:30:06.683
we really only covered one of
those particular exam objectives.

549
00:30:06.683 --> 00:30:09.000
And there's actually
a couple of them to go.

550
00:30:09.000 --> 00:30:11.539
So, Zach, we may actually
have to head into a part two,

551
00:30:11.539 --> 00:30:14.202
cuz I notice that we're actually
running low on time now.

552
00:30:14.202 --> 00:30:17.165
>> And that's okay,
cuz you're doing a marvelous job, Ronnie.

553
00:30:17.165 --> 00:30:19.862
And it's very procedural, so
we have to take it step by step.

554
00:30:19.862 --> 00:30:22.086
Incident response elements part two,
coming up.

555
00:30:22.086 --> 00:30:23.361
You've seen part one.

556
00:30:23.361 --> 00:30:24.518
And of course,

557
00:30:24.518 --> 00:30:29.592
there is a whole bunch of videos you

558
00:30:29.592 --> 00:30:31.010
Make sure you watch every one of them.

And in fact, visit our course library.

There's hundreds of videos

00:30:36.061 --> 00:30:38.247
And tell everybody you

They'll be glad you did.

563
00:30:39.471 --> 00:30:40.229
Thanks for watching.

564

I'm Zach Memis.

[MUSIC]

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie discuss incident response plans. They link those elements discussed previously to the analysis steps in SP 800-61 r2 and identify the stake holders that also belong in each analysis category.
episodes.title: Incident Response Elements Part 2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:06.746
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don [CROSSTALK].

2
00:00:06.746 --> 00:00:10.508
>> You're watching ITProTV.

3
00:00:10.508 --> 00:00:13.007
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

4
00:00:13.007 --> 00:00:15.096
helping you learn wherever you go.

5
00:00:15.096 --> 00:00:19.823
I'm your host Zach Memos and
this is CCNA's SECOPS and

6
00:00:19.823 --> 00:00:23.122
Incident Response Elements Part 2.

7
00:00:23.122 --> 00:00:26.940
And we're looking to our IT expert
Ronnie Wong for some answers.

8
00:00:26.940 --> 00:00:28.233
Ronnie tell us what we need to know.

9
00:00:28.233 --> 00:00:32.713
>> [LAUGH] All right Zach, well thank you
again for having me back on the show as we

10
00:00:32.713 --> 00:00:36.770
continue on taking a look at
the idea of incident response here.

11
00:00:36.770 --> 00:00:42.019
And we are basing this off, of course, of
the NIST Special Publication SP 800-61 R2.

12
00:00:42.019 --> 00:00:46.742
And we've already talked in
previous episode at least on taking

13
00:00:46.742 --> 00:00:51.120
a look at the elements inside
of an incident response plan.

14
00:00:51.120 --> 00:00:54.603
And we're now going to still be
talking about that a little bit, but

15
00:00:54.603 --> 00:00:56.200
in a different manner as well.

16
00:00:56.200 --> 00:01:00.217
And so now we're actually taking
a look at, well, the procedures or

17
00:01:00.217 --> 00:01:03.485
the categories that we also
find in incident response.

18
00:01:03.485 --> 00:01:07.900
And that's what we need to address
now as we continue to move forward.

19
00:01:07.900 --> 00:01:09.020
>> And so as I understand it Ronnie,

20
00:01:09.020 --> 00:01:11.700
we're gonna be looking at steps
of analysis maybe up front?

21
00:01:11.700 --> 00:01:15.834
>> We are, we're gonna of course make sure
that we understand that now that we have

22
00:01:15.834 --> 00:01:17.140
a response plan in hand.

23
00:01:17.140 --> 00:01:21.936
It means that different elements are gonna
happen when we deal with the incidents

24
00:01:21.936 --> 00:01:22.815
themselves.

25
00:01:22.815 --> 00:01:24.900
>> Mm-hm,
>> And that's gonna be important.

26
00:01:24.900 --> 00:01:27.682
So if we think about the idea, right?

27
00:01:27.682 --> 00:01:32.810
That now that we have a plan ready to go,
okay?

28
00:01:32.810 --> 00:01:37.155
Our hope of course is that we really
don't ever have to deal with it,

29
00:01:37.155 --> 00:01:39.442
as far as it being an after the fact or

30
00:01:39.442 --> 00:01:43.440
being a mitigation in a response
to an ongoing attack, okay?

31
00:01:43.440 --> 00:01:46.673
That's the whole goal,
is that we just set up everything so

32
00:01:46.673 --> 00:01:49.100
that we don't ever really have to do it.

33
00:01:49.100 --> 00:01:52.080
>> Right.
>> But what happens if we need to do it?

34
00:01:52.080 --> 00:01:55.980
What happens when we have to make
sure that everything is going wrong?

35
00:01:55.980 --> 00:02:00.367
Well, this is where we step up and
we start to take a look and

36
00:02:00.367 --> 00:02:06.023
find some guidance inside of that
SP 800-61 that is going to help us.

37
00:02:06.023 --> 00:02:10.327
And also using some of those elements
that we saw in the previous episode and

38
00:02:10.327 --> 00:02:13.078
that we talked about and discussed.

39
00:02:13.078 --> 00:02:16.920
That that's gonna help us to make sure
that we are also ready to do what

40
00:02:16.920 --> 00:02:18.770
we need to do.

41
00:02:18.770 --> 00:02:20.530
So in that particular sense, right?

42
00:02:20.530 --> 00:02:23.570
We wanna go ahead and
take a look at the actual SP 800 here.

43
00:02:23.570 --> 00:02:27.368
And I'll show you a diagram and
what we're actually gonna be doing, okay?

44
00:02:27.368 --> 00:02:28.966
>> Good.
>> So here on my screen,

45
00:02:28.966 --> 00:02:32.970
this is actually the incident
response life cycle.

46
00:02:32.970 --> 00:02:36.250
This is directly from
the Special Publication

47
00:02:36.250 --> 00:02:37.970
that we've been mentioning here.

48
00:02:37.970 --> 00:02:42.160
And we wanna make sure that we
understand these elements in particular.

49
00:02:42.160 --> 00:02:43.720
I was gonna actually remake this diagram.

50
00:02:43.720 --> 00:02:45.470
I was like, well,
it's actually right there and

51
00:02:45.470 --> 00:02:47.900
I'm showing the actual diagram, so=
>> It's very pretty too.

52
00:02:47.900 --> 00:02:51.810
>> Yeah and it's actually much better than
what I could actually have ever made.

53
00:02:51.810 --> 00:02:54.005
And let's make sure we understand
the element and then we'll go back,

54
00:02:54.005 --> 00:02:57.440
do little more breakdown these kind
of concepts just a little bit.

55
00:02:57.440 --> 00:03:00.098
And we'll talk about what we need to
understand about the elements and

56
00:03:00.098 --> 00:03:02.240
the way that these all fit
together as well, okay?

57
00:03:02.240 --> 00:03:06.025
When an incident happens, okay?

58
00:03:06.025 --> 00:03:10.490
Our response needs to also happen in terms
of what we consider a life cycle, okay?

59
00:03:10.490 --> 00:03:15.830
It is not just a punch, counter punch
idea that we are dealing with here, okay?

60
00:03:15.830 --> 00:03:19.970
An incidence happens, we respond,
and that's pretty much it, okay?

61
00:03:19.970 --> 00:03:21.750
The whole goal behind this, right?

62
00:03:21.750 --> 00:03:25.150
Is to make sure that we talk about
those elements once again, or

63
00:03:25.150 --> 00:03:28.570
to meet those elements, those goals, and
those strategies that we've talked about.

64
00:03:28.570 --> 00:03:31.880
Ensure that our purpose is actually there,
and that we're maintaining it,

65
00:03:31.880 --> 00:03:35.770
as well as to have that uniform
response to whatever we do.

66
00:03:35.770 --> 00:03:39.650
So here,
everything that we do in incident response

67
00:03:39.650 --> 00:03:44.435
happens in terms of a life cycle that
hopefully we can learn from as well, okay?

68
00:03:44.435 --> 00:03:48.500
So here's how the initial reaction begins,
okay?

69
00:03:48.500 --> 00:03:52.581
If we do come across a security event that

70
00:03:52.581 --> 00:03:57.391
requires us to handle it as an incident,
okay?

71
00:03:57.391 --> 00:04:02.053
We now take all the preparation work
that we've been doing for a long time,

72
00:04:02.053 --> 00:04:06.345
when we said here's what we want to
do to make sure that we are ready for

73
00:04:06.345 --> 00:04:07.710
everything, okay?

74
00:04:07.710 --> 00:04:10.510
So we take all that, and
notice here in the green box,

75
00:04:10.510 --> 00:04:14.480
we now put it into action with this
arrow as it moves through, okay?

76
00:04:14.480 --> 00:04:19.990
At that point the real work of incident
response really begins to happen here.

77
00:04:19.990 --> 00:04:24.990
And these middle two types of analysis
situations that we're really talking

78
00:04:24.990 --> 00:04:25.990
about, okay?

79
00:04:25.990 --> 00:04:29.300
The detection and
the analysis portion of this,

80
00:04:29.300 --> 00:04:32.020
even though you might put them
in order to detect first and

81
00:04:32.020 --> 00:04:35.390
then analyze, they just group
it together right here, okay?

82
00:04:35.390 --> 00:04:37.430
So the goal here is simple.

83
00:04:37.430 --> 00:04:41.570
We detect it, we try and
figure out what's actually happening here.

84
00:04:41.570 --> 00:04:44.349
We break it down to it's components and

85
00:04:44.349 --> 00:04:48.993
then we come up with what we can
do to either contain what happens.

86
00:04:48.993 --> 00:04:53.992
And we might find out that that's actually
the situation that we want so that we can

87
00:04:53.992 --> 00:04:58.991
evaluate a little bit more and to try and
understand what has actually occurred and

88
00:04:58.991 --> 00:05:03.370
who the bad actors are in this
particular incident that goes on.

89
00:05:03.370 --> 00:05:08.270
It may be where we just need to get
rid of it, the eradication part, okay?

90
00:05:08.270 --> 00:05:11.300
But we also might need to determine,
of course, the damage and

91
00:05:11.300 --> 00:05:13.740
recover from that damage as well.

92
00:05:13.740 --> 00:05:17.630
We might find out something, that our
initial response in terms of containment

93
00:05:17.630 --> 00:05:22.410
did not do everything, but actually
gave us at least a hint on what to do.

94
00:05:22.410 --> 00:05:26.070
So we start that process over for
the next part if we need to.

95
00:05:26.070 --> 00:05:29.960
We continue to go through this
cycle right here in the center

96
00:05:29.960 --> 00:05:32.730
until we are completely satisfied.

97
00:05:32.730 --> 00:05:38.140
That we have actually either contained
everything that we need to eradicate it.

98
00:05:38.140 --> 00:05:40.590
And we have our process of recovery.

99
00:05:40.590 --> 00:05:43.390
So that we can get back to
the productivity that we need within our

100
00:05:43.390 --> 00:05:44.820
organization, okay?

101
00:05:44.820 --> 00:05:49.610
So all that actually does end up working,
and when we are satisfied at that point,

102
00:05:49.610 --> 00:05:54.310
that allows us then to move onto
the post incident activities.

103
00:05:54.310 --> 00:05:57.230
And this is where we start
to actually reevaluate or

104
00:05:57.230 --> 00:06:01.420
debrief on the actual
situation that we're facing.

105
00:06:01.420 --> 00:06:05.650
Taking a look at the elements of
the idea of lessons learned, okay?

106
00:06:05.650 --> 00:06:09.110
And who is involved and
who needs to know what?

107
00:06:09.110 --> 00:06:13.300
Essentially for us here and what we're
seeing here in the entire lifecycle.

108
00:06:13.300 --> 00:06:17.324
It is a projectized response,
is what we're looking for, okay?

109
00:06:17.324 --> 00:06:22.674
And the whole goal behind that projectized
response is that it makes it simple and

110
00:06:22.674 --> 00:06:26.060
easy for a couple of things to happen.

111
00:06:26.060 --> 00:06:27.470
One, let's say that Zach and

112
00:06:27.470 --> 00:06:31.550
I are on an incident response team along
with three or four other people, okay?

113
00:06:31.550 --> 00:06:35.940
And we've actually been the ones to put
it together and the preparation time,

114
00:06:35.940 --> 00:06:37.720
all that we put together, okay?

115
00:06:37.720 --> 00:06:41.120
Actually does work and
we've all been heavily involved.

116
00:06:41.120 --> 00:06:42.960
By projectizing this and

117
00:06:42.960 --> 00:06:47.950
actually providing solid foundational
life cycle steps here, Zach or

118
00:06:47.950 --> 00:06:53.140
I could leave the company or end up being
moved off of that incident response team.

119
00:06:53.140 --> 00:06:56.079
Somebody else can actually
take our place and

120
00:06:56.079 --> 00:07:00.262
still follow this process through
with whatever has happened.

121
00:07:00.262 --> 00:07:03.643
So it doesn't break the continuity
of service that we have

122
00:07:03.643 --> 00:07:06.590
in terms of responding to the incidents.

123
00:07:06.590 --> 00:07:09.442
If it's just about me seeing it or
Zach seeing it?

124
00:07:09.442 --> 00:07:12.560
An incident happens,
Zach sees it right then.

125
00:07:12.560 --> 00:07:14.940
And then he goes let me
just fix it right then and

126
00:07:14.940 --> 00:07:17.340
he never mentions it
again to anybody else?

127
00:07:17.340 --> 00:07:19.295
Well I can't go back and reproduce that.

128
00:07:19.295 --> 00:07:21.480
Zach can say yeah, I did.

129
00:07:21.480 --> 00:07:22.290
What did I do?

130
00:07:22.290 --> 00:07:24.180
Let me remember what I tried to do here.

131
00:07:24.180 --> 00:07:25.165
>> [LAUGH]
>> Let me try and fix that.

132
00:07:25.165 --> 00:07:29.339
Zach, you've probably never had that
happen where you actually fix something

133
00:07:29.339 --> 00:07:33.650
and then you kinda go no I don't remember
what I did to fix it but it's working now.

134
00:07:33.650 --> 00:07:34.935
>> Forgot the steps, right?

135
00:07:34.935 --> 00:07:36.225
I forgot the steps [LAUGH].

136
00:07:36.225 --> 00:07:38.775
>> Yeah, you knew that you fixed it.

137
00:07:38.775 --> 00:07:40.505
But you forgot what
the steps were to do so.

138
00:07:40.505 --> 00:07:43.945
By projectizing this,
essentially is what we're doing here,

139
00:07:43.945 --> 00:07:47.955
it really allows us to essentially be able
to replace those elements to do that.

140
00:07:47.955 --> 00:07:51.028
The other thing is it makes
ramp up time quicker.

141
00:07:51.028 --> 00:07:54.000
Whoever Zach or
I are replaced with, right?

142
00:07:54.000 --> 00:07:58.311
It's not that they have to actually obtain
every bit of knowledge that we have as As

143
00:07:58.311 --> 00:08:02.559
feeble as it is, the amount of knowledge
that you and I combined may have in this,

144
00:08:02.559 --> 00:08:04.390
it allows them to ramp up quicker.

145
00:08:04.390 --> 00:08:05.260
Why?
Because

146
00:08:05.260 --> 00:08:08.900
we're actually feeding the process,
we're not feeding

147
00:08:08.900 --> 00:08:14.100
a special little secret sauce that only I
have access to or that Zack has access to.

148
00:08:14.100 --> 00:08:17.420
It is about the entire process itself.

149
00:08:17.420 --> 00:08:21.500
So that's why we want to make sure
that we follow something like this

150
00:08:21.500 --> 00:08:24.560
as we continue to move forward from there.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe CSIRT and the goals of CSIRT.  They take some time to go over the 6 goals when given a CSIRT.

We'll now taking a look at

We're in this section of our exam

And the way that the world, and

00:01:21.011 --> 00:01:25.510

So the easiest way for us to do this is go

But if we take a look at

Computer Security Instant Response Team.

00:02:07.030 --> 00:02:12.244

Emergency Response Team.

55

This is according to
the special publication, and

61

any incidents to US-CERT.

62
00:03:47.680 --> 00:03:50.940

65

information unfortunately,

00:04:02.659 --> 00:04:05.490

67
00:04:05.490 --> 00:04:09.156
I would recommend you conducting your
own open-source research to gather

68
00:04:09.156 --> 00:04:10.500
the information you need.

69
00:04:10.500 --> 00:04:14.405
In other words they're telling you to
Google it is what they're actually telling

71
00:04:14.973 --> 00:04:16.155

00:04:16.155 --> 00:04:17.410

73

So this is one of those unusual things

I know that you might see this

>> Well, once an official government

82

83

the term PSIRT instead.
