00:18:07.700 --> 00:18:08.850
So it is very possible.

314
00:18:08.850 --> 00:18:11.750
And you might hear that product
security instant response team

315
00:18:11.750 --> 00:18:15.325
instead of the vendor teams
that are out there, okay?

316
00:18:15.325 --> 00:18:17.140
>> Mm-hm.
>> Six one way, half a dozen the other,

317
00:18:17.140 --> 00:18:20.680
they mean the same thing, okay,
is what they really mean, okay?

318
00:18:20.680 --> 00:18:22.980
The other one that is also called out.

319
00:18:22.980 --> 00:18:24.650
And this is actually our final one here,

320
00:18:24.650 --> 00:18:28.680
okay, is the incident response provider,
okay?

321
00:18:28.680 --> 00:18:32.820
Now, incident response provider,
you also see MSSP.

322
00:18:34.100 --> 00:18:39.090
Manage security service provider, okay.

323
00:18:39.090 --> 00:18:42.970
And this manage security service provider,

324
00:18:42.970 --> 00:18:48.240
okay, this is instead where you might
outsource your instant response team.

325
00:18:48.240 --> 00:18:53.045
Either as a co incident response kind of
team that comes in to help you out or

326
00:18:53.045 --> 00:18:56.830
you've contracted them to be
essentially an advisor or supervisor or

327
00:18:56.830 --> 00:18:58.350
something like that.

328
00:18:58.350 --> 00:19:00.078
But, they are out there.

329
00:19:00.078 --> 00:19:04.170
>> And running that, wouldn't that be
recommended to have an objective team

330
00:19:04.170 --> 00:19:06.990
if the incident was sufficient
enough to warrant that?

331
00:19:06.990 --> 00:19:12.000
>> Well, yes, if it's sufficient enough
to do that, but it is also expensive.

332
00:19:12.000 --> 00:19:14.130
Don't get me wrong.

333
00:19:14.130 --> 00:19:18.090
You should never base it on
the fact of is it expensive or not.

334
00:19:18.090 --> 00:19:21.460
Same time the reality is,
can you afford to do it, okay?

335
00:19:21.460 --> 00:19:26.310
Having this team essentially
specialized in something like this,

336
00:19:26.310 --> 00:19:27.930
it does mean it's gonna
cost you a little bit,

337
00:19:27.930 --> 00:19:32.590
but they're essentially saying we'll
handle the actual incident for you.

338
00:19:32.590 --> 00:19:36.800
They're essentially saying this then, that
the term is probably similar to service or

339
00:19:36.800 --> 00:19:38.345
subscription as a service.

340
00:19:38.345 --> 00:19:39.070
>> Mm-hm.

341
00:19:39.070 --> 00:19:44.190
>> So you essentially pay a fee and they
provide you that service instead of you

342
00:19:44.190 --> 00:19:47.530
having actually having to mountain your
own team and keep that up and and going.

343
00:19:47.530 --> 00:19:49.760
They actually provide
the analysis that you need and

344
00:19:49.760 --> 00:19:53.330
everything to continue to move forward and
do what they need as well.

345
00:19:53.330 --> 00:19:54.180
Okay?
>> Makes sense.

346
00:19:54.180 --> 00:19:58.140
>> So this is normally a subscription
base when you see the MSSP or

347
00:19:58.140 --> 00:20:00.892
you hear that term,
Incident Response provider, okay?

348
00:20:00.892 --> 00:20:05.615
>> Mm-hm. Mm-hm. >> They're contractors is
what they are and they help you out too.

349
00:20:05.615 --> 00:20:06.800
>> Mm-hm.

350
00:20:06.800 --> 00:20:11.540
So take a moment and
go back an look at the CSIRT

351
00:20:11.540 --> 00:20:16.720
website and try and understand its
goal and its focus, and realize that

352
00:20:16.720 --> 00:20:20.120
not everybody is gonna automatically
funnel everything through them.

353
00:20:20.120 --> 00:20:23.220
But understanding some of those different
terms especially when you're reading

354
00:20:23.220 --> 00:20:26.890
documentation is going to help you out
in understanding the goal of your own

355
00:20:26.890 --> 00:20:31.710
internal CCERT organization, as well as it
was coordinated with other ones out there.

356
00:20:31.710 --> 00:20:34.500
These are some of the terminologies
you need to be familiar with

357
00:20:34.500 --> 00:20:37.220
as you actually prepare for
the SecOps exam.

358
00:20:37.220 --> 00:20:40.350
So Zach, that pretty much covers just
about everything that we're gonna be

359
00:20:40.350 --> 00:20:42.385
talking about in terms
of CCERT at that point.

360
00:20:42.385 --> 00:20:43.610
>> Mm-hm.
>> So

361
00:20:43.610 --> 00:20:46.660
we are kind of at the end
of this right here.

362
00:20:46.660 --> 00:20:47.950
>> Well thank you very much, Ronnie.

363
00:20:47.950 --> 00:20:52.470
Wonderful information as usual, and
CCERT goals, re watch it, play it back,

364
00:20:52.470 --> 00:20:53.350
freeze frame it.

365
00:20:53.350 --> 00:20:58.220
And then, by the way, see, every single
episode in the CCNA SecOps series.

366
00:20:58.220 --> 00:20:59.380
Go to our course library,

367
00:20:59.380 --> 00:21:03.500
review the hundreds of videos there
all designed to help you go further.

368
00:21:03.500 --> 00:21:08.490
And tell everybody you know about ITPRO.TV
thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos,

369
00:21:08.490 --> 00:21:09.250
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong

370
00:21:09.250 --> 00:21:10.649
>> And we'll see you very soon.

371
00:21:12.590 --> 00:21:18.302
[MUSIC]

372
00:21:18.302 --> 00:21:20.702
Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie help identify server profiling elements and link data types to 3 of the compliance frameworks: PCI, HIPPA and SOX.  Lastly, they also identify elements that must be protected according to PCI-DSS.
episodes.title: Identify Cybersec Elements and Frameworks
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.240 --> 00:00:03.515
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.515 --> 00:00:07.302
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:07.302 --> 00:00:11.071
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:11.071 --> 00:00:13.720
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITProTV,

5
00:00:13.720 --> 00:00:15.820
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:15.820 --> 00:00:21.320
I'm your host Zach Memos, and this is
CCNA SECOPS with Ronnie Wong and myself.

7
00:00:21.320 --> 00:00:25.170
And in this episode, we're taking a look
at identifying Cybersec elements and

8
00:00:25.170 --> 00:00:25.770
frameworks.

9
00:00:25.770 --> 00:00:28.220
Ronnie, can you tell us
what that's all about?

10
00:00:28.220 --> 00:00:31.700
>> Sure thing Zach, thank you again for
having me back on the show as we continue

11
00:00:31.700 --> 00:00:35.620
on to take a look at, well,
this idea of elements and frameworks.

12
00:00:35.620 --> 00:00:39.150
Now, what we're specifically
talking about here is that there's

13
00:00:39.150 --> 00:00:43.640
a couple of different exam objectives that
we're really covering in one episode.

14
00:00:43.640 --> 00:00:47.120
Now, normally I do break them up
into a couple of different episodes.

15
00:00:47.120 --> 00:00:51.160
In other words, a topic for each episode,
but these are relatively small.

16
00:00:51.160 --> 00:00:53.670
So, instead I kinda say, well,
let me combine them together,

17
00:00:53.670 --> 00:00:55.570
the idea of cybersecurity.

18
00:00:55.570 --> 00:00:56.230
I wanna talk about,

19
00:00:56.230 --> 00:00:59.290
of course, elements that we use in things
like server profiling a little bit.

20
00:00:59.290 --> 00:01:01.350
And we're just gonna run
some of the commands.

21
00:01:01.350 --> 00:01:03.800
Now we've already seen
these commands before.

22
00:01:03.800 --> 00:01:06.340
But this is more of
a refresher than anything else

23
00:01:06.340 --> 00:01:08.480
that you might actually
have to be able to run.

24
00:01:08.480 --> 00:01:10.570
So we're gonna look over some
of those commands again and

25
00:01:10.570 --> 00:01:12.050
the outputs that they give us.

26
00:01:12.050 --> 00:01:13.920
As well as talking about, of course,

27
00:01:13.920 --> 00:01:18.990
some of the compliance frameworks that you
may also find yourself having to deal with

28
00:01:18.990 --> 00:01:23.550
as you work in a cybersecurity operations
center, is what we're taking a look at.

29
00:01:23.550 --> 00:01:25.455
>> So server profiling, right?

30
00:01:25.455 --> 00:01:26.920
>> Mm-hm.
>> We're looking at that and so

31
00:01:26.920 --> 00:01:29.640
this is all encompassing.

32
00:01:29.640 --> 00:01:30.548
>> Well, to a point, right?

33
00:01:30.548 --> 00:01:31.513
>> Yeah.
>> The whole goal and

34
00:01:31.513 --> 00:01:35.420
the whole idea is to understand what your
server is really doing at that point

35
00:01:35.420 --> 00:01:36.430
in time.

36
00:01:36.430 --> 00:01:41.460
So we wanna make sure that we point out
at least some of the different utilities

37
00:01:41.460 --> 00:01:42.750
that we're actually going to,

38
00:01:42.750 --> 00:01:47.660
maybe, look at as we are suspecting
connections that are happening.

39
00:01:47.660 --> 00:01:51.743
>> Of course understanding what is running
in the background in terms of applications

40
00:01:51.743 --> 00:01:52.395
processes.

41
00:01:52.395 --> 00:01:54.180
And understanding things like that.

42
00:01:54.180 --> 00:01:57.540
But all of this is just important elements
that we just wanna make sure that

43
00:01:57.540 --> 00:01:58.190
we do know.

44
00:01:58.190 --> 00:02:00.340
Now, remember that this
is more of a refresher.

45
00:02:00.340 --> 00:02:05.236
Because, in previous episodes, and even
all throughout the security fundamentals

46
00:02:05.236 --> 00:02:09.590
series that we've done, we've actually
done quite a bit of this, okay?

47
00:02:09.590 --> 00:02:10.510
Over and over and

48
00:02:10.510 --> 00:02:14.330
over, so we're not gonna actually do
a full-blown kind of thing again.

49
00:02:14.330 --> 00:02:17.580
Cuz if I did that, it'd probably
take me another six episodes to do.

50
00:02:17.580 --> 00:02:21.135
But overall though, just kinda realize
that it's just kind of a reminder here.

51
00:02:21.135 --> 00:02:22.571
And it gets called out on the exams.

52
00:02:22.571 --> 00:02:25.855
And sometimes, that's what will
end up happening is that we'll see

53
00:02:25.855 --> 00:02:28.470
that there is overlap in those exams,
between exams.

54
00:02:28.470 --> 00:02:30.830
But even just in the concepts, themselves.

55
00:02:30.830 --> 00:02:34.460
And this one just happens to be that way,
and that's why we're doing this.

56
00:02:34.460 --> 00:02:35.610
>> Wonderful, thank you.

57
00:02:35.610 --> 00:02:37.404
>> So Zach, as we begin here,

58
00:02:37.404 --> 00:02:42.085
what we want to do is we wanna take a look
at that idea of what is it normally

59
00:02:42.085 --> 00:02:46.712
that we're looking at in terms of
profiling here and what we wanna do?

60
00:02:46.712 --> 00:02:49.795
The first thing that we're
actually going to talk about here

61
00:02:49.795 --> 00:02:51.980
are identifying listening ports, okay.

62
00:02:51.980 --> 00:02:54.090
And remember that the idea
of using port numbers,

63
00:02:54.090 --> 00:02:57.920
right, is how others connect to us.

64
00:02:57.920 --> 00:03:01.085
And we want to make sure that we
understand that when we have listening

65
00:03:01.085 --> 00:03:04.596
ports, it is saying hey, here's a sign
I am ready for a connection to do so.

66
00:03:04.596 --> 00:03:09.230
And you do need to at least be able
to identify that on your machine.

67
00:03:09.230 --> 00:03:13.170
So the great thing is most of us have
actually kind of figured this out before.

68
00:03:13.170 --> 00:03:15.580
But there's a few
utilities that we can use.

69
00:03:15.580 --> 00:03:16.840
And of course, when getting ready for

70
00:03:16.840 --> 00:03:20.880
the exam, you need to be able to identify
the utility that you would end up using.

71
00:03:20.880 --> 00:03:23.520
So for example,
let's go to my machine here.

72
00:03:23.520 --> 00:03:27.004
I'm running a Kali Linux box
because it was up and it was easy.

73
00:03:27.004 --> 00:03:28.975
And it will actually help us to
demonstrate what we need to.

74
00:03:28.975 --> 00:03:32.880
But you can run this on a Windows
machine if you want to as well.

75
00:03:32.880 --> 00:03:33.775
And this will all work too.

76
00:03:33.775 --> 00:03:38.420
So if I needed to identify listening
ports on Kali Linux machine,

77
00:03:38.420 --> 00:03:41.550
apparently I double clicked on this thing.

78
00:03:41.550 --> 00:03:43.700
Let me just click on it one time.

79
00:03:43.700 --> 00:03:46.290
And there we go,
that'd make it actually easier.

80
00:03:46.290 --> 00:03:50.558
Well, the utility that I'm probably gonna
end up using is kinda the utility that

81
00:03:50.558 --> 00:03:54.286
we've been using for pretty much
a long time here, which is gonna be.

82
00:03:54.286 --> 00:03:58.580
Let me zoom in here a little bit,
which is gonna be netstat, okay?

83
00:03:58.580 --> 00:04:01.760
Now, netstat, itself, is actually quite a,

84
00:04:01.760 --> 00:04:05.490
pretty sizable tool that
we can end up using.

85
00:04:05.490 --> 00:04:07.420
But it does show us quite
a bit of information,

86
00:04:07.420 --> 00:04:11.370
especially when we start using the options
that we can see along with this.

87
00:04:11.370 --> 00:04:15.260
So notice I just typed in netstat -a,
which just means all.

88
00:04:15.260 --> 00:04:17.340
So if I press Enter from that point,

89
00:04:17.340 --> 00:04:23.840
now you can see that it actually does give
me quite a bit of output that goes on.

90
00:04:23.840 --> 00:04:26.520
And from right here, we can see currently

91
00:04:27.830 --> 00:04:33.470
Active Internet connection (servers and
established) at this particular point.

92
00:04:33.470 --> 00:04:38.300
So it allows us to take a look at the
information that we see, not only up here,

93
00:04:38.300 --> 00:04:40.250
and these are the ones
that are established.

94
00:04:40.250 --> 00:04:44.100
But what I'm also looking for
is the ones that are in listening state,

95
00:04:44.100 --> 00:04:46.610
which is how people can connect.

96
00:04:46.610 --> 00:04:49.230
And what we actually need
to be able to find out.

97
00:04:49.230 --> 00:04:52.513
So inside of, let's say if you were
taking a look at a Windows box,

98
00:04:52.513 --> 00:04:56.384
what you would end up finding out, right,
is that you might see established,

99
00:04:56.384 --> 00:05:00.280
you might see listening, you might see
closed, wait, whatever it might be.

100
00:05:00.280 --> 00:05:04.250
But the listening ones are the ones that
you're really needing to pay attention to.

101
00:05:04.250 --> 00:05:06.590
Here, of course,
are some that are connected.

102
00:05:06.590 --> 00:05:08.570
So at least knowing that listening and

103
00:05:08.570 --> 00:05:12.360
where you might suspect that
somebody is able to attack.

104
00:05:12.360 --> 00:05:15.100
Well, that's what you want
to be able to identify

105
00:05:15.100 --> 00:05:17.140
at the very beginning using netstat.

106
00:05:17.140 --> 00:05:21.200
Now if you're not sure,
of course, about all

107
00:05:21.200 --> 00:05:25.760
of the options that are available
you can always do netsat -help.

108
00:05:25.760 --> 00:05:30.450
And then if I scroll down a little bit,
you can see some of the additional

109
00:05:30.450 --> 00:05:34.030
options here that we can run
along with netstat itself.

110
00:05:35.120 --> 00:05:38.017
So for example,
the one that I chose is right here, all.

111
00:05:38.017 --> 00:05:41.830
And now lot of times of course,
that's just too much information.

112
00:05:41.830 --> 00:05:45.290
So instead, if I wanted to identify
the ones that were listening, and

113
00:05:45.290 --> 00:05:52.130
you saw it right here -l,
it displays listening sever sockets.

114
00:05:52.130 --> 00:05:54.630
Well that might actually help
me a little bit more than

115
00:05:54.630 --> 00:05:55.862
what I wanted to be able to do.

116
00:05:55.862 --> 00:06:00.430
So let's scroll all the way down here,
or up I should say.

117
00:06:00.430 --> 00:06:02.410
If i scroll up, you'll see that right now,

118
00:06:02.410 --> 00:06:07.470
I only really have one that looks
like it's a active connection here.

119
00:06:07.470 --> 00:06:09.690
But all the rest of these,
according to what we're seeing,

120
00:06:09.690 --> 00:06:11.580
are listening states as well.

121
00:06:11.580 --> 00:06:15.070
So that is another filter that we
can use to help us to provide at

122
00:06:15.070 --> 00:06:18.730
least a little bit more information
on the listening ones that we need.

123
00:06:18.730 --> 00:06:21.640
So this will allow us to at
least see that information, too.

124
00:06:21.640 --> 00:06:23.762
Now that's not all, right?

125
00:06:23.762 --> 00:06:26.305
We wanna filter this
a little bit more as well.

126
00:06:26.305 --> 00:06:30.238
So if I do the same thing,
which is a netstat -l, let me stop that,

127
00:06:30.238 --> 00:06:32.997
because that looks weird
on the screen there.

128
00:06:32.997 --> 00:06:34.730
Let me scroll down here.

129
00:06:34.730 --> 00:06:38.340
I can use this in combination
with some of those other options.

130
00:06:38.340 --> 00:06:44.659
For example, I do the listening, I can
even say I wanna limit this to TCP ports.

131
00:06:44.659 --> 00:06:48.187
And all I have to do
is actually do the LT.

132
00:06:48.187 --> 00:06:51.570
And now it's actually showing
me I don't have any of them.

133
00:06:51.570 --> 00:06:52.230
So remember that, and

134
00:06:52.230 --> 00:06:54.510
when we start talking about
the later four protocols, right?

135
00:06:54.510 --> 00:06:56.730
We have TCP,
the transmission control protocol.

136
00:06:56.730 --> 00:07:00.800
And there's also UDP,
the user datagram protocol.

137
00:07:00.800 --> 00:07:03.920
I can even go in and
find that out if I want to.

138
00:07:03.920 --> 00:07:08.701
If I wanted to do the user datagram
protocol, I instead can do a -lu.

139
00:07:08.701 --> 00:07:13.635
And that would also show me something if I
did have some type of connection there off

140
00:07:13.635 --> 00:07:15.800
and going and ready to use.

141
00:07:15.800 --> 00:07:20.330
So those are all different, at least, some
of the things that we can do to help us,

142
00:07:20.330 --> 00:07:23.140
to kind of pinpoint what
we're really looking for

143
00:07:23.140 --> 00:07:26.360
when we're talking about listing ports
that are actually available, okay?

144
00:07:26.360 --> 00:07:27.440
>> Great.

145
00:07:27.440 --> 00:07:32.250
>> Now the other one that we can also
end up taking a look at, of course is,

146
00:07:32.250 --> 00:07:36.707
let me do the help again, netstat -help.

147
00:07:36.707 --> 00:07:44.770
And what I'm looking for to remind
myself is statistical information, okay?

148
00:07:44.770 --> 00:07:47.751
So I can even see some statistical
information based on some of the same

149
00:07:47.751 --> 00:07:49.735
elements that we were
just looking at as well.

150
00:07:49.735 --> 00:07:55.281
So for example,
if I now go back instead and

151
00:07:55.281 --> 00:08:01.454
I type in netstat [LAUGH] -s for
the statistics.

152
00:08:01.454 --> 00:08:05.210
I can also just run that.

153
00:08:05.210 --> 00:08:08.960
And now take a look at
the information that displays for me.

154
00:08:08.960 --> 00:08:12.620
I can of course see the IP information and
the packets received.

155
00:08:12.620 --> 00:08:14.810
Incoming as well as outgoing.

156
00:08:14.810 --> 00:08:17.100
ICMP, another protocol.

157
00:08:17.100 --> 00:08:23.220
Notice Tcp active connection
openings right now, 14 failed ones,

158
00:08:23.220 --> 00:08:27.730
resets, connections established,
reset messages.

159
00:08:27.730 --> 00:08:30.460
Notice that Udp also has
that same information.

160
00:08:31.790 --> 00:08:34.730
And you can continue to scroll down and
find out some more information.

161
00:08:36.320 --> 00:08:39.490
If I hit my up arrow one time and
I see that statistical information.

162
00:08:39.490 --> 00:08:42.420
But what if I only wanted
to see the Tcp itself.

163
00:08:43.790 --> 00:08:48.556
Well, I simply add in an st and
now when I do that notice that it

164
00:08:48.556 --> 00:08:52.676
really does limit me from st up here,
netstat-st.

165
00:08:52.676 --> 00:08:56.572
And now all I'm seeing of course is just
that filtered out information instead of

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe what they 5 tuple are, as well as how they correlate in events. They also show how the 5-tuple can help to isolate and identify a compromised host in logs.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie look at a threat analysis report and show how to identify a possible compromised host.  They show indicators of compromise and how to drilldown to find information.

00:17:41.700 --> 00:17:43.250
>> I'm very,
very impressed with Firepower.

308
00:17:43.250 --> 00:17:45.132
>> Yeah, it's amazing, okay?

309
00:17:45.132 --> 00:17:48.320
You can go in and
you can create your own rules here too.

310
00:17:48.320 --> 00:17:52.530
That way, you actually filter out and
do exactly what you need to as well.

311
00:17:52.530 --> 00:17:55.010
So, just realize that when
you start taking a look at,

312
00:17:55.010 --> 00:17:57.370
especially something like this, okay?

313
00:17:57.370 --> 00:18:00.320
Even though we don't,
we've showed you actually quite a bit more

314
00:18:00.320 --> 00:18:04.365
in earlier episodes, almost every tab,
if I remember right, okay?

315
00:18:04.365 --> 00:18:05.410
>> Mm-hm.
>> Showed you some of those

316
00:18:05.410 --> 00:18:06.090
different things.

317
00:18:06.090 --> 00:18:08.370
>> Sure did.
>> But at least at this point, right,

318
00:18:08.370 --> 00:18:11.030
you kind of understand its power and
its ability.

319
00:18:11.030 --> 00:18:12.520
So, that means if you do get a chance,

320
00:18:12.520 --> 00:18:16.570
as you work in a security operations
center, explore a little bit more.

321
00:18:16.570 --> 00:18:19.690
Don't worry about creating rules cuz
that's probably not your particular place

322
00:18:19.690 --> 00:18:20.765
as an entry level analyst.

323
00:18:20.765 --> 00:18:22.610
>> Mm-hm.
>> But you can at least see this

324
00:18:22.610 --> 00:18:27.660
information and then go on and
continue to be able to use even the simple

325
00:18:27.660 --> 00:18:32.360
things that we've learned to help you to
focus in and identify on what you need to.

326
00:18:32.360 --> 00:18:35.740
So Zach, thatâ€™s kind of a very good and
high level overview for

327
00:18:35.740 --> 00:18:40.650
what we need to know a little bit more
about the Firepower Management Console and

328
00:18:40.650 --> 00:18:41.970
Management Center here.

329
00:18:41.970 --> 00:18:47.470
It really is kind of a very robust tool

330
00:18:47.470 --> 00:18:51.930
that you may actually end up being
able to work with at some point.

331
00:18:51.930 --> 00:18:55.320
So, don't overlook it,
don't think you'll never have a chance.

332
00:18:55.320 --> 00:18:58.573
It is something that you do want to
discover, and it will only help you to

333
00:18:58.573 --> 00:19:01.680
actually learn it more as you
continue to move through your career.

334
00:19:01.680 --> 00:19:05.984
So Zach, that's pretty much a good wrap
up for us right there in taking a look at

335
00:19:05.984 --> 00:19:10.505
what we normally are gonna see in terms
of Firepower for an entry-level analyst.

336
00:19:10.505 --> 00:19:12.988
>> Well, I'm very impressed with
Firepower Management Console, and

337
00:19:12.988 --> 00:19:15.140
I'm very impressed with how
you presented that, Ronnie.

338
00:19:15.140 --> 00:19:16.580
Thanks very much, and

339
00:19:16.580 --> 00:19:21.290
make sure you watch also all
the episodes in the CCNA SecOps Series.

340
00:19:21.290 --> 00:19:24.265
Also, visit our course library,
check out the hundreds of videos there.

341
00:19:24.265 --> 00:19:26.662
They're all designed to
help you go further,

342
00:19:26.662 --> 00:19:30.418
and tell everybody you know about
ITPro.TV, they'll be glad you did.

343
00:19:30.418 --> 00:19:31.834
Thanks for watching, I'm Zach Memos.

344
00:19:31.834 --> 00:19:32.730
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

345
00:19:32.730 --> 00:19:34.308
>> And we'll see you soon.

346
00:19:34.308 --> 00:19:41.135
[MUSIC]

347
00:19:41.135 --> 00:19:44.073
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie compare and contrast deterministic and probabilistic analysis methods to help with Data and events analysis.
episodes.title: Compare and Contrast Analysis Methods
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.276
Welcome to ITPro.TV,
I'm your host, Don Peezt.

2
00:00:03.276 --> 00:00:04.274
>> [CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.274 --> 00:00:08.088
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.088 --> 00:00:10.964
>> You're watching ITPro.TV.

5
00:00:10.964 --> 00:00:14.030
>> Hello, and thank you for
watching ITPro.TV.

6
00:00:14.030 --> 00:00:17.991
I'm your host Zach Memos,
this is CCNA SECOPS.

7
00:00:17.991 --> 00:00:20.381
And on this episode
we're gonna compare and

8
00:00:20.381 --> 00:00:23.750
contrast analysis methods with the one and
only Ronnie Wong.

9
00:00:23.750 --> 00:00:25.980
Ronnie, thanks for joining us again.

10
00:00:25.980 --> 00:00:29.757
>> Thank you, Zach, for having me back as
we continue on in our journey together.

11
00:00:29.757 --> 00:00:35.230
Taking a look, of course, at security
operations and the CCNA exam as well.

12
00:00:35.230 --> 00:00:38.469
And today we're gonna be taking a look,
of course,

13
00:00:38.469 --> 00:00:42.227
at the idea here of different
analysis methods that we can use

14
00:00:42.227 --> 00:00:45.926
when handling data events or
incidents that we might have.

15
00:00:45.926 --> 00:00:49.906
And the reason why we want to
make sure that we do this, right?

16
00:00:49.906 --> 00:00:54.140
Is because it is very easy in the,
and I don't know how else to put it,

17
00:00:54.140 --> 00:00:58.301
in the heat of the moment when you
believe that an attack is going on,

18
00:00:58.301 --> 00:01:02.779
That you can't learn anything from it,
that your whole idea is simple.

19
00:01:02.779 --> 00:01:05.860
It's a reaction to what is happening.

20
00:01:05.860 --> 00:01:09.667
And when you take that and
you make that your main focus,

21
00:01:09.667 --> 00:01:14.139
the problem is all other aspects
of thinking is pretty much done.

22
00:01:14.139 --> 00:01:17.944
So in that aspect,
a lot of times as security professionals,

23
00:01:17.944 --> 00:01:21.130
we actually act more like
the way that dogs happen.

24
00:01:21.130 --> 00:01:24.430
In which you have to snap them out of
their response before you can get their

25
00:01:24.430 --> 00:01:25.300
attention.

26
00:01:25.300 --> 00:01:27.686
To kind of say, all right,
now let's kind of back this back down.

27
00:01:27.686 --> 00:01:31.060
And I learned that from Cesar,
the dog whisperer, right?

28
00:01:31.060 --> 00:01:33.564
>> Right, the dog whisperer guy.

29
00:01:33.564 --> 00:01:36.659
>> So that guy, and that's the same
thing that happens when you think.

30
00:01:36.659 --> 00:01:40.157
And if you're new at this,
your whole goal is protection, and

31
00:01:40.157 --> 00:01:44.447
you kind of get offended when somebody
slips past your particular protective

32
00:01:44.447 --> 00:01:47.720
defenses that you've set up for
your network.

33
00:01:47.720 --> 00:01:48.849
But if that happens,

34
00:01:48.849 --> 00:01:52.375
we understand, it is very easy to
get a little bit more defensive.

35
00:01:52.375 --> 00:01:57.149
But at the same time, you need to take
some time to think about the situation.

36
00:01:57.149 --> 00:02:01.930
In other words, to do some analysis, which
means to break the situation down and

37
00:02:01.930 --> 00:02:06.330
then determine what is the best
thing to actually do at this point?

38
00:02:06.330 --> 00:02:10.160
Or what do we learn from
the event that has just happened?

39
00:02:10.160 --> 00:02:14.780
So when it comes down to the idea
of different analysis methods.

40
00:02:14.780 --> 00:02:19.680
We kinda fall back on something that we
learned way back in school at some point.

41
00:02:19.680 --> 00:02:21.880
You took something like probability and
statistics.

42
00:02:21.880 --> 00:02:24.340
You've probably talked about
deterministic methods.

43
00:02:24.340 --> 00:02:27.310
You've also talked about
probabilistic methods as well.

44
00:02:27.310 --> 00:02:31.580
And normally not so much on retroactive or
retrospective analysis,

45
00:02:31.580 --> 00:02:33.970
but we're gonna actually throw
that one in there as well,

46
00:02:33.970 --> 00:02:37.030
just to kind of sweeten the pot and
make sure that everything is done.

47
00:02:37.030 --> 00:02:40.120
So we're gonna look at all
three just briefly, and

48
00:02:40.120 --> 00:02:44.010
then we'll kinda show you an example
on using retrospective analysis and

49
00:02:44.010 --> 00:02:47.360
what it can show us, especially when
we're dealing with some type of event.

50
00:02:47.360 --> 00:02:50.110
>> Ronnie, is there any one
analysis better than the other, or

51
00:02:50.110 --> 00:02:51.670
should you use all three?

52
00:02:51.670 --> 00:02:54.600
>> That's actually a good question,
and the reason why is that

53
00:02:54.600 --> 00:02:58.240
you have to actually determine what
it is that you're trying to do.

54
00:02:58.240 --> 00:03:02.864
So in that aspect, it really does depend
on what the situation is at the moment

55
00:03:02.864 --> 00:03:04.516
that you're trying to do.

56
00:03:04.516 --> 00:03:08.254
Or it actually kind of lets you do it,
depending on where

57
00:03:08.254 --> 00:03:12.720
you are in this lifecycle of
an event that ends up happening.

58
00:03:12.720 --> 00:03:17.150
So remember that when an event happens,
it's not just it happens and

59
00:03:17.150 --> 00:03:19.480
it's over with and
we're done and we don't know.

60
00:03:19.480 --> 00:03:21.791
We've already seen in some
of the other episodes, or

61
00:03:21.791 --> 00:03:24.960
if you're watching this in the order
of the way that we have it on the show.

62
00:03:24.960 --> 00:03:27.329
It may actually be in a future episode for
you.

63
00:03:27.329 --> 00:03:30.679
But the idea of some type
of incident happening,

64
00:03:30.679 --> 00:03:33.520
goes though a lot of different steps.

65
00:03:33.520 --> 00:03:36.284
We've talked about the seven
phases of the kill chain at some.

66
00:03:37.585 --> 00:03:41.125
So when you start seeing that,
you kinda realize that an intrusion or

67
00:03:41.125 --> 00:03:45.165
some type of event does happen, and
it's a process that it happens in.

68
00:03:45.165 --> 00:03:49.595
It's not always where it's just done and
it's over.

69
00:03:49.595 --> 00:03:53.205
It always is this process, and it really
depends on where we're taking a look at it

70
00:03:53.205 --> 00:03:57.390
in that perspective, which one we
may choose at some point in time.

71
00:03:57.390 --> 00:04:02.139
So I made a kind of chart, I guess,
to help us to compare and contrast.

72
00:04:02.139 --> 00:04:02.920
>> I love these charts.

73
00:04:02.920 --> 00:04:04.895
>> What we're going to actually see here.

74
00:04:04.895 --> 00:04:07.372
So if we take a look at the screen,

75
00:04:07.372 --> 00:04:12.593
it's not exactly graphic rich here,
but it should help us to try to and

76
00:04:12.593 --> 00:04:17.450
figure out what methodology that
we may end up trying to use.

77
00:04:17.450 --> 00:04:19.940
At what particular point in time, as well.

78
00:04:19.940 --> 00:04:21.730
So let's talk about this
first one over here,

79
00:04:21.730 --> 00:04:25.110
which is the deterministic
method just briefly.

80
00:04:25.110 --> 00:04:29.030
And I'll kind of zoom in so that we can
see that a little bit better, okay?

81
00:04:29.030 --> 00:04:32.820
Now when we start talking about
the deterministic method,

82
00:04:32.820 --> 00:04:35.160
notice that one of the first
things that I list here,

83
00:04:35.160 --> 00:04:38.120
really across the top in that
second row that you see.

84
00:04:38.120 --> 00:04:42.310
It's about the data that you use in
this type of analysis here, okay?

85
00:04:42.310 --> 00:04:47.278
And in this one, in deterministic method,
essentially all the data that is

86
00:04:47.278 --> 00:04:51.327
used in the analysis is already known or
structured that way.

87
00:04:51.327 --> 00:04:52.369
So in other words,

88
00:04:52.369 --> 00:04:56.800
there's no real deviation to the way
we're gonna do the analysis here.

89
00:04:56.800 --> 00:05:01.207
We're given all the parameters,
we're given all the data that we can use.

90
00:05:01.207 --> 00:05:04.050
And when we do that analysis,
that's pretty much it.

91
00:05:04.050 --> 00:05:06.228
It essentially allows us to focus in and

92
00:05:06.228 --> 00:05:09.660
limit ourselves to one particular
perspective that we want.

93
00:05:09.660 --> 00:05:14.462
And in that way, what we should end
up seeing in terms of the result of

94
00:05:14.462 --> 00:05:17.600
this type of analysis is right here, okay?

95
00:05:17.600 --> 00:05:20.932
If we know all the parameters
that we're given, and

96
00:05:20.932 --> 00:05:23.516
we've taken a look at the information.

97
00:05:23.516 --> 00:05:26.249
And we go, all right, here is what it is,

98
00:05:26.249 --> 00:05:30.490
then in the end result it should
be exactly what I expect it to be.

99
00:05:30.490 --> 00:05:32.500
So Zach, for example,

100
00:05:32.500 --> 00:05:37.220
let's just kind of use an example here
of something that will help us out.

101
00:05:37.220 --> 00:05:40.680
If you go and, because you and

102
00:05:40.680 --> 00:05:43.460
I love food, let's say you go and
buy a breakfast sandwich somewhere,

103
00:05:43.460 --> 00:05:47.390
at your particular favorite
restaurant that's out there, okay?

104
00:05:47.390 --> 00:05:51.538
And you hand them a $10 bill, and
let's say that the sandwich costs $5.

105
00:05:51.538 --> 00:05:53.589
I don't know if you'd ever pay that much,
but me,

106
00:05:53.589 --> 00:05:55.518
I'd find a little bit of
a hard time doing that.

107
00:05:55.518 --> 00:05:57.375
>> [LAUGH]
>> But the end result of that though,

108
00:05:57.375 --> 00:05:59.141
it should be you get the sandwich and?

109
00:05:59.141 --> 00:06:00.000
>> Five bucks.

110
00:06:00.000 --> 00:06:04.620
>> $5 back, okay, it shouldn't be $4.75.

111
00:06:04.620 --> 00:06:08.585
It shouldn't be a close to $5, right?

112
00:06:08.585 --> 00:06:11.528
It should be the sandwich and $5.

113
00:06:11.528 --> 00:06:12.550
>> Correct.

114
00:06:12.550 --> 00:06:16.683
>> Well, that's kind of determined,
because of you know how much the price of

115
00:06:16.683 --> 00:06:21.026
the sandwich is, because they've told you,
here's what the sandwich cost.

116
00:06:21.026 --> 00:06:24.055
Here is what it is and
you hand them a $10 bill.

117
00:06:24.055 --> 00:06:26.640
Well, the outcome of that
is relatively simple.

118
00:06:26.640 --> 00:06:30.208
Sandwich, $5 that should
be in your pocket.

119
00:06:30.208 --> 00:06:34.097
$4.65, would you kinda go,
that's close enough?

120
00:06:34.097 --> 00:06:38.448
>> I would probably say, I think you need
to reevaluate your mathematical skills.

121
00:06:38.448 --> 00:06:39.750
>> [LAUGH]
>> Something like that.

122
00:06:39.750 --> 00:06:42.109
>> Yeah, but it's not close enough, okay?

123
00:06:42.109 --> 00:06:44.230
Deterministic says what?

124
00:06:44.230 --> 00:06:47.741
I know what the outcome should be, okay?

125
00:06:47.741 --> 00:06:50.412
So given the parameters
that I have access to, and

126
00:06:50.412 --> 00:06:52.840
we're not dealing with any other scenario.

127
00:06:52.840 --> 00:06:56.080
We're not dealing with any other
situation out there, okay?

128
00:06:56.080 --> 00:07:00.206
Here's what the end result should be,
makes sense.

129
00:07:00.206 --> 00:07:04.895
Sometimes Zach, you may actually choose
that particular method and you go, look,

130
00:07:04.895 --> 00:07:06.790
I have a coupon today, though.

131
00:07:06.790 --> 00:07:09.906
That will get me two sandwiches for
$5 instead.

132
00:07:09.906 --> 00:07:12.080
And what that does is add in
that second parameter, but

133
00:07:12.080 --> 00:07:13.740
you already have that parameter.

134
00:07:13.740 --> 00:07:18.798
So now if you did the same thing,
and you got that buy one, get one.

135
00:07:18.798 --> 00:07:23.599
That idea, the BOGO that we actually
talk about here, you get that.

136
00:07:23.599 --> 00:07:27.542
Well, this time you should end
up with two sandwiches and

137
00:07:27.542 --> 00:07:33.330
$5 if you give $10 to the customer
service person that's there, right?

138
00:07:33.330 --> 00:07:35.946
So it's determined, you're not guessing.

139
00:07:35.946 --> 00:07:43.090
You're not going, I should get two and
a half sandwiches maybe, and $4.35 back.

140
00:07:43.090 --> 00:07:46.474
It's predetermined that you
already have it situated

141
00:07:46.474 --> 00:07:49.203
where the outcome is
gonna be what you want.

142
00:07:49.203 --> 00:07:53.297
So now let's bring that back in then,
Zach, to the idea of analysis and

143
00:07:53.297 --> 00:07:56.657
what we're talking about in
Security Operation Center.

144
00:07:56.657 --> 00:07:59.719
Most of the time when we're
doing analysis like this,

145
00:07:59.719 --> 00:08:03.459
it's not really after the fact
that an event has happened, okay?

146
00:08:03.459 --> 00:08:06.385
It's not really even during
an event has happened, but

147
00:08:06.385 --> 00:08:10.790
we've gotta think about here if we're
trying to predetermine something.

148
00:08:10.790 --> 00:08:11.425
it's probably what?

149
00:08:11.425 --> 00:08:16.853
Planning,before anything happens, so
it might be when we are setting up for

150
00:08:16.853 --> 00:08:21.780
intrusion detection, when we
are actually setting up our defenses in

151
00:08:21.780 --> 00:08:24.633
place of what we believe should happen.

152
00:08:24.633 --> 00:08:29.140
We wanna put this here because we know
that this type of attack is gonna happen.

153
00:08:29.140 --> 00:08:33.750
So when we take a look at
the diagram again, okay,

154
00:08:33.750 --> 00:08:37.370
this will help us out in the end
when it comes down to it,

155
00:08:37.370 --> 00:08:40.830
deterministic really is about cause and
effect, right?

156
00:08:40.830 --> 00:08:45.110
Okay, I know that connecting
to the Internet is

157
00:08:45.110 --> 00:08:50.220
a bad thing in terms of how many people
are connecting and trying to attack.

158
00:08:50.220 --> 00:08:52.440
For me, let's say that that means for
my company,

159
00:08:52.440 --> 00:08:54.640
I'm going to put a firewall in place,
okay?

160
00:08:54.640 --> 00:08:56.570
That's my automatic response.

161
00:08:56.570 --> 00:08:58.150
Now are there different
things that you can do?

162
00:08:58.150 --> 00:08:59.360
Yes, okay.

163
00:08:59.360 --> 00:09:04.020
But let's say what I automatically do
right away to give me some protection.

164
00:09:04.020 --> 00:09:07.140
Now, in the cause and
effect that's what we are thinking about.

165
00:09:07.140 --> 00:09:10.620
So when we think about
a particular type of attack,

166
00:09:10.620 --> 00:09:13.200
it only brings up a defense that we have,
okay.

167
00:09:13.200 --> 00:09:17.940
When we think about a particular
defense that I want to actually have,

168
00:09:17.940 --> 00:09:22.530
I may also think about the particular
attack that I'm defending against.

169
00:09:22.530 --> 00:09:24.390
So that's what we talk
about at that point, and

170
00:09:24.390 --> 00:09:26.340
that is normally the planning stage.

171
00:09:26.340 --> 00:09:28.840
It doesn't mean it covers everything,
right?

172
00:09:28.840 --> 00:09:32.310
We only know what we're
actually given at this point.

173
00:09:32.310 --> 00:09:35.840
We're not determining
every possibility here.

174
00:09:35.840 --> 00:09:39.790
We only know what we
believe is already known.

175
00:09:39.790 --> 00:09:43.420
And most of the time, our planning
can only really be based off that.

176
00:09:43.420 --> 00:09:47.990
Now, it's not always the only thing
that it's based off of, but at least

177
00:09:47.990 --> 00:09:51.880
up into this point, okay, if you want to
do something, if you want to actually

178
00:09:51.880 --> 00:09:54.570
understand the term deterministic,
it's probably more in the planning phases.

179
00:09:54.570 --> 00:09:59.400
Than in anything during a mitigation or
even after the attack is over for

180
00:09:59.400 --> 00:10:00.510
retrospection as well.

181
00:10:01.530 --> 00:10:04.420
So that then of course leads
us into the second one.

182
00:10:04.420 --> 00:10:08.970
Let me zoom out a little bit so

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe the use of the Diamond Model of Intrusion and how it helps us to handle events.  They also show how the Kill Chain and Diamond Model work together for a complete security intelligence model.
episodes.title: Classify and Categorize Intrusions
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.260 --> 00:00:03.175
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:03.175 --> 00:00:04.751
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:04.751 --> 00:00:05.360
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:05.360 --> 00:00:10.846
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:10.846 --> 00:00:13.750
>> Hello, and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

6
00:00:13.750 --> 00:00:16.050
helping you learn wherever you go.

7
00:00:16.050 --> 00:00:20.820
I'm your host Zach Memos, and
this is CCNA SECOPS Classifying and

8
00:00:20.820 --> 00:00:23.350
Categorizing Intrusions,
the name of the episode.

9
00:00:23.350 --> 00:00:26.920
And our IT expert whose bringing us
the information we are looking for

10
00:00:26.920 --> 00:00:28.150
is Ronnie Wong.

11
00:00:28.150 --> 00:00:30.410
Ronnie, good to have you here,
and great to see you.

12
00:00:30.410 --> 00:00:33.505
>> Thank you for inviting me back
on the show as we continue on,

13
00:00:33.505 --> 00:00:35.261
in our CCNA SECOPS.

14
00:00:35.261 --> 00:00:40.200
We are now taking look, of course,
at this idea of classifying and

15
00:00:40.200 --> 00:00:42.750
categorizing intrusions.

16
00:00:42.750 --> 00:00:46.743
Now the issues that we have,
especially in dealing with intrusions,

17
00:00:46.743 --> 00:00:50.140
as an IT professional or
security professional is simple.

18
00:00:51.240 --> 00:00:55.110
Most of us like this idea
of protecting our systems,

19
00:00:55.110 --> 00:01:00.160
being relatively responsive when we
think about an intrusion happening.

20
00:01:00.160 --> 00:01:03.900
And when we do so,
we tend to react very quickly.

21
00:01:03.900 --> 00:01:06.540
And we tend to try and
fix everything very quickly,

22
00:01:06.540 --> 00:01:09.320
which is the way that we want it to be,
okay?

23
00:01:09.320 --> 00:01:10.300
But the problem is,

24
00:01:10.300 --> 00:01:14.910
after that intrusion is over, we may
not have a plan of action after that.

25
00:01:14.910 --> 00:01:16.910
Did we learn anything from it?

26
00:01:16.910 --> 00:01:18.990
Did we actually produce anything that,

27
00:01:18.990 --> 00:01:23.330
if I were to see this again, I would
be able to spot it much quicker, okay?

28
00:01:23.330 --> 00:01:26.180
So, instead what ends up
happening normally is simple.

29
00:01:26.180 --> 00:01:29.670
We stop the attack, we're kind of
grateful that we stopped the attack.

30
00:01:29.670 --> 00:01:32.540
We're kind of glad that we're
able to catch it very quickly.

31
00:01:32.540 --> 00:01:35.511
But now it happens again
when I'm off duty, and

32
00:01:35.511 --> 00:01:37.601
now somebody else has to stop it.

33
00:01:37.601 --> 00:01:39.224
I'm going,
why didn't they do what I would have done?

34
00:01:39.224 --> 00:01:42.992
And it's because we don't have
any real system to essentially

35
00:01:42.992 --> 00:01:47.130
help us to standardize within our
own companies a lot of times.

36
00:01:47.130 --> 00:01:50.210
And so, we don't have a formalized
process, we don't have a system.

37
00:01:50.210 --> 00:01:53.670
We don't have something in place that
allows us to be consistent across

38
00:01:53.670 --> 00:01:58.525
the board within our own organization
in terms of securities and operations.

39
00:01:58.525 --> 00:01:59.855
And that's why it's
actually important that

40
00:01:59.855 --> 00:02:01.505
we discuss what we're
about to talk about today.

41
00:02:01.505 --> 00:02:04.805
>> So there's a list that we can
actually refer to, right Ronnie?

42
00:02:04.805 --> 00:02:07.530
>> Yes, there is, there's actually
a couple of different things that we're

43
00:02:07.530 --> 00:02:09.705
gonna be referring to today.

44
00:02:09.705 --> 00:02:11.010
That is going to help us out.

45
00:02:11.010 --> 00:02:14.435
And not only is it pertinent,
of course, to your organization.

46
00:02:14.435 --> 00:02:17.810
As your organization continues to grow,
you're going to actually need to

47
00:02:17.810 --> 00:02:21.320
do something that we've had to
do here at ITProTV, as well,

48
00:02:21.320 --> 00:02:26.560
which is to start formalizing the way
that we handle things like intrusions and

49
00:02:26.560 --> 00:02:29.495
incidences and different things like that.

50
00:02:29.495 --> 00:02:31.475
So at the very beginning, let me tell you,

51
00:02:31.475 --> 00:02:35.075
Zach is one of our most recent
edutainers that's come onboard.

52
00:02:35.075 --> 00:02:36.645
But I was here from the very beginning.

53
00:02:36.645 --> 00:02:37.280
>> Yes, you were.

54
00:02:37.280 --> 00:02:40.455
[LAUGH]
>> So when we started ITProTv,

55
00:02:40.455 --> 00:02:43.995
or I shouldn't say we,
I was a part of the original team.

56
00:02:43.995 --> 00:02:47.455
But when it started, right,
it was really like, all right,

57
00:02:47.455 --> 00:02:49.485
what do we need to get started basically?

58
00:02:49.485 --> 00:02:51.990
And we just kind of did what we needed to.

59
00:02:51.990 --> 00:02:56.770
And we kind of went along and it was like,
well how do we stop intrusions?

60
00:02:56.770 --> 00:02:59.845
We can't say we'll implement this system,
we'll do that system.

61
00:02:59.845 --> 00:03:02.190
And it might have been between Don and

62
00:03:02.190 --> 00:03:05.720
I at that point there trying to go okay,
I'll do this part, Ronnie.

63
00:03:05.720 --> 00:03:06.935
You do this part, Ronnie.

64
00:03:06.935 --> 00:03:09.840
I'll make sure to double check on this,
and that was it.

65
00:03:09.840 --> 00:03:12.520
It was just kinda that
communicative process.

66
00:03:12.520 --> 00:03:15.413
Well now that we're continuing to grow,
and we're continuing to add on.

67
00:03:15.413 --> 00:03:19.480
And now we're actually getting to that
point where, we're kind of bulging at

68
00:03:19.480 --> 00:03:23.710
the seams to a point in terms of
infrastructure and what we need, okay?

69
00:03:23.710 --> 00:03:27.397
We now need a more formalized process,
because now that we're doing so

70
00:03:27.397 --> 00:03:30.110
many shows a day by comparison
to what we did before.

71
00:03:30.110 --> 00:03:33.110
And we actually have to produce so much.

72
00:03:33.110 --> 00:03:36.900
It's more difficult for me just to simply
stop what I'm doing in the middle of

73
00:03:36.900 --> 00:03:39.540
a show and go and check on something.

74
00:03:39.540 --> 00:03:43.310
And just say, hey, look,
we're noticing some strange activity here.

75
00:03:43.310 --> 00:03:47.230
It really needs to be a process to where
I can hand that off to somebody else,

76
00:03:47.230 --> 00:03:51.490
an infrastructure team,
maybe our own IT staff that actually says,

77
00:03:51.490 --> 00:03:54.020
we'll check on that,
Ronnie, you do your shows.

78
00:03:54.020 --> 00:03:56.920
And the only way for
us to that consistently and faithfully and

79
00:03:56.920 --> 00:03:58.860
make sure that it's done
the way that we want it to,

80
00:03:58.860 --> 00:04:01.230
is to have some type
of formalized process.

81
00:04:01.230 --> 00:04:05.210
Or to understand what has to
happen in every process, so

82
00:04:05.210 --> 00:04:07.600
we are consistent across the board.

83
00:04:07.600 --> 00:04:12.160
And that is when we can start talking
about the actions that need to be done.

84
00:04:12.160 --> 00:04:14.380
And what particular model or

85
00:04:14.380 --> 00:04:19.190
approach that we need to take when we
start dealing with things like intrusions.

86
00:04:19.190 --> 00:04:22.590
Now, in the realm of cyber security,

00:17:30.270 --> 00:17:33.110
And then realize,
you're pretty much the same way.

312
00:17:33.110 --> 00:17:36.410
Knowledge that you gain on the attack or
the attacker,

313
00:17:36.410 --> 00:17:41.410
okay, is actually going to
give you some timely defense.

314
00:17:41.410 --> 00:17:45.530
So not only can you actually take
a look at the intent here, but

315
00:17:45.530 --> 00:17:47.560
it may actually show you, hey,

316
00:17:47.560 --> 00:17:51.830
we're getting more of this activity now
that I'm starting to suspect something.

317
00:17:51.830 --> 00:17:56.540
And maybe even provide a timely defense,
and not only after the fact, okay?

318
00:17:56.540 --> 00:17:59.510
So the reconnaissance stage
where we acquire the target,

319
00:17:59.510 --> 00:18:01.030
you do have some things you can do.

320
00:18:01.030 --> 00:18:05.300
But at this point, there's nothing really
concrete except for you setting up and

321
00:18:05.300 --> 00:18:10.590
preparing for the fact that the attack is
possibly going to end up happening, okay?

322
00:18:10.590 --> 00:18:13.830
Now once we actually get through,
and once the attacker gets through

323
00:18:13.830 --> 00:18:17.400
with the reconnaissance, okay,
he doesn't attack right away.

324
00:18:17.400 --> 00:18:22.880
He actually does something that we call
weaponizing, okay, or weaponization.

325
00:18:22.880 --> 00:18:27.150
And this is weird because most of us go,
you're kind of using these kind of battle

326
00:18:27.150 --> 00:18:30.670
tactics here or this language that-
>> Cyber battle.

327
00:18:30.670 --> 00:18:32.590
>> Yeah, something like this we have.

328
00:18:32.590 --> 00:18:37.810
But the weaponization part is really
preparing for the battle, okay?

329
00:18:37.810 --> 00:18:42.380
So not every single type of military
charge just begins with, all right,

330
00:18:42.380 --> 00:18:44.420
there's the target, hit it, okay?

331
00:18:44.420 --> 00:18:47.140
At some point before
somebody said go ahead and

332
00:18:47.140 --> 00:18:51.000
run the attack, or
make the charge that you need to,

333
00:18:51.000 --> 00:18:55.310
somebody's decided what the ultimate
goal is for that particular attack.

334
00:18:55.310 --> 00:18:59.260
They've prepared, they've actually said,
what do we need to make the attack occur?

335
00:18:59.260 --> 00:19:00.560
Whatever it is, they planned it out.

336
00:19:00.560 --> 00:19:02.940
And you name it, that's what happens, too,

337
00:19:02.940 --> 00:19:06.280
when we start talking about
this idea of that intrusion.

338
00:19:06.280 --> 00:19:07.570
The attacker does the same thing.

339
00:19:07.570 --> 00:19:10.368
He prepares, plans, and stages the attack,

340
00:19:10.368 --> 00:19:13.321
ensures that he has the right equipment,
okay?

341
00:19:13.321 --> 00:19:16.330
And if he doesn't have the right
equipment, he gets it.

342
00:19:16.330 --> 00:19:20.180
So it may be where there's
a piece of malware out there

343
00:19:20.180 --> 00:19:23.920
that is a generalized piece of
malware that he can now take and

344
00:19:23.920 --> 00:19:27.940
go, I know if I kind of modify this
a little bit, it may help me to

345
00:19:27.940 --> 00:19:32.250
take advantage of this particular
vulnerability a little bit better, okay?

346
00:19:32.250 --> 00:19:37.388
So the weaponization also involves how
that delivery of the attack is going on,

347
00:19:37.388 --> 00:19:41.170
and usually it's some type of malware, so
that they can exploit the weakness that

348
00:19:41.170 --> 00:19:43.730
they found during the reconnaissance,
okay?

349
00:19:43.730 --> 00:19:48.470
So this weaponization is really more of
an important part than we think it may be.

350
00:19:48.470 --> 00:19:52.751
So the idea of discovering
reconnaissance is great, okay?

351
00:19:52.751 --> 00:19:54.721
It's something that we can try and do, but

352
00:19:54.721 --> 00:19:58.682
it doesn't necessarily mean that we'll
actually discover it a lot of times, okay?

353
00:19:58.682 --> 00:20:02.690
If we're vigilant about it, it means
we have a more likely chance to do so.

354
00:20:02.690 --> 00:20:07.190
But even by alerting someone that you are
more vigilant about it, you may again just

355
00:20:07.190 --> 00:20:12.540
stem the tide of someone attacking, or
at least that one individual attacking.

356
00:20:12.540 --> 00:20:14.970
But Zach, we've mentioned this before,

357
00:20:14.970 --> 00:20:19.032
that the issue that we have is not
that we can stop one attacker, okay?

358
00:20:19.032 --> 00:20:22.390
The issues that we actually have
to deal with is the very fact that

359
00:20:22.390 --> 00:20:25.640
there's an overwhelming number
of attackers versus defenders,

360
00:20:25.640 --> 00:20:29.010
okay, in terms of intrusions and
networks that go on.

361
00:20:29.010 --> 00:20:32.120
So it's not the very fact that you
can't stop a single attacker or

362
00:20:32.120 --> 00:20:33.420
even a few attackers.

363
00:20:33.420 --> 00:20:36.882
It's you can't stop the millions
of attacks that end up happening.

364
00:20:36.882 --> 00:20:40.820
Is your network able to actually withstand

365
00:20:40.820 --> 00:20:45.290
1,000 attacks per day, or
per hour, if it needs to?

366
00:20:45.290 --> 00:20:49.200
Well, most of us are probably gonna say
no, we don't actually know how to do that.

367
00:20:49.200 --> 00:20:50.130
But being able to go,

368
00:20:50.130 --> 00:20:53.630
all right, here's what we can do to do so,
is gonna help us out, all right?

369
00:20:53.630 --> 00:20:54.360
>> Perfect.
>> So

370
00:20:54.360 --> 00:20:58.450
what can we do in terms of weaponization
as a defender, then, okay?

371
00:20:58.450 --> 00:21:02.470
Well, as a defender, it means,
let me see if I can highlight this and

372
00:21:02.470 --> 00:21:06.170
move it over so we don't have
to kind of full screen too much.

373
00:21:06.170 --> 00:21:07.010
There we go.

374
00:21:07.010 --> 00:21:07.900
>> Perfect.

375
00:21:07.900 --> 00:21:11.884
>> All right, so as a defender,
first and foremost, we must look for

376
00:21:11.884 --> 00:21:13.820
clues as to the weaponization.

377
00:21:13.820 --> 00:21:15.610
Now what does that mean, okay?

378
00:21:15.610 --> 00:21:20.120
Well, it means you discover the same
thing that the attacker does.

379
00:21:20.120 --> 00:21:23.546
Once you understand your vulnerabilities
and your exploits, okay,

380
00:21:23.546 --> 00:21:26.635
you now need to actually figure
out that's a possible target.

381
00:21:26.635 --> 00:21:29.546
Once you understand what that target is,
okay,

382
00:21:29.546 --> 00:21:34.090
you might now be able to essentially
reverse engineer your way back to saying

383
00:21:34.090 --> 00:21:38.003
what attacks take advantage of
that particular vulnerability?

384
00:21:38.003 --> 00:21:41.332
But once you actually understand this,
the vulnerabilities, right, and

385
00:21:41.332 --> 00:21:44.723
you start to seal those things up,
harden those types of systems and do that.

386
00:21:44.723 --> 00:21:49.279
But then at the same time, you start
gaining more knowledge about the types of

387
00:21:49.279 --> 00:21:54.346
attacks that have gone on against those
particular types of vulnerabilities, too.

388
00:21:54.346 --> 00:21:55.972
So you have to look for clues, or

389
00:21:55.972 --> 00:21:59.062
artifacts, that are actually
part of that weaponization.

390
00:21:59.062 --> 00:22:02.232
>> Yeah, because your defense
shouldn't be a one size fits all.

391
00:22:02.232 --> 00:22:04.143
>> Right.
>> It's going to depend on what

392
00:22:04.143 --> 00:22:06.010
the situation calls for.

393
00:22:06.010 --> 00:22:08.110
I mean, right off the top of my head,
I'm thinking,

394
00:22:08.110 --> 00:22:11.240
well, having a honeypot or
maybe a bunch of honeypots.

395
00:22:11.240 --> 00:22:13.350
But that might not be the answer for
everything.

396
00:22:13.350 --> 00:22:16.515
>> Yeah, there's no doubt that we
can't think about it all, okay?

397
00:22:16.515 --> 00:22:20.510
But the very fact is we have to
be able to prepare for something.

398
00:22:20.510 --> 00:22:24.216
So here, thinking about it in this way,
where we kind of just go, all right,

399
00:22:24.216 --> 00:22:26.911
let's examine it from
the standpoint of the attacker.

400
00:22:26.911 --> 00:22:29.955
If we find those vulnerabilities,
we're not gonna take advantage of it,

401
00:22:29.955 --> 00:22:31.370
we're gonna seal that up, okay?

402
00:22:31.370 --> 00:22:34.935
And then we're gonna actually take
a look at how those attacks work, and

403
00:22:34.935 --> 00:22:36.695
then match it against our systems.

404
00:22:36.695 --> 00:22:41.385
And go, well, where would that work
against my network or my computer system,

405
00:22:41.385 --> 00:22:46.075
whatever it might be, to help prepare for
this particular type of battle here?

406
00:22:46.075 --> 00:22:47.803
Now up to this point, okay,

407
00:22:47.803 --> 00:22:52.850
it really is not something that we
are countermanding against the attack.

408
00:22:52.850 --> 00:22:55.740
Everything that we're doing, essentially,
is a chess move at this point, right?

409
00:22:55.740 --> 00:22:57.690
>> Right.
>> The reconnaissance does one thing.

410
00:22:57.690 --> 00:23:00.826
We essentially kind of react and
we observe what's going on.

411
00:23:00.826 --> 00:23:02.637
And weaponization is just preparation.

412
00:23:02.637 --> 00:23:07.473
We're setting up our pieces,
hopefully in a strong defense order, so

413
00:23:07.473 --> 00:23:12.725
that we can take advantage or we can
defend against what attacks come, okay?

414
00:23:12.725 --> 00:23:18.804
But the first time that we really do
get to kind of defend against anything,

415
00:23:18.804 --> 00:23:25.188
okay, is when the attacker actually
delivers whatever the attack is, okay?

416
00:23:25.188 --> 00:23:30.094
So the delivery concept is how in
the world do we get our attack to run

417
00:23:30.094 --> 00:23:34.306
on that system, or
to get our attack inside of a network.

418
00:23:34.306 --> 00:23:36.104
Well, believe it or not, Zach,

419
00:23:36.104 --> 00:23:39.849
the most common of these all deal
around social engineering, okay?

420
00:23:39.849 --> 00:23:44.460
And that means manipulating you and
me is still the most common way.

421
00:23:44.460 --> 00:23:46.200
So-
>> Opening e-mails?

422
00:23:46.200 --> 00:23:47.279
>> Yeah, so there it is.

423
00:23:47.279 --> 00:23:50.950
E-mail attachments, phishing
websites that offer you, of course,

00:23:50.950 --> 00:23:54.694
deals that you can't turn down, and
you go, I've gotta find that one.

425
00:23:54.694 --> 00:23:56.241

00:23:56.241 --> 00:23:59.258
>> Yeah.

427
00:23:59.258 --> 00:23:59.960
>> This is from Amazon.

428
00:23:59.960 --> 00:24:01.093
And you go, Amazon?

429
00:24:01.093 --> 00:24:02.971
Well, I just ordered He's ordered

00:24:02.971 --> 00:24:05.184
>> Right, yeah and so
you're seeing that too.

431
00:24:05.184 --> 00:24:10.550
And even still,
USB keys left in conspicuous locations.

432
00:24:10.550 --> 00:24:12.650
Now this is one that's
actually fairly easy.

433
00:24:12.650 --> 00:24:18.460
And we've seen it done over and over again
where people do just take USB keys and

434
00:24:18.460 --> 00:24:22.650
they kind of leave them in conspicuous
locations and what does the individual do?

435
00:24:22.650 --> 00:24:24.340
They go, I wonder what's on here?

436
00:24:24.340 --> 00:24:28.400
They plug it right into their computer
systems without ever knowing,

437
00:24:28.400 --> 00:24:32.660
without ever checking, without ever
thinking which is the hard part here

438
00:24:32.660 --> 00:24:35.540
that they shouldn't do anything like,
okay.

439
00:24:35.540 --> 00:24:38.440
So in other words if you don't where
it's been, it's probably not safe for

440
00:24:38.440 --> 00:24:40.540
you to plug it into your systems.

441
00:24:40.540 --> 00:24:44.120
Though it's probably not a good thing ever
for you to actually do anything like that.

442
00:24:44.120 --> 00:24:45.566
It's still very complicated.
>> There was this TV show where

00:24:45.566 --> 00:24:46.117
they left a CD.

00:24:46.117 --> 00:24:46.894
>> Yes.

445
00:24:46.894 --> 00:24:49.662
>> They put the CD in the system,

00:24:49.662 --> 00:24:50.210

00:24:50.210 --> 00:24:53.567
>> It was like material that was recorded

448
00:24:53.567 --> 00:24:54.943
>> Right.
>> I mean, they really,

00:24:54.943 --> 00:24:56.076
they researched this.

450
00:24:56.076 --> 00:24:57.322
>> Yeah.
>> They knew who they were targeting.

451
00:24:57.322 --> 00:24:58.436
They put it in the system.

452
00:24:58.436 --> 00:24:59.460
And infected everything.

453
00:24:59.460 --> 00:25:00.530
>> That's exactly right, and

00:25:00.530 --> 00:25:04.250
that's what happens a lot of times
is that people are just curious.

455
00:25:04.250 --> 00:25:05.340
So why not?

456
00:25:05.340 --> 00:25:06.980
Well, what do we do?

457
00:25:06.980 --> 00:25:08.880
Well, it's fairly simple here.

00:25:08.880 --> 00:25:12.180
Notice it's really about blocking and
tackling at this point, okay?

00:25:12.180 --> 00:25:15.280
You go back to the basics

00:25:15.280 --> 00:25:19.800
Whatever your defense plan was at the

00:25:19.800 --> 00:25:22.790
in the end of this,
right what we want is simple.

462
00:25:22.790 --> 00:25:26.670
We wanna block,
we wanna tackle what we have left here.

00:25:26.670 --> 00:25:28.200
We block by doing what?

464
00:25:28.200 --> 00:25:30.930
By saying hey let's do some training here.

465
00:25:30.930 --> 00:25:34.476
Don't open up attachments that you're not
expecting from someone you don't know.

466
00:25:34.476 --> 00:25:35.410
>> [LAUGH] It's basic but yeah, mm-mm.

467
00:25:35.410 --> 00:25:36.363
>> Yeah, okay?

468
00:25:36.363 --> 00:25:41.700
USB keys that are left around, don't
plug that into your computer at work.

469
00:25:41.700 --> 00:25:42.320
Do not.

470
00:25:42.320 --> 00:25:44.550
Plug it in your own machine at home
if you want, no don't do that either.

471
00:25:44.550 --> 00:25:47.377
>> No, no, no, no.
>> Yeah, but don't plug it here at work.

472
00:25:47.377 --> 00:25:50.197
>> [LAUGH]
>> Do not go to sites that not authorized

00:25:50.197 --> 00:25:53.240
by you when you're working
with your company.

474
00:25:53.240 --> 00:25:54.150
To go to those sites.

475
00:25:54.150 --> 00:25:58.680
Don't click on links from emails unless
you're expecting it from a particular

00:25:58.680 --> 00:26:02.500

00:26:02.500 --> 00:26:05.760
If you're not sure what that link in that

00:26:05.760 --> 00:26:09.680
over to the link and verify that it's

00:26:09.680 --> 00:26:12.101
If all of a sudden,

actually you go I don't even know what

00:26:15.696 --> 00:26:17.823
Just get rid of it, don't do that at all.

482
00:26:17.823 --> 00:26:22.873
But this is kinda really the first
real time that we actually

00:26:22.873 --> 00:26:30.290
have the ability to stop the attacker

484
00:26:30.290 --> 00:26:34.770
So before, right We can kind of look and

00:26:34.770 --> 00:26:38.480
we're kinda moving our chess pieces in

00:26:38.480 --> 00:26:40.150
This time though,

00:26:43.405 --> 00:26:46.420
So this is really the first

00:26:46.420 --> 00:26:49.930
And where we block and

We've just hit this idea

So, Zack, it looks like we're gonna

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe the use of the Diamond Model of Intrusion and how it helps us to handle events.  They also show how the Kill Chain and Diamond Model work together for a complete security intelligence model.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie take some time to look at how NIST.SP800-61 r2 incident handling process to an incident event. They break down the process and show recommended process for incident handling
episodes.title: Apply NIST.SP800-61 r2 To Events

So I don't want to read thing, cuz

That this guide is really designed to

Notice that under A2 in Scenarios,

So if you are actually facing

If you actually want to take a look at

00:07:25.890 --> 00:07:27.450
Here's another scenario for

It doesn't just say,

Here it is, compromised database server,

Disappearing host that

Telecommuting compromises Anonymous

unknown wireless access points,
rogue access points that end up appearing.

149
00:08:07.350 --> 00:08:09.310
Well, that's quite a few scenarios.

150
00:08:09.310 --> 00:08:10.360
>> But it's very comprehensive.

00:08:10.360 --> 00:08:15.470
>> Yeah, that you can at least walk

And that depends on your organization.

00:08:20.490 --> 00:08:24.150
But doing this in terms of game play,

00:08:24.150 --> 00:08:28.640
the idea of actually running through it as

156
00:08:28.640 --> 00:08:33.530
you good thought processes as you develop

157
00:08:33.530 --> 00:08:38.550
So let's go back and see what it is

158
00:08:38.550 --> 00:08:40.460
So when we start off, right?

159
00:08:40.460 --> 00:08:43.980
And we start taking at whatever

00:08:43.980 --> 00:08:47.795
We always want to make sure that we walk
through those steps according to the NIST
