00:08:47.795 --> 00:08:49.130
document here.

162
00:08:49.130 --> 00:08:51.260
Of what needs to happen, okay?

163
00:08:51.260 --> 00:08:55.060
Well, there's always this idea
of preparation time, okay?

164
00:08:55.060 --> 00:08:56.810
Detection and analysis, okay?

165
00:08:56.810 --> 00:09:00.150
Each one of these, containment,
eradication and recovery, and

166
00:09:00.150 --> 00:09:02.448
of course, post-incident activity here.

167
00:09:02.448 --> 00:09:03.030
>> Mm-hm.
>> And

168
00:09:03.030 --> 00:09:05.820
let's just take a look at a sampling
of some of these questions.

169
00:09:05.820 --> 00:09:07.330
They help us out a little bit.

170
00:09:07.330 --> 00:09:12.145
So if I thought about that idea of
a compromised server at some point,

171
00:09:12.145 --> 00:09:13.960
okay, well here it is.

172
00:09:13.960 --> 00:09:16.790
Would the organization consider
the activity to be an incident?

173
00:09:16.790 --> 00:09:23.270
If so, what are the policies and what
policies are violated during this action?

174
00:09:23.270 --> 00:09:26.035
They're telling you to think
about it in these terms, right?

175
00:09:26.035 --> 00:09:28.950
>> Mm-hm.
>> That, hey, how do we handle this?

176
00:09:28.950 --> 00:09:31.670
What is the policy for
us actually dealing with it?

177
00:09:31.670 --> 00:09:36.250
Does the policy state that there's
a particular order that we have to follow?

178
00:09:36.250 --> 00:09:38.460
People or
stakeholders that we have to contact.

179
00:09:38.460 --> 00:09:41.345
Whatever it might be,
we have to follow those policies.

180
00:09:41.345 --> 00:09:42.070
>> Mm-hm.
>> And

181
00:09:42.070 --> 00:09:44.670
you think about that a lot of times for
technicians.

182
00:09:44.670 --> 00:09:47.030
We normally don't think
about the idea of policy.

183
00:09:47.030 --> 00:09:50.730
So here is giving us this idea that, hey,
one of the thing you may actually wanna do

184
00:09:50.730 --> 00:09:55.420
is figure out what policies may validate
if you are incurring something like this.

185
00:09:55.420 --> 00:09:57.850
It's actually a good thing to think about,
okay?

186
00:09:57.850 --> 00:10:00.940
Secondly, what measures
are actually counteractive,

187
00:10:00.940 --> 00:10:03.020
okay, to what we're actually doing.

188
00:10:03.020 --> 00:10:03.640
Okay.

189
00:10:03.640 --> 00:10:05.420
So, in other,
not counteractive to what we're doing,

190
00:10:05.420 --> 00:10:08.510
but counteractive to the attack or
to the incident that we're handling.

191
00:10:08.510 --> 00:10:09.270
Okay.
>> Mm-hm.

192
00:10:09.270 --> 00:10:12.350
>> So do we have anything in place
to address this writ, and if we do,

193
00:10:12.350 --> 00:10:14.031
do we know what those elements are.

194
00:10:14.031 --> 00:10:16.508
Most of the time if you work for
a large organization,

195
00:10:16.508 --> 00:10:19.758
you may not have a comprehensive
understanding of what elements are in

196
00:10:19.758 --> 00:10:23.360
place to handle certain types of
scenarios that end up happening.

197
00:10:23.360 --> 00:10:27.110
But it is something that if you're part
of an instant response team though that

198
00:10:27.110 --> 00:10:30.480
you may actually choose to learn
a little bit more about it.

199
00:10:30.480 --> 00:10:33.870
And this preparation time is also
what would help you to do that

200
00:10:33.870 --> 00:10:35.520
as you're handling an incident, or

201
00:10:35.520 --> 00:10:41.260
at least going over it in the idea of some
type of scenario game play to doing this.

202
00:10:41.260 --> 00:10:45.130
Now, if you are actually having to
do this when it happens, right,

203
00:10:45.130 --> 00:10:50.470
this becomes a little
bit more time sensitive.

204
00:10:50.470 --> 00:10:53.680
In other words, you can't just take
all the time you've gotta just find

205
00:10:53.680 --> 00:10:55.250
the information out quickly.

206
00:10:55.250 --> 00:10:57.030
But if you have to, you have to.

207
00:10:57.030 --> 00:10:59.860
Make sure you document
everything because in the end,

208
00:10:59.860 --> 00:11:05.200
it is gonna be something that they'll want
to have some post-incident activity on.

209
00:11:05.200 --> 00:11:08.550
Notice the other thing here,
detection and analysis as well.

210
00:11:08.550 --> 00:11:13.175
Did we actually find out what precursors
the event actually showed us?

211
00:11:13.175 --> 00:11:15.040
Yeah, is there anything like that?

212
00:11:15.040 --> 00:11:19.730
Indicators of the incident that the,
might the organization detect.

213
00:11:19.730 --> 00:11:22.790
So did we actually find out any indicators
that might have actually led us,

214
00:11:22.790 --> 00:11:23.750
did we just ignore it?

215
00:11:23.750 --> 00:11:25.410
Did we figure something out here?

216
00:11:25.410 --> 00:11:27.620
Any tools that we might need?

217
00:11:27.620 --> 00:11:31.390
Additional response team analysis,
okay, that validate this.

218
00:11:31.390 --> 00:11:35.950
You need it, it actually tells us,
again, what particular situation and

219
00:11:35.950 --> 00:11:41.970
tools that we might actually end up
considering here as we walk through this.

220
00:11:41.970 --> 00:11:45.040
How would the incident response team
analyze and validate the incident?

221
00:11:45.040 --> 00:11:47.570
What personnel would be involved?

222
00:11:47.570 --> 00:11:49.170
Do you have enough resources?

223
00:11:49.170 --> 00:11:52.378
Okay, especially on people that you need.

224
00:11:52.378 --> 00:11:56.470
How would a team prioritize the handling?

225
00:11:56.470 --> 00:12:01.450
Prioritization is big because you may have
multiple instances at the same time, but

226
00:12:01.450 --> 00:12:03.690
what if you only have one security team,
okay?

227
00:12:03.690 --> 00:12:08.480
And you only have one team responding,
how do you prioritize the event itself?

228
00:12:08.480 --> 00:12:10.270
Or do you not prioritize it and

229
00:12:10.270 --> 00:12:14.515
you split everybody off to try and
handle the events that go on, okay.

230
00:12:14.515 --> 00:12:20.290
But all these are actually very good
types of gamification things that you can

231
00:12:20.290 --> 00:12:26.470
think about and even go through, the
forest scenario ends up happening, okay?

232
00:12:26.470 --> 00:12:30.820
Notice here in containment,
eradication and recovery, okay.

233
00:12:30.820 --> 00:12:35.430
This is where you start to see,
a little bit more action here, okay?

234
00:12:35.430 --> 00:12:40.320
Is there a strategy that the organization
should take to contain the incident?

235
00:12:40.320 --> 00:12:43.160
This is where its actually
a little bit more critical.

236
00:12:43.160 --> 00:12:47.110
Most of the time especially in a small
company, there is no strategy except for

237
00:12:47.110 --> 00:12:48.720
one, stop it.

238
00:12:48.720 --> 00:12:52.190
Okay, contain it, do whatever rules
you have to, or get rid of it, okay?

239
00:12:52.190 --> 00:12:55.400
That is pretty much the only
strategy that's in place.

240
00:12:55.400 --> 00:12:59.320
Well, that itself is not really
a strategy as much as its just saying,

241
00:12:59.320 --> 00:13:02.610
throw everything that you can,
add it until it stops, okay?

242
00:13:03.640 --> 00:13:06.810
And I guess you could
consider that a strategy.

243
00:13:06.810 --> 00:13:10.060
But if you stopped it one time and
you don't know which of those things

244
00:13:10.060 --> 00:13:13.820
actually stopped it, well, what prevents
an attacker from trying it again?

245
00:13:13.820 --> 00:13:19.340
And you still have to throw everything
at it before it actually stops again.

246
00:13:19.340 --> 00:13:21.230
Well, that means you haven't
learned anything from it.

247
00:13:21.230 --> 00:13:24.130
You haven't figured out what
it is that really stopped it.

248
00:13:24.130 --> 00:13:26.850
You're just hoping that one of
those things ends up happening.

249
00:13:26.850 --> 00:13:29.950
So that happens to me
a lot just in my own help.

250
00:13:29.950 --> 00:13:33.380
>> You don't want to be throwing some
forensic mud up against the side of a barn

251
00:13:33.380 --> 00:13:35.170
and hoping something will stick, right?

252
00:13:35.170 --> 00:13:35.970
>> Yeah, I know.

253
00:13:35.970 --> 00:13:38.380
But that's what we hope for
a lot of times, right?

254
00:13:38.380 --> 00:13:39.780
>> Yeah.
>> Is that we've done this, this,

255
00:13:39.780 --> 00:13:40.770
this, this, this.

256
00:13:40.770 --> 00:13:42.150
But which one stopped it?

257
00:13:42.150 --> 00:13:42.980
One of those, yeah.

258
00:13:42.980 --> 00:13:45.580
Yeah, one of those actually stopped it.

259
00:13:45.580 --> 00:13:48.020
Well, how does that help
you as an organization?

260
00:13:48.020 --> 00:13:48.880
It really doesn't.

261
00:13:48.880 --> 00:13:51.600
So trying to figure stuff like that out

262
00:13:51.600 --> 00:13:56.310
really comes when you do have a strategy
that's in place to make that happen, okay?

263
00:13:57.650 --> 00:14:01.840
What is the ultimate end result
if you cannot get it contained?

264
00:14:01.840 --> 00:14:05.860
Think about the end result scenario,
is what you want to be able to do as well.

265
00:14:05.860 --> 00:14:06.440
>> End game.

266
00:14:06.440 --> 00:14:09.530
>> Yep, the end game and
what might end up happening.

267
00:14:09.530 --> 00:14:12.440
Do you have the right tools,
once again, to respond to this?

268
00:14:12.440 --> 00:14:14.330
You may find out that you don't, okay?

269
00:14:14.330 --> 00:14:16.935
And that means, well, you have to
actually get the right tools in place.

270
00:14:16.935 --> 00:14:19.180
>> Mm-hm.
>> Same thing with the personnel and

271
00:14:19.180 --> 00:14:20.540
the involvement here.

272
00:14:20.540 --> 00:14:24.430
So these two steps are really
very active in what they do.

273
00:14:24.430 --> 00:14:27.910
The detection and analysis as well
as the containment eradication and

274
00:14:27.910 --> 00:14:32.520
recovery, they may require more resources
than we have at hand at the point.

275
00:14:32.520 --> 00:14:37.250
They may require more or different people
with different skill sets to come in and

276
00:14:37.250 --> 00:14:41.920
help us to determine whether or not we're
actually headed in the right direction.

277
00:14:41.920 --> 00:14:45.350
If all of us aren't sure, then somebody
else needs to able to step in and

278
00:14:45.350 --> 00:14:47.560
go, here's what needs to be done next.

279
00:14:47.560 --> 00:14:51.670
But following this guideline can at
least help you to get to that point

280
00:14:51.670 --> 00:14:54.720
where you realize,
I'm in over my head, okay, so

281
00:14:54.720 --> 00:14:59.520
that is a big part of understanding
that aspect of it as well, okay?

282
00:15:00.900 --> 00:15:01.470
All right.

283
00:15:01.470 --> 00:15:05.930
What sources of evidence, if any,
should an organization acquire?

284
00:15:05.930 --> 00:15:07.200
How would the evidence be acquired?

285
00:15:07.200 --> 00:15:08.140
Where would it be stored?

286
00:15:08.140 --> 00:15:09.830
How long should it be retained?

287
00:15:09.830 --> 00:15:13.520
This goes back, once we start getting
into the evidence part, right,

288
00:15:13.520 --> 00:15:16.510
this goes back to the nature of forensics.

289
00:15:16.510 --> 00:15:21.393
So if we are now talking about that
idea of containment, eradication, and

290
00:15:21.393 --> 00:15:26.508
recovery, and we are gonna be prosecuting
all of these events that happened,

291
00:15:26.508 --> 00:15:29.627
we have to also think about this as well,
okay?

292
00:15:29.627 --> 00:15:33.383
So if we know that that's part
of the strategy at the end,

293
00:15:33.383 --> 00:15:36.357
is not only to stop it but
to actually learn and

294
00:15:36.357 --> 00:15:41.470
figure out what tools stopped it to try
this particular methodology to do so.

295
00:15:41.470 --> 00:15:45.130
And in the end, the goal and
result is not just to stop it but

296
00:15:45.130 --> 00:15:49.850
to be able to prosecute or
to be able to have evidence.

297
00:15:49.850 --> 00:15:53.800
So that in the future if a case is brought
against the attacker then we have that.

298
00:15:53.800 --> 00:15:56.426
We also have to think of place of storage.

299
00:15:56.426 --> 00:15:58.031
Where are we storing that?

300
00:15:58.031 --> 00:16:00.212
How long is it gonna be stored for?

301
00:16:00.212 --> 00:16:03.159
How do we actually protect that
information for future use,

302
00:16:03.159 --> 00:16:04.270
whatever it might be?

303
00:16:04.270 --> 00:16:06.626
This is where you might also have
to go into law enforcement and

304
00:16:06.626 --> 00:16:08.135
ask how long should we keep this stuff?

305
00:16:08.135 --> 00:16:11.090
And actually figure all that out as well.

306
00:16:13.140 --> 00:16:16.950
This other part here,
Post-Incident Activity.

307
00:16:16.950 --> 00:16:20.800
Who should attend the lessons learned
meeting regarding this incident?

308
00:16:20.800 --> 00:16:24.240
This was actually a little bit more
generalized than you believe, and

309
00:16:24.240 --> 00:16:29.410
that's because it's not only the security
team that's responding to these instances

310
00:16:29.410 --> 00:16:34.380
that really need to know about,
of course, the overall incident itself.

311
00:16:34.380 --> 00:16:38.310
Usually, there has to be, of course,
some level of education or

312
00:16:38.310 --> 00:16:41.450
some level of information
that gets passed out.

313
00:16:41.450 --> 00:16:45.220
It doesn't mean that everybody
needs to know everything, okay?

314
00:16:45.220 --> 00:16:48.960
But it does actually give you
a little bit of an example here,

315
00:16:48.960 --> 00:16:53.160
that maybe on the technical side,
your internal response team

316
00:16:53.160 --> 00:16:57.100
does need to know all of the details and
elements of what happened.

317
00:16:57.100 --> 00:17:01.434
But maybe the manager just needs to know
that not only did we know exactly what

318
00:17:01.434 --> 00:17:04.017
happened, this is how we stopped it, okay?

319
00:17:04.017 --> 00:17:06.202
This is how long it took us to stop it.

320
00:17:06.202 --> 00:17:07.842
This is what would have made it faster.

321
00:17:07.842 --> 00:17:11.766
Then the manager could take that to
somebody that makes decisions in terms of

322
00:17:11.766 --> 00:17:12.757
spending, okay?

323
00:17:12.757 --> 00:17:17.820
And then they actually might just need
to know, here's what I need to know.

324
00:17:17.820 --> 00:17:18.452
Is this gonna happen again?

325
00:17:18.452 --> 00:17:21.340
And the manager says, well, it can.

326
00:17:21.340 --> 00:17:22.746
Here's what would actually
help us to prevent this.

327
00:17:22.746 --> 00:17:26.990
Once again,
it's still the information that gets out.

328
00:17:26.990 --> 00:17:30.230
But notice, everybody might actually
have a piece of that information.

329
00:17:30.230 --> 00:17:33.920
Somebody else just working inside the
company might just need to know, yes, and

330
00:17:33.920 --> 00:17:35.330
this didn't happen, okay?

331
00:17:35.330 --> 00:17:39.732
Yes, we were able to successfully stop it,
okay, and that might be enough.

332
00:17:39.732 --> 00:17:42.210
But whatever it might be, right?

333
00:17:42.210 --> 00:17:45.560
We want to make sure that we understand
that we have lessons learned,

334
00:17:45.560 --> 00:17:47.330
that everybody might need to attend.

335
00:17:47.330 --> 00:17:51.650
We might find out that it actually
happened from the very fact that

336
00:17:51.650 --> 00:17:56.410
someone internal to the organization got
socially engineered at some point here.

337
00:17:56.410 --> 00:17:58.825
And that's something else we might
actually have to talk about about as well,

338
00:17:58.825 --> 00:18:00.100
in terms of training.

339
00:18:00.100 --> 00:18:02.610
>> Mm-hm, those who forget
the past are doomed to repeat it.

340
00:18:02.610 --> 00:18:04.750
>> That is true, okay?

341
00:18:04.750 --> 00:18:08.950
What could be done to prevent similar
incidences from occurring into the future?

342
00:18:08.950 --> 00:18:12.690
This is where that training comes in,
the tools, you name it.

343
00:18:12.690 --> 00:18:14.290
Whatever it might be,

344
00:18:14.290 --> 00:18:19.080
you always have to also think about
the future events from happening as well.

345
00:18:19.080 --> 00:18:23.780
And then the improvements of
what you can do to detect it.

346
00:18:23.780 --> 00:18:25.350
So detection is kind of the key.

347
00:18:25.350 --> 00:18:28.160
Now just when you think you're done,
there's actually

348
00:18:28.160 --> 00:18:31.250
a different general question that
you might have to think about.

349
00:18:31.250 --> 00:18:35.210
It doesn't mean you go through every
single one of them, but if you need to,

350
00:18:35.210 --> 00:18:38.560
you definitely want to here.

351
00:18:38.560 --> 00:18:42.160
So how many incident response team members
would participate in the handling?

352
00:18:42.160 --> 00:18:44.525
That's a big important question
in terms of resources.

353
00:18:44.525 --> 00:18:48.813
And the way that you do it is by
prioritizing every single instance that

354
00:18:48.813 --> 00:18:50.490
ends up happening, so

355
00:18:50.490 --> 00:18:55.520
you assign the proper amount of resources
to handle the event that goes on, okay?

356
00:18:55.520 --> 00:19:00.750
Besides the instant response team, what
groups within the organization would be

357
00:19:00.750 --> 00:19:04.370
responsible, okay, or
would be involved in handling it?

358
00:19:04.370 --> 00:19:05.790
To which external parties?

359
00:19:05.790 --> 00:19:08.660
Now you might be wondering
what is this about?

360
00:19:08.660 --> 00:19:12.650
Well, remember that a company really
hardly stands alone any more, okay?

361
00:19:12.650 --> 00:19:15.550
So some companies,
they can be internal all by themselves.

362
00:19:15.550 --> 00:19:20.090
But if your company also has,
let's say part of their infrastructure in

363
00:19:20.090 --> 00:19:23.830
the cloud as well as on premises there,
remember that you're

364
00:19:23.830 --> 00:19:28.610
teaming up with that organization that
is providing your cloud services.

365
00:19:28.610 --> 00:19:33.580
You might need to know exactly and report
to them what would have actually happened

366
00:19:33.580 --> 00:19:36.950
here, and what information you need
to share with them as well, okay?

367
00:19:36.950 --> 00:19:41.050
So it all does actually
have to take place.

368
00:19:41.050 --> 00:19:43.910
And you really do have to think about

369
00:19:43.910 --> 00:19:48.600
the idea of what these questions really
do give you to handle the incident.

370
00:19:48.600 --> 00:19:51.500
And then from that point,
that's where each scenario,

371
00:19:51.500 --> 00:19:55.580
right, can give you a little bit
more detail and even more questions

372
00:19:55.580 --> 00:20:00.880
to help you to focus in on different
aspects of the attack, okay?

373
00:20:00.880 --> 00:20:02.000
Now I told you,

374
00:20:02.000 --> 00:20:05.170
you don't have to actually follow
every single one of these questions.

375
00:20:05.170 --> 00:20:08.630
But if you do,
it's a more comprehensive result

376
00:20:08.630 --> 00:20:12.770
that you'll end up getting from instant
handling than you would if you try and

377
00:20:12.770 --> 00:20:15.430
pick and
choose which ones you want at the time.

378
00:20:15.430 --> 00:20:18.410
So doing it at the beginning and
then figuring out the way that your

379
00:20:18.410 --> 00:20:22.000
organization is gonna do
it is really kind of key.

380
00:20:22.000 --> 00:20:25.640
Then you'll get a system together and
a particular process together, and

381
00:20:25.640 --> 00:20:27.570
that working the way that we want to.

382
00:20:27.570 --> 00:20:30.700
And once that's done,
it'll be a more efficient, and

383
00:20:30.700 --> 00:20:33.900
you'll actually have a more
experienced team that has now even

384
00:20:33.900 --> 00:20:37.770
thought about the process of those
different scenarios we've talked about.

385
00:20:37.770 --> 00:20:40.477
And now they have a standard
guide to help them through it,

386
00:20:40.477 --> 00:20:42.921
regardless of who's actually on your team,
okay?

387
00:20:42.921 --> 00:20:45.080
And that's what really helps.

388
00:20:45.080 --> 00:20:48.594
When you're no longer dependent on
that one particular person that knows

389
00:20:48.594 --> 00:20:52.561
everything, okay, and there are people
in organizations that know everything,

390
00:20:52.561 --> 00:20:53.574
which is great.

391
00:20:53.574 --> 00:20:54.355
>> The know it alls.

392
00:20:54.355 --> 00:20:57.380
>> Yeah, well,
it's just the nature of experience, right?

393
00:20:57.380 --> 00:20:58.138
>> Well, certainly.

394
00:20:58.138 --> 00:21:02.002
>> Yeah, and if you hire a younger team or
a new team that is just fitting together,

395
00:21:02.002 --> 00:21:05.925
and that experienced person goes on
vacation, and an incident happens, well,

396
00:21:05.925 --> 00:21:07.400
do you call that person back?

397
00:21:07.400 --> 00:21:08.970
Well, most of us would, okay?

398
00:21:08.970 --> 00:21:11.811
You go, let me just get so and so
on the phone, and there we are.

399
00:21:11.811 --> 00:21:14.030
We're back in business.

400
00:21:14.030 --> 00:21:17.880
Well, that can be done, but
what we want is we wanna develop a team.

401
00:21:17.880 --> 00:21:20.540
>> A team, yes.
>> We wanna develop the skills in that

402
00:21:20.540 --> 00:21:24.200
team, to really consider how
to handle these incidences.

403
00:21:24.200 --> 00:21:28.340
And then whoever comes in, they know
exactly where they are in the process of

404
00:21:28.340 --> 00:21:31.642
doing this event handling, and
that's what we also wanna see.

405
00:21:31.642 --> 00:21:37.160
So by following this document and taking
a look at it, we can now apply those steps

406
00:21:37.160 --> 00:21:43.320
and those questions about every event,
which I can't say right now.

407
00:21:43.320 --> 00:21:47.432
Every event that happens, and then we'll
see that it'll actually give us a more

408
00:21:47.432 --> 00:21:51.196
comprehensive and a fuller approach
to the way that we handle instances.

409
00:21:51.196 --> 00:21:57.080
>> So applying NIST.SP.800-61 r2
to events, and a great episode.

410
00:21:57.080 --> 00:21:59.496
And but better still,
make sure you read that document.

411
00:21:59.496 --> 00:22:02.260
You're gonna have to, and
it's very important for the exam.

412
00:22:02.260 --> 00:22:07.250
Also important, watch everything, all
the episodes in the CCNA SECOPS series,

413
00:22:07.250 --> 00:22:08.430
and go to our course library.

414
00:22:08.430 --> 00:22:12.590
There's hundreds of videos there,
all designed to help you go further.

415
00:22:12.590 --> 00:22:13.933
And thank you for watching ITProTV.

416
00:22:13.933 --> 00:22:15.471
Tell everybody you know about ITProTV.

417
00:22:15.471 --> 00:22:17.070
They'll be glad you did.

418
00:22:17.070 --> 00:22:17.760
Thanks for watching.

419
00:22:17.760 --> 00:22:18.500
I'm Zach Memos.

420
00:22:18.500 --> 00:22:19.270
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

421
00:22:19.270 --> 00:22:20.042
>> And we will see you soon.

422
00:22:20.042 --> 00:22:27.961
[MUSIC]

423
00:22:27.961 --> 00:22:30.449
>> Thank you for watching ITProTV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie describe Evidence Handling as documented in NIST SP800-86. They explore it's importance and key in forensics.
episodes.title: NIST SP800-86 Evidence Handling
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:02.941
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host Don Pezet.

2
00:00:02.941 --> 00:00:06.380
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:06.380 --> 00:00:08.248
[MUSIC]

4
00:00:08.248 --> 00:00:12.028
>> You're watching ITProTV.

5
00:00:12.028 --> 00:00:15.642
>> Hello, and thank you for
joining us on ITProTV,

6
00:00:15.642 --> 00:00:19.035
I'm your host Zach Memos for CCNA SecOps.

7
00:00:19.035 --> 00:00:22.725
And with me is Ronnie Wong, and we're
gonna be talking about evidence handling.

8
00:00:22.725 --> 00:00:24.470
Ronnie I'm so
excited to have you hear and I'm so

9
00:00:24.470 --> 00:00:25.840
excited to be working with you again.

10
00:00:25.840 --> 00:00:29.368
>> Well Zach, thank you again for
having me back on the show,

11
00:00:29.368 --> 00:00:32.037
as we continue on in
our SecOps series here.

12
00:00:32.037 --> 00:00:36.257
Remember that we've actually talked about
a lot of different things, and as we start

13
00:00:36.257 --> 00:00:40.199
to take a look at some of the things that
we actually have to know and understand.

14
00:00:40.199 --> 00:00:45.260
And that is, of course, the idea of
making sure we do some incident handling.

15
00:00:45.260 --> 00:00:49.713
And specifically today, we're gonna be
addressing evidence handling as well,

16
00:00:49.713 --> 00:00:51.010
in a forensic process.

17
00:00:51.010 --> 00:00:55.150
Now, whenever we talk about that
idea of forensics are normally,

18
00:00:55.150 --> 00:00:57.840
I'm not gonna say for
every one of you out there.

19

Sometimes you'll get one, and they'll only
last about for about six months or so.

472
00:24:55.970 --> 00:24:58.520
So don't even trust things like
hard drives to really give you

473
00:24:58.520 --> 00:24:59.800
something like that.

474
00:24:59.800 --> 00:25:02.490
Things like even paper and pencil, right?

475
00:25:02.490 --> 00:25:08.030
After a while, if you actually wrote
everything down in this old ink pen, you

476
00:25:08.030 --> 00:25:12.210
might end up seeing that after a while,
it fades away, it kind of disappears.

477
00:25:12.210 --> 00:25:14.420
Receipts also do the same thing.

478
00:25:14.420 --> 00:25:15.410
>> Yeah.
>> Zach, one of the things that-

479
00:25:15.410 --> 00:25:16.810
>> Thermal paper disappears after a while.

480
00:25:16.810 --> 00:25:17.920
>> Yeah, thermal paper is, yeah,

481
00:25:17.920 --> 00:25:21.330
that was the one that got me the most is,
I ended up buying a battery for my car.

482
00:25:21.330 --> 00:25:24.820
And it had a little pouch on the side
that said, put the receipt here.

483
00:25:24.820 --> 00:25:26.905
I did, but when I had to take it back for

484
00:25:26.905 --> 00:25:27.518
prorating-
>> Nothing there.

485
00:25:27.518 --> 00:25:28.240
>> You can't even read it.
>> [LAUGH]

486
00:25:28.240 --> 00:25:30.710
>> So I couldn't even get my prorating for

487
00:25:30.710 --> 00:25:31.890
it anymore, either.

488
00:25:31.890 --> 00:25:34.910
So, you have to worry about
evidence preservation.

489
00:25:34.910 --> 00:25:38.200
So, not only the acquisition of the data,
making sure we get it all.

490
00:25:38.200 --> 00:25:43.100
Not only the integrity, but also, of
course, the preservation of that evidence

491
00:25:43.100 --> 00:25:46.920
is something that we have to
make sure that we understand.

492
00:25:46.920 --> 00:25:50.850
Even before we start and
is something that we also wanna make sure.

493
00:25:50.850 --> 00:25:53.315
>> Or backup on back up as I used to say.

494
00:25:53.315 --> 00:25:54.270
[LAUGH]
>> And

495
00:25:54.270 --> 00:25:57.530
really is kind of those important
things that we don't consider, okay?

496
00:25:57.530 --> 00:26:03.873
But missed at least in this special
publication 800-86 here, yep.

497
00:26:03.873 --> 00:26:06.530
I'm trying to make sure I say
the right number, 800-86.

498
00:26:06.530 --> 00:26:11.230
It will give you the foundations and
the beginnings of what you might need.

499
00:26:11.230 --> 00:26:14.470
No, now your organization
may enhance that a bit.

500
00:26:14.470 --> 00:26:16.700
But most of them as far
as the bare framework,

501
00:26:16.700 --> 00:26:21.170
it comes back to what we see right here
inside of that particular document.

502
00:26:21.170 --> 00:26:22.150
And when that happens,

503
00:26:22.150 --> 00:26:26.050
right, it means that you at least have
a starting point that you can go to.

504
00:26:26.050 --> 00:26:27.990
So my recommendation as
you're getting ready for

505
00:26:27.990 --> 00:26:32.080
the exam, make sure you look at
that section specifically and

506
00:26:32.080 --> 00:26:36.910
understand those elements of the evidence
collection order and of the data

507
00:26:36.910 --> 00:26:40.520
integrity the data preservation and
the ideal of the volatility.

508
00:26:40.520 --> 00:26:41.310
Okay?

509
00:26:41.310 --> 00:26:43.920
The volatile data collection as well,
making sure that we get

510
00:26:43.920 --> 00:26:47.180
all of that stuff in there, and
that's what we want to do right?

511
00:26:47.180 --> 00:26:52.040
So read about, understand a little
bit more because it is highly

512
00:26:52.040 --> 00:26:56.368
likely that you're gonna see more on the
exam on stuff like this than you realize.

513
00:26:56.368 --> 00:27:01.390
And that's because they expect you to
understand that a big part of everything

514
00:27:01.390 --> 00:27:05.660
that you're gonna do as an analyst one day
is that if you do catch something you have

515
00:27:05.660 --> 00:27:09.850
to be able to understand that process
because they hope to prosecute it one day.

516
00:27:09.850 --> 00:27:12.940
Don't just look at it as
an interesting science experiment.

517
00:27:12.940 --> 00:27:17.290
Or an interesting idea of ooh this is
neat and something for me to find and

518
00:27:17.290 --> 00:27:19.030
something for me to protect against.

519
00:27:19.030 --> 00:27:21.810
It is all leading to something,
which is, of course, to stop this.

520
00:27:21.810 --> 00:27:23.700
And the way you do that
is by prosecuting them.

521
00:27:23.700 --> 00:27:27.530
And the way to prosecute them is,
if you can handle the evidence correctly.

522
00:27:27.530 --> 00:27:33.773
So here's a good place for you to begin,
by taking a look at the missed SP 800-86.

523
00:27:33.773 --> 00:27:36.580
Make sure you familiarize yourself with
that particular section that we showed you

524
00:27:36.580 --> 00:27:37.590
here in the show.

525
00:27:37.590 --> 00:27:39.610
And that should help you to
not only prepare for the exam,

526
00:27:39.610 --> 00:27:42.900
but also get ready for your career
at a security operations center.

527
00:27:42.900 --> 00:27:44.120
>> That's right.
You can prepare to

528
00:27:44.120 --> 00:27:45.470
help stop those bad actors.

529
00:27:45.470 --> 00:27:49.880
This has been evidence handling, and this
is in the CCNA sec ops series of videos.

530
00:27:49.880 --> 00:27:52.800
And make sure that you watch every one of
them because these episodes are great and

531
00:27:52.800 --> 00:27:54.270
they're going to help you in the long run.

532
00:27:54.270 --> 00:27:56.320
And also, check our our course library.

533
00:27:56.320 --> 00:28:00.080
There's hundreds of videos there,
all designed to help you go further.

534
00:28:00.080 --> 00:28:01.945
And tell everybody you
know about IT Pro TV.

535
00:28:01.945 --> 00:28:03.370
They'll be glad you did.

536
00:28:03.370 --> 00:28:04.060
Thanks for watching.

537
00:28:04.060 --> 00:28:04.800
I'm Zach Memos.

538
00:28:04.800 --> 00:28:05.600
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

539
00:28:05.600 --> 00:28:08.630
>> And we'll see you again real soon.

540
00:28:08.630 --> 00:28:14.488
[MUSIC]

541
00:28:14.488 --> 00:28:17.410
>> Thank you for watching IT Pro TV.

episodes.description: In this episode, Zach and Ronnie apply VERIS schema categories to incident handling events.
episodes.title: Apply VERIS Schema Categories
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.008 --> 00:00:03.344
Welcome to ITProTV,
I'm your host, Don Prezet.

2
00:00:03.344 --> 00:00:08.222
[CROSSTALK]

3
00:00:08.222 --> 00:00:12.003
>> You're watching ITProTV.

4
00:00:12.003 --> 00:00:14.316
>> Hello and thank you for
choosing ITProTV,

5
00:00:14.316 --> 00:00:16.380
helping you learn wherever you go.

6
00:00:16.380 --> 00:00:20.241
I'm your host, Zack Memos,
as we continue on with CCNA SECOPS,

7
00:00:20.241 --> 00:00:21.869
VERIS Schema Categories.

8
00:00:21.869 --> 00:00:24.350
>> [LAUGH]
>> That's the episode title.

9
00:00:24.350 --> 00:00:28.510
And Ronnie Wong is here to deliver us the
information we need to keep on going and

10
00:00:28.510 --> 00:00:29.330
keep learning.

11
00:00:29.330 --> 00:00:30.310
Hey, Ronnie, good to see you.

12
00:00:30.310 --> 00:00:31.500
>> Good to see you too, Zach.

13
00:00:31.500 --> 00:00:35.270
As we continue on in our
CCNA SECOPS series here.

14
00:00:35.270 --> 00:00:38.880
We are now taking a look,
of course, at VERIS schemas.

15
00:00:38.880 --> 00:00:42.010
And if you're looking at it like,
what, what is a VERIS schema?

16
00:00:42.010 --> 00:00:44.985
>> Well, that was my first question,
Ronnie, what is a VERIS schema?

17
00:00:44.985 --> 00:00:47.910
>> [LAUGH] Yeah,
it actually is a good question for

18
00:00:47.910 --> 00:00:51.260
what we actually need to think about and
handle.

19
00:00:51.260 --> 00:00:55.233
Well, Zach,
when you think about it in this way, okay?

20
00:00:55.233 --> 00:00:59.218
Industry-wide, in terms of security and
the IT field,

21
00:00:59.218 --> 00:01:03.210
everybody in different shops
speaks in different ways.

22
00:01:03.210 --> 00:01:07.060
And when you talk about
a particular incident or

23
00:01:07.060 --> 00:01:11.120
a security breach that may have
happened and I listen to it,

24
00:01:11.120 --> 00:01:16.120
I may not have a good understanding of
what actually happened at your shop.

25
00:01:16.120 --> 00:01:18.860
Because I might interpret
it a little bit differently

26
00:01:18.860 --> 00:01:22.000
based on the evidence that you gave me,
okay?

27
00:01:22.000 --> 00:01:25.670
So, I might not understand
what exactly happened.

28
00:01:25.670 --> 00:01:29.385
And then you hear something that
either I or somebody else told you and

29
00:01:29.385 --> 00:01:32.270
you're not in full
understanding of that either.

30
00:01:32.270 --> 00:01:36.820
And it makes it difficult then to
bring an issue up to somebody that

31
00:01:36.820 --> 00:01:41.205
may have more experience at times or
a different perspective,

32
00:01:41.205 --> 00:01:45.589
and to get everybody on board in
terms of the same information so

33
00:01:45.589 --> 00:01:50.339
that decisions and even help can be
offered in the way that needs to.

34
00:01:50.339 --> 00:01:55.668
VERIS, V, E, R, I, S is a particular
way of handling instance and

35
00:01:55.668 --> 00:02:02.124
reporting on incidences that's supposed
to be what relatively uniform to be able

36
00:02:02.124 --> 00:02:08.690
to provide good quality information to
whoever ends up getting this information.

37
00:02:08.690 --> 00:02:11.550
And it has really has
one purpose behind it.

38
00:02:11.550 --> 00:02:17.111
And the entire purpose behind trying to
use something like VERIS schema is not so

39
00:02:17.111 --> 00:02:21.348
that you have the most greatest
documentation in the world.

40
00:02:21.348 --> 00:02:26.133
But it's so that you can present
the right information that is needed to

41
00:02:26.133 --> 00:02:29.826
give you the best
decision-making possible, okay?

42
00:02:29.826 --> 00:02:33.010
And that's what it's all
based around when we started

43
00:02:33.010 --> 00:02:35.840
the talk about this idea of what
VERIS scheme has helped us to do.

44
00:02:35.840 --> 00:02:38.560
>> So is VERIS latin or
is it alphabet soup?

45
00:02:38.560 --> 00:02:40.640
>> Yeah, believe it or not,
it's alphabet soup, right?

46
00:02:40.640 --> 00:02:44.448
So it's actually an acronym for
vocabulary, for

47
00:02:44.448 --> 00:02:47.720
event recording, and incident sharing.

48
00:02:47.720 --> 00:02:52.569
Yeah, so, guys at Verizon essentially
came up with the foundation of

49
00:02:52.569 --> 00:02:55.785
this when they had a breach
several years ago.

50
00:02:55.785 --> 00:02:59.055
And they realized that the breach was
pretty much not understood by different

51
00:02:59.055 --> 00:03:00.211
teams within Verizon, but

52
00:03:00.211 --> 00:03:03.320
as well as others when they
started sharing the information.

53
00:03:03.320 --> 00:03:08.130
And so here, they've essentially put out
this understanding in the schema to allow

54
00:03:08.130 --> 00:03:12.540
for the anonymization of certain things
that might reveal company secrets, but

55
00:03:12.540 --> 00:03:16.490
at the same, time to allow for other
people to be able to see the information,

56
00:03:16.490 --> 00:03:18.504
and get help that they need to.

57
00:03:18.504 --> 00:03:22.500
So the VERIS schema is actually
a kind of community-driven and

58
00:03:22.500 --> 00:03:27.850
a community-maintained way of documenting
information that we have out there,

59
00:03:27.850 --> 00:03:31.570
that's supposed to provide that
common language for us, okay?

60
00:03:31.570 --> 00:03:34.550
So where in the world do we find
out more information about and

61
00:03:34.550 --> 00:03:36.640
how are we actually gonna use
it right here on the show?

62
00:03:36.640 --> 00:03:38.870
Now let me show you the site here, okay?

63
00:03:38.870 --> 00:03:43.790
So the easiest place to go, and
you want to actually be careful here, and

64
00:03:43.790 --> 00:03:46.340
there's no other way for
me to describe this.

65
00:03:46.340 --> 00:03:48.854
Notice how it actually says, Not Secure.

66
00:03:48.854 --> 00:03:49.810
Can you see that?

67
00:03:49.810 --> 00:03:50.740
>> It says unsecure.

68
00:03:50.740 --> 00:03:52.670
>> It says Not Secure, okay?

69
00:03:52.670 --> 00:03:54.944
So you might be wondering like,
Ronnie are you sure?

70
00:03:54.944 --> 00:04:01.750
Yeah, it's got a GitHub certificate on it
and the site name is veriscommunity.net.

71
00:04:01.750 --> 00:04:06.500
So the certificate doesn't match up but
this is the official site right here

72
00:04:06.500 --> 00:04:09.990
that you would go to, and
that's why we're on this site.

73
00:04:09.990 --> 00:04:13.820
And if you take a look,
there is VERIS, the vocabulary for

74
00:04:13.820 --> 00:04:16.910
event recording and incident sharing.

75
00:04:16.910 --> 00:04:23.000
And the entire project is hosted on GitHub
itself, is what they've actually done.

76
00:04:23.000 --> 00:04:26.780
So when you take a look at what
they're talking about here, okay,

77
00:04:26.780 --> 00:04:31.280
is that right here in this first sentence
is kind of the key in what we wanna

78
00:04:31.280 --> 00:04:36.350
understand about this manner and this
format that we're talking about, right?

79
00:04:36.350 --> 00:04:39.290
Set of metrics designed to
provide a common language for

80
00:04:39.290 --> 00:04:44.890
describing security incidents in
a structured and repeatable manner, okay?

81
00:04:44.890 --> 00:04:47.210
And here they're talking about,
here it is.

82
00:04:47.210 --> 00:04:48.760
It's a response to one
of the most critical and

83
00:04:48.760 --> 00:04:50.840
persistent challenges in the industry.

84
00:04:50.840 --> 00:04:55.910
And that is because without it we might
not have the information that we need

85
00:04:55.910 --> 00:05:00.560
to make the best possible decisions
that need to be made for my company, and

86
00:05:00.560 --> 00:05:03.460
also to get help from other
people as well, okay?

87
00:05:03.460 --> 00:05:07.620
So the overall goal is to lay that
foundation, it says, constructively, and

88
00:05:07.620 --> 00:05:12.420
learn cooperatively, okay,
from our experiences and to measure and

89
00:05:12.420 --> 00:05:14.260
manage risk, okay?

90
00:05:14.260 --> 00:05:19.490
So this is where it all begins and
everything that we've talked about here

91
00:05:19.490 --> 00:05:22.980
Is trying to help us to understand
some of those categories.

92
00:05:22.980 --> 00:05:27.790
Now, the issue though, that were really
called into, especially on the exam,

93
00:05:27.790 --> 00:05:32.550
is that if we were given,
okay, an incident, okay,

94
00:05:32.550 --> 00:05:38.090
could we categorize that incident
according to the VERIS schema, okay?

95
00:05:38.090 --> 00:05:40.980
Can we do something like
that to help us out?

96
00:05:40.980 --> 00:05:42.110
Well, yes, you can.

97
00:05:42.110 --> 00:05:44.126
And the best place for you to do that and

98
00:05:44.126 --> 00:05:47.729
understand that is gonna be right
here on their own website, okay?

99
00:05:47.729 --> 00:05:52.116
And the reason why I wanted to bring up
the website is because it actually has in

100
00:05:52.116 --> 00:05:54.360
great documentation on how to do this.

101
00:05:54.360 --> 00:05:57.850
It doesn't mean that you're not
gonna get confused by this, okay?

102
00:05:57.850 --> 00:06:00.330
But at least you get documentation.

103
00:06:00.330 --> 00:06:04.390
And you get a great navigation on some of
the things that we can actually do and

104
00:06:04.390 --> 00:06:08.310
will take a look, especially on that
scheme documentation to help us to

105
00:06:08.310 --> 00:06:11.285
understand the categories that we're
talking about especially in VERIS schema.

106
00:06:11.285 --> 00:06:14.921
>> And this is on GitHub and this is
also gonna be free of charge, right?

107
00:06:14.921 --> 00:06:18.234
>> Right, yeah, so this is all free and
is community-driven,

108
00:06:18.234 --> 00:06:20.160
is designed to be this way.

109
00:06:20.160 --> 00:06:23.155
And what we'll see is that there's
a lot of different categories and

110
00:06:23.155 --> 00:06:28.710
subcategories and some different ways
of actually describing everything.

111
00:06:28.710 --> 00:06:32.450
And we'll talk about that
just briefly here, okay?

112
00:06:32.450 --> 00:06:37.980
But this overall idea, right,
is to really allow a company that really

113
00:06:37.980 --> 00:06:43.900
take advantage of the documentation and
the way that it happens and the language.

114
00:06:43.900 --> 00:06:48.348
So that it's consistent across the board
with whoever else is actually following

115
00:06:48.348 --> 00:06:50.609
the same standard as what is to do, okay?

116
00:06:50.609 --> 00:06:54.078
So ultimately in the end,
as you look through this website,

117
00:06:54.078 --> 00:06:57.683
you'll see the idea of actually
recording all of our events and

118
00:06:57.683 --> 00:07:01.670
instances in this way is to help
answer really two questions, okay?

119
00:07:01.670 --> 00:07:07.225
And the first question that it should help
to answer, especially for someone that's

120
00:07:07.225 --> 00:07:12.489
making the decision, okay, is what is it
that I want to know about this instant?

121
00:07:12.489 --> 00:07:17.791
Okay, not everybody needs
to know the details exactly

122
00:07:17.791 --> 00:07:25.408
what the technical term was that ended
up happening to your company right now.

123
00:07:25.408 --> 00:07:30.202
But they may need to know about the detail
such as the time of the breach and

124
00:07:30.202 --> 00:07:33.510
also the impact of the breach itself,
okay?

125
00:07:33.510 --> 00:07:37.580
That might actually more important than
you telling them that it was a malware

126
00:07:37.580 --> 00:07:41.620
breach from so and so file that
hit the server that did all these.

127
00:07:41.620 --> 00:07:43.661
Don't get me wrong,
those are important details for

128
00:07:43.661 --> 00:07:45.574
someone at the level of
trying to respond to that.

129
00:07:45.574 --> 00:07:50.002
But in making a decision on what needs to
be told or what needs to be passed on,

130
00:07:50.002 --> 00:07:53.760
they may just say, what do I really
want to know from this event?

131
00:07:53.760 --> 00:07:57.190
And that's when a CEO or
somebody else might come and say,

132
00:07:57.190 --> 00:07:59.786
Here's what I need to
know about the event.

133
00:07:59.786 --> 00:08:02.686
Well you might know all those
other technical details, but

134
00:08:02.686 --> 00:08:04.980
you don't know how to
actually respond then.

135
00:08:04.980 --> 00:08:09.180
This is why the idea of understanding
the schema can't be helpful enough.

136
00:08:10.190 --> 00:08:15.860
Secondly, is how should I prioritize
the different various elements

137
00:08:15.860 --> 00:08:20.970
that I get to help me support the decision
making that might have to be done.

138
00:08:20.970 --> 00:08:24.050
So from that standpoint,
somebody that is making the decision,

139
00:08:24.050 --> 00:08:28.890
how do they then take what they're
given from the actual VERIS schema

140
00:08:28.890 --> 00:08:33.400
ideas as presented, how do I actually
make the best decision from those?

141
00:08:33.400 --> 00:08:38.180
So the VERIS schema allows us essentially
the idea of prioritization, it allows us

142
00:08:38.180 --> 00:08:43.060
the ability then to actually understand
what other people may be going through and

143
00:08:43.060 --> 00:08:48.910
what my response should be and how I can
answer questions like this as well, okay.

144
00:08:48.910 --> 00:08:52.139
The advantage of VERIS,
is because it is community driven and

145
00:08:52.139 --> 00:08:55.330
it allows for
other people to communicate, okay.

146
00:08:55.330 --> 00:09:01.750
It allows you then to collect and
share information anonymously and

147
00:09:01.750 --> 00:09:06.190
responsibly to the people
that follow this schema.

148
00:09:06.190 --> 00:09:09.930
So you don't have to reveal all of your
company's secrets, but you do have to

149
00:09:09.930 --> 00:09:14.130
reveal certain things in certain elements
here if you want to participate in it and

150
00:09:14.130 --> 00:09:18.400
get help from it and get better
decision making from it as well.

151
00:09:18.400 --> 00:09:22.390
So that's the whole goal and aspect of
what we really want to make sure that we

152
00:09:22.390 --> 00:09:26.600
